As for the female protagonists Ellen Burstyn made a disappointingly weak chief villainess Sobieski (who had been so impressive in Stanley Kubrick's EYES WIDE SHUT [1999]) was strangely flabby and unattractive(!) and only Kate Beahan (as Cage's ex-fiancée) manages to emerge with a grain of dignity from the wreckage.One had hoped that the remake would turn audiences on to the 1973 version but in the face of the appalling (indeed depressing) results such a thing is highly doubtful: what was fascinating powerful and haunting - in one word unique - about the original has been killed stone dead by this hollow wretched and totally unnecessary revamping!! The "Unrated" version I watched featured an alternate "shocking" ending to the one provided in the PG-13 theatrical-release print (for which the violence was reduced but apparently had an open-ended postscript added to it)!

I wont go into the "why it sucks" that has been blown through in a dozen other reviews instead I will simply try to project a warning to those considering to use this movie even for killing time:I watch movies. Lots of them. I've gone through 3-10 new movies a week for the past two years and I thought I had seen rock bottom a few years back with "Hostel". Now one thing I don't do is write reviews. Despite my passion for movies this is actually my first one. The Wicker Man is something I was prepared to not only type a review over but register into IMDb 3AM in the morning while under influenza. From the bottom of my heart I promise this is not exxageration and I mean it to the full extent when I say - it's that bad.

column4: I really hate Hollywood! When are they going to stop taking everyone else's films and making them God awful?
column5: First The Ring then The Italian Job then The Grudge... now The Wicker Man! When I first saw the trailer for this film I honestly thought it was a joke. I mean who would be so stupid as to try and remake a brilliant classic horror like The Wicker Man? Well it turns out they really weren't joking but I wish they had have been!There are certain films that no one should ever remake. The Wicker Man is one of them. I thought however this film would be much like The Omen remake and would be a word for word replica of the original which would not be as bad but may just invite a new generation of younger cinema goers to watch the original film which in 99% of the time is better than the remake. Wrong! They changed almost the entire story with the island mainly being run by women under the leadership of Sister Summersisle. Where did Christopher Lee's character go? Everybody knows that Lord Summerisle is the best character in the original!And what were they thinking casting Nicolas Cage in the part that is unbelievably similar to Edward Woodward's? Nicolas you're not a great actor at the best of times. Maybe you should just keep to films where you can just pout and display no discernible acting skills whatsoever? I think that would be best for all.I've heard some people describe this as a sequel rather than a remake. To those of you that are thinking that why make a film that is similar to the original in far too many ways to be distinguishable from it? If this is indeed what the filmmakers where thinking they should step aside and allow writers with actual talent to write screenplays from now on.Honestly this film is just a 100 minute waste of your life and if you are a true fan of the original you'll just leave the cinema feeling cheated and sick to you stomach.And just a quick suggestion to the people who made this film and indeed to Hollywood in general if you have run out of ideas stop making films. Don't just take other people's films and remake them into horrible monstrosities and try to pass them off as films. Its not working!

column4: Why do they let Nicholas Cage keep making movies...
column5: Especially since they are so bad they don't even show them to the critics in advance? Essentially this is a remake of the British film. a bunch of Pagan babes running an Island need a human sacrifice to make their honey crop improve (in the Brit version it was apples!) The British version has a cult status it doesn't deserve but it is far better than the American version which seems to involve Nicholas Cage punching out and terrorizing women before they burn him alive.Bear suit. That's all I have to say.I didn't really intend to review this movie I just want to put in another 1 star rating to bring the average down.

I wasn't very interested in checking out the new version of "The Wicker Man" because the preview left me cold pretty much a few of these year's blockbusters did but I went in and couldn't force my eyes off the screen. The film is hypnotic and grabs you until its very disappointing conclusion. It's somehow what one expects but the final piece somehow lands with something of a thud.Everyone in the film is relatively good. Ellen Burstyn never makes a false move in a role that could have been quite cheesy. She recreates a character and makes it mysterious intelligent almost Machiavellian and walks away with another triumph. Nicholas Cage does wonders with a part that it's overburdened by some stupid dialog and expressions like "Step away from that bicycle..." no comments here.The music and photography complement this production that dares to explore worlds that were left behind with the 70's and the results are spooky for the most part. Sadly the ending is to be kind weak. I'd say go and enjoy what it's there and let's hope the next time this one works again.

Seriously what were they thinking? Now I've never even seen the original but from the reviews I heard over it it must be pretty good. So I went and bought myself this remake just to prepare for the original.Now I've heard about of how horrible this movie was so I took that already in precaution.Instead I found myself laughing till my sides split. This is not a thriller more so even a serious one at times this is a very funny movie although unintentional. The laughs I got were unforgettable especially with the usually-good Nic Cage hamming it up with his superb overacting that makes the film look comedic. The bad supporting actors horrible music score and atrocious subplots all make this a hilariously bad movie.The cinematography and set pieces are good but even them cannot save the movie from what it is - an abysmal horrendous train wreck that instead of leaving audiences terrified for months left us howling in laughter unintentionally of course. The director LaBute seriously needs to get help fast. His commentary on the DVD proves that there's something wrong with him. He's telling us the hardships and determination the cast and crew took while trying to make this a serious picture but what we see on the screen is an exact opposite of what he is trying to vision. Neil come on! You are better than this!! Aside from unintentionally (there's that word again) funny lines this movie is a must to avoid - especially if you are a fan of the original. If you like comedies bad movies or simply unintentionally funny movies then give this a try.Had this been a comedy I would have given this an 8.4/10 but seeing this as a serious movie gone horribly wrong I give this a 1.2/10 showing it as it is. IMDb users I know some of you voted it a 10/10 as a funny film but please this movie deserves its place in the Bottom 100 alongside Battlefield Earth and Baby ''shudder'' Geniuses. Please if you are reading this change your votes to 1 so that it is listed in its rightful place as a piece of rubbish.Thank God Cage came back with National Treasure: Book of Secrets!!1.2/10Delton

column4: A bizarre island hard to reach and even harder to leave.
column5: California cop Edward Malus(Nicolas Cage)takes some time off after a woman and her small daughter die in a fiery crash. It happened so fast all he could do is watch and his rescue attempts failed. Still recovering from this traumatic tragedy Malus receives a call from his former girlfriend Willow(Kate Beahan) who asks him to come to a private island off of Washington state to help find her daughter Rowan(Erika-Shaye Gair). Malus arrives on Summersisle and finds the occupants are a bit bizarre. The community is under the iron fist rule of Sister Summersisle(Ellen Burstyn). The island is populated by women who treat men as second-class citizens and take part in ancient rituals and human sacrifice. Malus has no idea what he is getting into as he desperately hunts for the lost little girl.This film seems too contrived and the acting is pretty damn stale. There is absolutely no chemistry between Cage and his leading lady Beahan. Burstyn is eerie as the clan's matriarch. Other cast members: Leelee Sobieski Frances Conroy Diane Delano and Molly Parker.

There has been a lot of talk around this movie most of all about its famous scenes with Nicolas Cage at his worst. I watched a Youtube-video with the "highlights" of this train wreck and it sounded like a lot of unintentional fun. Sadly only a small part of the movie is like that. For the most time you're left with a very boring film and wonder yourself why the hell you decided to watch this movie. (Exception: You're watching it with the rifftrax because than it is a really hilarious film)A cop named Edward is traumatized after he couldn't save a little girl from a car accident and as he receives a letter from his ex-girlfriend asking for help he sees his chance for atonement. So he goes to Summersilse looking for his ex-girlfriend's daughter but not everything is as it seems...The director for this film apparently wanted to give it a melancholy and deep touch but he fails miserably and instead the movie just seems boring. The dialog isn't doing a lot to grab your interest either and something to lighten the mode only happens very rarely. Nicolas Cage is here at his craziest and even though he isn't very good in this movie is the only saving grace. His madness was the only thing that kept me watching because I was sure there would be another mad line of his. The other actors are pretty colorless and will be forgotten soon after.It's not the worst film I've ever seen (Manos Red Zone Cuba & others are way worse) but it's still quiet bad. Nicolas Cage delivers a few hilariously bad lines to save the movie from being rated worse

column4: unimaginable disaster of a suspense not to mention a horror film
column5: the plot was loosely tied together. Many logical question a sane viewer of the film will ask are left unanswered or left be answered with your much more creative mind. One would ask why was Cage seeing so much illusions? was he high on drugs or medication? Many events in the movies are outright extraneous because they adds to the barage of confusion that the plot instills into the story already. Why and when his gun was unloaded of the bullets and why would he not notice that if he already checked his clip once in the film? contradiction? Were not the antagonists in the final climax of the film not disabled by Cage? how did they show up at the end? and what's the point of the last part of the movie; to add to the insult the film producer has already done to viewers like me? Cage's performance was awful also he acted like how he acted in every other film; I'd put Cage in the same category of actor as Keanu. They just play the same person in different situation.

column4: A turkey that didn't even deserve to go straight to video!!!!
column5: As a great fan of the original film I couldn't resist going along to compare this remake with it. I went with an open mind despite the fact that I had read the reviews on this site which overwhelmingly rubbish the film. I'm afraid that very quickly I realised how true the comments/opinions were. This truly is a dreadful film. I was never a fan of Nicholas Cage who has made a good living from movies despite being particularly unattractive and having absolutely NO acting talent whatsoever. This turkey reinforces my opinions of him. I don't know what's happened to the man's face but I just couldn't take my eyes off his peculiar appearance and it detracted from the film. The idea that an attractive young woman would be overcome by attraction to this weird looking individual is ludicrous. He looked more like the child's grandad than her father as well as looking like Miss. Gulch from the Wizard of Oz as he rode his bike!!! His 'perfomance' is deeply embarrassing as is that of the supporting cast. Ellen Burstyn really is diabolical - and I don't mean in the threatening sense!!! She appears to have taken actinglessons at the Nic Cage school of wooden!!!! I'm at a loss for words as to say how bad this film is. Anyone could be forgiven for wondering whether or not this film is meant to be tongue in cheek with all the unintentional laughs. All copies of it and its negatives should be burned and the ashes scattered to the wind. A genuinely awful movie.

column4: RenFest Feminazi Hobbits Go Wilding On World's Worst Actor!
column5: The worst actor of our generation the male Elizabeth Berkley (Showgirls) Nicholas Cage walks out in the middle of the road to pick up a brat's doll causing an 18 wheeler to swerve and hit the car the girl is in. The girl and the mother die. Serves them both right that little monster would be riding in a pet kennel if I was the mommy.So of course he's tragic over it. We know this because he constantly pops pills out of this one regular sized medicine bottle. He pops them so much that obviously they aren't strong enough because if they were he would have been dead from an OD already and there is no way the pill bottle could hold that many pills as often as he pops them. And I do mean POP. He moves like a sloth except when he's got some pills in his hand. Then it's like a boa constrictor on a mouse.He receives an unpostmarked letter (the only plausible thing in this movie since the USPS is so AFU) from his ex her daughter has gone missing. The letter is written in very pretty neat calligraphy or as I call it HobbitFont. He goes up to some island in Washington complete with bad CGI waves and barges in to look for her.Firstly let it be said that I'm not homophobic. In fact I'm a big ole Ikea-shopping Hillary-loving fudge packer. But as soon as he sets foot on the island he encounters every female PE teacher that has ever lived if you catch my drift. I think I saw Large Marge in there. The stereotypes were so broadly drawn that I am truly surprised there wasn't a WNBA game at some point in this movie. And their clothing! They're all dressed like something out of a Renaissance Festival or the Lord of the Rings or one of those planets that Star Trek The Next Generation was always landing on. Same difference. You just know that none of them shave their armpits. And they cackle this hysterically funny evil witches' laugh. I can only imagine how many tries it took to get the entire cast to laugh like that on cue without cracking up. And the only 2 men on the island are mute. And the young females are ALL pregnant. Work it Amish Pimps!So our Nic informs everyone loudly he is a police officer and is looking for a missing girl. But he is a policeman from California in Washington on private property it is pointed out by the barkeep who serves mead. MEAD? When is Gollum going to pop out? Nic does find his precious she's this Fiona Apple look alike who is always crying and seems to have some form of autism preventing her from speaking complete or coherent sentences. But to her advantage she's got this waif hobbit-chic thing going on and her pits are shaved and she looks adorable.Cut to spoilers: Her daughter is missing and is on the island and is Nic's daughter but he's sooooo completely oblivious to the weirdness going on he just keeps yelling louder and louder and flashing his badge and obviously these diesels are getting irritated. I can understand why the worlds loudest stupidest man is ordering them around. One moment he's deathly allergic to bee stings. The next time he's stung he lives. Come to find out Fiona went out into the world to get knocked up and then had daddy Nic come back to the island so they could sacrifice him in a pagan ritual (they need a blood connection) so their honey harvest would be better next year. (Oh I forgot to mention this is a commune that produces honey for a living. I'm sure Whole Foods sells it. I would buy their honey just for what they do to Nicholas Cage keep reading.) They get the pagan feminazi thing SOOO incredibly wrong that I can see Jerry Falwell using this movie around the next election to terrify his Sheepublicans into voting against that dangerous womyn Hillary. The movie ends on a very satisfying note however with them breaking his kneecaps then hoisting him up to the top of the Burning Man dude and then burning him alive. Set it and forget it! But since Ghost Man just came out it wasn't real unfortunately they didn't actually crisp out Nicholas Cage. Well damn.Other highlights:1. Leelee Sobriety or whatever her name is jumping on Nic and screeching and pulling his hair. He knocks her out by throwing her against the wall and her face shot as she loses consciousness had me howling. There is no way she did this movie for anything but the money.2. Nicholas Cage in a bear suit. Don't ask me how or why. In fact everyone in masks and animal costumes. And dancing Renfest / LOTR maidens. Maidens! Furries! Were the Flaming Lips shooting a video on the island at the same time?3. Ellen Burstyn having fun with her ridiculous role in an awful movie. She's such a brilliant actress and part of being a good actor is knowing when you're in a turkey bomb of a movie so it's OK if you just go wild and do your absolute worst and you still get paid.4. "Step AWAY from the bike!"5. "OH NO THE BEESAAAAAAAAHOHMYGODDDD BEES IN MY EYES!"This movie is Showgirls bad which is ultimately a compliment. It's so bad it's funny. If you want a good laugh and are like me a connoisseur of unintentional camp and really terrible movies then rent it and grab a bottle of tequila on the way home. Yes it's true of all the bad movies in 2006 we were blessed with one so awful that you can turn it into a drinking game.

column4: Totally worth seeing if never before
column5: I find most of the comments here are more disturbing than the movie itself. Viewers are pretty much "angry" and some even want to "punch a baby"The truth is without seeing the so-called original one I find The Wicker Man is quite interesting not in a way of horror but in a way of mystery. The opening is done pretty good to build up the suspense you need to hang on with. A bizarre accident event followed by a letter from ex-girlfriend draws the police officer Malus into a potential case of kidnapping; a little girl is at stake. The plot sounds good to me as I was brought up by The X-files though there is no paranormal activities involved except Malus has vision and nightmare about weird things and "trust no one" thing... And the bear costume thing that people laugh about it is really nothing serious cos you would find it in stadiums so why not in a celebration event taken place in a movie?Do not let other people's rage to cloud your judgment this is a good movie with decent acting at work.

column4: How do you ruin a classic film ?
column5: How do you wreck a good OLD film--let the Americans re-make it . They just cant help themselves  it must be American genetics.You take a plot- and change it- you film it in another country  You apply actors that don't fit the cast properly.You then throw a shed load of cash into the remake  and hope for the best.Only you get a mear trifle without sugar to flavour. Rather sad as the original was without 'x' amount of millions thrown at special effects .The U.S.A do it all the time take an excellent CLASSIC re-make it and botch it right up--its a shame .The movie should be about Wicka religion  it should have been re-made as close as possible to original (which was freaky as hell :o))Now we have a re-make to fall asleep to in the early hours of the morn.

column4: Sacrifice Your Sanity By Watching This Trash......
column5: This is a dreadfully bad movie.Nicolas Cage gives a shockingly bland and banal performance which looks like it is made up as it goes along.Each time I see him in a film its the same plodding dumb one dimensional "character" boring and wholly uninteresting.The script in this movie is comical without being funny. And the premise of the story is ludicrous aided by nonsense acting from all in this story.The plot so called:A traffic cop is asked to investigate a missing child case by his ex girlfriend. It happens that he goes to a commune on an island to do this where the inhabitants are dominated by an odd womens' cult: blah blah. blah..... If you want to waste your time on total trash well: see this rubbish.1/10.

column4: This suffers from the great film it was trying to imitate much like the Psycho remake
column5: The Wicker Man (2006) is a movie I recently watched on Tubi. The storyline for this picture is about a detective who receives a letter from an ex-fiancée who mysteriously disappeared. The letter says her child is missing. The detective sets out to find and help her and instead finds a secluded island with a cult. As he digs into the missing child and gets to understand the cult better he discovers more about the why she disappeared the cult and whose life is really at risk. This movie is directed by Neil LaBute (In the Comany of Men) and stars Nicolas Cage (Face/Off) Leelee Sobieski (88) Ellen Burstyn (The Exorcist) and Kate Beahan (The Matrix). The storyline and execution of this is so poor compared to the original. This was missing so many required elements - the mystery behind the letter the orgies/sexual games of the cult and the European feel and that really detracted from the potential of the film. The acting was also just okay as I loved the detective in the original so much more than Cage and Christopher Lee was such a great villain even if Burstyn was solid. This suffers from the great film it was trying to imitate much like the Psycho remake it just never had a chance from the start. Overall this isn't a complete waste of time and is worth watching once but isn't half the movie the original was. I'd score this a 4.5-5/10.

Everything that I thought after watching this film centred around the word 'why':Why was this film necessary? Why have they made pointless irrelevant changes to the original? Why is Nicholas Cage still cast in anything? Why have I just paid £4.50 to see this futile rubbish?I just can't comprehend why Neil LaBute felt he needed to change every single thing about the original that made it a classic. Unlike a lot of people I actually saw the original after I saw this remake and I was baffled as to what the point in the new one is.Once in a blue moon there is a good remake of an old film. Peter Jackson's 'King Kong' is an example of this - it didn't undermine the original at all and yet was still a superbly made film. But LeBute is no Peter Jackson and there was nothing in this film to bring it to life. Cage was simply dull and the way his voice tails off towards the end of the sentence is one of those little things that will probably annoy you throughout the entirety of this film.I can't think of what the demographic was for this film. Perhaps unsighted fools like me. Fans of the original will hate it for how unfaithful it is to Anthony Shaffer's original screenplay. People who haven't seen the original will dislike it for the fact that it is... well... boring. There is no explanation as to how they get from one scene to another which makes it feel far too long and there is no tension at all - you know that whenever anyone opens a box a bat will fly out.***SPOILERS START HERE***The ending is probably the worst part of the film (quite an achievement). The sight of the Wickerman burning the Cage to death (although it may make you cheer given that you are made to intensely dislike his character. Either that or you will just dislike him) could be made poignant and shocking - it certainly was when Seargant Howie was burnt in the original. So why did you need to see what happened 6 months later? It was completely unnecessary.In the words of Alan Hansen it was diabolical.

column4: the most unintentionally comedic film ever made....
column5: This movie is a laugh riot! You'll be rolling in the aisles with all your buddies as Nicolas Cage attempts to ride a bicycle! Or when Leelee Sobieski tries to act! Or when the film totally jumps the railings in the final few scenes! I saw this movie with a few friends in an almost completely empty theatre and we were giggling from the first reel to the last. Full of misogyny lines that are completely unintentional howlers every horror movie cliché you can imagine and a performance by Ellen Burstyn so awful that you'll wonder how she was ever nominated for an Oscar let alone allowed to be in films. When the ending of your movie has your character punching out a giant fat woman stealing her bear costume from her and prancing along to save a little girl from a bunch of other people dressed up in animal costumes you know you've got a stinker. Not only that but it's from everyones favorite woman hater Neil Labute. Hey Neil still scared of girls? That's too bad maybe some day you will no longer fear the cooties. The original Wicker Man was an absolute laugh riot as well (the art school crowd will tell you it's really really DEEP but don't listen to them) but at least it sort of knew it was bad...I think. So I guess I can recommend this film as an evening of laughs but don't go in expecting anything scary.

I rate this a 2 out of 10 because this movie in no way lived up to its promises of of thrills scares and intrigue. I've seen telly-tubby episodes that have been scarier than this movie. However I'd rate it an 8-10 on my own personal favorite movie scale- whoever you are I urge you to watch this movie- it will surely brighten your day. This movie took itself so seriously that the unintentional humor in it gave me stitches from laughing so hard. I had some friends watch it with me and they all swore that they never laughed so hard in their lives. From Cage's horrendous acting and classic lines like "how'd it get burned?!" this is true (though unintentional) comic genius. Watch it!

I love the original Wicker Man. This one on the other hand was beyond bad. And not in a fun bad way either. I could not enjoy it on any level. None of the good things from the original were present in this one and when they did use lines from the original it just sounded fake and forced. Even worse they added a bunch of crap that didn't improve anything. Lord Summerside was a chick in this instead of Christopher Lee. They raise bees for no reason. They changed the back story i.e. Rowan's dad just so they could add the last pointless scene. The original ending was great this was lame. Mr Cage is terrible as usual. He punches several women which was disturbing. If you were waiting for a chance to see him kick Leelee Sobeski (sp) in the head I guess this is your chance. The highlight is the "step away from the bike" line although at this point you are clearly laughing at a movie that is not a comedy. To sum it up the original one was a masterpiece of film making and this one was a stupid and pointless bore. Nothing good about it I would never watch this again. The real Wicker Man I have seen several times and watch it again and again on a regular basis. This is one the worst remakes I have ever seen almost spitting in the face of all the people who think the original was a classic. 2/10 from me I thought going in the current score on here was probably going to be overly harsh. Not at all this was garbage.

column4: A far better and more ambitious remake of a classic than the disastrous 'Omen'
column5: Beautifully visualised with some excellent sequences and a strong central performance from Cage this new 'Wicker Man' deserves much credit for rethinking and reworking the original rather than just regurgitating it like the recent remake of 'The Omen'. Be warned though that many of this film's better sequences are in its trailer and you will enjoy it much more if you haven't seen the trailer. There are also loose ends and things that don't tie up properly which leave the viewer feeling slightly cheated. But the overall conception is wonderfully creepy with the Paganism of the original being given a feminist spin which ties in with the theme of 'The Da Vinci Code' Given the fact 'The Wicker Man' is a hard film to remake this has enough originality and power of its own both to reward fans of the first and engage those who never saw it.Given the slightly hostile reception to this movie and one extraordinarily unfair and grossly inaccurate review in 'Variety' I'd like to add a few words to the above. The film is being condemned firstly by fans of the original secondly by people who hate this kind of film anyway. The two types are very different but have merged into an unholy chorus (fuelled by beefs about the soundtrack which are a complete red herring). If only they had done this for the vastly inferior 'Omen' remake which really was a lazy and cynical disgrace. By contrast here enormous care has been taken to rework the story from scratch. None of the detractors are giving any credit at all to the film's first half which is entirely different from the earlier film and intelligently so.Indeed the reviewer in Variety appears to have forgotten the plot of the first 'Wicker Man' altogether for he seems to think no changes have been made of any substance! Let me remind him that in the first film the hero was just a dogged ordinary policeman doing his somewhat routine duty. Here Cage is a man returning to find a lost love and his own lost child after an electrifying and very strange opening involving a horrifying encounter with a woman and child who are killed before his eyes. The brutal fact is Variety that up to the halfway point this is a completely different movie from what we last saw and in some ways an improvement.It's true of course that at the climax the film does revert in my view rather misguidedly to the original. I think it would have been far better to evolve a different ending for this very different story. In the first film there was a sense that the narrow-minded hero was bound to meet his end it was his destiny. Here in contrast it just seems unfair and somewhat arbitrary and not even entirely credible. For the the hero of this film who has no blinkers would have seen it coming and acted accordngly. I would submit that here is the reason people are so upset by the film. "An audience will forgive you anything at the beginning of the film and nothing at the end" as Hithcock observed. That is unfair but not entirely surprising. What is surprising is that because of the similarity of the climax few seem to have noticed just how different this film is from its model or paid any attention to its more original elements. And even more that a usually accurate journal of movie record could come up with such a slipshod review.

Although the sets were beautiful and interesting and the locale lush and serene the rest of the movie just stunk. It's really too bad - the plot starts off intriguing but early on you feel as though there's just ... something missing somehow and that's usually a bad sign. I kept waiting for this movie to save itself somehow but it all just became too predictable and there wasn't enough done to paint the 'baddies' of the film in a truly menacing or deeply sinister light surprising indeed given what the actual plot turns out to be -- I never really felt intimidated by them; I just thought they were odd.It wasn't the fault of the actors or actresses who all gave wonderful performances (although Nicolas Cage is somewhat controversial in this regard according to the forums for this film I have always enjoyed watching him though this one wasn't one of his best films). Instead I lay blame to the screenwriter and the editor - sometimes no matter how much talent you have working on a project if an editor pieces a film together poorly there's nothing that can save it and that's what seems to have happened in this case which also explains why viewers feel much is missing from the film.It's worth a look on DVD perhaps at least because the plot is somewhat interesting for a good part of the movie. Ultimately though save your cash and stay far away from this stinker. Why oh why can't someone make a truly great horror / suspense film anymore??

THE WICKER MAN of the 70's was the cult film of the 20th century. It gripped audiences with its terrifying themes and golden cast including Christopher Lee as the mysterious Lord Summerisle who appears so kind and helpful... but is the stepping stone which leads the dumbfounded lead Edward Woodward to his appointment with the Wicker Man.The 2006 remake is an awful step back from what the original film had in it. It's tacky and unbelievable as a film. The horror of the original was that it played with your mind by luring you into the possibility that the events of the film could happen... The American remake is just stupid and the only thing that grips you is your hands around your neck as you try to strangle yourself just to get away from Cage's wooden acting.As an American I can fairly say that British classics have to be left alone. Avoid this nightmare at all costs... I recommend this only to the die-hard Wicker Man fans and the British and that's only because it'll give them a chance to throw the heads back and laugh at what a joke Hollywood have made of their beloved British classic.I salute you British film makers! Hollywood have tried to better you and failed miserably.

column4: Somewhat flawed but enjoyable in the least
column5: Now having not seen the original 1973 version but having read many positive reviews and feedback regarding that film and seeing how this remake was universally panned by critics and fans alike for not living up to the original's expectations. A lot of the criticism seems fair regarding this film as many claim it isn't much of a horror film with no scares and a strong lack of suspense or mystery. While this may be true there was an enjoyable and entertaining factor since one did not exactly know where the film was heading.Nicolas Cage delivers one of his lesser performances but in this film he makes it worthwhile simply because of his deliver and his mannerisms. This is intended in being a serious role but his delivery comes off as unintentionally funny at many parts- which is not completely his fault. The writer's dialogues should be more at fault. Cage is also never boring here as we see him spewing funny one-liners. and acting out of sorts (ex. punching the women/wondering around/hallucinating) and it most definitely makes up for a lackluster story.The twist ending isn't completely predictable but later as the film progresses we start to get a sense that everything was simply a set up in trying to engage in Nicolas Cage's character into being the one to get tortured. The Wicker Man is definitely a bizarre and weird type of film not so much a horror but more so a drama/thriller with the lack of thrill.Considering one thought this film was going to be much worse. Perhaps a major part of the criticism comes from the fact that it doesn't match up to the original and people seemingly feel the need to compare the original to the remake and nitpick every little detail. This is very common with remakes. It is not the greatest film but it's current IMDB rating (3.7) is severely low as it is passable for a time waster.

The Wicker Man is a horror film written and directed by Neil LaBute and starring Nicolas Cage Ellen Burstyn and Kate Beahan.The film is a remake of 1973 film with the same name which is inspired by a 1967 novel 'Ritual'.This film will always be remembered for its bad and comical acting and is filled with lots of faults. The worst part of the film is that despite of being a horror film the film is not at all scary rather it's funny.The acting is average to bad and despite of Nicolas Cage being a seasoned actor was ineffective and bad Ellen Burstyn is also a great actor was just average and rest of the cast were average.Screenplay is slow and bad and the film must've been made considering that the film is a horror film climax is similar to the original film but doesn't looks ineffective. Overall an ineffective film.

some how Hollywood took an English made class B horror movie and turned it through Hollywood magic into a horrible movie. the English concept is sound: a child disappears in a remote village with strange local practises the type of out of the way place where the locals eat dirt on a regular basis. there's a strong suggestion of foul play either one that has occurred or will occur. yet the policeman invited in can make little headway establishing exactly what happened.in the American version the story drags to the point that it becomes difficult to sit through the film.Hollywood has shown very little creativity in recent years preferring to repackage through remaking old movies or TV shows and recasting foreign made movies into an American vicinage.it is difficult to transpose the English original into an American venue as much of the imagery is laced with jibes at their Keltic neighbors that might be lost on an American or of no interest even if he/she understood it.

column4: weird and on purpose fun ride
column5: Even if i wasnt big fan of original movie it was still a lot better then this but this movie at some times makes a fun experience

column4: A police officer investigates the case of a missing girl on a strange island.
column5: I went and to see the wicker man the other day and had pretty high expectations. The trailer promised a very exciting thriller. Unfortunately the wicker man is the worst film I've seen this year. The acting in this movie is awful. For instance many characters have conversations which obviously contain relevant information for the viewers but normally would never be held because they would be totally irrelevant to the characters themselves. This movie is Neil LaBute's first thriller ever and maybe he should leave it this way because this film is at no time at all even the slightest bit thrilling. The few shocking moments the film does contain are rubbish too. It really is a shame that an actor such as Nicolas Cage manages to get himself such a (excuse the language) crappy role. The worst part about this movie is the ending and in addition I would like to award it with my personal "Worst ending in ages"-award! Curious he? See for yourself! (or spare yourself the time and money and look for a proper thriller)

column4: So dire I think I may need counselling
column5: I will make this short as most reviewers have summed this bag of sh1te up already! Have to say if I was reviewing a comedy it would've done pretty well! Both the script and the acting is appalling nothing short of insulting to the original.And where do I start? Too many questions.. 1 - how come when Cage gets to meet the Sister Summersisle he has been in the water rolled down hills and run away from bees yet his suit looks perfectly pressed?2 - How come he offered to help the mute man put a couple of logs back on his cart yet when the rest fell off Cage walked away cos the man happened to be mute?3 - Why did he have a major allergic reaction to the bees and nearly died yet when talking to the Sister as the bees were flying into him it didn't have any reaction?4 - why did the pregnant women he encountered walking in the wood look like they had hidden jumpers up their dresses?5 - why does he show no sign of hypothermia or weakness after getting out of a full of water well he has just spent hours?6 - why does he shout continuously lines like "how did it get burned?" repeatedly6 - Why is he so thick and exceedingly stupid?Far too many more to list. And in all honesty at least for those who love the original we had some empathy for Edward Woodward's character - but actually i couldn't care less what happened to Nic's character because he was so awful and unlikeable with a real arrogant attitude and a clear hatred of womenTerrible - 1 out of 10 for sticking to the original font on the title nothing else

column4: Its the worst show i have ever seen in my life! Completely disappointed!
column5: This show is by far the worst i have even seen. There is completely no horror or suspenseful element. It is poorly made. There is no interaction or much plot in this movie. The sound effects are horrible and poor. Sometimes the storyline make no sense at all. Worst of the worst the ending is the lousiest i have ever seen in any movie. I would rather watch snails crawling or count the number of grass in the backyard than to watch this show! Waste of my precious time. It is so lazy so slow so unexciting draggy and if there is a zero star rating this movie got my vote for that! Completely and utterly disappointed by this movie.

column4: A horrendous movie that delves into the 'so-bad-it's-good' category
column5: Some films are bad. These bad films usually just get forgotten about over time however some films are just so bad that they go full circle to being good. Examples of this include Battlefield Earth Silent Night Deadly Night 2 and perhaps the most famous of all Plan 9 From Outer Space. The Wicker Man is one of these movies.The original 1973 The Wicker Man was a horror classic that played on some very real fears that built themselves up to an unforgettable conclusion. It was a must-see movie. This is also a must-see movie but for different reasons. It is flat out hilarious. I have never laughed so much at a supposedly serious movie in all my life. The plot involves Nicolas Cage as a police officer investigating a missing girl case on a remote island which follows a strange cult that incorporates human sacrifice as one of it's traditions. No originality is present in this remake except the fact that the cult is an all-female cult who believe men are inferior. The blatant sexism here is preposterous.Nicolas Cage used to be a good respected actor. His previous films such as Raising Arizona and Face/Off were critically acclaimed and liked by many. However in the decade of the noughties it all went sour. National Treasure was good natured fun that audiences loved but critics hated and with films such as Gone in 60 seconds Con Air and Knowing it was clear that his career was dwindling and this movie did for Nicolas Cage what jumping on the couch on Oprah did for Tom Cruise.Let me just give you some actual samples of dialogue from this film and yes these are actual lines from the film: ''No not the bees not the bees! Aaaaaah! They're in my eyes my eyes! Aaaaaah! Aaaaaah'' ''What you got in there(a bag) a shark or something?'' ''Off the bike. Get off the bike. (Shouting and holding gun)Step away from the bike'' This film also has the infamous ''How'd it get burned'' rant by Cage who also proceeds to punch women while wearing a bear suit. The film is worth seeing for it's comedic value. I rate it 1 out of 10 because as a horror film it fails on almost every level. It is not scary thrilling or suspenseful. Forget Borat Superbad American Pie or Hot Fuzz. For a truly great recent comedy check out this movie you won't be disappointed.

column4: Think Manos with a Bigger Budget
column5: I went to see this movie having seen the original and quite curious as to what might have become of it. I anticipated a horrendous piece of cinema unfit for film of any kind. I was pleasantly surprised to find that I was right but wrong at the same time.The 2006 version of The Wicker Man was absolutely atrocious but in a way that made it absolutely hilarious. Much like chop-socky or MST3K the film's flaws are so outrageous that they end up being silly rather than painful.Take for example the scene towards the end where Cage is being led to the Wicker Man. He is screaming and yelling as the procession carries him forward. A loud THWACK sound is heard followed by Cage screaming "AHH MY LEG!!!" Or when he's in the head of the Wicker Man and Rowan is running toward it holding a lit torch. Cage responds by saying something along the lines of "Sweetie drop the stick! Drop the stick honey!" Nobody can act the dramatic elements and suspense of the original are cut out and the end result is a terrible piece of silliness. I recommend you see it in a few weeks when theaters are empty and you and your friends can heckle it to your heart's content.
3 words: Not The Bees!............ Nic Cage at his finest

Edward Malus receives a letter from his former fiancée Willow who left him years ago without any explanation telling that her daughter Rowan is missing.Edward travels to the private island of Summerisle where Willow lives in an odd community that plant fruits and she reveals that Rowan is actually their daughter.Along his investigation with the hostile and unhelpful dwellers Edward discloses that the locals are pagans practising old rituals to improve their harvest....Is the film as really as bad as the critics and people on this site make it out to be? Well it depends which way you view it. It you watch it for what it really is a serious movie which is a remake of a cult classic (which in my opinion many people here hadn't heard of until this was green lighted but not all mind) or watch it a second time and view the film as a comedy.I guarantee you will have a better time.Cage is on complete autopilot for this and not even when he is being covered in bees does he change his monotonous voice. Which is annoying after seeing him in so many great roles he could have put something a little more 'wired' into his role.But then the rest of the cast look like they are on some sort of honey/mead high.The story is okay and the narrative trundles along at a snail pace but the film does lack any tension or thrills whatsoever.But if you watch it from a comedy point of view you get to see Cage in a bear suit Cage roundhouse a barmaid Cage commandeering a bicycle and Leele Sobieski (correct spelling?) doing the best passing out routine ever committed to film.Don't think of it as the Wicker Man think of it as The NIcolas Cage comedy house party.....with friends.

column4: A Visionary Director Courageously Reinterprets a Classic Film
column5: Visionary director Neil LaBute has fashioned a motion picture that is not a remake but a beautifully realized personal interpretation of the original source material. Sensitively observed and carefully crafted this is a film that is breathtaking in its imagery and quite disturbing in its haunting surrealism. An outstanding cast is uniformly excellent and the characters in this story are as gripping as they are fantastical. Nicolas Cage gives one of his finest performances in a role fashioned originally by the great Edward Woodward and Cage manages to make that iconic character uniquely his own. LaBute's depiction of a sinister alien culture is accentuated by his creation of a heavy atmosphere of fear dread and ultimately overwhelming terror. He takes tremendous risks with his reinterpretation of the classic film and they pay off spectacularly. Courageous artistic choices and creative vision make this Wicker Man a stunning motion picture experience.

Nic Cage goes in search of his lost daughter in THE WICKER MAN and runs afoul of an isolated community of pagans. This remake of an old Chris Lee flick has little suspense and nothing to hold the attention as Cage literally scrambles about the countryside thinking he has glimpsed his kid first here and then there. Some of his search becomes downright comical especially in a scene where he is trapped overnight in a cistern. Cage's character is allergic to bees and there's a scene involving torture-by-bees where Cage utters what is destined to become an immortal line: "Oh God not the bees!" Ellen Bursteyn of THE EXORCIST fame is wasted here as the head of the mysterious coven much the way veteran horror actress Alice Krige was underutilized for a similar role in SILENT HILL. Skip this one.

column4: I know horror Nick Cage/ Neil whatever his name is director.
column5: I'm afraid you couldn't even discern the plot of the only movie to be called The Wickerman from 1975. However thank you for pissing so fiendishly like a 12 year old boy who's just found his daddy's playboy and is nervous on one of the finest films I've ever seen. You changed the story you changed the Scottish theme. You pussied out on a story about a man dying for his religion at conflict with another. You pussied out on plot development for the sake of cheap and I mean crack whore cheap thrills and red herrings (I'm not even sure you knew the purpose for those devices used with supposed care in even the most thoughtless mystery story.) that went no where near the plot. It was nothing but random and had the feel of a really bad student film. Student films are where you screw up to learn. You should not do this at the professional level. No offense but MY student film was better. Though I shouldn't compare it to student films because that is offensive to student films!!! I don't even want to know how much money all what 20 studios that tried to get their hands on this you ruined. But at least the trailer was decent so maybe many people will go see it. And even though it will more than likely never be a fan success maybe it won't lose money though at this point it deserves too.And for all obvious reasons a MAY POLL represents the penis. Not man you douche but you thought you were being clever I guess changing the meaning of an actual religious pagan tradition.It was however worth my 5.00$ Because I spent the majority of the time laughing with my friend Rachel we couldn't even keep a strait face after the film had finished. And I did get to see the trailer for The Fountain which looks good.I'm giving you a three because I didn't leave and or vomit.

Man Hollywood is a fickle beast lately. I guess they figure they've earnt some kudos with movies like 300 and The Departed and so think we'll let them off wasting our time and money with complete crap like The Wicker Man. Unlike the remakes of Texas Chainsaw Massacre and The Hills Have Eyes which were total re-imaginings that stood well on their own here we have an unimaginitive retread of the original the only bit of note that I remember being the ending (which they kept here).I was really unimpressed with Cage in Ghost Rider and here he does nothing to redeem that travesty. Although he isn't quite as terrible he phones in another "couldn't give a rats arse" performance. Guess he needs to eat same as everyone else. There isn't a single scare in the whole movie and AGAIN it's cliché cliché cliché some of which were a push when used in the original over 35 years ago for heavens sake.Even people who haven't seen the original version will see the ending coming a mile off. The photography is pants the acting is pants and the direction is lacklustre and by the numbers and this movie is just an exercise in banality all round really.I think I'm just going to get a rubber stamp made up for my IMDb reviews (a cyber one obviously)as I seem to be saying the same stuff over and over again for most of the movies I'm seeing lately. Are we really reaching the bottom of the barrel? It seems we might be. Well as long as we're mug enough to keep supporting this crap someone somewhere will keep churning it out....

column4: An attempt at a remake of an understated classic smart "thriller"
column5: Don't. Just....don't. There are so many problems with this movie. What's bad is that you have really quality actors who could pull it off. Burstyn looks great and is a great actor. Cage the same. Leelee looks like she was just thrown in. That was a waist. At least put her in as the bar wench. Having the community cast in such a mysterious light was wrong. The key element to the original was that the lifestyle led on the isle was normal but different from society on the mainland. This is not horror. The original was not horror but more of a thriller. I will direct you to my friend blakndn's analysis of the film you can view on this board. I cannot go on further.

column4: Well that was worse than I thought
column5: I actually think 4 is a little generous but I'm feeling nice today. So to start I wanna say that I know this is a remake but this quick review is based on me not seeing the 1st film and watching as it's own entity.So on that note I'm going to start with what annoyed me the most. And that would be Nicholas Cage. I don't like to give actors grief for bad performances but my word this is a bad one. Overacting from start to finish. So much so that it puts you off the film entirely. Honestly awful.So the plot. It was just bland and very predictable. Nothing really of note happens until the final 10 mins but what I found really poor was the holding of suspense was dire. I'm supposed to be on the edge of my seat wanting to know more and I never did that once whenever something "major" happens that is supposed to be a big turning moment it was so underwhelming and underdone that it kind of just floated by like any other scene. Really badly done and the ending just summed up the whole film. Nothing was solved and it just answered what we already assumed about 2 minutes into the film.The characters were all a bit pointless as well nothing to relate us to them or "root" for them. Again didn't help the acting was poor throughout but the writing of the film clearly didn't help either.So yeah wouldn't recommend this one personally it's a boring flat and predictable plot with awful acting. A very weak 4/10 from me here.

column4: Don't see this one if you saw the original. And if you didn't see
column5: the original don't see this one either -- see the original.A few weeks ago I hadn't seen either. I rented the original which was a very good movie. It had an intriguing and unusual plot decent acting and a cultural charm all of its own. You ended up enjoying the scenery on the way to the destination complete with memorable characters and a far more captivating setting.Perhaps if I had not seen the original this would have been less of a disaster. Suffice it to say that it took me almost two weeks to make it through the film it was so bad. I would turn it off come back a couple days later hoping it would be better and it never was. Watching movies is supposed to be enjoyable. This wasn't.Cage is a combination of overacted obnoxiousness and wooden boredom. Imagine a cop that is rude to everyone he meets (after the opening scene) jumps jurisdictions and begins bossing everyone around and even pointlessly bullies children. By the end of the movie I was rooting for the Wicker Man. He even pulls a gun on a woman half his size to take her bike brandishing the gun as if she were from Delta Force.Others have detailed many other problems I won't repeat. I would add that I found that the opening scene became annoying after watching it a dozen times as a flashback inserted randomly into the movie. What the heck was that about? And an unloaded handgun that he doesn't "notice" as he moves toward the final confrontation? He is supposed to be a policeman. Even the rankest rookie would check to make sure a weapon is loaded before venturing into what was clearly a hostile and high risk encounter. I only wish my shirts stayed pressed and spotless after swimming in them fighting in them rolling around on the ground in them. And is there any man in the audience who can even imagine digging a six foot hole while dressed not only in a tie and dress shirt but a jacket as well? See the original. Don't see this movie. Treat yourself to a movie pass -- literally.

column4: nearly beat for beat remake but without any art to it
column5: Watching this film now long after it came out and very much aware of the memes and comedy to be had from Nicolas Cage's performance I don't know what I expected from this film. I didn't expect it to be good but I can say at the very least it is not so painfully awful or boring that it's unwatchable.I had watched the original The Wicker Man long before this one and fell in love with it. It was a whimsical tale of an entire island's worth of bright friendly musical people all coming together for a celebration and all laughing in the face of Sergeant Howie as if all in on a joke at his expense.Here there is no music there's no friendliness there's no real energy or drive to much of anything or anyone. Part of what made the original The Wicker Man a delight was seeing just how painfully tense each situation could get as Sgt Howie struggled to keep his calm against increasingly cryptic and unhelpful island folk who all smile and lie to his face too polite and proper to arouse blatant suspicion but just so obviously malicious in some unspoken way as to give you the creeps.Everyone here on this island is either a rude and obnoxious or just randomly weird for no real reason. There's no interplay between Nicolas Cage's character and really anyone as they are almost all either snippy and hostile to his face or just blandly tolerating him no matter how often he metaphorically or literally waves his badge and gun.The story is almost beat for beat a copy of the original The Wicker Man with Edward coming to the isle investigating a missing persons case of a girl named Rowan asking around at the inn and getting a room there asking at a school meeting Lady Summersisle digging up a grave stealing a costume to blend in the entire ending sequence.The main difference is that there's a very distinct lack of any real art or soul to it all. Every scene or sequence taken from the original The Wicker Man is arranged and shot as if not for The Wicker Man 2006 but for The Wicker Man 1973 and then edited into The Wicker Man 2006. There's no clear reason in-story why Edward should be taking certain actions or doing certain things instead of other things except that that's how it was in the 1973 version.The 1973 version had much greater chemistry with its lead and all the townsfolk actors had much more interesting and lively townsfolk and had lots of music and singing with lyrics macabre enough to make it all unsettling. Everyone looks and feels like they're living great lives on a great island having a wonderful time despite everything.The 2006 version has none of that. Everyone looks sounds and acts either bored or miserable. No one seems to want to be there and no one seems to care about anything going on.About the only bright spot in the entire film is Nicolas Cage all concentrated in the last 10-15 minutes of the film which made me genuinely laugh out loud. It's probably the only thing about this movie that works beautifully but it's not worth it all. If they had taken the risk of having Cage's character react hysterically all throughout the film it would've made it far more watchable but it's not clear if that would be enough to carry the whole of the film.

The Wicker Man is the best British horror film of all time so why did they remake it? What could be gained? Those are just some of the many questions one will ask after watching this unintentional comedy and they are all virtually unanswerable. The existence of this film is offensive. However this is not just any horror remake. This is the worst horror remake of all time. There is not one redeeming quality not one bright spot not one silver lining. Nicolas Cage as many have forgotten is a good actor and apparently Neil LaBute was considered a good director before this misfire. The biggest question of all is how did these 2 talented people and all of the other unfortunate people working on this (Who would probably gladly pay to erase their name from the credits) not realize that this mixture of screaming bees bear suits bicycles idiots martial arts ugliness plot holes and scares which consist of... nothing is less scary than your average episode of Barney The Dinosaur?Nicolas Cage gives the worst performance by a good actor ever and spends the entire film either being wooden or screaming louder than Jamie Lee Curtis in Halloween while the other actors are blocks of wood with no personality. The script is toilet paper with numerous plot holes and a total lack of what made the original so powerful. Neil LaBute may have done some noteworthy things before this but judging from the direction here this could easily be mistaken for some laughably bad home horror movie made by 10 year olds. Still at least 10 year olds could make a better horror film than this! This is a movie with no positives at all and is an offensively pointless jaw droppingly dreadful movie which has no right to exist expect as a guide for how not to do a horror movie a Nicolas Cage screaming compilation or an advert for bee keeping and bear suits. There is nothing scary about this film except for the terrifyingly low quality. As for the unintentional comedy... I don't see what's funny about a great film being destroyed. The worst horror film of all time. Objective not subjective.0/10

Yes this is a terrible terrible movie - but it's absolutely hilarious and worth seeing just for the unintentional humor. Poor Ellen Burstyn poor Nicolas Cage poor extremely attractive woman who play's Cage's ex-fiancée...A masterpiece of unintentional comedy plays like a Christopher Guest film at times - yes it's THAT funny towards the end when Nicolas Cages traipses around the forest in a bear suit...Hilarious trust me.By the end that it manages to keep topping itself becomes a remarkable feat considering the ridiculousness and surreal humor the first hour-plus of this movie holds. Oddly enough it's entertaining.

column4: One of the best unintentionally funny movies in years...
column5: The Wicker Man is not a good movie. There now that that's out of the way I can tell you that this movie is certainly worth seeing. Not in the way you would think of it however because "The Wicker Man" is one of the funniest movies I have ever seen. I would rank it up there with "Airplane!" and "Monty Python and the Holy Grail." What's the best part about this? This film is supposed to be a horror movie. I wasn't scared at all. In fact I couldn't be scared or even shocked because there were parts where I couldn't stop laughing.The acting is terrible. Nicolas Cage is an incredibly wooden actor delivering almost all of his lines in the same monotone voice (although the more memorable parts of this movie are when he gets angry). The plot...? What plot this movie makes no sense at all. And when the point of the movie is to scare the audience this movie fails miserably. The music also sometime seems incredibly inappropriate even laughable.So if you can stand the bad parts of this movie and enjoy it as it should be watched you may find yourself a "Wicker Man" fan. I did.

column4: I take it the old one is better...
column5: Over the past couple of years I have come to realise why people dislike Nicholas Cage so much. His what I feel one tone acting...is the biggest let down. It is reflected in this film a lot if I closed my eyes i could easily believe that I was watching National Treasure 2. His actor screaming is also incredibly off putting and made me want to laugh.I really thought that the idea of the film was good hence why I have gave it 3 stars. I especially liked how the women scared the men with there brains insead of violence.I didn't want it to end when it did either I really thought the complete opposite would have happened.Great twist at the ending!

Poor Nic Cage. I went to see this movie alone and with an open mind even though I had been warned how bad it was. I should have listened. I left the theater simply in a bad mood.The plot seems interesting at first with Nic Cage as an investigator to find a missing girl on an island. Cage was obviously the only person in the entire cast who could act. Cage makes you laugh through out the movie at how ridiculous the characters are and the environment. They spend the whole movie developing his character and you really want Cage to find the girl and leave the stupid island.After waiting and waiting and waiting for the end through all the stupid twists. They basically just burn Cage's character alive. Thats it. After all the who's and whats and with all the development of him they just burn him alive. Waste of talent development and time. Bad acting worse plot and the worst ending. Garbage...complete garbage.

Killing me won't bring back your f*cking honey! - Edward Talk about a clunker my god! The original was half-way decent because it was just so easy to laugh at but celebrated Neil LaBute's remake is just too bad to be good and too good to be bad. It's a film with awful confusing and stitled dialogue a good cast but not a single good performance from anyone. Nicolas Cage returns to his 'Con Air' roots and delivers yet another lackluster performance. The only good thing about the movie is the way it's filmed -- that was pretty neat. 'The Wicker Man' tries to be compelling but in reality it's a cheesy as it gets. Neil LaBute -- What the f*ck man? I thought you were better than this! Grade: C-

column4: Reaction after watching this movie: Wow!!!
column5: My reaction shortly after watching the movie is WOW!There are three types of good movies. Ones based on: plot message both. After watching this thing I was really angry. Not so much at the movie but at myself for obviously having somehow missed something in the movie that would explain everything and tie the whole thing (either the plot or the message) together in some way...then I glanced at the reviews of critics and other viewers; it finally settled in. My subconscious suspicions were correct. This is no message. There is no plot. One sometimes comes across movies that have obviously been padded with extra material to lengthen the movie. This material usually does not tie in into the story in any way. This movie definitely has a lot of padding but it appears that the producers forgot to insert the actual movie to go along with the padding. It feels like the entire movie is actually a spliced version of all of the Deleted Scenes of another bad movie.*Spoiler warning (although I am not sure how this would spoil anything)* Things that do not make any sense or whose purpose is never explained: 1. Motivational Tape 2. The whole accident in the beginning 3. Hallucinations of the cop thereafter 4. The awkward visit of the female cop 5. ANY of the unnatural phenomenon that happens on the island (weird looking man in the bed woman with a whole bunch of bees on her etc) 6. The whole allergy thing (what is the point of even mentioning that?) 7. The stupidity of the main character and his inability to ask the most obvious questions of those he "interviews" 8. The complexity of the entire scheme to get Edward to the field at the end 8. Although the above pretty much covers the entire 102 minutes there is something else that does not tie in at all; Every other scene in the movie. Really.I am guessing that the climax of the movie was supposed to be the death of the protagonist; however his stupidity and annoying nature make the viewer care very little about his ultimate demise. There is no climax in this movie. Things just...happen - for no reason. I would have felt more sorry if the little girl fell and bruised her leg on her way to burn him. Actually I probably wouldn't care either. This movie would actually get two stars from me if it had Jim Carrie play the main character and have a few bad jokes thrown in here and there. At least we would then have some hint that the director was trying to make things look bad on purpose.What is so sad about this movie is that the acting was rather bad as well. The reason why this is unfortunate is because there are a few really good actors in this movie (Nicolas Cage obviously being the most apparent). Unfortunately because of the stupidity of the movie they had absolutely no chance in ever getting into character. Mr. Cage would have a better chance portraying a Russian Birch tree than playing this character. At least the tree has physical characteristics nonsense does not.THE PROS: The "quality" of the post-production effects and cinematography. Basically the quality of the way things look is better than that of raw footage.P.S. I honestly believe that those who say that they see something in this movie are the same people who stare at unoriginal abstract paintings painted by an uncreative child. The people realize that the painting is crap but they do not wish to look odd or not intelligent enough in front of those who are wondering and saying the same thing. Let me put your peoples' minds at rest -- there is really nothing to this movie.

column4: Yep it's really bad. Like a sci-fi channel movie without the good acting.
column5: The worst part of this movie is that it lays any claim whatsoever to lineage from the original classic.This is the worst remake since the remake of The Shining.This movie makes you wonder how something so bad came about. I really don't know much about movie making but I know somebody has to write a script and get some money to make it. Isn't there some type of quality control?Awful writing terrible acting (that's what I expect from Cage).I blame the sci-fi channel for this. The sci-fi channel movies have lowered the bar so low for movie making that anything looks good in comparison.But not this movie. It resembles a sci-fi channel movie not a real movie.The only reason I watched the whole thing was to see Leelee.

column4: Interesting Remake Not Quite That Bad.
column5: The Wicker Man is a remake of the 1973 cult classic that starred Christopher Lee. This film opens with Edward Malus (Nicolas Cage) a police officer who witnesses the accidental death of a young woman and her daughter. Six months later his ex-fiancée Willow (Kate Beahan) sends him a letter asking him to come to Summers Isle a secluded island that homes an isolated farming community with their own ways of life where she now lives to help find her daughter Rowan who has gone missing. The locals seem to be living in a different time and consist mainly of women whom aren't too friendly with Edward. While investigating into the young girl's disappearance and rehashing his previous relationship with Willow Edward discovers that a pagan-type ritual is about to begin and he thinks that Rowan may be part of the sacrifice. But while Edward becomes obsessed with saving the little girl he isn't aware of the fact that it might be himself who needs to be saved.I really loved the original "The Wicker Man". It wasn't a 'scary' film per se but it was a unique clash of belief systems and was captivating to watch - especially because of Christopher Lee's amazing performance. While it did have a few downfalls it was overall a fine piece of work and is fully deserving of it's cult status. Neil LaBute updates the film twisting the plot around a little here and there and adding in some new characters and revelations in the story. This film is actually fairly well written and while many disagree I didn't find it boring in the least. The script was very well-plotted and paced and the revelations in the plot were given out at the right moments. Aside from the story there's some great scenery to offer and the island really is beautiful - the landscape of the island is very well established in this film which is one improvement on the original in my opinion.The acting wasn't all bad either. Nicolas Cage was good for the most part there were a few scenes that I think were a little overdone and his acting was a bit hammy but nothing too major. Unlike the original film in which the island's leader was a man in this film the leader is Sister Summersile played perfectly by Ellen Burstyn - probably most famous for her role in the 1973 horror landmark "The Exorcist". She's great in the movie she's really great in everything I've seen her in so no complaints there. Kate Beahan is okay as Willow but at times she conveyed mixed emotions and I wasn't sure what she was going for. Molly Parker ("Intensity") plays another villager very well and Leelee Sobieski ("Joy Ride" "The Glass House") is good as an odd worker. The acting is overall okay some of it wasn't great but I've seen worse.What I really don't understand more than anything is the consistent hate directed toward this movie. The story really isn't all that different from the original it has a few spins on it (among them being the female-dominant community and the island leader being a woman and Edward's relation with the Willow character) but for the most part this film is pretty close to it's predecessor. I hear a lot of complaints about the way that the film ends also which leads me to believe that the majority of this film's audience never even saw the original film because they both ended in practically the same way (I did watch the extended ending on the DVD which was much better than the theatrical ending I might add although not really all that different). The ending is harsh and abrupt just like the original film's was and just as it should be. So why all the complaints? I thought it was a pretty solid suspense film and it'd be hard to convince me otherwise.Overall "The Wicker Man" isn't that bad of a movie - and nowhere near as bad as some reviewers have made it out to be. I thought it was an entertaining well-done horror film with all things considered. Some of the acting was questionable but besides that I thought it was good. You probably won't be scared by it but if you enjoy a good suspense-thriller you'll more than likely find this as a good rental. Also check out the original film which is excellent (and better than the remake). 7/10.

Edward Malus a police officer played by Nicholas Cage is lured by his ex-fiancé to an island to locate her missing daughter. While there he encounters endless frustration as the inhabitants of the island resent his presence and lie to him repeatedly.This movie is so bad that it occasionally warrants laughter. The plot is a cross between Hostel and The Village but it is not as entertaining. At no time are the characters believable or interesting. The opening scene has no relevance to the plot at all. The movie subjects the viewer to pointless flashbacks of the opening scene with slight variations. The only action this movie has is Nicholas Cage getting into an occasional fight with women. These fights are not intended to be amusing but one fight is so poorly choreographed it's hard not to laugh.The most annoying part of the movie is watching a policeman disregard all due process and legal jurisdiction. In the story's attempt to make Nicholas Cage appear as a ruthless investigator they only succeed in making him look stupid. This movie is so bad it's not even worth renting.

Contains some spoilers. Be warned.My first review. This movie deserves a much higher score and I'm going to try and explain why. Hitchcock said something like "I like to scare people and while making them smile". That is exactly what this movie does. It has mysticism that builds up while also getting more and more comical and not in a slap-stick sort of way but in a subtle absurd one which is my favorite kind of humor. It's not funny if you know it's for fun. If you feel the same way you'll enjoy this movie.I just love "my god� Oh my GOD!" when Cage is introduced to the wooden statue and "NOT THE BEES!" and all the slapping and the bear costume. That and the thick mystic atmosphere makes a lovely recipe of a movie if you ask me. A mixing of genres. It is not a thriller and it is not a comedy it's something rare which is both engaging and comic.I've read some of the reviews here and would like to address the issue people tend to have on Cage's acting. I though it was superb. One must have in mind that his character is suffering from lots of trauma and medication and that it is a rare genre. Despite this I though his character was deep and dynamic with lots of layers that might confuse people expecting a B-thriller and one-dimensional leads. I love the way he approaches Willow that I think every hurt/love-sick man can identify with. Lots of layers there. Impressive. One must also consider the fact that he is not a "good guy" but a just a man with issues and possibly quite anti-feminist.Don't have much to add to the other actors but would like to point out that they are not bad actors but are portraying complex characters and seen from Cage's perspective whom himself is delusional and mentally ill and it all adds to the mysticism and they're all doing a good job.I think the problem many people have with this movie and its characters is that it enters an alien world with alien people in it. You need someone to cling on to and that would be Cage. Only problem is that he turns even worse than the others� I on the other hand like it and want to see more of it.

This is a terrible film theres no getting away from it. I've seen many remakes that are serviceable or just a new coat of paint that aren't as good as the original but this just at a level way below it. All its achieved is had Nic Cage act crazy and spawn multiple memes and gifs because of it.

column4: Nowhere near as good as the original...
column5: I have just seen the Remake of The Wicker Man this evening and found it to be nothing like the original 1973 version. Only some parts of the film contained the same storyline. The story is about a patrolman called Edward Malus who is recovering from a tragic accident on the road he gets a letter from his former fiancée Willow who left him years ago without any explanation telling that her daughter Rowan is missing. So Edward travels to the private island of Summerisle where Willow lives which is in an odd community that happen to plant fruits she reveals that Rowan is their daughter. Edward starts an investigation into what has happened. along the way he meets the locals who are hostile and unhelpful Edward finds out that the locals are pagans practising old rituals to improve their harvestand believes that Rowan is still probably alive and is being prepared to be sacrificed. I found that the story did not fit very well like the original version of the film. VERY DISAPPOINTED.

column4: Too many producers spoil the broth.
column5: I've heard the remake excuse me "re-imagining" of The Wicker Man was bad but never in my wildest dreams did I think it was this God-awful. Thank God I watched this on HBO instead of renting this or seeing it in theaters; I would've felt severely ripped off. This was so bad I'm still trying to cleanse my brain from the stench. You'd think that with a child missing the residents of the island would be a hellava lot more concerned than they were. Willow mother of said child was so evasive and came across as such a brainless idiot I kept hoping Nicolas Cage would either slap the bejesus out of her to get ANY information or just leave the island altogether and let the kid stay lost or dead or whatever happened to her. And what is Ellen Burstyn doing embarrassing herself with with flowing costumes and painting her face like Braveheart? The festival looked like a bad version of The New York Renaissance Festival. And how many producers were involved in the atrocity? There must have been four or five different logos on the screen before the credits even started to roll. Talk about too many cooks spoiling the broth.

column4: I'm Glad They Made This Awful Film
column5: Why am I glad that they made this shoddy excuse for a film?
