This has to be the worst remake of a British classic yet and Hollywood is out to ruin every one it can (Get Carter Alfie The Italian Job etc.). What will they butcher next Billy Liar? Percy? A Clockwork Orange? I cringe at the thought! Well this did inspire hundreds to seek out the original who hadn't seen it though it no doubt ruined a bit of the suspense for them. I must warn anyone who has yet to see the 1973 classic that there are prints with about 12 minutes cut floating around so be sure and get a copy that runs 100 minutes! Last but not least the remake is hilarious and inspired all these equally hilarious reviews. I just spent the last hour laughing so hard my jaws and ribs hurt. Thank you IMDb contributors for making something so bad into so much fun! Anyone out there who hasn't see the original. It is a brilliant picture!

Leave it to Nick Cage to star in a terrible re-make of one of my favorite horror/thriller movies of all time. Oh boy were to startwell first thing is that the acting was terrible. I mean I don't understand how you can have such an amazing actress such as Ellen Burstyn who was spectacular in Requiem for a Dream and still have such flat boring acting. Besides the acting they threw in some stupid plot lines that I don't recall being in the original.Then I get to my biggest problem why in gods name is Nick Cage still being hired to star in movies. Nick Cage is the same character in every single movie the only actor in my eyes that is worse then Cage is Megan Fox and at least she is attractive and not a 40 something year old actor with fading talent. All in all I would not recommend this film to anyone unless your the kind of person who enjoys crappy re-makes of good movies and I know there are some of you out there. -S.o.t93

I'm probably not saying anything new here that somebody already hasn't said in a review but I just got done watching this and the only reason being was to see how bad it actually was. First major gripe I had with it was the writing and the dialogue are awful. The writers didn't think a lot through. There were so many loose ends and things that went unexplained. They were just waiting for their next paycheck. Second gripe I had with it was that the acting is terrible. I've never been much of a Cage fan and the rest of the cast weren't any better either. A good rule of thumb I go by is that if you can tell they are acting they aren't doing a good job. Good actors sell their roles and convince you. Needless to say I wasn't convinced. I'm not a very harsh critic and if a movie entertains me it did its job but when a movie is this blatantly bad it can make anybody a harsh critic. Overall a poor movie. Just don't see it. Don't waste your time.

column4: don't watch this movie. you will hate this sad excuse of a film.
column5: someone said it 100% true the the bone and i wanted to say the same thing. worst movie i've ever seen. now that may sound exaggerated but I honestly believe it was. There are bad movies that are still good because you can make fun of them or appreciate them for what they are(i.e. Evil Dead) then there are movies like the Wicker Man that take you down a dramatic path into absolute terrible storytelling and a waste of film. I honestly felt insulted as a viewer to watch this crap. I've never seen a movie so disloyal to it's main character. Why on earth was this film made? Nicholas Cage used to be one of my favorite actors now he's on a downward spiral doing Shiite like this Nextand Ghost Rider. Nicholas Cage we all miss the cool version of you. What are you thinking?

column4: Good much better than I expected
column5: With the typical scepticism of someone who has seen and admired the original I wasn't expecting that much of this film but the reviews I read suggested it may be worth a look. I found the original a haunting and tricky movie in many ways and was fully prepared for a dumbed down version. What I got was a slickly filmed and credibly spooky horror which was sufficiently different to the original as to hold my attention until the climax.As already stated in a review here the scenery and cinematography is stunning and although I didn't think the plot was quite as clever as the original the professional style of the acting and filming more than made up for it. God bless Hollywood!Not quite as haunting as the original but is this because I'd seen it before? Well that can never be known but whether or not you saw the Edward Woodward version (and as this film makes clear - it is after all Woodward's film when all's said and done) this film is an intriguing way to spend an enjoyable couple of hours without disappointment. I'm not sure I liked the final twist as don't think it added anything to the film and the viewers' imagination could probably add that in anyway but it didn't spoil the film.

column4: What an extraordinary piece of cr*p.
column5: Firstly I would like to say I have never been so moved by the complete stupidity of movie to actually submit a comment online.This script was terrible. Why would so many fairly respectable actors take part in a disaster with such a preposterous plot line? Not withstanding the fact that it was obvious half way through the film he was the intended victim. Why why why would these people go through such an elaborate ruse to claim their victim when they merely could have bonked him over the head or something the second he stepped onto their farcical little island. At least the movie would have only been 15 minutes long that way and I wouldn't have felt I had wasted two hours of my life on this P.O.S.I can't even describe the silly dialogue. The entire audience was laughing at lines that were intended to heighten the suspense. Speaking of which not much in the way of suspense to divvy about either.I was so fed up with Nicolas Cage's character (how stupid is this guy? You're being set-up.... duh? Isn't he supposed to be a cop?) that I was actually glad to see him go up in flames.How ridiculous was that bear suit scene huh? I thought the movie had suddenly turned into comedy. That seen would have played wonderfully for the Wayans brothers.P.S. who's the woman hater anyway? This Neil LaBute guy must really have had some bad experiences to portray women in such a way.

I never saw or even heard of the original so I'll handle this on its own merits. Unfortunately it has no merits! I don't ever say this kind of thing but this may be the worst movie I have ever seen. I rented it because Nick Cage was in it. I'll know better in the future.The opening scene with a roadside car wreck implies promise and yet this event is not really connected to the rest of the movie. It goes downhill from there.Cage plays a highway cop who was injured and traumatized in the roadside accident. He gets a letter from an old girlfriend frantic to find her missing daughter. Naturally Cage goes to the private island she lives on to help out. The island is run by Ellen Burstyn who heads a female cult of people who wear bird masks and act like the children of the corn.Cage is in really poor form in this picture. Shuffling about clumsily and constantly jumping into water (and emerging dry). It is not meant to be funny but when you have a procession led by Burstyn with her face painted like a football fan scores of women in bird masks following her and Cage disguised in a bear suit well you just have to wonder what these people were thinking and its funny! I was astonished that the players could all keep a straight face (maybe they just did LOTS of takes).And then it ends with nothing resolved or accomplished. So aside from its poor script bad plot lousy acting overcast cinematography lack of suspense poor score painfully slow pacing and overall unintended hilarity it is a fine film deserving a -10 stars if that were possible. What a turkey! Nick what happened?

Not only was this drivel horribly written directed and produced IT HAD NOOOO POINT. I mean what was the point: don't help out an old girlfriend? Don't visit private islands? Paganism will prevail? What? This entire movie was a bunch of banter by female weirdos in an attempt to set the viewer up for a Shaymalan type twist. This movie dragged on mercilessly and dragged the audience with it every painful step of the way. There was a bunch of meaningless events and meaningless conversations right up to the very bitter disgusting and disappointing end.The movie took place on an island dominated by women. These women have chosen to isolate themselves on this island to get away from the stereotypical feminine role placed upon women in the outside world. It is bad enough that the "Village" storyline has been played out but at least in other occult isolationist type movies there is an acceptable ending. This movie was so very pointless that it defies logic. I can't believe Nicolas Cage signed on to such a film. This movie was a joke and what sucks is that the young lady working at the rental store warned me but I didn't heed the warning. I guess this is what I get.

I never watched the original and I had suspected the ending to this stupid movie ten seconds after his landing on the island.I am not sure what the death of the girl/mother had to do with the story. Did we require some validation that Nic would love his daughter once he learned of her? I assume it led to some explanation why he wanted to help the girlfriend.I didn't understand why it was there......Or why he would trust/want to help/respond to a loony bird girlfriend that left him cold....Or why he would continually show a badge and refer to "police duty" in a place he had absolutely NO jurisdiction....Or why he wouldn't have contacted the Washington State Police FBI etc. in the matter of a missing little girl so someone in the world knew he was there......Or how these women of significant planning was going to explain his disappearance to all the police that he worked with and for......Or why the fact that the other men/boys were treated as slaves without tongues and he expected to somehow intimidate or influence the women...There are several hundred more "ors" I just don't have the interest to continue with them...Really Bad movie.

column4: The ends do not justify the beginnings
column5: The Wicker Man (2006) dir: Neil LaButeI never cared for the original The Wicker Man. I found it slow dull and rather uninteresting with the exception of lots of boobies.LaBute has taken the idea and made it into a Neil LaBute rant about feminism. However the movie tells more about the creator than it does about feminism.Police Officer Edward Malus works the motorcycle beat in California when a girl and her mother are hit by a truck and the car explodes while he tries to save them. However the bodies are never found. Coincidentally while he's on leave and taking meds he receives a note from his ex-fiancée (7 years ago) whose daughter is missing and he feels summoned to the location of Summersisle a private island in Washington. There he finds that the residents to be mainly female pagans who believe in femininity as God. The residents however make it out that the missing daughter doesn't exist. And with an oncoming ritual of fertility to appease the Gods will Malus be out of time before the girl is sacrificed? Edward Malus is a poorly drawn Neil LaBute male protagonist. He is the uncaring machismo male who is one-minded and full of wrath. This time however he is also dumb irrational and makes a lot of decisions out of his character. Acted by Nicholas Cage the character loses all hope of even resembling a fully-drawn character. Nicholas Cage emphasizes every distinct mood change and irrational moment to the point of nausea.He is up against a man-hating female society led by Sister Summersisle played by Ellen Burstyn who is still a good actress slumming it in this picture. All of the females have a distinct personality trait but not a full-fledged personality. But this is the point.And what a point it is. Reinforcing the idea that women are smarter than men (see The Shape of Things) The Wicker Man sends Malus to his inevitable conclusion regardless of logic and behavioral standards. LaBute adores feminism and hates men. However he also resents male brute strength over females. He also resents female emotional strength over men. And this cements his beliefs fully. But his ideologies aren't even at fault here.The beginning of the movie starts out fair enough but as the movie pushes its way down you have to make more and more leaps of faith. And then the bad dialog comes pouring out in the final 20-30 minutes. From "I'm going to find Rowan and what I need from you is to stay out of my f---ing way!" to "Ahhhh my legs!!" the movie gets some really silly dialog...and considering its a LaBute film its a shame to see his talent for dialog go to pot.The big questions however are "Is it better than the original?" and "Is it worth it?" It is arguably worse than the original. It is vastly different and in some aspects better and other aspects much much worse. But it isn't worth it.C-

column4: I liked this movie especially its conclusion!
column5: First of all I must say that when I decided to see this movie I didn't know it was a remake from a 1973's British movie I thought it was an original plot� Second I also didn't know it has such a low rate here on IMDb. If we just forget about the "remaking issue" (ok I usually don't appreciate remakes too!) what the well is so wrong with this movie to have such a bad rate?? In fact the original movie has a great rate and as far as I could see (here on IMDb) this remake is very close to the original one. So as this one is the only one I saw I will vote on this movie as I was voting on the original and my vote will be very close to the rating of first movie then�I really did appreciate this film! I think it has a good plot it has mystery suspense great scenarios and an ending that in spite of not being unexpected is a good conclusion because it doesn't turn out well. Yes it has a tragic end and I appreciate it because it's not very common and fits extremely well in this story! I just still don't understand what the hell has the car crash in the beginning to do with all the rest. It seems that it was included just to create guilt and memory flashbacks in the main character� but has nothing to do with the rest of the plot! Though it was a nice beginning because it created more tension to the movie�The bad points of the movie are that sometimes it turns a bit slow and too centered in the main character but it's all a part of the game anyway! The good points are its plot and the ending� I thing it was cruel but extremely real to a story like this!

column4: Best comedy I've seen this year
column5: How did THIS masterpiece go overlooked? Such a great movie. It's one of those movie for movie buffs really but I'm sure even the broader mainstream audience will pick on its genius. That's what this is: sheer genius.It might be unintentionally so but how many times do you see a --Bear Suit-- in the final act of a film being pulled out with such nonchalant bravery? The beginning might leave you a little confused but the moment you catch that horrible acting delivered by the police buddy you get a hint of what's to come: a lot of laugh-out-loud moments. Many lines of dialog are sure to become cult classic such as "Phallic symbols phallic symbols" "The bees are in my eyes" "How'd it get burned? X 4" "Step away from the bike" and many others.It could use a little trimming in the editing but the slow moments are crucial to enhance the precision with which it walks on the fine line that separates farce from tragedy. Highly recommended to any film fan or to anybody looking for some (many) laughs.

I haven't seen the old one but kinda enjoyed this one even though it's terribly rated everywhere. The build up is good  once Nicolas Cage arrives in the place it seemed it will go the Midsommar way but still the suspense was good. Few illogical scenes here and there and also the background of the wicker man wasn't exposed but it's still a pretty decent watch.

column4: I thought it was really good
column5: Why everyone is giving this movie such a low rating is beyond me. I thought it was very exciting and suspenseful. Then again I haven't seen the first one so to me it doesn't have a standard to live up to. I mean come on is the old one REALLY that much better? The only bad part of this movie is that once you see it it becomes a lot less exciting because you know what is going to happen. And I must say the end is rather surprising and disturbing. I really do not know what else to say but since my comment has to be 10 lines I will proceed to tell you that you should go see this movie. I will also proceed to tell all of you that this movie is a whole lot better than the cure for insomnia snore-o-rama movie "Solaris" and should have gotten a much higher rating.

I'm not against remakes in fact I'd go as far to say that I thought the Dawn of the Dead remake is better than the original. If they'd have just stuck to the original story they may have done a bit better on this but as it stands... well inconsistent in pretty much everything.The characters are the worst part and I'm going to blame the director on this as Nic Cage is a good actor but there are scenes where he just completely changes his personalty without a seconds hesitation.The whole bee-sting allergy was just odd. The set up for it was ridiculous Nic wonders through a large open expanse looking up into the sky for no apparent reason and bumps directly into a bee hive but he's in the middle of 100's of hive. Oh noes !! Seriously c'mon - he must have really been looking at the sky very intently to get into that situation.The female lead was also woeful - how can you not pick up on her suspicious behaviour or her paper-thin attempts at lying.Awful.. that said I saw the score on IMDb and wanted to watch it to see if it was that bad. It was and then some.

column4: If you need a good laugh....
column5: This is definitely the movie to see. To simply put it it was horrendous. There were so many places where this went wrong. For one thing the acting was awful. The main actress looked so distraught and wide eyed that I honestly thought that there was drug use involved especially since she couldn't complete an entire sentence. Throughout this movie there was never any straight answers too many inconsistencies and it was inconceivably boring up until the point where things got "serious." The feeble attempts to cause suspense just ended up being awkward and often hilarious. At the end I completely forgot that this movie's intention was to be horrifying and suspenseful and just became fully aware that this was indeed humorous and a complete waste of two hours that sadly I will never be able to get back.

The original Wicker Man from 1973 is one of the most unique and haunting films ever made. It defies genre and is brilliantly scripted and acted. Christopher Lee's character of Lord Summerisle is one for the ages. The image of the Wicker Man will stay emblazoned upon your mind long after you watch it. Those responsible for this execrable remake which is an absolute disservice to the original should be placed inside of the Wicker Man as it is being kindled. The worst part and there are many of this filmic abortion is Nic Cage. Remember a time when this dude could act? Raising Arizona Leaving Las Vegas and Joe all come to mind as prime examples. Now Nic has transmogrified into a drunken demented Pacino-like man/turkey hybrid that runs around in a crapulous state and yells at women and scares small children. Pathetic and bathetic. He still gets marquee roles but only because of the Coppola bloodline. Even the great Ellen Burstyn couldn't salvage this one. Her mere presence merits that 1 star though.

How on earth is it possible to take an intelligent script with superb dialog once made into a sublime movie ... and turn in into a bomb remake? Everything is wrong. The dialog is childish the acting hammy the sentiments phony subplots stupid the gun-waving ridiculous the explaining speeches excruciatingly embarrassing.And for good measure the director throws in a shovelful of supernatural antics which turns out trite and awkward. Nicolas Cage is a skilled actor so how it is possible to make him act like a first year theater student is the real mystery. He has ridiculous outbursts of anger which must be due to misfired directing efforts.On the small scale two pieces of dialog baffled me. The scriptwriter and the director must regard the audience to be incredibly dumb (only an American audience or worldwide?) unable to understand what they see with their own eyes. On the pier Cage makes every effort to look like he is searching for the girl and cries out the missing girls name. But Cage has to verbally assert to himself "where is she?". Oh dear! We the audience would NEVER have guessed he was searching for the girl from the clumsy acting alone. Why not dispense with the big budget of making a film when the dialog is ready made for radio? The second high-school cliché is the ubiquitous "are you OK?". If somebody let go of a wind they all rush around asserting each other "are you OK?". Why won't grown- up directors leave out these school theater clichés?The final scene when the girls go pickup new victims is so heavy-handed and overly explained that it makes your toes curl.If you see yourself as a normally intelligent person then watch this bomb only as a study of inept directing. Otherwise get the original version!

Nicholas Cage should be ashamed of himself for acting AND producing such as lousy movie. The ending made the entire movie pointless and irrelevant. The on;y redeeming feature was the scenery. From the one dimensional characters to the lame plot the "hero" is driven on the flimsiest "evidence" never questioning anyone longer than it takes to get out a cliché. This movie annoyed and aggrevated me you saw the ending coming after 20 mins and still cannot believe they actually did it. Like spoof horror movie the "hero" constantly takes action that you know will get him trapped or killed. Better writing and a more positive ending could have saved this movie but it did not happen. Avoid this movie and do not rent the DVD.

column4: Wow a thriller with no thrills!!!
column5: I didn't see the original but I have to say that this movie was truly awful. I am a real Nic Cage fan...he rarely makes a misstep when choosing scripts (notice I didn't say NEVER I said RARELY) but this time he should have passed. Every "twist" I saw coming a mile away including the ending. I knew he was being set up from the get-go and I knew that Leelee Sobieski was going to walk into that bar in the end. Even the acting was overwrought and as a woman I resented the fact that when we actually see a society ruled by women they are nothing more than a bunch of backwards superstitious man-hating loony tunes with no redeeming qualities whatsoever. I have nothing against paganism in fact I consider myself to be somewhat of a pagan as I am not a fan of organized religion and believe that there is merit in herbal medicine and natural remedies. But these chicks belonged somewhere with upholstered walls wearing those lovely jackets with the wrap-around arms. And his character deserved to be there as well for listening to his ex-fiancée who acted like the female version of Rain Man. This movie was not worth the free ticket I used to see it.

Christopher Lee would be spinning in his grave. Yes i know hes not dead but i think a screening of this travesty of a remake could kill him. Hollywood has done it again.They have taken what many including myself think is one of the greatest movies to come out of the British isles and taken a giant star spangled bannered crap all over it. Why did they bother they left out everything that made the original work including the acting which was so bad i think they stopped bothering halfway though. To be fair Nicolas Cage did try but the script was so bad that he never stood a chance. But the rest of the cast including Kate BeahanEllen Burstyn Molly Parker and Leelee Sobieski didn't even bother. To End my passionate review i can only say this. If you hated the uniquely storylined Beautifully scripted Wonderfully acted musically innovated 1973 directors cut of the wicker man. Well you should love the shallow boringsanitised farcically scripted badly acted remake. I personally will be building a wicker man in director screenwriter Neil LaBute's garden. I THINK THAT SAYS IT ALL!

As a long-time fan of the classic original movie it took me 4 years to get around to watching this pile of crap.I wasn't disappointed it really was as bad as I thought it was going to be - maybe worse.If you ever have a choice between watching this movie and pulling out one of your own teeth go for the dental work you'll have more fun...Greg.PS: Yes it really is that bad & proof (if any were needed) that you should never ever (under any circumstances) remake a great movie! The producers of "Suspiria" beware...

column4: Neil Howie would be spinning in his grave.... if he wasn't a Summerisle apple
column5: I had read reviews of this in the past and I knew that it wouldn't be great but I decided to buy a copy off ebay for a laugh.When watching it i began to get quite bored at the start I didn't really care to much of the car crash and the depression that resulted after that. When Malus arrived on the island things slowly began to pick up but when the people on the island began talking to him I knew they wouldn't be as sinister or interesting as in the original. When Malus entered the Tavern I thought to myself how dull and when he got talking to Willow I though oooooooo something exciting wrong!!! Eventually as we all know Malus meets Sister Summersisle and a similar conversation to the original (however not as fascinating)results.However by the end of the film I was quite keen to see how the precession would be handled. Besides the fact that Sister Summersisle looked like brave heart and also that the villagers were not really into what was happening I knew to expect little. At the conclusion when Malus pulled his gun I thought how cliché and crap we all knew it would be empty and the stinging of the bees rubbish.I actually watched the unrated and the released version and I felt that the released versions ending was crap. I believe in the movie as like the original the bees and honey failed so thats why they had to sacrifice Malus to bring the bees and honey back to life and burning him in the Wicker Man would solve their problems as it would please the Gods however at the end Willow and a friend are picking up new victims obviously for their next sacrifice which in a way discounts the whole notion of the movie on Pagan rituals that a sacrifice will make the crops thrive so I found that utterly stupid.When comparing this to the original the actors in this were terrible especially Burnstyn Cage and the one who played Willow as she seemed very indecisive about everything. The music was unoriginal compared to the original nothing was explained very well in the remake like their way of life and the ideas of the animal costumes and going deep into their religion and its beliefs. I also didn't like the slight hints at rip off from other films ie don't look now (the girl in the red dress leading the man to his death) and village of the dammed (most of the kids in bland clothes and with blonde hair).Overall I was disappointed I think if I hadn't seen the original I might have given it 5 out of 10 but as their were little shocks and little interest for all involved only watch if you have time to kill.

column4: As intriguing as a dog poop mustache.
column5: Where oh where to begin in describing the comprehensive wretchedness of Neil LaBute's latest attempt at film making?There are many kinds of film fans out there but by far the most annoying and shallow is Mr. Intriguing. You know Mr. Intriguing don't you?He's the fellow that no matter how stupid lame and incomprehensibly dull a film is he says "Gee I don't know why everyone hated it I found it intriguing." He's the kind of guy who finds the scent of dog poop intriguing. Especially when he smears it in the shape of a Hitler mustache on his upper lip and marches about the house ranting about the brilliance of science fiction that features thinly veiled references to Greek mythology. He's also the guy this version of The Wicker Man was made for. No one else could stand it.

OK first off watch the original the acting is far better and so is the storyline. Anyway onto the review I watched this film once alone and never again. Nicolas Cage is awful in this he has two emotions throughout the entire film; dull and angry. He mumbles his lines most of the time (except when he's shouting) so it's kinda hard to tell what he's saying though that may not be a bad thing. They've messed with the storyline a bit though I don't know why. In the beginning SPOILERS he sees a woman and her daughter die in a car crash (he's a policeman who pulls them over the girl throws her doll he goes to get it and they are hit by a truck) he is then comforted by his friend a female officer. I bring this up because apparently all three of them are in on the plan to get him to the island (the girl and the mother didn't die) what part they played I couldn't tell and this twist just really really complicated things. In the films defence there were some laugh out loud moments unintentional though they were just saying how'd it get burned causes me and my friends to burst out laughing. However there aren't enough so- bad-it's-funny moments to save the film. My advice; watch the film with some friends having other people laugh with you always makes a film more enjoyable.

OK I have to chime in here. The Wicker Man is a remake of a British cult movie of the same name. I cant remember the details of the original but I don't think it was as dull as its remake. Nicolas Cage is poorly cast and everyone else is used poorly or not at all.Ellen Burstyn could have done so much more here with a better writer.Speaking of which Anthony Shaffer who wrote the screenplay for the original is credited for the remake yet he died in 2001?!?!?!? Either way the premise for the Wicker redo is not shocking or moving or intelligent.I know nothing about what drives feminist in our present day culture but I have to assume that their ideas and motives are a little bit more evolved than what this movie suggests. Personally as a viewer I would liked to have seen a director/actor team up. As in Burton/Depp-Boyle/Rea you know?! The one two punch knockout that sinks this remake is Cages performance and Lebute. Cage really ruins this movie by playing into the character way too literally. Lebute trys to recreate something weird and its apparent that he has no clue how. I think someone slightly afeminite would have been better more sympathetic in the lead for instance Cillian Murphy. As for a director & writer who can do weird really good man take your pick there are a lot of really good artists out there. Hell forget weird it would have been nice to see someone helm Wicker that understood the source material and could have added a little something of themselves in the process. In the end Wicker Man 06 has no identity. Heres a silly idea that might have stirred'something"up. Why didn't they write the character of Edward Malus as gay? Then maybe those feminist islanders could have attacked him for perpetrating a woman and surprise surprise maybe we could have found out that Sister Summersisle was in fact a lesbian leading these feminist under false pretenses. Thats just my opinion. As it stands Cages performance in The Wicker Man was just one breath away from "Git er Done!"

Of the very WORST movies I have ever seen. From Nicholas Cage's Hysterics to the boorish "mystery" of the plot. It makes "Night of the Lepus" look like a Academy Award Winner. I bet the Porn industry knockoff "Evening of the Dicker Man" makes more money that this. On a sad note... What the heck was Neil Labute thinking! They must have kidnapped his poodle and threatened to send the cute little pooch to Iraq to get him to make this film. Another promising artist ruined by a certain producers need ( I groaned with dread when I saw his name in the opening credits... BUT... at least you might see some hot babes. What a foolish presumption that turned out to be) need to churn out cheap schlock hoping a name actor could fool enough rubes into spending a chunk of their teeny tiny paychecks in the hope they will be able to forgot about being poor. Ohh Mr Producer darling.... You have an Island full of hot Wiccan Pagen babes and not ONE of them gets naked!!! A festival celebrating fertility with NO SEX!!! By the end of this travesty I would have begged to see Ellen Burstyn nude just to relieve the assault on my psyche.Would someone let me know if a class action suit is filed to get our money back? Thanks.

I guess I shouldn't be surprised to see Neil LaBute's name here. Some of his films were good but there is a constant theme of hatred towards women. (I'm a male if it matters). This film fits the theme as the "hero" sucker punches an older lady who is not threatening him.Dumb awkward misogynist story. Great cast given comically bad lines to say. Also demonizes people whose religious beliefs are different than one's own but we can thank the (far superior) source material for that.I hope that by puking this stuff up onto the screen--with his hero carried off screaming "Bitches! You bitches!"--Neil is able to exorcise his demons at least enough to not hurt women in real life.

The original 1973 version was memorable. Somehow the idea of a remnant pagan cult ruling an island off NW Scotland in the 1970's seemed less absurd than a such a cult this time run by women on an island off today's Washington State. Or perhaps back in the '70's I was more willing to suspend disbelief (never completely of course) than I am now in my more jaded senescence. Perhaps the dialogue of the original version was more intelligent. Or perhaps I was somewhat in love with Diane Cilento back then. Not sure. And of course the surprise factor is no longer there (for me) - which perhaps(?) was what made the original version so memorable.

column4: Some Horror Remakes Work Some Don't. "Wicker Man" Collapses Into The Latter Category
column5: Let's face it: Remakes of classic movies are comparable to treading on thin ice. Remakes of classic horror movies are considered worse especially when the original was excellent. There are few examples of horror remakes that manage to shine brighter than the originals (The Fly and The Thing); remakes that are nowhere near as good as the originals but still manage to work (House of Wax The Omen and The Texas Chainsaw Massacre); and the remakes that sully both the original and all involved in the remake (Van Sant's Psycho Carrie and The Fog). Unfortunately playwright Neil LaBute's redo of the cult classic The Wicker Man falls (very hard I might add) into the third category.The plot remains the same as the original except for a few minor changes: police officer Edward Malus (Nicolas Cage) is summoned to the honey-collecting colony of Summersisle by a former lover of his Willow (Kate Beahan). It seems her daughter Rowan (Erika-Shaye Gair) has disappeared without a trace and Edward is the only one who can find her. The townspeople – all women (Frances Conroy Leelee Sobieski Molly Parker and Diane Delano among countless others) sans a few men who help around the colony – are all unhelpful some claiming that the girl does not exist while others say that she has died. The search leads Edward to Sister Summersisle (Ellen Burstyn) the leader of the island who also happens to be the head priestess of the Pagan religion that dominates the whole island and a terrible realization: every year a sacrifice is given to the Sun Gods through something known only as "the Wicker Man" in exchange for healthy crops and delivery of honey. And it seems Rowan has been picked as this year's sacrifice...When the preview first aired in June (around the same time the remake of The Omen was released) it was evident that LaBute's Wicker Man would be nothing like Robin Hardy's 1973 classic which can best be described as "a sexy Pagan musical." Gone are the ongoing musical numbers nubile young women parading around flames in the nude hares Christopher Lee in drag and a dubbed Britt Ekland seducing Edward Woodward's pious Sgt. Howie through the walls of her room while she sings dances and caresses her sensual form replaced with a dull Nicolas Cage who will most likely be up for a Razzie nomination next February (which is especially sad considering how perfect he was last month in Oliver Stone's World Trade Center) who gets a laugh every time he beats up a woman (in a bear suit no less!) an opening that has nothing to do with the story itself (as well as an unneeded epilogue that God help us leaves the door open for a James Franco-headed sequel) an uninspired score by Angelo Badalamenti and a complete reworking of the townspeople and the idea of good vs. evil which is the biggest mistake the movie makes. LaBute famed for his unapologetic misogyny has changed it from a township of men and women sacrificing a pious virgin (but let's be honest: who in their right mind would buy Nicolas Cage as a virgin?) to better their crops to an island of droning feminine-worshiping butchers who only use men to procreate and toss them away (well burn them away) like yesterday's garbage. Original Wicker Man scribe Anthony Shaffer must be rolling in his grave over this.However for all the wrongs of The Wicker Man there is one element that nearly makes up for most of them: Ellen Burstyn as Sister Summersisle. While she is no Christopher Lee Burstyn commands the screen with her revered presence and manages to salvage the last half-hour of the movie which is when the plot actually starts to heat up."Welcome Mr. Malus. You have come of your own free will to keep your appointment with the Wicker Man." This short line of dialog uttered by Ms. Burstyn is nothing more than a reminder of an appointment I regret having made. But I will not attempt to persuade or dissuade you the reader from viewing The Wicker Man. If you want to see it to see how the American movie studio has converted a British classic or for Ellen Burstyn and the ending (which remains faithful to the original in almost every detail except without Edward screaming for Jesus and the townspeople rejoicing and singing as the Wicker Man burns) be my guest. I am just offering a notice of caution and recommendation towards other movies in theaters within the genre. Or better yet just go to Blockbuster or Netflix and rent the original Wicker Man. At least you won't want to throw a half-full Diet Coke at the screen watching the original.D-

column4: Step away from the bike. Mmm.....
column5: I have never seen anyone run around aimlessly in a film quite as much as Nicholas Cage does in the Wicker Man. Most of the film seemed to consist of him sprinting from one location to another either shouting at women or knocking them unconscious. At least he got a rest at the end of the movie when they carried him off to the Wicker Man.There are a lot of irrelevant parts to the film the bees and even the car crash at the beginning seemed to have no real significance to anything that actually happened in the film. Also the fact the men were so subservient they couldn't utter a word was unbelievable.In the 1973 original Edward Woodward's character investigated in such a way that it gave some understanding as to why a sacrifice was being made and explored a conflict of beliefs between the pagans and the Christian policeman. The remake does not touch on this subject or give any real reason for his sacrifice other than the fact they were trying to "get one over on him".The "step away from the bike" line though is a classic and there are quite a few similar unintentionally funny moments in the film.The scenery was probably the best part of the film but overall the movie lacked cohesion and credibility and could only be recommended for the "unintentional comedy moments" and to see how bad it really is.

The 2006 edition of THE WICKER MAN is without a doubt in my mind the very worst remake in cinematic history. It is also dangerously close to being one of the worst films ever made. I think that Robin Hardy Ed Woodward Christopher Lee Britt Ekland and all that were a part of the 1973 version (a great film everyone should see) should get a free kick to the nuts of "George Lucas Look-alike Contest" runner up Neil LaBute and Nicolas Cage. I couldn't believe how awful Cage was in this pile of llama dung! I wanted to turn the movie off so many times but I was frozen in awe of how utterly atrocious it was. Watching this movie is almost self-mutilating. I know this is just another negative review but I feel it is much more. I feel a need as a compassionate human being to steer as many people away from this movie as I can!

wow this is definitely one worth watching again this is the one my daughter has been waiting to see this movie is a little hard to follow at first told in a series of flashbacks makes you wonder if you're losing it. the story starts out innocent enough the only warning i would have is that there is graphic violence and some gore so not suitable for very young children otherwise a teen would be fine with this one nicolas cage gives one hell of a performance kathy bates is back in a familiar role ie.. stephen king's misery... lelee sobieski well what can i say she is just a hottie who can act... this movie really makes you think and has plenty of twists and turns.. what really made this movie for me  is well if i said it it would ruin it so i wn 't  but this one is well worth watching a great thumbs up to this movie and i hope more are like it in the future.

Wow the script-writer must have been jilted by women quite a bit. Or have suffered some serious maternal abuse in the past. This is the most gynophobic movie I've ever seen.I've never seen the 1973 original but they morphed the original Christianity vs paganism concept into a serious anti-feminism rant--women can't be trusted women will crush men's if given the freedom to do so women are prone to insanity etc etc. The writer firmly seems to believe in the principles that prompted the Salem witch trials back in the 1600's.What a ridiculous movie. Highlight of the film is when Nick Cage starts running around in a full bear suit punching women around. Seriously.Most of the problems in this horribly flawed film came from the screen play. Meandering nonsense. Overall look and feel of the movie wasn't horrible although director failed to capture the eeriness and the suspense that this film I felt was intended to produce. They hired competent actors/actresses who really didn't get to do much acting in this except for Nick Cage. He was struggling by himself to make this thing float--I would feel bad for him except he was the producer for this abomination.I'm really sorry that all these actresses partook in a production with a really misguided message.I've got to admit it was funny. Unintended but funny.

column4: The slow painful demise of the horror film
column5: There is a glimmer of hope at the beginning of 'The Wicker Man'. Aaron Eckhart appears fleetingly and one is reminded that Neil LaBute was the brilliant playwright-turned-filmmaker that made two of the best films of the nineties with 'In the Company of Men' and 'Your Friends and Neighbours' before churning out the enjoyable yet comparatively undistinguished 'Nurse Betty' and 'Possession'. All these films starred Eckhart in memorable roles but here as he exits the first frame of 'The Wicker Man' so does one's hope that this will be as dark and disturbing as LaBute's other self-penned material albeit in a different genre. A playwright (Anthony Schaffer) after all had adapted Robin Hardy's novel in the earlier film and the results were along with 'Witchfinder General' and 'Don't Look Now' one of the most memorable British horror films of its era. The new version suffers from both LaBute's inability to direct horror with nothing resembling atmosphere or scares and the surprisingly dull screenplay which could have been churned out by any Hollywood hack. Sure he gives us a matriarchal society this time around a concept that allows him to waste an outstanding female cast (Molly Parker Ellen Burstyn and Frances Conroy among them) but Cage's character is so irritating and the townsfolk so bereft of menace that most viewers will simply persevere to see how the ending is staged. And needless to say there is nothing in the climax to rival the impact and tragedy of the original. Not as ill-conceived as the rumored remake of 'Don't Look Now' (which one hopes will never come to fruition) 'The Wicker Man' will nevertheless join 'The Fog' 'When A Stranger Calls' 'Black Christmas' and countless other pointless and insipid remakes of classic horror films that should never have seen the light of day. If Rod Zombie desecrates 'Halloween' it could be the death knell for the genre.

column4: Vastly underrated a terrific intellectual thriller no need for blood
column5: I'm tired of horror films that shock you with trick camera cuts or lots of blood and gore. To me the intellectual thrillers are the best like Silence of the Lambs or the works of H.P. Lovecraft and Edgar Allan Poe.I'm aware that it's a minority opinion but I really enjoyed the film and I would urge you to overlook the huge fans of the original. Fans are a strange bunch. They have such nostalgia for the past that they can't see that the quality of movies have improved vastly in 40 years. Instead of celebrating the attention that a remake (of whatever quality) brings to the original of course they can't help themselves in a frenzy of shredding it because their favorite plot points are gone.My my. Aren't we serious.I've seen both versions and to me the remake is superior. The production quality is higher as reflected in the costumes and visual and sound quality.Also the "Christians as victims" theme has been removed leaving to me a purer distilled theme: that humans can do unimaginable things to each other. Of course it's horrific because it's also true. Humans did create the Nazis. We do create cults.The plot is tighter with fewer lags for exposition and the nudity in the original is really unnecessary.To me it was spookier than The Island of Dr. Moreau. And the original is great too. I think we should support them both and stop being such whiners.I give The Wicker Man (2006) an 8 out of 10 and if you're looking for just one good review to encourage you to give this film a try you have found it! :)Johnny Monsarrat Consulting. All content by Jon Monsarrat!

column4: For people who haven't seen the original!!
column5: When you haven't seen the original and you think why all the hate for this movie...?Ignore it because if you haven't watched it then you have nothing to compare it to. As a standalone movie away from the original its a good movie and will leave you entertained for its duration.If you have seen the original its 100% superior to this nicholas cage version but that movie was groundbreaking for its time and people seem to forget that we have had so many movies since then with simular ideas and a remake of that great Britisch horror movie with an American cast was always going to be an issuenot to talk about anyone who has seen the original knows what to expect because this is very simular in how the story unfolds so in a way your at a disadvantage starting the movie because you most definitely will start comparing from the beginning but nonetheless this movie is far from terrible as people make it out to be.Watch it with an open mind and you will see its a very decent thriller.

Wow. That's all I have to say about this movie. Nicholas Cage's acting was captivating in every way. That was by far the funniest movie of 2006. It put Clerks 2 to shame. Every single scene was absolutely ridiculous. The best scene though was the one where Nick was wearing the bear costume. Then he blasted that woman directly in the face and all you see is him triumphantly standing over her while she's rolling down the hill. Another great thing about the movie was how it kept showing the little girl unexpectedly getting plowed by that car (On the boat in Nick's dreams etc.). But the best thing about the movie has to be the fact that it was trying to be completely serious. I'll repeat. IT WAS TRYING TO BE A SERIOUS MOVIE!!!. What was Neil LaBute thinking? Honestly what in the world could have been going through his mind in making this atrocity of a film? He'll never be able to live this down. Nicholas Cage will never be able to live this down. Never. This movie is just a gigantic practical joke on all of us if anything.

column4: Run away from if offered to watch
column5: Based on DVD with alternate shocking ending: Oh my! How can one of the best actors in recent times get stuck in such a horrible movieeven one remade off of a cult classic from the early 70's. Not one scary or truly suspenseful moment. Cage acts like he is needing a paycheck and phones in his performance while the rest of the crew is just there. My wife and 14 year old son hated it too. The scenery of the island is beautiful and the opening scenes of the crash are great but without those two items you have a poor attempt at movie making. Will this keep me from watching another CAGE movie? No. All actors make at least one bad flick. In comparison the original version is the best.

i generally do not do these comment things on sites but i feel that i must speak up on behalf of the original Wicker Man. don't be put off by this remake it may not be as good but the original is really very good and definitely worth the attention of both movie buffs and fans of cult films. the original is different rather ingenious and a major hallmark in British film history and is regarded as one of the greats of British horror cinema.please give it a shot don't let the crappiness of the remake put you off watching the original (and superior) Wicker Man.^^ ta for reading my ramblings

column4: Disgusting waste of film or tape or CD material...
column5: There are classics and there are bombs.. which leads to the conclusion that this is a classic bomb. Nay a classic DUD. It is the worst freaking movie that Nicholas Cage has ever starred in seen or fast forwarded through himself. Even he cannot possibly find one valid reason to watch this farce.. It is a joke.. It is a crying shame.. It is so bad that it should be banned. It has to be a straight to the video rental store venture and a Herculian effort to bilk the public of their hard earned dollars. Once upon a time Hollywood attempted to provide entertainment. Many of today's so called actors writers producers directors etc seem content to put a pretty "package" on a piece of dung and call it a movie.. This is nothing but garbage. Shame on all who had even an honorable mention at being apart of it. Shame Shame Shame on you!!

I'm a big fan of horror/suspense films. I went to the theatres with my friends and we decided to see "The Wicker Man." And oh boy that was a mistake.It was obvious that the movie was an attempt at some sort of a "scary movie." It was also painfully clear half way through that it had failed horribly in it's attempts to thrill me. I'm not that hard to scare seeing as the movie "Darkness" made me jump in my seat.The plot was poorly constructed: the beginning of the movie bored me extensively and the end half made me laugh until my stomach hurt. Admittingly there were several short moments that were placed in the movie for comic relief but they weren't enough to make up for the impression I had. There was one climax at the end of the movie; barely any resolution. The last five minutes was supposed to be a cliffhanger. It made absolutely no sense. The only way you would understand the short ending was if you had spent 10 minutes thinking up theories. However I was left with too bad of an impression to even think twice about what it could have meant.I could tell that I wasn't the only one who thought this. The rest of the audience laughed at the "scary" scenes as well. Not only were jokes made but chatter could be heard in the theatre throughout the movie.In compensation this would be a delightful movie to you if you're looking for something to laugh at.

If the ratings included going in the other direction i.e. giving a -1 or -10 I would have done so because 1 star is just too much for this drivel. I don't understand why this movie was even made! Couldn't they figure out a better way to waste money? How about a better way to spend money like on research (faustmanlab.org) or charity (purple hearts) or relief efforts (Katrina and Indonesia). But someone somewhere decided that this movie just had to be made and the works were set in motion to waste a boatload of money on something that would have left the world better off quite frankly had it not been finished. This movie is so bad that I was actually wondering if I was missing my cue to laugh as my mind had thoughts that this might in fact be a comedy. Alas the laughs are unintentional and it is just dreck.Going through the motions is not acting memorizing lines is not acting putting words on a page does not a good script make yelling "cut" or "action" is not all there is to directing. This was dreck from every conceivable angle.

I have never before been compelled to write a review on a movie that was bad. UNTIL NOW. I mean was this movie supposed to be about witchcraft or cults or women in power or was it just SUPPOSED to be a thriller? It was never clear but it was never any of these. It started out great - for about 10 minutes and went straight downhill. I went with 2 friends - girls night out and all 3 of us were extremely disappointed.HERE's the spoiler - This movie had so many ridiculously unrelated and stupid parts. What was in the burlap bag that was bleeding everywhere. Someone help me here... did that ever play out? The biggest one was killing the float boat pilot. I guess the idea was to make you think that these STRANGE women didn't want anyone to come to their island so the float boat captain that brought this stranger here was being punished. Then you find out the whole reason for the movie was to bring the stranger to the island and yet they kill the float boat boat pilot who presumably was the person who was bringing all of the supplies to the island. I cannot express here how TRULY disappointed I was by this movie and am really wondering what in the work Nicolas Cage was thinking when he took this role. Is this the best that Hollywood can do? Come on - I'm going to stop WASTING my money. This movie wasn't even good enough to waste your money on renting let alone the outrageous price of a ticket and popcorn at the theater.

column4: Cinch for a Golden Raspberry Award. Most awful movie of 2006!
column5: This is absolutely the worst movie in 2006. How Nicolas Cage got talked into this is a mystery. It's not like he needed the money. And it will only hurt his next offer. He must have owed someone big. Wow!The original 1973 version is a wonderful B movie a sort of film-noir horror/mystery. So I was excited to hear about this new version. I wondered what kind of twists and turns they might throw in. But it was such a let-down. It was obvious from the start where this train-wreck was going. I even saw people walk out about 5 minutes before the end. I guess they figured they had seen enough. I was thinking the same thing about 30 minutes before that but I was with some people so I just sat and bared it.The acting was passable. The plot wasn't bad. The special effects were even OK. But the dialog was so stupid it was funny. The script was so obvious as to be mind numbing. And the flashbacks were just confusing and not needed. My God! What is happening to Hollywood? They keep churning out these crappy remakes without a thought in the world about quality.If you like the idea for this movie then go rent the 1973 version you won't be disappointed. But this remake should be removed from the theaters and burned perhaps with some kind of ritual to keep them from making a sequel! You know it's coming!

column4: Movie is not all that horrible.. it's the last 15 minutes that's obnoxious
column5: I just watched the movie after reading all these reviews and it's not as bad as so many people are saying it is. The movie was pretty good until the last 15 minutes or so. It was weird interesting and also had me on the edge of my seat because I had no idea (along with the main character) what was going on sometimes because that is the nature of the story. OK... the ending sure seemed like they cut a lot of corners in the story telling and the finale leaves a bitter taste for antagonists in the story.It didn't make any statements about Pagans or religion for that matter in my opinion but did involve a matriarchial cult (meaning made up of women). It was entertaining and I think falls into the psychological thriller genre that left me sitting in my seat... dumbfounded at the end and saying to myself... "These women are really evil." and "why do I now fear islands near Washington state?"

column4: Did Nicholas Cage lose a bet?
column5: Let me say up front that I really didn't see the end coming. I never saw the original movie so didn't know what to expect. It did become clear that Cage's character was either going to rescue his wife and daughter and live happily ever after or he was going to meet a bad end. We all know what happened. I like Nicholas Cage and this movie was a complete waste of his talent.Things I can't believe: Why would a guy who is allergic to bees (a rather heavy-handed plot point) ride a bicycle into a field full of bee hives? Why would a California highway cop who is hundreds of miles out of his jurisdiction act like such a storm trooper? What are the islanders going to do for supplies after they disposed of the pilot? How did his suit last as long as it did? Why did they need to break his legs? He was outnumbered about a hundred to one and they nearly killed him with bees.The only purpose of this movie is to get drunk with friends watch it and make fun of it.

After seeing the original with Christopher Lee never in my wildest nightmares did I think such a remake could even make it out of the editing room. This is not just bad it is murder of the first degree of a wonderful earlier version. Sure the story is fanciful but the original at least MOVED the actors had PRESENCE the ending was shocking not hysterical. How the mighty Cage has fallen. I really do love Cage as an actor - I think he is talented. But what in the name of all that is holy is responsible for his bumbling shrieking over acting drooling performance here? Did he owe Lucifer something? This is BAD. REALLY REALLY REALLY BAD. So bad I almost died laughing at the absurdity of the the trainwreck on the screen. Good God Nicolas come on!!! Take some time off and remember the days where your talent actually won you a well deserved Oscar. Please do not EVER utter these phrases on screen: "How did it get burned? How did it get burneddddddddddddddddddddddddddddd?" and the immortal "Not he beeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeees!!!!" Finally what the hell is Ellen Burstyn doing in this one of the finest actresses of all time? Did she kill scads of bees and had to atone for it by appearing in this mess?

The Wicker Man "2006" is a strange movie and not in the way the 73 version was strange. I'm sure on paper the whole thing sounded great. Giving the film a hyper feminine twist and make it more accessible by casting a big star and throwing in some punch lines. It must have also sounded great to have this remake directed by Neil Labute famous for his films that have strong female leads and feature the dissection of men. But on screen it just doesn't work. It's no surprise that Labute has no experience in the genre and it's just a one of the films many problems. Cage stars as Edward Malace a highway cop who supposedly becomes involved with a horrific accident that claims the lives of a young girl and her mother. While on leave he gets a letter from his ex fiancée bidding him to come and help her find her daughter who has gone missing. Against the advice of his friends he travels to the mysterious island filled with people who worship gods and goddesses make sacrifices to ensure a good harvest and dress up as animals. He pokes around the island a bit and everyone is fitfully weird until that dreaded somewhat disturbing but clichéd conclusion. This version of that classically creepy film is strange for the fact that it tries so hard to be strange while remaining mainstream. It has the oddball dancing disturbing imagery weird dialogue and cultish festivities but it lacks being involving. And in a film like this it must be involving otherwise it comes off as being unintentionally funny. Which it is it's a laugh riot. there is not one genuinely creepy or suspenseful sequence within the entire film. All the characters are one dimensional giving questionable performances. And the plots pacing and direction give one pause when assuming the films credibility. The biggest thrills come from Cage knocking out women and jump kicking them in the faces. The 3 things this film has to offer are (1) gorgeous cinematography (2) a creepy if slightly under developed performance by Ellen Burstyn and (3) a reminder that Cage is an attractive man. Even in his older years he still retains his hard physique and chisseled face. He is always the hero the good guy succeeding to a fault. Besides the direction pacing performances and screenplay what the films ultimate problem is  is that just tries too hard. If a film is weird it's just weird. You can't try to be weird it comes off as fake. And everyone associated with this project from Labute to Cage to Sobeski is just not weird. There is no doubt that talent went into this film but talent doesn't guarantee a good movie. And with a little less tampering and a lot more originality this could have been a truly compelling take on the original. What remains is an unintentionally funny wannabe weirdo flick...and thats not really very appealing to anyone.

All I have to say about The Wicker Man is what was Nicolas Cage thinking???? YUCK!! Maybe he was high or drinking when he signed on to this film. This has got to be the worst film ever next to "Snatch" starring Brad Pitt (What was HE thinking???) The acting is awful the whole movie premise is awful the ending is just stupid. The scenery was lovely though!! The trailers present the best parts of the movie if they can be called the best parts. I even apologized to my husband after seeing this film for him agreeing to come along with me!!! Please don't waste your money or your time-Nicolas you can certainly do better than this!!

column4: i don't usually say this is crap but for this word crap is too good
column5: I think this is the worst movie i ever seen in my entire life and i will never forget the worst two hours i sat in front of a screen waiting for something to happen and ended with nothing but the main role burnt to dust while his girl friend and child watch him burn i mean what is the point of this whole movie? i mean whats wrong with nicholas cage? why is he taking roles like this? this is nothing but a pile of junk and it only takes few lines for me to tell you the whole story Horror movie fans be aware don't watch this i didn't take the IMDb reviewers advise so i watched as usual and i wasted two hours so don't join us by not taking their advice whole movie is about a cop who goes in to some sort of an island looking for a lost daughter of his long ago ex girl friend and some how she appears to be his daughter and in the end she was a part of some sort of ritual which brings honey to the farmers in the island so the whole point is bringing this stewpid policeman to the island and burning him as a sacrifice to their god to bring more harvest..... he was so stewpid that he never checks his gun whether is is loaded or not he couldn't even feel that it was not heavy with bullets DON"T WATCH THIS

This is the worst movie that I have ever seen that didn't star Jim Carey (his movies are in a class of dreadfulness all their own). The original was brilliantly scripted and other than the appalling miscasting of Britt Ekland as Willow well cast. Nicolas Cage is an excellent actor but he could not bring this one off.My advice to all would be to save your time and your money and get a copy on VHS or DVD. The original cut is on an old VHS cassette. There are various DVD versions ranging from a butchered 88 minute version to a 102 minute. Go for the 95 min or 102 min versions if you can.By the way the original soundtrack is great.

The beginning was disjointed and nonsensical and it didn't get much better. All through the supposed plot I was shaking my head at how stupid our hero was. It was supposed to be a suspenseful thriller but I saw every supposed plot twist coming. The ending was a surprise only because I didn't believe they would let the movie end with such an empty thud. I had to fast forward through it. Nothing changes no character grows there's no moral or impact on the viewer it's just an "here's an idea the end" story. The worst movie I have ever seen. At least a mindless slasher movie has a monster and shocking gore to give your spine a tingle. This movie has no redeeming qualities whatsoever.I rented the DVD (free coupon thank God) with the "shocking alternate ending". A complete lie -- the new ending was identical to the old ending with a final scene cut out. This scene was a dull cliché but at least it had two pretty girls in it and so was more interesting than the rest of the movie.

column4: What a waste of time and money
column5: Not having the privilege of seeing the original I still think this movie was an absolute waste of time not to mention wasting my money to see it. Too bad there wasn't a satisfaction guarantee because I would have taken them up on that one.They spent more time orchestrating the preview than the actual movie. The story line was so chopped up it left you wondering what in the world was going on. The humor they attempted was not funny but ridiculous and out of place however it was a relief to actually understand something in the overall movie. This actually prompted the audience to start talking during the movie and make comments about what happened or what was about to happen. I have to admit that the movie was very suspenseful....it held you in suspense waiting for something to actually happen! Nicolas Cage constantly had a dumb look on his face as did all the other supporting actresses. The whole movie seemed as though they slapped it together just to get it done. Everyone in the movie including Cage had no personality at all.

Without a doubt one of the worst films I have ever seen. Mr. Cage you should be ashamed of yourself a really really bad movie. If it wasn't for the fact I was with a group I would have walked out and demanded my money back. The movie bounced all over with no general direction.Touted as a horror/suspense it was neither. - We spent most of the time laughing through it was such a drag it seemed like it would never end.I am simply baffled as to why Moviefone has this dumper rated as three stars. I wouldn't give it one period. I'm sure this will be on DVD in about a week but to all potential renters don't waste your time or money.Simply put a complete STINKER!!!!

column4: A good reason to rent a "CSI" DVD
column5: I rarely comment on a board like this. Few movies are worthy of true scorn and the ones that merit praise have other posts that cover their successes.This movie merits scorn. Heaps of it.There isn't much need to give away the plot. There isn't much to give away this movie could have been 45 minutes shorter and it still would have dragged. Suffice to say Neil LaBute has no idea how to direct a suspense or horror movie. Much less how to write either genre. Cage tries to do his part but he is given little to work with. As for the ending it's so bad it beggars description. If this is LaBute's take on feminism I'll take Sigourney Weaver's (Alien series) and Joss Whedon's any day.Save your money and two hours that you'd waste on this remake. If you want to see a horror film with a pagan/naturalistic bent rent "Lair of the White Worm". If you want a girl powered scary movie try "The Descent". The spelunkers in the latter and Amanda Donohoe in the former are worth the price of admission.Before you pay $9 for this rent almost any "CSI". Grissom Warrick Catherine Nick and Sara are a helluva lot better than this "Wicker Man".

column4: Wow I want my money back.
column5: First of all (IMHO) this was a horrible display of Nick Cage's abilities. This film is filled with horrible acting awful scene transition and horribly slow progression. The plot has potential but the screenplay and directing is a far cry from entertaining. It felt as though the whole movie was pieced together from a string of first shots with no intention of fixing. Although I haven't seen the original I have no doubt in my mind that it is much better. Under better direction and maybe a modified screenplay this might have been a decent film. The previews give this film WAY too much credit. Stay far away.

column4: Everybody deserves to watch this movie for one reason.
column5: The Wicker Man drinking game. Drink if:0. Nic Cage in a bear suit punches a woman in the face – chug fill chug. 1. Nic Cage pops pills. 2. Nic Cage hits anything trying to hurt it (including/especially people). 3. Willow fails to complete a sentence. 4. Anything gets hit by a truck. 5. Nic Cage raises his voice/shouts. 6. Nic Cage makes an unreasonable demand. 7. Nic Cage points with his entire arm. 8. Any time you suspect Nic Cage has been allowed to supply his own wardrobe. 9. Someone is intimidated by bees. 10. Nic Cage threatens or accuses someone or something. 11. Nic Cage looks perplexed/stares blankly. 12. If Nic Cage drinks you drink. 13. Drink for the entire time Nic Cage is on a bike.One of the most entertaining movies I've ever seen.

I had seen both the original with Christopher Lee and the new one. I liked them both. They may not necessarily be your "Average" horror movies but both are amazingly deep in their subject matter. Looking past whatever arguments other posters have to say about these movies the plot is rich and full and keep the viewer guessing until the end.The first one was much better at keeping the viewer guessing because Christopher Lee is such a good actor and movie goers expected to have to think when they went and saw a movie.The new movie was "dumbed down" quite a bit because modern movie-goers seem to want everything spelled out to them which is why I think movies in general are going down the tubes. There is no more critical thinking or discussion about movies anymore. Everything is spelled out and explained to the fullest extent so no one has to come up with their own opinions.

I'd been told to stay away from this film for my own sanity but morbid curiosity got the better of me and I had to watch it. I really wish I hadn't. The story as told in the previous film is interesting and there's enough her to warrant a worthwhile retelling but I'm not sure if it was the script or Nicholas Cage's horrifying overacting that ruins everything. At a certain point you stop even trying to relate to Cage as a human being and start seeing him as a cartoon in a Looney Tunes sketch where you're free to laugh and cackle at the mess he's gotten himself into. The slow burn terror of the original is nowhere to be found.

Woefully mis-cast - Nic Cage is by no means qualified enough or versatile enough as an actor to be able to emote for the character he plays.The entire film feels like it's been cobbled together from the drunken memory of an educationally-subnormal simpleton who wasn't paying attention when they watched the original.The appalling score only serves to highlight what a complete pile of rubbish this film is.Build a large wicker man and burn all the copies of this film - do the world a favour.

column4: Not nearly as bad as they would like you to think it is
column5: When I saw that rating is 37 and numerous reviews here calling this the worst film ever I really wanted to see it. Firstly because I watched the original The Wicker Man several times and consider it to be a true masterpiece. Secondly a film that has so low rating must be fun to watch. While watching the film I saw that cinematography is excellent and film is not boring at all. I constantly expected that really awful part that has to come soon judging by low rating and bad reviews here but it never came. Yes this film was totally unnecessary since there was no way it could be better than perfection the original had achieved. Yes the atmosphere is not nearly that creepy and bizzare as in Hardy's film but we are talking about one of the best horrors ever and any comparison is with it is unfair. I think that misfortune of this film is that it is a remake of masterpiece. It shouldn't have been made because there was no reason for that. However if we forget about original this film is neither bad nor boring I know thousands of films that are worse than this one some of them are many new films that are recently among Imdb's top 50 and are rated 85 or more. I would give this one 5 stars. If there wasn't some bad and corny dialogue at the very end of the film (not by Cage) and also if I hadn't seen the original maybe even 6.

The Wicker Man is a "horror/thriller" starring Nicolas Cage who has just dropped a few notches in my book for making this movie. He plays a cop investigating the disappearance of a little girl who lives on an strange island. He gets there and finds there's a bigger mystery involving the weird natives of the island. This plot may sound okay on paper but on screen it seems like the dumbest concept ever. The plot is filled with gaping holes bigger than the grand canyon and the acting is so horrific it is probably the scariest part of the movie. At first the movie doesn't seem that bad but as the story progresses it gets progressively worse. It gets to a point where you question if they're actually being serious. At about half way through the movie I was chuckling a bit but by the 'climax' of the movie I was nearly on the floor of the theater rolling around with uncontrollable laughter. Whether Cage was screaming at 10 year old girls that they're liars or was running around in a bear suit and roundhouse kicking women you will be laughing so hard at how bad and intentionally funny the movie is. To be honest this is one of the worst movies I have ever seen in my entire life. The tag line is "Some Sacrifices Must Be Made". Trust me and don't 'sacrafice' your time or money on this absolutely atrocious movie. 2/10... for making me laugh.

column4: Wow this is as cringe as the memes suggested
column5: In the entire genre of "women kill good men by playing victim" movies this one has to suck the hardest.It's like Midsommar or Knock Knock (and countless others) but worse somehow. I didn't even get a chuckle out of how bad it is which was kinda my best hope.So - I came in with low expectations and was still disappointed. Whoever keeps writing movies like this needs to perform one of those "rituals" you love so much on yourselves for the betterment of humanity.The original movie was not like this by the way. It didn't have the cringe obsession with little girls this one has. The leader of the cult was freakin' Christopher Lee not generic waHmAn. Generally it wasn't obsessed with women and little girls but this movie is - and from the start! So even as a remake this is garbage you can't attribute its failure to being a remake of a bad movie. Nah the original is quite good actually. Watch that instead.

column4: People need to stop being so picky.
column5: Look a remake isn't made to outdo or compete with the original version it's to take the original and give it a new concept try something new and different. It's to take one classic idea and take it in a new direction. The Wicker Man was NOT in ANY WAY a bad film comparing it to the original with how different it is will lead people to think so but it's a very good movie. It's creepy for a movie that takes place entirely in the daylight. Yes it's predictable very but so what? It has a good feel to it. For a movie that hasn't really gotten much attention until it HIT theatres... it's very good.7/10

No. Bad. Wrong. Worthless. Remakes are bad. Stupid remakes are worse. Conservative remakes are worst. Stupid Conservative remakes deserve annihilation.Interesting point: Neither "side" in the movie generates sympathy.*Sort of plot-spoiler.*Evil matriarchal wiccans do evil evil stuff. Not even Christians! The horror! Give me a break. Thank goodness Cage's character didn't play some sort of Super Christian at least.*end of spoiler-ish stuff*Even Reverend Phelps would find this movie dumb beyond mortal comprehension.

column4: Why on earth was this dreadful remake of an original masterpiece made?
column5: This remake of the original Wicker Man is dreadful and pointless. All the charm of the original is lost. The plot is more or less the same as the original but crucial elements of the original (the conflict between Christianity and Paganism the wonderful music the eroticism the sheer terror as the victim realises his fate etc) are missing.This film adds nothing to the original leaves out fundamental aspects of the original so WHY MAKE IT??? Apart from being a dreadful film the whole notion of re-making the original Wicker Man is equally dreadful. It's like trying to re-make the Wizard of Oz. Some films are SO unique that re-filming them is idiotic.Don't bother seeing this LaBute catastrophe. Just get the original out on DVD.

I am a Nicholas Cage fan. For the most part he rarely does a crappy movie. Anybody wishing to rent or purchase this movie here is some helpful advice. Take the money you would have spent attempting to see this movie ball it up go to the bathroom take a crap and wipe your ass with the money you have just balled up. It would be better used to wipe your ass and flushed down a toilet than spent seeing this movie. The only good thing about this movie is the production value. The locale's and wardrobe sounds and environments were exquisite. The plot was horrible which in turn means the acting was even worse because they actually put effort into acting out this horrible movie. Think The Blair Witch all hype and no delivery. I hope this brief description helps.

column4: Killing me won't bring back your f*cking honey!
column5: Well I am going to go waaay out on a limb here and recommend that you watch this movie. The title seems familiar to me so it must be that I saw the original but I do not remember it so I am judging this remake entirely on its own.It is a strange movie as most people are unfamiliar with alternative religions; especially those that are based in nature. These nature-based religions have been around a whole lot longer than anyone reading this so who is to say they are not the best way to go. There are also many societies in history that are matriarchal.
