I only mention this as I feel that most people who dislike this movie are probably entrenched in patriarchal Christian-based religions and cannot grasp the fundamentals behind the story.Nicolas Cage was probably the best person to play this role. he can play over-the-top with ease which this story called for. He is out of his element in this investigation and it stretched his cop mind to the limit as it should.The actions of all the villagers seem odd until it all comes together at the end. Then everything makes perfect sense. Director Neil LaBute (Nurse Betty) did a great job of keeping the story moving.

column4: You sit through the intensely boring parts to laugh whole-heartedly at everything else. A real winner in an ironic way.
column5: As much as I hate to admit it this film is one of those that are so good because they are so bad. A common thing to say about a truly awful film is that you can laugh AT it but never really mean it this film however had me roaring with laughter and I didn't see it whilst drinking with a room full of friends either I saw it alone in the middle of the night!Nicholas Cage stars as an unintentionally slow minded drawling trundling behemoth of a character who mumbles some things and yells everything else in no particular pattern. The acting in this film staggers along without confidence or the vaguest amount of skill it's a sad sight really.Anyway he plays a copper who pulls over a mother and young daughter to the side of the road after he steps away from the car and looks back a huge truck comes and smashes into the front of it for no reason (I say no reason because this truck must've been driving NEXT to the road AND going the wrong way) Cage immediately runs to the back of the car and begins smashing away at the rear window to save the completely unharmed and surprisingly apathetic looking young child. Needless to say the car is soon to explode and chooses to do so as Cage is halfway leaned right inside the car. The car goes BANG obliterating the mother and child and just gently shoves Cage out the back of the car leaving him without a scratch. Well we're told Cage has a hard time coming to terms with this and spends i dunno an hour or so off-work to grieve at home. At this point he receives a letter asking him to come to some secluded island to find the whereabouts of his ex-girlfriend's missing daughter. So he goes there aaaaaand the place is full of strange culty weirdos (run entirely by women the men are mindless zombies. Wouldn't want to appear misogynistic you see)The ferry-ride over contains one of the more funny parts of the film. He sees a little girl out on the deck from inside and a truck FLIES out of the sky and runs her over! we're even treated to a crushing splatting sound. Brilliant. Later on he's lying in bed and has a flash-back but not of the little girl in the car who was killed but of the same girl in the ferry being killed by his own daydream!The original Wicker Man is an incredible film (as are the two songs based on it) and remake really is an abomination. The music of the original is one of it's finest most important points to which the director of the remake (whose name I don't care to learn) says is 'poor' music and the fans of which he doesn't WANT enjoying his remake. In other words this remake is made by someone who didn't like or even GET the original.They also got rid of the Christian themes (wouldn't want to appear anti-Christian) which was another of the driving forces behind the original The nudity in the original was also something that had a god point to it and made a good impact which was something else the remake avoided (wouldn't want to appear too liberal) The sensible malice of Christopher Lee's Lord Summerisle has been replaced by some frail dottering old woman who cares? In short ALL the originality ALL the power ALL the character ALL the music ALL the emotion ALL messages and ALL the interest the original garnered has been replaced by...well nothing really.Still I advise you do rent this and do sit it through for the funny parts favourites include:Nicholas Cage charging around in a bear suit yelling at people (Imagine if you just walk into the room when this scene starts)Nicholas Cage (the cop) beating up helpless women out of sheer anger and being hailed as a hero for it (so much for no appearing misogynistic)Nicholas Cage fighting his way through loads of bees ("they're in my EYES!")Nicholas Cage yelling "how did it get burned!? how did it get burned!? howdiditgetburned!?HOWDIDITGETBURNED!?!?"*********SPOILERS AHEAD***********Thought I'd best add this too probably my favourite scene in any movie ever:Nicholas Cage being caught by the cultists and yelling "BITCHES!! YOU BITCHES!!" and "Killing me won't bring back you're GOD DAMN HONEY!!"Finishing with the SIDE-SPLITTINGLY hilarious sounds of him being beaten up like the Will Ferrel skit from Austin Powers "I don't want to die! *CRACK* ...I don't believe in your gods!! *CRACK* ......AAaaaarrrggghhhh!! MY LEGS!!!"Hahaha! He actually yells "AArrrgghh!!! My legs!!"*********END SPOILERS*********Yeah so I reeeaaally wouldn't bother with this if you're after something of high quality. Go and rent Apocalypse Now or something.

Negative reviewers make Neil LaBute's 2006 remake of "The Wicker Man" out to be an incredulous turkey on the level of "Plan 9 from Outer Space" and "American Beauty" but it's simply not the case.First of all let's be honest about the original 1973 version: Yes it's a unique and original film in multiple ways and has numerous strengths including fine Scottish locations and the presence of Britt Ekland and Ingrid Pitt (the former's siren-like "How Do" song & dance is a definite highlight) but it's not the masterpiece that many claim. What's wrong with it? For one thing the protagonist Sgt. Howie (Edward Woodward) is annoying and unlikable; he comes off as a Pharasaical tighty-righty (which is how he struck me and I'm a Christian!). This is a serious flaw when you consider that the entire film focuses on Woodward's progressive search for the missing girl. In addition Christopher Lee is just 'there' as Lord Summerisle (which is blasphemy to Lee fans since Lee considered his part in "Wicker Man" his personal best). The biggest problem with the original is that the film plays out in a dull manner; the plot itself is interesting but the delivery isn't.Woodward is so unlikable and annoying that on some subconscious level I was almost glad with his outcome at the end. Which brings up another criticism of the original film: I didn't find the ending horrifying. It was supposed to be but somehow it wasn't.One last criticism of the 1973 original is that it's understandably dated. It's obvious a product of the free-love hippie era and it shows. If any film screamed out for a remake this was it.THE PLOT: The story in this new version switches to America. Nicholas Cage plays a California cop searching for his ex-fiancé's daughter on a mysterious privately owned island in Washington's Puget Sound. The society is backwards pagan and matriarchal; the men are mute and second class. As the film progresses Cage comes to see that the inhabitants are lying to him about the girl's disappearance.WHAT WORKS: Unlike Woodward Cage is likable as the protagonist (or at least we can relate to him). His mounting frustration and anger over the situation are understandable. When he ultimately turns to outright violence against the women we understand what has driven him to such actions.The British Columbian locations are good pretty much on a par with the Scottish locations of the original in their own unique way.Ellen Burstyn is better than Christopher Lee as the villain. We don't even meet her until an hour into the film and she comes off as a creepy religious psycho (just because she's pagan doesn't mean she's not religious). Lee was bland in the original.Molly Parker as the school teacher and Leelee Sobieski are fetching (with Kate Beahan a distant third). Molly and Leelee are fully clothed at all times and yet somehow ooze beauty. Molly in particular has a very unique allure. One reviewer complained that there weren't any scenes of naked women as was frequently the case in the original but the director didn't feel the need to go the softcore porn route. Lebute shows that true beauty is far more than numerous displays of softcore eroticism and overt nudity. If you want that rent a porn video.The story is generally entertaining sometimes fun and at times unintentionally amusing. For instance the scene where Cage talks with the "barmaid" and the patrons has some laugh-out-loud aspects. There are other humorous moments (Cage apprehending the bicycle: "STEP AWAY FROM THE BIKE!" running around in a bear costume the dead girl suddenly appearing in his arms on the dock numerous hilarious lines like "OH NO NOT THE BEES NOT THE BEES!!" etc.). Despite this the picture somehow maintains a serious aura. The original by contrast was dead-pan serious and never entertained in this manner.The ending is horrifying (more so than the original) even though I knew it was coming. If you're in the right mood it can also be funny. The alternate ending is even better with the inclusion of overt torture scenes (although I know why they cut one of the torture scenes the bees would've killed Cage since he was allergic to them). The Wicker Man prop is intimidating and over twice the size of the original.In the theatrical version there's a "6 months later" coda tacked on which is an important scene. It shows how pre-meditated the actions of the women are in the film. It also explains one of Leelee's mysterious lines earlier in the story "When you leave take me with you." This sequence shouldn't have been cut from the alternate ending.WHAT DOESN'T WORK: The search-in-the-barn sequence is pretty useless but adds to the mounting mystery. Also the story really bogs down in the graveyard scene where Cage and Kate have a heart-to-heart talk.Some people may look down on the film because of the unintentionally funny scenes noted above. I think it makes it more entertaining. If you don't agree with me STEP AWAY FROM THIS REVIEW!FINAL ANALYSIS: Both the 1973 and 2006 versions of "The Wicker Man" are equally valuable for their positive aspects noted above. The insane criticisms of the remake are unwarranted (remakes are of course a lose-lose situation: if the film in question is remade frame for frame like "Psycho" people complain and if the filmmakers deviate from the original they'll complain even more; you can't win). The fact is that the 1973 version is severely dated and NEEDED to be remade and this is a quality updating. It's worth catching if you like mounting mystery stories with creepy elements. On top of this there are amusing elements. And thankfully the protagonist isn't some irritating legalist with a corncob stuck up his arse.The film runs 102 minutes.GRADE: B

After seeing previews you think this film is going to be great. Especially with some of the actors in this movie. I had very high hopes which were shot down fairly quick.Unfortunately the previews showed the best parts of the movie and everything else was pretty dull. I even felt like I was going to doze off during it.This movie was slow paced and had me slightly confused. Just when you think it is going to pick up and get better it gets even slower and more lost. I kept trying to guess and predict based on past films as to the outcome. I was unable to do so but it just was not what it appeared through the previews.Overall it is not very good and I would not recommended it to anyone.

A boston globe critic gave this movie 3 out 4 stars. Couple that with the fact that I liked the 1973 version and thrillers in general and I reasoned: look at the cast--how bad can it be? Really really really bad. Nicholas Cage was terrible; simply unconvincing. I laughed out loud when he pulled his handgun on one of the waif-ish women and screamed: "Step away from the bicycle now!" Actually most of the acting was wooden--not even Ellen Burstyn could pull this one off. The dialog was downright silly and the action sooooo predictable. And a lot of red herrings.I just don't have anything good to say about this movie. So sad that this had so much potential that went nowhere.

column4: Well it could have been worse......
column5: ......Im not sure how but it could have been.First I never saw the original so I am not even remotely upset that this was a remake that may or may not have done justice to the original. Of course unless the original was as unconvincingly muddled through by the cast as this one I don't see how it could have.The entire film gives you the "first take impromptu " scene approach where the actors aren't really trying to act at all but merely reading through lines and getting their positions on stage correct. Yep pretty bad.The plot is.......well about as forced as you can get while somehow remaining completely implausible even to me someone who can believe in werewolves if the movie is done well enough. Aside from showing Cages' character a video tape of them burning a little girl for witchcraft purposes the residents of this island could not possibly hint at what they wanted him to think they were doing any more clearly which makes the audience reach the conclusion that the policman Cage plays is supposed to be semi-retarded as he can't seem to connect the dots at all.I actually found myself wondering if the people on the island were getting at all pissy about how hard they had to try to spell out what they wanted the cop to think to the point they are seen reading books on ritual sacrifice.Skip this one.

column4: I hated the ending which spoiled a fairly good plot.
column5: The movie was fairly good until the end completely spoils the entire thing. DON'T see this movie if you want to feel good at all after. I have never felt as bad about an ending to a movie as this film. Everything else wasn't bad in fact was rather suspenseful  however the ending (which I am trying to not divulge) is horrendous). Please take my advice as a Nicholas Cage fan don't go see it. I really am sorry for the time I spent watching it. I now wonder if the first Wicker Man was as badly ended as this edition. Again try and avoid this if you don't want to be angry. Having second thoughts abut writing this piece because ten lines is way to many to have to explain that the ending of the movie was totally inadequate. In summation I would say don't go see this movie. Summary: Don't see it! How many times do I have to say IN SUMMATION I would not recommend this movie? That is the summation.

This is not the best movie Cage has ever made. The story starts off with quite a heavy and brutal car accident and that is about the only interesting scene in the whole movie. It's Cage that has to do all of the acting. The other actors don't seem to care much about it. Also there is a constant flashback throughout the movie of the car accident in the first sense of the film but at the end of the flick I couldn't quite see the connection to the other events that go on.I also find it totally unbelievable that Cage starts the investigation on the island all by himself. He isn't even a detective so he has no jurisdiction to be wandering around questioning people and sneaking around in their houses.Even though the ending is quite surprising and might shock the viewer a bit it still doesn't make up for the 90 minutes of rubbish that already struck you.Summary: The trailers and posters of the "The wicker man" are just like an image of a MC Donalds Big Mac on a billboard. It looks better in theory than it is in practice !

column4: LaBute Cage And Company Have Committed Murder And The Victim Is A Great Film Called "The Wicker Man"
column5: I saw a murder committed this Labor Day at a movie theater near me and the victim's name is a great film called "Anthony Schaffer's The Wicker Man". Neil LaBute's dreadful remake of "Anthony Schaffer's The Wicker Man" might very well be the most unnecessary remake since Gus Van Sant's shot-by-shot remake of "Psycho". This movie should never have been made.This an utterly dreadful contemporary Hollywood defiling of a British classic. The remake follows the basic plot of the original. A cop named Edward Malus a.k.a. Sgt. Howie in the original played by an overacting Nicolas Cage is lured to an island called "Summersisle" by a letter reporting a missing girl this time on Puget Sound in Western Washington state instead of Scotland. Like in the original Malus discovers an unhelpful neo-pagan community who appear to be ready to sacrifice the girl he is looking for after a disastrous crop failure the previous year.Along the way the makers of the remake have made some "creative" changes to the original. Gone is the clash of religious beliefs replaced with a battle of the sexes. The island in the remake is a matriarchy filled with unlikable man-hating females and subservient mute males and led by a matriarch named "Sister Summersisle" (Ellen Burstyn).Gone is the compelling character of the devoutly Christian cop Sgt. Howie from the original. Gone is the ideal sacrifice who is a virgin a man who represents the law and is King for Day replaced with an aimless secular pill popping dolt of a cop from California named Ed Malus played by an overacting Nicolas Cage who in an extraordinary departure from the original plot turns out to be the father of the girl he is trying to rescue.In the original the Punch costume worn by Howie symbolizes the Fool and the King for a Day or part of what makes Howie an ideal sacrifice for the islanders. In the remake comedy ensues as Ed Malus dons a silly bear suit. The islanders never tell Malus the meaning of his suit or what it has to do with his impending sacrifice. Hence the silly bear suit symbolizes all the attributes of a movie that seems to be trying to get multiple Razzie nominations (Cage and his bear suit received a nomination for "Worst On screen Couple").The sacrifice of Sgt. Howie at the end of the original is a chilling homage to Christian martyrs of the past and the viewer doesn't doubt for a second that he is a martyr who is sacrificed in part for his religious beliefs. In the remake you can only laugh when Malus is told that he is dying a martyr's death. Martyr for what? Popping pills all day and his self-help book? Yes the ineptness of the execution of the film is so bad it makes you laugh but this is hardly a credit to the makers of the film. The film is not categorized as a comedy and yet viewers are counting the ways it made them laugh. The funniest line of them all is when Malus yells "Killing me won't bring back your goddamn honey!" More comedy ensues as Cage knocks out three female cast members. Some are arguing that it should be a comedy and they've got a point. It just doesn't raise my opinion of the film.Watching the actors in the film deliver their lines you get the sense that nobody in this movie is taking it seriously and are only doing it for a paycheck. Perhaps this is because everybody in the cast recognized that they were making a turkey that would be ridiculed as one of the worst films of the year.May this dreck garner many a Golden Raspberry nomination (It got five) this Spring. May it also be sacrificed to the Gods and Goddesses of Great Film-making this May Day so that we might have a better crop of Summer movies to see next year. Overall a dreary moment in film history I regret having seen.

column4: Not the Campiness! Not the Campiness!
column5: Before I start this review I would like to say that I have not seen the original Wicker Man.This is unexpectedly hilarious even for a film starring Nicholas Cage playing a detective going to an island populated entirely by woman who use men as slaves trying to solve the disappearance of a little girl that's suppose to be his step-daughter. I was confused and bored multiple times throughout the film.But the ending really annoyed me. They sacrificed Nicholas Cage in a giant wicker man statue (that they somehow built without Cage's character knowing about it) and set it on fire. That makes no sense seeing how he was detective in the police force and the islanders didn't think that anyone from the police force might investigate Cage's disappearance.But there were some hilarious moments like when Cage dressed up like a bear and punches a woman and of course the bees scene.But all in all this film is not worth your time and money. I'm sure the original had better pacing and the ending had a better payoff but I am not interested in anything with a Wicker Man at the moment.

column4: Not even considered a guilty pleasure
column5: I sometimes enjoy watching Nicolas Cage go completely nuts on camera. But this is just bad. But don't be dissuaded from checking out the 1973 version....it's excellent.

column4: Another harshly reviewed decent thriller that isn't as bad as they say
column5: I have not seen this original classic 'The Wicker Man' that has everyone up in arms about how this new remake couldn't hold a flame the size of Texas to. Perhaps that was my saving grace in thinking that this remake was not bad at all. Of course it won't walk away with any Academy Awards but to say that it is "trash" and "utterly poor" and all the other harsh comments especially simply because it's not as good as it's original. But maybe my opinion will change after seeing the original...until then The Wicker Man is a complex and intelligent thriller with a touch of religious overtone and well directed with an air of mystery and darkness in a world of light. Highly acclaimed director Neil LaBute makes an honest effort to entertain and draw you into this twisted world on this mysterious island. He puts you right into the main characters place as he tries to unravel the mystery which goes far beyond a missing girl. The setting of the film is quite captivating an island set apart from the civilized world living in a manner of the old days and yet sadistically following a religious cult.I am not nor have I ever been a huge of Nicholas Cage. I think he's got an ego that shares too much screen space with him...however he has impressed me this year already with the beautifully poignant World Trade Center and he has done other great work. He fit into this film very well and played the angry and anxious detective to the utmost. He is watchable and this part was designed for him I think. The entire film relies on him and you are entirely in his shoes every step of the way and things unfold through him and he is a good enough actor to pull that off. The rest of the cast is truly just a supporting cast to Cage. Mult nominated Oscar winning actress Ellen Burstyn makes a cameo appearance as Sister Summersisle the proclaimed leader of the island and the cult and the spokeswoman on behalf of the goddess they worship. In her small screen time she does very well with her performance she is an expert in her craft. Kate Beahan does well as the confused and confusing mysterious former lover of Cage's character Willow. Her only role is really to confuse Cage and the viewer as everything on the Island twists into what you don't expect.If nothing else The Wicker Man is a unique mystery that does keep you entertained right up the very twisted ending. Everything unfolds properly and I think all the questioned asked are answered which is impressive and good for a film that is very complex to do. While not all the characters made a difference in the film most of them do their job very well. Nicholas Cage does shine in this performance and he is good at the part. The Wicker Man is absolutely worth seeing if you want a though provoking intelligent film that will leave you satisfied when you leave the theater. Is it spectacular?? No. It doesn't raise emotions or leave you blown away but it succeeds in being entertaining and keeping you engaged and that's far more than I can say about a lot of other films out there that people see. PLUS the long missing former Hollywood 'IT' girl Leelee Sobieski who hasn't done a mainstream film since 2001 makes an appearance as well as a disturbed and wide eyed worker Sister Honey. And if you ever wanted to watch Nicholas Cage punch the hell out of Leelee Sobieski...well he decks her a good one. The Wicker Man might even raise some controversial questions about women and men and religion...it's worth seeing...draw your own conclusions and don't let anyone steer you away from this one!! A Solid 7/10

Reviewers here are outraged I tell you outraged at how horribly sensible this movie is! It is a horror movie without the horror -- oh the horror! Worse than that it is actually consistent within itself and doesn't rely on shaking first person camera shots. Unacceptable! But seriously 3.5 out of 10? This movie is a 6.x to 7.x movie. Nicholas Cage was well cast and did a great job. The no-name actors are very convincing and were a lot stronger than many female leads in other movies.This leaves just one complaint vector -- the remake is not as good as the original (or doesn't slavishly follow the book). Who cares? Why is that an issue? Thomas Crown two is very different from TC1 -- and both are great movies.Book readers get over yourself. By your "logic" The Shawshank Redemption is unfit for human consumption. Create iBOOKdb.com and be done with it.This movie is for people who don't want to watch blood and guts horror movies. Those who prefer The Green Mile to Carrie. And it works just fine thank you very much.

This movie was stupid and I felt stupid for having watched all of it. The writers seemed to forget some very obvious police procedure during an investigation of an alleged crime. Not to mention the opening scene is a terrible set up. The society set up the accident but the driver survived a semi truck plowing through it? There are too many holes in this movie to even list.I like Nicholas Cage but he was terrible in this movie. He is supposed to play a career police officer from a family of police officers but he seems to have no clue how to investigate an alleged crime.By all means avoid this movie.

column4: A new worst all time film!
column5: For years and years I had no trouble answering the question "What's the worst film you've ever seen?". The answer gave me no trouble what-so-ever why it's the "Wicker man". It's completely unconvincing and is in addition handicapped with the most incompetent and wooden actor of all time Edward Woodward. But time moves on folks a new champion steps up to the line - the remake of "The Wicker Man" not possible? Oh it's possible. Even worse than the original and with an even worse leading actor! What more wooden than Edward Woodward? Yes folks take a bow Nicolas Cage! Why is it that we continue with these lame remakes of films best fogotten? One can surmise that an honest attempt to improve the original was what motivated the makers. In this case it surely must have been possible to make an improved version but in my opinion this is a miserable failure and actually worse than a very poor original.

Pretty good - but disturbing and yucko ending. I really don't have much more to say about this movie - I never saw the original and don't want to after seeing this one. It was well-made and great acting by Nicolas Cage.For some bizarre reason I'm not allowed to make a simple 2 or 3 line comment. No...IMDb demands at least 10 lines so now I'm trying to fill space so my comment will be accepted. So I think I'm getting close to line 10 now -- therefore after this sentence I'll stop typing. Oops...still didn't take so I'll now type 1 more line of ridiculous text to meet the all-important 10-line minimum.

column4: This was the opposite of a great movie
column5: Forget about even bothering to compare this disaster to the original masterpiece. It is a silly nonsensical poorly-acted mess on its own merits. It says plenty about a film when you leave the theatre wanting to shake the director Nicholas Cage and/or anyone else involved with this film by the shoulders and scream "What the eff were you thinking?! ANSWER ME!"But of course there never will be an answer to why (or rather how) movies this bad manage to get made. You could have given a chimpanzee the original script a pair of scissors and a crayon and it would have turned out a better draft (with fewer plot holes).Please just stay away from this movie. Go watch the original. It's not even worth your time reading the reviews or my time analyzing the details of this putrid film.

column4: Terrible...see the original but skip this one
column5: As a fan of the original 'Wickerman' I was hopeful that this one would be alright as Neil LaBute stated he was 'so inspired' by the original 1973 version. I stand disappointed. If there was anyway to give this thing zero stars on the above voting slot I would. In short this remake is terrible.Well okay the scenery is beautiful and the girls are pretty.But the script is very incoherent with the logical connection between the cop's nervous breakdown (with hallucinations) and the events on the island is totally not established and the mythological background of the island's feminist society can best be described as mostly inaccurate out of context where at all even close to accurate and a hash of misused ideas overall. Even the concept of a hive-type society is not used in a proper manner. It's as if Mr. LaBute and his colleagues just slapped together a bunch of stuff that scared them as children.Nicholas Cage's emotional expressions run the gamut from A to B (to paraphrase an earlier critic). Ellen Burstyn and the other ladies are not allowed to use any of their formidable talents. One can only conclude bad direction is at fault.Much of what made the earlier movie so wonderful: the old-style folksongs and music (many of which were authentic) the use of surviving pre-Christian English customs and festival-practices the emphasis on fertility and sexuality (without being crude another thing that most modern film-makers seem incapable of doing) are all missing.One can only conclude that Mr. LaBute may have watched the original movie but he didn't really SEE it.Save your money & rent or buy the original.

column4: An Insult to Wicca and Feminism!
column5: As a practicing Wiccan I had high hopes for this remake until I saw it. It misses the practice of the craft on every point. It is an Insult to Feminism and an Insult to Paganism.SPOILER!: This newly written last part in a bar where Willow & Honey pick up their next victims Oh Please! You might as well have been filming a Girls Gone Wild and Psychotic DVD!The original British Lion movie was more accurate. This remake is too extreme. The original had the inhabitants of the island in unity women and men together. The insult to feminism is that the island is totally run by women with the men walking around as "Tommys"... Deaf Dumb & Blind not "Pinball Prodigies". That should also be claimed as an insult to Dianic Wicca as Well! Feminism is NOT about hating men and Wicca is "And it Harm None do what ye will". We still have bonfires but we don't sacrifice Animals and Humans in them anymore. In the original they followed the ritual correctly even if it was disturbing. In the remake it's nothing but total Bloodlust!I hope the filmmakers are aware of the law of Three-Fold. They sent out this horrible remake that distorts Paganism they get back 3X losses. The next time you do a remake of a movie with a Pagan theme stick with the facts that we don't hunt and sacrifice animals & humans and shun out the opposite sex in our practice. Do your research and don't assume things.

It would seem that there are film people who feel that taking a really interesting film (or a cult film) playing with the plot and the character's historical being can produce a good movie. It would be like taking "The Sound of Music" and finding out that "Maria" was actually the Captain's Illegitimate daughter. Remakes are doomed to failure if the original was really quite good.

column4: Best example of an anti-feminist film I've seen in a while
column5: The best part about this film is that it was made in 2006 so its misogyny has all sorts of nuances. If toxic masculinity were put on trial this film would be key evidence of its pervasiveness in popular culture. Its tagline is "This is what happen when women are in charge." The men are in Nicholas Cage's own words "second class citizens." I'm pretty sure they've all had their tongues cut out. The men are kept around solely for breeding and heavy lifting while the women are given all the important responsibilities like governing farming doctoring etc. All in all I was laughing the entire time. This film is unintentionally hilarious and is worth a watch with the right mindset. Seven stars because I was truly entertained and I feel like a Cinema or gender studies student could write her entire thesis on this film.

column4: Just bad in every way. Destroys the original Nic Cage sucks
column5: I LOVE the original Wicker Man. It was really really cool and I saw it when I was going through this phase when I was obsessed with Paganism. So when this remake came out I knew I would see it. I figured it'd probably not be that great and when I realized it had Nicholas Cage in it I figured it wouldn't be that great at all. Boy was I right! Ouch! This movie SUCKS! S U C K S! Do yourself a favor and no matter what you have to do go find the original film and watch it. It's Waaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaay better in every way. Nicholas Cage is awful this movie is stupid plodding crap. Man was this just awful don't bother.If you happen to love the original stay far far away from this crap.

For the longest time I've always thought Nic Cage couldn't possibly come as close to the horror of Vampire's Kiss. While that movie is still very bad this movie comes about to that same level of suck. At no point does this movie try to be entertaining or interesting. This movie is so bad it makes Birdemic look like The Birds. Don't see this movie. Coming from someone who hates Twilight I would rather watch all the Twilight movies than have to see this movie (sorry Twi-hards). It amazes me that someone like Ellen Burstyn would do this movie. I feel bad for whoever had to edit this stinker. It would be wise to not see this movie. Stick to watching the "How'd it get burned" or "Not the bees" videos off of YouTube.PS Don't see this movie under any circumstance!!

Well they did it again. Took a little gem of a movie and remade it in the usual way -- bigger stars more special effects and thoroughly dumbed down so that the kind of minds of the targeted audience which is evidently judged to be of the same caliber as the producers won't be subject to the stress of either waiting or thinking.As far as I could tell before I had to shut it off and run for the Pepto-Bismol the story is roughly the same. A police investigator comes to an isolated place to investigate the reported disappearance of a young girl.In the original the villagers tolerate the outsider (Nicholas Cage here) and treat him with polite evasiveness edged with a bit of impatience the way you might deal with a child who keeps asking where babies come from. It's an odd attitude -- wrong but only subtly wrong. Here the villagers are openly hostile from the beginning. Cage (as Officer Malus) manages to get a room at the village inn but it's accompanied by the remark "Well if you won't take a hint -- ". If the goal is anything like that in the original this is not only over-obvious it actually militates against the villager's success.Much of the sex and theology of the original is toned down at least as far as I could tell. The sergeant is no longer a virgin nor is he very religious for instance. (How could Nicholas Cage possibly be a virgin?) It was hard enough to believe that the original investigator (Edward Woodward) was a virgin -- but that is precisely what made him suitable for the role he was to take in village affairs his staunch and unyielding Scottish Presbyterianism. Of course Nicholas Cage is an easier character for a modern audience to identify with and Cage does a good job. Perhaps it's a minor quibble that one of the original's chief plot points is sacrificed so that we can now more comfortably put ourselves in the cop's unambiguous shoes.Here are a few more notes then I'll quit. (1) This does not happen in the original but Cage spots a girl at night who seems to be the missing youngster chases her into an old barn investigates with only a flashlight falls through the floor of the loft and hangs by his fingers over a forest of upright pitch forks. Unlike the implements the scene is pointless. (2) In the original Woodward is quizzing an elementary school class and investigates the missing girl's empty desk. Lifting the top he finds a beetle tethered to a string to a nail in the center of the otherwise empty space so the beetle is slowly crawling round and round tightening the thread around the nail. Woodward registers surprise and disgust and remonstrates with the class over their cruelty. In this one Cage opens the lid of the desk the music shrieks and a great big black bird flaps out into his face in a series of rapid cuts. Instead of an off-kilter but thoroughly plausible event you get a cheap shock. (3) Not in the original. Cage strolls to the end of a pier and sits down. Then he notices the body of a drowned blond girl locked in a cage under the water. He strips off his jacket dives in and brings the body of Rowan Woodward out of the cage and onto the pier where he holds it in his dripping lap. Then -- "HUH?" and he shakes his head. It was all a daydream. (4) Not in the original. Cage walks into a field and is attacked by bees -- as in "The Swarm" "The Killer Bees" et al. (5) The original music by Paul Giovanni at once sprightly bawdy and ominous is replaced with a by-the-numbers mystery score straight out of a computer archive labeled "Mystery Music."By the way did the movie end happily? It should have. The mystical tragedy of the original just wouldn't fit on this pandering piece of junk. On the other hand a happy ending would deprive the remake of another crack at shocks and violence. On the bright side: I think this movie gave me an idea though. How about a remake of "Citizen Kane" with Brad Pitt? No? Okay then. How about remaking "Battleship Potemkin" only instead of rebellious Russian sailors we make them honest cops and instead of Tsarist soldiers we make them a gang of international terrorists who speak with German accents? I see Keanu Reeves in the lead with Angelina Jolie as the love interest.

column4: Yes it's a bad movie this review is focused on why
column5: I didn't realize until reading one of the other viewer's reviews that this was a remake. Having said that upon watching the movie I immediately recognized that LaBute was striving for that 1970s genre that I enjoyed so much growing up. Other movies in this genre that I grew up watching annually on TV to give you an idea were THE PEOPLE THE SPELL AUDREY ROSE THE REINCARNATION OF PETER PROUD and there was one with Leonard Nimoy BAFFLED! and another the name escapes me about a woman in a new town but she's having reoccurring dreams of having been tortured as a Salem witch.But the problem with Neil LaBute's THE WICKER MAN is all in the writing and editing.I don't agree with the other reviews about the acting. I have my master's in acting and I believe myself to be a pretty critical judge in that department. The acting only looked bad because of what they had to work with. But everyone was fine everyone except the actress who played Willow. I thought she was very poor. And I was distracted by her lips which looked overly injected with collagen. However Nick Cage Ellen Burstyn Leelee Sobieski and the actresses who played Sisters Beech and Rose were all very good. They have no control over the words and the editing--and the directing--and that's wherein the problem lies.I thought about the movie afterward and decided that the movie would have been fine if two actions had been done: 1. completely taken out the whole mother-daughter car scene in the beginning and all the hallucinations with those characters throughout the movie.Between trying to figure out the meaning of the missing bodies in that car and watching Nick Cage pop pills and seeing those people over and over in his present reality AND relive the car scene over and over I was sure that that experience and those characters were going to have to come back in the movie sometime and they did not.and 2. fixed the choppy editing. One minute Nick Cage is running here then he's running there then he's under water then he's running through Sister Summerisle's house then after looking in two rooms he can't find her so he leaves then he's marching with the group and he's wearing a bear suit etc.Because of the choppiness of the editing I could only assume that this was in connection with the pills Cage's character is popping throughout the movie and it's got to turn out to be "this was all a hallucination" stirred on by the trauma the character went through having seen the girl burn up in the car and not being able to save her. I would have been disappointed but at least it would have made the whole film cohesive.In addition there were some other scenes that should have been cut because they were just confusing such as Cage running into a room and seeing Sobieski covered in bees and the scene when Cage sees a woman in the field and says "Aren't you Sister Rose? Didn't I just speak with you?" and she says no. I didn't even think it was the same actress. And if it was what the hell did that mean?This movie needed to be kept much more simple and systematic. Then step by step we would have seen Cage's character the "fly" if you will being led and ultimately caught in the spider's web. We would not have understood what was happening until the end but then at the end we would be able to look back on the whole thing and it would all make sense. The plot is complex enough. It would have shone through if everything else in the film was kept simple.And if I were to substitute the beginning car inferno scene with something it would have been some history and perhaps flashbacks of Cage's character with Willow so that we had something to connect with when he travels all the way there to help her.Sometimes it is fun to see a badly made movie and pick it apart. If you agree then go see THE WICKER MAN.

column4: The worst I've seen in a long time
column5: To start out with I didn't know this was a remake and I've never seen the original. I liked it at first I thought it was a great mystery story and sort of a psychological thriller. From what I've heard the first one was supposed to make a point about fanaticism; this one didn't do that very well (it's a remake so what do you expect) so I was just focusing on the plot not the supposed message.The ending was the most horrible ending I think I've ever seen in a movie. I hate endings that don't turn out well for one but having the main character that we're rooting for the whole movie get trapped beaten and burned alive...that is NOT the kind of movie I want to go see thank you. Call me cheesy but I was hoping he'd find the little girl and he and the little girl and the mother would start where they left off. So much for my idealism.If you're looking for a really clumsy showing of a deep message or if you're just looking for a movie to make you feel terrible and lose sleep this is for you.Otherwise make your own popcorn pop in a GOOD movie at home and save yourself the money and aggravation.

column4: The Wicker Man: A Mixture of brilliance and awfulness
column5: I have never seen the original Wicker Man a fact I'm not proud to admit as I am aware that it is supposedly an all time classic and containing a great performance from Christopher Lee. A shame that I never manage to catch it on TV as its a movie I desperately want to see. So when I got the opportunity to see the remake I just couldn't resist I was aware it was hardly going to live up to the original movie but I just wanted to see the plot and see whether the remake was actually any good at all. Remakes are funny things for every decent one you get (Ocean's Eleven) you then go and get two along the lines of Planet of the Apes and The Grudge. So as I watched The Wicker Man I wondered what category of remake it would fall into. At first it started off quite well in fact I was surprised as I was really getting into the movie during the first half an hour. Alas the movie then literally falls flat on its face until the last ten minutes. The dialogue while passable at first descended into horrific territory. The acting was pretty lame Nicholas Cage practically sleepwalking throughout the movie in fact only one person showed any sign of an effort and she was rushed off in a couple of scenes (Ellen Burstyn!). Matters aren't helped as we see some of the most ludicrous scenes I have seen in cinema history. Nicholas Cage running through a forest in a bear costume! Oh and did I mention the lamest dialogue in ages from Cage "I think something terrible is about to happen!". While it might not sound bad written when you hear it you just want to die laughing it is executed so badly. Thankfully the ending redeems the movie quite a bit as the surprise twist and shock finale remain intact from the original (One of the few things I knew about.)Okay then the plot of The Wicker Man follows Edward Malus a police officer who receives a message from his ex-fiancé. She lives on an old fashioned island called Summers Isle. Her daughter has gone missing and she wants Edward to help her find her. Edward himself is suffering from distress after he failed to save a mother and daughter earlier on in his career. When he arrives on the island he soon realises all is not as it seems. The island is mostly occupied by women all of whom deny the very existence of the missing girl. As Edward investigates further he discovers mysterious cover ups aplenty and a mystery that leads to something much darker and much more ancient. As far as I am aware this is still the exact same plot as was in the original movie in fact its actually a very good plot. The mystery element and the actual characters are always intriguing. The head of the island Lady Summersisle is an intriguing character as is Edward's ex-fiancé Willow. I fact the only one truly dull character is Edward himself. His background story seems more forced than anything else and you really couldn't care too much for him.So what are the big problems for the movie then? Well its major problem is the editing and how poorly written it is. The first half an hour while poorly written contains atmosphere a creepy scene where Edward investigates a barn really does send shivers up the spine. The editing here is spot on and works brilliantly. And then the director just seems to go haywire with the editing scissors. It becomes more about Edward riding a bike round the island then trying to deliver anything remotely like scares. To make matters worse when the twist does come around its done in such a silly way that its impact is dimmed slightly. The ending is still brilliantly edited and something to savour hence why the rating of this movie is considerably higher than I suppose it would be without it.All in all The Wicker Man isn't a bad movie in fact its a half decent one at times. Yet its lacking something to really excel it in the brilliant territory. With a dull performance by the lead poor editing and poor writing the movie could have been a disaster. It redeems itself with the plot always standing strongly the ending being a shocker and the actual characters on the island always being intriguing. A shame then the movie just can't live up to all expectations though. Still I now want to hunt down the original and try and compare it to this movie.

I watched this movie because I like Nicolas Cage and well I found it strange and completely pointless... so I decided to poke around a little bit and got my hands on the 70s copy of it. Wow. what a difference. The original one was way better. I'd like you all to know it did originally actually make a statement it's existence did have a purpose. It was really the Christian public expressing their fear of paganism. If you dig deeper into it it also makes comments on life but I don't want to go into details just simply put if you were disappointed and you'd like to know what it SHOULD look like feel free to watch the 70s version a little dated but A lot better.

I don't get the hate for this movie because I think a lot of the stuff in it is supposed to be funny and I found it hilarious. The bike and the bear suit were just classic. I mean people hate this movie but they talk about it a lot and I think that says something for the movie. You remember it and I think that's because it was actually made really well. It's always a good laugh for me. Just don't try and take it too seriously.

I don't understand why all the bashing on it. Okay I understand this film isn't original different or innovative but the outcome is really good and I guess most people didn't see it coming (I'm included).Nicolas Cage shows he's a good actor. He may be a little strange because of his accent which I don't know where is from but he acts much better than lots of American actors. All the girls in this film work good as well.This film just doesn't deserve a better rating because of it's date. Many things that may have worked in the 73' movie don't work here anymore. One of those is the cellphone thing: nowadays if the cop is in danger he's very able to call his police department and he'll get help in minutes. They all have helicopters and stuff to protect themselves. Another thing that didn't look real: a cop that is a cop always check if he's out of bullets. He should have checked it every time instead of just hanging around as if he doesn't need protection.And I don't support men hitting women but those girls really asked to be punched lmao. We respect you girls but we expect respect from you as well.

The only good to come of this crappy remake is that perhaps it led hordes of inevitably disappointed movie-goers to rent the original Wicker Man which is a haunting nuanced masterpiece full of religiously and anthropologically sound lore and ethereal anachronism.I curse Hollywood Nicolas Cage and everyone involved in ruining the integrity of the original film and mainstreaming its ethereal metaphors and deep symbolism into puerile pseudo-blockbuster garbage.Any semblance of meaning was stripped away.Without a coherent paganistic society as a backdrop what was the point of even attaching the Wicker Man to this pathetic endeavor?It's a grave injustice to its predecessor.We can all rejoice however at Nicolas Cage's career smoldering in the Wicker Man's cinders... his moronic aging efforts to combine action with dumbed-down arcane will only lead to movies even worse (if that's even possible) than Ghost Rider and National Treasure

I wish I could give it 0 but I gave it a 1 to be generous because Nic Cage tried he really tried to do his best to keep a straight face throughout this whole thing as he ran all over that country farmland. If ya gonna re-make something then you're supposed to at least make it as good if not then better than the original. He failed on both counts. What was he thinking and what were the producers thinking when they green-lit this stupidity? I don't think Labute himself understood what he was making. At least what he should've done if he wanted to give it a slightly more glitzy modern-day look to the film was to remake the film shot-for- shot as Gus Van Sant did for Psycho. That might have worked albeit with American accents of course and new music. Every scene in this film that was supposed to be somewhat shocking and surprising and scary were executed poorly. Labute seemed to not quite understand where to put the camera how to cut the jumpy bits and it just felt as though every scene seemed like a real trifle to direct as if he was at conflict with the script that he wrote himself! Perhaps Labute was lost for words as to how to describe what he saw when he wrote the new version and that was what made it to the screen the whole mise-en-scene and photography completely dull and flat with no real mysterious feeling in any of it. The music also did not help and that is because the composer must have found it difficult to accompany anything with any sort of crescendo when the shots and scenes sort of go from one to the next in a meander without specific moments of tension that should've heightened everything. It's amazing that these things get made at all what a waste of time and money for everybody involved (except for the crew and actors who got paid to work on it).

column4: Nicolas cages performances are OK but not the movie
column5: Nicolas cage had done some good performances on the movie which made me watch the DVD till it ends but the story line of the movie is really bad and boring ... and Kate beahan is so sweet although she turns to be an evil womens daughter ...the movie had no horror as i know ... includes a bit of mystery drama and thriller ... its more kind of a detective story ... to tell the truth i fell asleep sometimes while watching it so that i pause the movie slept and watched again after a good half an hour sleep ... if it isn't for one of my favorite actors Nicolas cage and his best performances of all time i would have stopped the movie after the first half an hour forever ...anyway i recommend u not to watch it in a theater its not that worth ... but if its to kill some time you can use the movie DVD ... or else if your a Nicolas cage fan buy the DVD ...i give the movie 3 out of 10 but it would have been 1 or 2 out of 10 if it wasn't for n.c.

What a travesty. This is the worst remake of a classic English movie that I have ever seen. Why don't these guys leave things alone if they don't have the skills to make at least a half decent version. I will definitely be looking out for the Directors name with a HUGE AVOID written against it. Thanks for wasting my time.... At least the TV station that played it had the good sense to show the Edward Woodward version after it. I still cannot understand how people get the money or the nerve to remake movies that have an obvious Strong Following by people with equally strong opinions. The director does no one especially himself any favors by butchering such films.

column4: Two stories in one the first really good second really bad
column5: This started out really good. Excitement no end. Then later we see he is recovering and a fellow officer brings him his mail and out of the blue he says "Did they ever find the bodies?" WOW! Mystery on top of excitement. This is going to be a great movie!! Then the bottom dropped out. No more is said about the accident that had me so enthralled. No more about the missing people in the car. Now we start out on a completely different story but surely we will return to the first and tie it all together. The second story is a puzzle because I'm waiting (still waiting) to see what became of the people in the highway wreck. So now we meet the colorful folks on the island. And then we finally see the Wicker Man. Oh now I get it. Cage is going to wind up in his hospital room after the auto wreck it's all been a dream. The biggest mystery: Did Ellen Burstyn (my favorite actress from "The Exorcist") really need the money that bad to appear in this turkey?

This was the biggest waste of my hard earned money i cant believe i actually payed for this i should of demanded me money back o my god i cant even believe the age group that voted this with a 10 first: bad acting second: story that wasn't even explained why the car crash what was the point in all these flash backs merciful god i don't know how they let this film get on screen then to really complete the disaster he there hero Nicolas cage who i like as an actor was his and of any top paid actors worst acting performance iv ever seeing any ways back to the death then this producer had the cheek to like leave it open for a sequel its no wonder people pirate the movies over the internet least then your the 1 doing the ripping off rather than being ripped off appalling isn't the word for this film what it does do ill give it is your dying to know the mystery surrounding the film but when it happens its heart breakingly crap i left the pictures depressed and really felt id being bear faced robbed to summarize Nicolas needs to do some sort of redemption the person who made the movie should give the business up id say stop copying films but i wont id hate to see his own ideas if he tought it was a good idea to remake this piece of crap

column4: Not nearly as bad as everyone says which is a big problem in its own right
column5: The remake of the classic British film The Wicker Man has in its own right become something of a cult favorite. This is because many find it to be a so-bad-it's-good type of film. I don't see it. Honestly it's mostly competently made and the story remains pretty good. And the one big twist of the remake that Summersisle is populated by a matriarchal cult of beekeepers is not too bad though it's certainly more than a little misogynistic. If I had never seen the original I might call it passable entertainment. Compared to the original though it's pretty weak. It's slowly paced and it makes an especially huge mistake of entering the protagonist's dreamworld every ten minutes or so. It also doesn't help that the cast is as lethargic as the pacing. Nick Cage whom I was told was at his craziest in this film actually tries to keep calm through most of the movie. Ellen Burstyn is a fine actress but she seems not to believe in the project and is just plain bland as Lady Summersisle. The lead actress Kate Beahan is cute but seems constantly stoned. Her eyes are even red most of the time. When it nears the end around the time when Cage starts busting down all the doors (as Edward Woodward did in the original) it starts to earn its reputation for lunacy. The film is almost worth watching just to see Cage coldcock a few women. The first time it's so unexpected that I laughed out loud. He also beats the living crap out of Leelee Sobieski which is great. And he dresses in a bear suit and gets covered with bees. Those are the highlights. You can see them on Youtube.

column4: A sacrifice in so many ways
column5: The Wicker Man (2006). A sacrifice of your time money and intelligence. Makes Children of the Corn a sophisticated exercise in film noir and Stepford Wives (2004) a brilliant social satire.It amazes me that intelligent adults with sterling achievements can deliberate inflict this stench of a movie upon an unsuspecting public.Specifics? No need. There is no plot. Events do not tie together at all. The "action" plods on. There is no suspense no tension. The only entertainment value is laughing at the brazen stupidity of the characters and the script. Acting is strictly at the primary school comedy sketch level. I kid you not.Not the worst movie of all time by any chance. But bad enough to make it a serious embarrassment to anyone remotely responsible for its existence. Bah.

column4: Not as bad as in the comments here but waaay below the original
column5: A movie that is not bad but not good either means it is a mediocre film. One that is not worth looking at or laugh at. I've recently watched the original British film and while it is not a masterpiece it was simple original to the point. This one was obscure with a few elements that were added completely without a point a lot of good stuff left out and some very boring screenplay.Long story short a failure! I couldn't believe how this neo-puritanism that plagues America would turn a slightly erotic horror with a backbone into a boring thriller. The point of the original story was completely lost. Only the ending scene was slightly better.Don't watch it and if you haven't watched any of the films yet watch the one from 1973. And if you are into hives read Hellstrom's Hive by Frank Herbert. Now _that_ would make a great movie.

The original British film starring Edward Woodward and Sir Christopher Lee is a great cult classic and naturally there came a remake by the Americans from director Neil LaBute (In the Company of Men Nurse Betty). Basically Edward Malus (Razzie nominated Nicolas Cage) is recovering after watching a mother and his daughter killed in a car accident when he receives a letter from ex-fiancée Willow Woodward (Flightplan's Kate Beahan). She left him years ago without explanation and now she needs him as a police officer to help find her missing daughter Rowan (Erika-Shaye Gair) on the private and remote island of Summerisle. He explores the island of very strange people led by Sister Summerisle (The Exorcist's Ellen Burstyn) who grow plants and keep bees for honey and Willow reveals that Rowan isn't just her daughter but also his. He is slowly realising that the island is overrun with women in a pagan cult practising old rituals and preparing for some big Godforsaking celebration to improve the harvest and sacrifice a helpless victim. He is convinced that they are all lying about the whereabouts and state of Rowan in order to kill her but when he does eventually find her that is when he finds out the terrifying truth. They are all in on it including Rowan and they are in fact going to sacrifice Edward first breaking both his legs stinging him with bees causing his allergic reaction and trapping him in the wicker man to be burned alive. Also starring Frances Conroy as Dr. T.H. Moss Molly Parker as Sister Rose / Sister Thorn Leelee Sobieski as Sister Honey and Diane Delano as Sister Beech. Whereas the cult pagan rituals and insanity are the original film's strength here it is one of the biggest weaknesses it would be much more believable with Cage's character being religious like the great Woodward was. The action has been too hyped up for its own good the mystery and menace has been dulled till the finale and the wicker man burns much too quickly for my liking. I don't mind Cage and Burstyn too much and tiny that don't exist in the original add tension but all in all it was a pretty awful experience and if you have any sense just stick with the much more influential and superior original. It was nominated the Razzies for Worst Picture Worst Remake or Rip-Off Worst Screen Couple for Cage and his bear suit and Worst Screenplay. Pretty poor!

Not even worth the one star I gave this movie. This is one of the worst movies I have ever seen. It's so predictable I saw the ending coming from the very beginning (although I hoped throughout the film for it to end differently) and it was an awful ending. The characters were undefined and just terrible. The script was awful (too much random HAHAHAHAHA from a mostly-female cast with 0 acting ability {except Leelee Sobieski who I adore}). Throughout the film Nick just runs around going "I'm an angry cop! GRRRRR!!!!". I love Nick Cage but this movie does not do his acting justice. It's honestly awful. Do NOT see this film whatever you do even if you're as big a Nick fan as I am. It is full of plot holes and has no where near enough violence or even blood for it's genre. And it's NOT. SCARY. AT ALL. So yeah. Don't waste your time."I want those two hours of my life back!" -My friend Maddy after seeing this movie.

This movie was ridiculous. I'm ashamed to have paid money to see it. I should have known by the fact that it was not screened for critics. The acting was terrible and cardboard at best. I hope the original was better than this pathetic remake. There are a few scares but nothing better than your typical 'jump out of the closet' types. Very little is ever explained and many characters and themes just seem to have been forgotten about after being introduced. Nic Cage isn't my favourite actor but he's usually better than this. I don't know how they roped in people like Nicolas Cage Ellen Burstyn James Franco and Leelee Sobieski. I can only guess that they must have had some sort of contractual obligation.

If after listening to approximately 60 shows the How Did This Get Made podcast taught me anything it's to appreciate Nicolas Cage. As a matter of fact I never truly knew about his outbursts until I listened to that internet show where they ridicule bad movies for about an hour. And they seem to favor Nick Cage a lot.A movie that was completely off my radar was the 2006 thriller/remake The Wicker Man. It was so much off my spectrum that I probably would've never seen it had the creative How Did This Get Made crew didn't spotlight it.To get me to hate it they did not. Contrarily I ended up liking it more for its "So Bad It's Good" vibe. After all I waited patiently the whole movie for the Real Nick Cage to bust a move. And he did. He did in spades.Don't get me wrong it's not a great or even good movie even when it started off decent. Sorta.Copper Cage gets all bent out of shape when he somewhat helps a single mother and child who inadvertently gets killed and disappears literally in front of his eyes.Spoiler Alert�.Forget I even said that as it never comes up again or at least not to move the plot forward. Instead focus on the note Cop Cage gets to help track down a missing girl on a mysterious island where the mother of said child resides.With some useless bargaining he makes it to the isle of the damned actresses and he begins his search. More and more frustrated Constable Cage gets until he�wait for it�does what I went into see: a meltdown.Oh this movie's bad so bad but it doesn't get that way until the second half and good news it's worth watching the whole thing for. It's so outrageous it's fun. I advise paying attention to all details. Not that they make sense but it will help you laugh completely unintentionally�which is all the fun of this.If the original The Wicker Man is like this or even ends like this one all the surprise is gone it's spoiled. Maybe it's better and maybe I'll see it someday. Until then I will enjoy great Edward "Nicolas Cage" Malus lines like:"BITCHES! YOU BITCHES!""Is this hers? How'd it get burned? How'd it get burned? HOW'D IT GET BURNED HOW'D IT GET BURNED?""This is murder! Murder! You'll all be guilty and you're doing it for nothing! Killing me won't bring back your goddamn honey!""Step away from the bike!""You little liars. Rowan Woodward IS your classmate isn't she? ISN'T SHE? That is HER desk! And you're the biggest liar of them all. I am warning you you tell me another and I'll arrest you myself. That is a promise MISS... Of course another plant! Rose!""Ahhh my legs!""OH NO! NOT THE BEES! NOT THE BEES! AAAAAHHHHH! OH THEY'RE IN MY EYES! MY EYES! AAAAHHHHH! AAAAAGGHHH!"* * * Final thoughts: Typically I don't even recommend "So Bad They're Good" movies like The Room Birdemic: Shock and Terror or Troll 2 but I guess I have to here and that will open the floodgates to those other three mentioned movies. Go ahead and make it a fantastic weekend with all four movies. You. Will. Laugh. Your. Arse. Off.

<<<<<< SPOILER WARNING: SOME SCENES ARE REVEALED IN THIS REVIEW >>>>>> This movie is in my lowest ten movies of all time and ultimately disappointing for a Nicholas Cage movie; normally I'm a fan of him.First would like to begin with the good parts of this movie the pros. The beginning flowed well and character creation and acquaintance was smooth. I really bought the whole Nicholas Cage as a cop and going to some mysterious private island and I was especially intrigued with the car explosion. The scenery of Summer's Isle was beautiful and the immediate Amish sort of mysterious satanic ambiance lured the watcher further into the movie. The bloody bag right when Nicholas Cage arrived on the island got the watcher's attention.But besides the good things there were three major flaws of this movie in order of increasing severity.First Sister Willow the dumb blonde bimbo who just can't get a single word out deflated the seriousness of the movie and sort of angered the watcher at her instead of drawing the watcher's concentration to the story at hand.Next the Pagan feel of the movie. I understand that it is the right and fairness of the producers to make Summer's Isle of Pagan or at least feminist custom but I think that it was unnecessary. By the end of the movie I was more angry at feminists than the whole conspiracy and on a whole I think this movie brewed hatred towards women and wrongly so.The final and most atrocious slip-up of this entire movie: the ending. If I were to make the Wicker Man into an analogy the beginning is like setting the foundation of a card castle. Repetitively stacking countless playing cards on top of each other with phenomenal method and beauty; the end is like placing a bent card in the last place and watching this beautiful set-up crash down in a falling maelstrom of misery. Here's how the ending worked out: Nicholas Cage comes out of a Crypt after being released by Willow from some sort of pool--with a Jesus statue in it?--after which he begins to run around the entirety of Summer's Isle looking for his supposed daughter. Barging in on peoples houses. One barging scene that I thought was particularly comical was the one in which he walks down from his room in the town tavern to find two of the "sisters" talking about the murder of the supply plane pilot. After the one leaves the other sister begins to talk to him. He then proceeds to make a swift punch to her face knocking her out (never seen Nicholas Cage glorification before.) Finally Nicholas Cage finds a bear costume that he uses to disguise himself in the ritual. Once the convoy arrives at the spot of sacrifice Nicholas Cage sees his daughter Rowan tied to a wooden pole and then presumes to run to the pole deliver another mighty blow to a poor woman's jaw and run away with Rowan. The dynamic duo manage to dodge the sisters sent after them and then progress (somehow) back to the place of sacrifice where Summersisle proceeds to reveal the whole cheesy conspiracy to make Nicholas Cage come out to the island. Nicholas Cage has his legs broken and he is drawn into a giant wooden structure in the shape of a man (finally we know what the wicker man actually is) and Rowan lights this structure on fire. Nicholas Cage along with about ten other farm animals are burnt to death... end. No wrap-up about Nick's random call to his partner while running from the "sisters" no wrap-up about the strange man in Sister Summersisle's bed no wrap-up about the bees swarming the bar-maiden in Summersisle's house no wrap-up about the bloody bag and no wrap-up about why the men couldn't talk. That is why I gave this movie a one out of ten.

column4: the worst movie in cinematic history!
column5: A trooper is on the side of the road making sure every1 is obeying the speed limit (doing his job); he then pulls over a woman who appears she is a mother (there is a child in the back seat); he then is telling her what is wrong and BAM...they get killed. Okay this is the start of what i personally thought would have been a good movie. When I was watching this movie in the theatre I was with some friends. This was our first night out after the summer so we wanted to go and see a good movie. We all decided to see a suspense/thriller that looked good to everyone in the group...this was one of the biggest mistakes of my life. Not only did I waste $7.oo on a movie ticket but I had to sit through torture for the brain. This movie started off with mystery and suspense and I seriously thought "this cant be bad"...I was so wrong. The whole problem with this movie is that it makes no sense; even if you can get passed the bad acting the "not so scary" storyline and the over all horrible mess this movie was you will still be puzzled. It's not because you're not smart enough to understand it it's because no human with a brain could comprehend what this stupid movie is about. Right now you may be thinking "Oh man! I have to watch this movie just to see if it's as bad as this person says it is". GET THAT THOUGHT OUT OF YOUR HEAD RIGHT NOW!!! I'm trying to save you the trouble of watching this movie by telling you that it is so bad that there is no point in even considering seeing it. Please people don't make the same mistake i did thinking that this movie has potential...it doesn't. I give this movie 1 out of 10 (if I could give a zero I would) and I do not recommend anyone to ever see this movie you'll be saving yourself many sleepless nights trying to think w.t.f. that freaking movie is about.

This had to be one of the worst acted movies out there. Cage seemed as though he was in a trance most of the time and had no idea what the producer was trying to get from his part. The plot was slow and boring. Cage may have not been the right part for this character. He only become somewhat believable about the last 15 minutes of the movie. He wasn't aggressive as a police officer at all. No policeman I have ever encountered acted this way. The whole religious plot tends to lead to all religions are crazy. There wasn't enough evidence to support that the religion was actually one that worked in the move or one of a bunch of crazy people. This may have been what they were hoping for but I couldn't tell if I not following it. The whole movie was very vague. I may be worth watching on video. It was not worth watching in the theater.

Where shall I begin? The only cool thing to happen in this movie was shown on the commercial (when the car gets hit by the truck and bursts into flames). After that it's all down hill. Are we supposed to believe that in modern day America there is a town full of people (besides the Amish) that live and dress like this? Get a grip. This movie explains why pagan rituals are no longer performed. They were dopey. Nicholas Cage (who I usually like) is looking kind of old and floppy in this one and the women are just strange...sort of like Stepford Wives. All in all no surprises here and of course as usual a remake being passed off as an original. Geez Hollywood really does suck these days. MORE SAW PLEASE!!!

I am sincerely confounded as to why this currently has a 3.7. This film is actually not that bad. Take a few scenes out of context and it looks odd but seriously it's better than 3.7. 6 stars minimum.

column4: Nicholas Cage must have had a contractual obligation
column5: I can only believe that some big-name actors and actresses have obligations that force them to be in absolutely horrible movies. This is the only reason I can think of that Mr. Cage agreed to do this movie.Ellen Burstyn gave no life at all to her character.Poor LeeLee who was so excellent as Joan of Arc being reduced to the insipid role she plays here.And then all the no-name "talent" in all the other roles.The dialogue was horrible ("step away from the bike"). Lines were delivered with no life at all to them. There were too many throw-away characters (Cage's cop buddies at the beginning whose roles I would assume were to provide some kind of background for Cage's character).It's not the worst movie I've ever seen but it ranks right up there with the worst. Heck The Lost Skeleton of Cadavra was 10 times better than this movie - at least you knew going in to the Skeleton movie that it was supposed to be bad!

This movie is not nearly as bad as the "jump on the bandwagon " poor reviews would have you believe. I was entertained enough to watch the entire movie it's not great....but really is not that bad. Many reviewers would also have you believe the original Wicker Man was some kind of "not to be missed" classic it most definitely is not!

column4: Okay; Who Is Mad At Nicolas Cage?
column5: This movie is so horribly bad that if I were Nicolas Cage or ANYONE affiliated with it I would DEMAND that my publicist make no reference to it at all in any materials published about me. Nicolas Cage looks dreadful in this movie. It is as if he threw a tantrum and angered some Hollywood power brokers who repaid him by forcing him to star in this huge joke of a movie. The writing is awful. There is no logical reason for Cage's character to be as overbearing and arrogant as he is to the people on Summersisle a place to which he has never been and the customs of which he has no knowledge. Also why would he go to this island on such a wild goose chase? The characters on Summersisle are odd (and bad actors to boot) but Cage's character has no right to be so boorish while he is there. There are several apparently important loose ends that are never tied up which only added to my frustration about this waste of time and celluloid. What about the twins on the island for example? Why was a big deal made about them and no resolution given? Who were the mother and daughter at the beginning of the movie?My daughter and I laughed through most of THE WICKER MAN. She was treating me to an afternoon at the movies and I told her I would give her her money back. Still we did laugh until our stomachs ached so that counts for something: we now know for sure that our tastes in movies are nearly identical.

column4: The Very Foundation That 'Mystery Science Theater 3000' Was Built On!
column5: Film Review: The Wicker Man (2006) Directed By: Neil LaBute Starring: Nicolas Cage Ellen Burstyn Leelee Sobieski Molly Parker and some chick with grotesquley big lips.WARNING: THIS REVIEW CONTAINS SPOILERS....but does it really matter? Question: Are you the type of person who could enjoy a movie in which Nicolas Cage karate kicks a bunch of annoying feminists? I AM!!! I really enjoyed this film. Not because it was good mind you but because it was so entertainly bad. This is the real deal the very foundation that 'Mystery Science Theater 3000' was built on! One thing elevates this film from being an unwatchable piece of s**t to pure comedic gold and that one thing is Sir Nicolas Cage.Let's talk about Cage for a moment. What can I say? The man is an enigma. Is he more than a little strange? Yes. Am I disturbed by the fact that he named his son Kal-el? Yes. Do I still find myself oddly attracted to him? YES. I think he's a brilliant actor who's capable of handling dark dramatic roles (8MM) eccentric comedic roles (Raising Arizona) and weird Christopher Walkeney type roles (Vampire's Kiss). He is now heading into Charlton Heston territory.The plot of the The New 'Wicker Man' is as follows: A police officer (Cage) witnesses a freak car accident (really freak because it makes no goddamn sense and is never explained). It tramatizes him (I guess?) so he just lays around on his couch popping pills. One day he receives a letter (no stamp on it so don't ask me how it got there) from his ex fiancée (played by the fish lip lady) begging him to come help her find her daughter who has been missing for two weeks. She lives on a remote island that has no phone service so the information he gets in the letter is all he has to go on. Now his ex dumped him in a pretty harsh manner so why he chooses to go help that bitch is beyond me. Though one of his co-workers is of sound mind and tells him to not go...guess what? Cage then ends up on this "Fantasy Island" which is inhabited by a cult of hairy arm pitted birkenstock sandal wearing Indigo Girl listening Lilith Fair rejects. Mere moments after his arrival he becomes instantly annoyed with these people. Wouldn't you? He meets up with the ex and she tells him that no one on the island believes that her daughter actually exists.
