Apparently the cult is run by an "earth mother" type known as Sister Summersisle (played by Burstyn) who doesn't take too kindly to fish woman's "wild ways" (being as how fish woman once ran away from the place and became involved with Cage). Therefore fish lady thinks that Burstyn is hiding the kid. But as Cage starts to ask around he gets a variety of stories. He's told everything from "she's not really Fish Lady's kid" to "Fish Lady's kid did exist but she burned to death in an accident" and back to "Fish Lady's kid never existed in the first place". Okay then Cage goes back to fish lady to vent his frustration over his failure to come up with any evidence. She then tells Cage that the girl is his daughter. Didn't see that one coming! (Please note the sarcasm.) We are then subjected to more cryptic scenes such as Cage being attacked by bees a few dream within a dream pop out sequences and a "what's behind that door?" chase sequence through Burstyn's house in which Cage stumbles upon a naked man covered in moles. At one point during the film Cage looks at the Fish Lady and says "I'm completely lost.". I can't begin to tell you how f**king funny that line was to me. This movie does not make one lick of sense and it has plot holes wider than Jessica Simpson's "ravaged by the cast of Jackass" vagina. But like I wrote earlier there is some comedy gold here. Cages sarcasm towards the islanders is hilarious! You just want him to punch one of these broads in the face and sure enough...HE DOES!!!! He also has a complete throw down with Leelee Sobieski (who's looking really hot in this flick!). As for the big sacrifice scene be prepared to bust a gut! This is the only part of the movie that sticks to the original except here it's not scary. Prior to hoisting Cage up into the Wicker Man (where he will suffer his firey fate) the islanders break Cage's legs prompting him to yell out "MY LEGS!!! MY LEGS!!!! YOU BITCHES!!!!!".But wait until the "six months later scene" which takes place in a bar. The last five seconds are the funniest I've HEARD all year! Will you like this sort of thing? That I don't know. I want to recommend it to those who love "good bad" movies. I'm not sure that you would want to spend the full ten dollars on it so maybe just do a matinée. But if you miss the matinée please be sure to rent it when it hits DVD. It truly has to be seen to be believed.

column4: Leelee Sobieski In A Small Role Is Best Thing In This Mess
column5: Anyone contemplating remaking a classic movie should watch this mess. Sometimes you can just tell when actors are appearing for the pay check. Nicolas Gage appearing in This remake of "The Wicker Man" is one such example.Plot In A Paragraph: Policeman Edward Malus receives a letter from his former fiancée Willow who left him years ago telling that her daughter Rowan is missing. Edward travels to the private island of Summerisle where Willow lives and she reveals that Rowan is actually their daughter. During his investigation with the hostile and unhelpful locals Edward discloses that the locals are pagans practising old rituals to improve their harvest and Rowan is probably alive and being prepared to be sacrificed.Cage sleepwalks through this and does not appear to be interested in what he is doing at all so why should the audience?? The supporting cast are all poor and I was disappointed to see Leelee Sobieski in this and truthfully she was the best thing in this mess. In the three years prior to this she had only appeared in 3 episodes of a TV mini series and had a role in a TV movie. So I'm guessing she was grabbing what ever work she could. But she deserves better than this.

column4: Alice's Sense of Shame Doesn't Live Here Anymore
column5: I could give this movie a proper review but really what's the point?Sure I could discuss the plot. But really all that happens is Nicolas Cage goes to an island populated entirely be Shrewish Lesbian Honey Witches� throws on a bear suit punches some women and dies. That's it. Sure Ellen Burstyn gets to dance around like Puck from 'A Midsummer Night's Dream' with her face painted like Mel Gibson's in 'Braveheart' but that's not necessarily interesting or campy enough to make the movie worth your while. You'd probably just be better off watching the YouTube video of all the best bits spliced together.Most of the good stuff happens in the last 20 minutes and there's a lot of Nicolas Cage grimaces and 'IT'S A DREAM-no it's not-BUT IT IS' moments that you have to get through before getting to the Leelee Sobieski throat kick.Oh . . . and P.S. Aaron Eckhart I saw you! Don't even think you can get away with being in this. Because you can't.

column4: Seen oh so many worse horror movies
column5: I did watch the "alternative version" that was in the same DVD. Maybe that's the reason why I disagree with the majority of the reviews. I've seen a large number of bad horror movies. Really bad. And so so many with no plot at all. Or reason. This one has both.The island is believable as a religious cult that is hostile to outsiders. If one would say cults sacrificing humans aren't believable I do not sign that. Unfortunately those have been practiced and still are. Oh yeah and seen so many horror movies that are completely unbelievable.What comes to the plot I did not expect it to turn as unfortunate to the cop (played by Cage) as it did. The conspiracy went deeper than it originally appeared. The end truly was surprising I was expecting this is about saving the girl. But then a classic ending in horror movies is with the victims really meeting their bloody fate and the monsters surviving.

column4: This movie gets worse the more you think about it.
column5: I watched this last night and I've been progressively feeling more frustrated since then that I have to put my thoughts to paper even though I don't think mere words can express the pain this film has put my mind through. Basically the film makes no sense it has very little plot and is not consistent with itself there are lots of strange or stupid things that happen in the movie that have nothing to do with the plot either directly or indirectly but appear to have been put in to give the movie a few shocks. Here are some problems with this film: 1) Entire start of movie where mother and child are burnt out in car but bodies are then missing and car cannot be identified has nothing to do with the movie. 2) The "fact" that the letter he receives from the island is not postmarked has no relevance. 3) Everything and anything to do with bees and his allergy to bees has nothing to do with the plot and is completely pointless. 4) The motivational tape he buys at the start and later looses/has stolen on the island is irrelevant filler. 5) All of Edward's flashbacks / dreams of things that "have not happened" are padding to make the movie look more interesting. 6) Introductions of random characters like "two blind crones" who then do nothing in the movie. 7) Everything to do with the flooded underground crypt which he gets trapped in the rescued 20 seconds later has no point. 8) Why Edward does not consider the child his girlfriend had shortly after she left him could be his but when she tells him that it is "his" he doesn't quibble. 9) They lured him to the island because their crops failed but the elaborate plan to lure him there was started 5 years before their crops failed. 10) The island being ruled by women with passive mute men as their breeding servants. Why are the men so passive why are their multiple people who look the same. Genetic experimentation? Who knows. 11) No details are given of the islander's beliefs to explain what they do other than it's something from old Britain to explain the Wicker Man at the end. 12) Why Willow keeps changing from looking a little bit sorrowful to gleefully happy at Edward burning to death at the end. 13) The acting is generally terrible although this may be a problem with the direction and lack of character to actually act.

column4: Whereas the original transcended multiple genres this version flunks them.
column5: It can perhaps be unfair to compare a remake with an original when one loves the original: every change will seem a flaw even when to somebody new to the film the changed might seem an improvement. But in this case I think that reference to the original genuinely helps to pinpoint what's wrong with the remake.Part of the genius of the original was the the slow but relentless build-up the way one was never quite sure where one's sympathies should lie the way one is never sure what's going on. Slow build ups don't seem to be the fashion now and so we get crashes and fireballs from the start. And it's made clear from the very outset that the cop (Cage) is the good guy and nothing changes this view throughout (even when he slugs women it's with good cause). And the inhabitants of Summersisle don't even try to hide the fact that they practice human sacrifice. So: no subtlety then.Losing the subtlety is bad enough but what about the story? Well in the original the individual seemingly unrelated adversities that the cop suffers all turn out to be cleverly building together to meet a complex set of criteria for the climax. Well that had the word "complex" in it so it plainly wasn't going to happen in this version. Instead most of those adversities (some of them from the original) turn out to be completely irrelevant to the plot the criteria for the climax this time being very simple. Which left me wondering "Why did they do that then?". The plot becomes a string of beads from which the string has been removed leaving the beads -- the individual scenes -- rolling around uselessly.Themes? The original had a conflict between Christianity and Pagainism (even if it got a bit confused between Roman Catholic and Presbyterian forms of Christianity). Well far be it from Hollywood to give Christianity any credence now; it's only glimpsed in this version as something plainly dead and out of the equation. "Self-help" books and pharmaceuticals look as if they might fill its place but ultimately the film turns into a nauseatingly misogynous men v. women conflict with paganism not set against anything in particular. And whereas the original was relentlessly natural the clumsy topping-and-tailing of the story try to give this version unnecessary supernatural overtones (and an excuse for some clumsy hallucinations in the vain hope of making it a "proper" horror film).With better acting from the scenery than the cast (was Leelee Sobieski just cast for her ability to roll her eyes badly?) and a horror-by-numbers musical score there really is no reason to see this film. Whereas the original transcended multiple genres (horror thriller musical drama...) this version flunks them all.I suppose some of the scenery and photography is OK.

A feel good film. After watching you'll be convinced that even you could act in and write A grade movies!Imagine your deathly allergic to bees so your riding through a field when you realize your in the middle of a bee farm! Of course you run head long into it knocking over every colony you see. You get stung and it fades to back. You wake up and the doctor says "oh thank heavens you've been out for hours". You grab your gun cock it and shout "WHERE AM I"?!That was an actual scene from the film. I mean wow.. just wow. I've read better twilight fan fiction.The character development is so poor you will actually want Nick to die at the end.Why would a grown adult a police officer no less bust into a class room demand they tell you where a missing person is then swear at all the children?! This just isn't based in reality.It feels almost like the film was supposed to be absurd (think fly kicking bar maids in the face) but this wasn't communicated to the actors who tried to play it deadly seriously. The result is a disjointed failure at either.I haven't seen the original but I felt that there could be a decent story beneath it it would have just required a lot more thought characterisation and acting. Watching this felt really did feel like reading pre-teen fan fiction. Yes you might have some good themes there its poorly developed but given to someone competent it could really be something.

I do not like N. Cage that much but I think it would be better for him to avoid acting in these kind of movie. The story is not clear from the beginning (and there is no explanation after)(why he goes to the isle why he lands hidden why he does not leave any trace back why he asks only a few questions to people he meets permitting them to give arcane/obscure answers). Finally there is no reason why what happens at the end of the movie could not happen at the beginning. The best part of the movie are the first twenty/thirty minutes then it starts to be boring. I was so disappointed that I registered with IMDb to rate and comment this movie. The current average of 3.5/10 has a large majority of 1/10 votes so I think I am in good company.

column4: Id rather be on fire in the Wickerman than ever watch this again....
column5: The Wickerman is one of the greatest British Horror films ever made. I think anyone who has seen the original would agree that its ironic humour 3d characters and soundtrack all show a great understand of Pagan rituals and traditions. In the original Howie is shown as the Battle of religion he is the Christian - Pure with virginity and Marital Values where as Willow is shown to represent the Pagan traditions of Freedom of Sexuality and Celebration.From the first time I heard that The Wickerman was being re-made I was open minded Although remembering how badly recent Re-makes of films have been (Texas Chainsaw Masscre Anyone?) I was still Very uncertain.Last night me and My girlfriend went to watch the Remake of the Wickerman And i can honestly say it is One of the Worst films i Have ever seen.Watching Nic Cage strut around the screen playing his Usual Good Cop/Bad Cop droopy role nearly made me throw my popcorn up back into my mouth. I cannot believe the Legeacy of the film has been completely (excuse my french) Shat on by this remake. The first thing that is annoying is the American Setting. WTF?!?! Since when was a Remote Scottish Island an American Island in the state of Washington.There are no good points to this film. The acting is at best Woodern by all parties - Willow's character played by Kate Beahanis one of the worst on-screen roles i have ever watched. I cannot believe that someone with the Calibre of Ellen Burstyn even signed up for this project The film manages to metaphorically rape away the magic and suspense of the original and turn it into a hollow below average film. This is one film you should avoid this summer

I've been a fan of the original Wicker Man for years and I had my misgivings when I heard that it was being remade. I avoided seeing the remake because I just knew it couldn't improve on the first one. I ended up with nothing to do one night and someone had rented the remake. I put it in the player and spent the next two hours grimacing and cringing with each lame cliché and unsubtle piece of acting. I began to wonder if it was an attempt to make the original look that much better in comparison. Seriously don't waste your time or money on this one. It's terrible and everything about it is about as ham-fisted and crudely done as it gets.

First off I'll admit that I loved Nic Cage's early work Valley Girl - Birdy - Peggy Sue Got Married but somewhere around The Rock his performances and appearance began to distract me from whatever I've seen him in. His melodramatic lumbering performance in The Wicker Man is one of the main reasons I found it hard to keep a straight face. Beyond the fact that his overly dramatic performance (a homage to Edward Woodward in the original?) made his character very unlikable his wig was completely distracting. It looked like he cut the tail off a horse and glued it to his head. It also seemed like he was medicated or chemically altered and delivered his lines with a Brando-ish slur (perhaps because of his grotesque porcelain veneers??). Anyway I'm confused by who his audience is? The elderly?? No idea but I could have seen World Trade Center shortly after Wicker Man but I couldn't stomach the thought of sitting through another Cage performance. (The previous paragraph is just MHO.) That aside the ending is just an unintentional hoot. As soon as Ellen Burstyn begins the "dance" she does whilst leading her followers to the sacrifice I couldn't keep a straight face and I was far from the only one. Nic Cage's bizarre over the delivery of his lines had people howling. The last film I went to where that happened was Basic Instinct II. (Basic 2 might have worked if Cage had played the male lead. He and Stone could have spent the whole film trying to top each other in the overacting department.) It also looked as if this thing was heavily edited. And what was up with the guy covered in boils and missing an eye in Lady Summersilse's house? It was apparent they didn't like men much - why would they keep that eyesore around - for a cheap creep-out whenever a California Highway Patrolman comes calling? Lame.Come on seriously how can you watch and listen to Cage deliver this howler of a line while pointing his gun at Molly Parker - "Step away from the bike!!!" I went to see this because I like Burstyn LaBute and the original film. Imho this is a botch from start to finish.

OK if your looking to waste your time by seeing a pointless remake- watch this! I will admit its a good thing that they kept beauty about it like the setting but apart form that it was CRAP! I love the original and this just took the biscuit- stealing lines from the original and twisting them into stuff that DOESN'T MAKE SENSE! e.gSS: Do you suspect foul play?NC: (heavy annoying American accent) YA!It was upsetting. OK I have made my point. That this is movie with no point and will make u wriggle in ur seat dying to escape but hoping that its going somewhere!

column4: Hilarious!!... For all the wrong reasons!
column5: There seems to be a lot of this trend going around lately and frankly I am not complaining. This whole thing with horror movies containing scenes so silly the only horror you'll experience is busting a gut laughing your ass off. Everyone knows about the "How'd it get burned?!" Scene but that's just the tip of the iceberg! Where else are you gonna find a scene where Nicholas Cage points a gun at a woman on a bicycle and tells her "STEP AWAY FROM THE BIKE!" then in another scene comes downstairs and just on the spur of the moment punches a woman knocking her out cold. Then Nicholas Cage dons a bear suit and punches another woman... I can't believe I just said that. I only give this movie a 2 out of ten because this movie needed more of these silly scenes then at least it would have attained to a "so-bad-it's-good" status. As it is though The Wicker Man even with it's scenes of ridiculousness is only good for one maybe two viewings then you'll never want to watch it again.

column4: Run away run away as fast as you can
column5: This is supposed to be an "A" movie but I've seen "B" movies with better acting and scripts. Quite possibly the worst movie I've ever seen... and I've seen a lot of movies. If it were possible to give this movie a negative vote I would. I have never walked out on a movie but this one had me edging towards the door. Just bad bad bad. Cage has never shown me to be a great actor but he's been at least watchable. In WTC he put forth a remarkable effort. For Wicker Man I can't even say he mailed it in. If it hadn't been his face on the screen I'd have never believed it was him. If you must throw away your money to see this save the couple hours out of your life and send me the rental fee instead. Trust me you'll thank me later. Of course that's just my opinion... I could be wrongWhip

A stupidly circular nonsensical waste of time. I was intrigued by the opening sequence but it went downhill rapidly from there. The plot had absolutely no believability. How can one man (Nicolas Cage's character) continually follow these mindless island dwellers then actually believe it his daughter from the mother who should absolutely been slapped a long time before the plot thickens? I mean really! My wife wanted to slap some sense into her too. What happened to Cage? How could he stoop to such role in a terrible waste of celluloid. The only redeeming value is Ellen Burstyn. She has aged so well she is absolutely stunning in her beauty. She could have done better by doing the Exorcist 15 or whatever the next number is. Save your money. Stupid utterly stupid!

I love the original. It is unlike any other film I have ever seen so I knew the remake just would not be any good. How can you recreate it? But because it is so different a film I had to watch the remake simply because I was interested. I went in with very low expectations and came away even more disappointed than I thought I'd be. I thought it would just be aweful and would be able to laugh at its attempt but unfortunately I actually came away bored. This film is just a bit meek. The acting was fine the production was fine and the film was just fine. I wanted it to be aweful or brilliant and what I got was entirely average. Surprised I didn't fall asleep. Just not worth the bother.

I'll have to agree with himebishojo who said this was the biggest waste of time.Mr. Cage should have phoned this one in he'd probably would have done a better job. And what was up with his hair sometimes its shades of black then brown sometimes you can see his roots and hair plugs.The plot was full of holes and very thin. dialog was worse and badly delivered from all. There are very good and interesting movies out there that were shelved and we may never get to see them on the big screen but yet this one gets made. SHAMEFUL!This is definitely a cable movie don't even rent it!

The whole movie is a "keep them guessing" plot. At first you think the movie is going places and then it starts to get stranger and stranger. Nic Cage is a cop who after witnessing a crash (in the commercial) takes a break from the biz. Then his ex-girlfriend writes him a letter asking him to come help her find her missing daughter Rowan. His ex Willow lives in one of those weird communes where they live in the past and all the girls wear their hair in braid. The plot then becomes "interesting" when everyone in the commune acts like there is no Rowan. Adding to the ackwardness there are bees crows and fetuses! By the time you figure out what is going on it's too late to get your money back. If you like bad movies see this one. It might be worth a good joke or two. Otherwise it's not that great of a flick.

Unfortunately there is no category lower than 1 or I would have given it. This "remake" bears absolutely no resemblance to the original 1973 version. The original was a thriller with pagan overtones clearly written by people who had done their homework. They did not seek to present a genuine modern pagan viewpoint but they worked hard to capture the essential flavor even including a bit of dry humor right at the beginning. The credits that read "We would like to thank the people of Summerisle for a look into their religious practices" that sort of thing.This sorry bit of bilge does nothing of the sort. It is simply an exercise in anti-male misogynism. Phony feminism carried to its ultimate level of ridiculousness. Not a single male "resident" ever utters a line which no doubt saved the producers a fortune but did nothing to establish this film's credibility which it sorely needed. As a movie which has nothing to do with The Wicker Man it's a loser in its own right. The original is a brilliant classic; this one's a lame poser that has none of the original's insight or TLC. Puke-O-Rama kids.

Let's try and get through this review without even mentioning the original shall we?Neil LaBute really doesn't make things easy for himself does he? Not only does he tackle a remake - never a popular decision - but he immediately reworks it into another of his gender-war pieces with a dispassionate matriarchy destroying an innocent man for their own (lunatic) ends. He must thrive on the accusations of misogyny - this just smacks of deliberate provocation.Whatever LaBute's motives however the decision to introduce the gender aspect was a canny one. Not only does it reinvigorate the well-trodden 'isolated community' storyline it provides an opportunity to gather together a raft of America's finest character actresses in one place; it's still relatively rare for women to predominate a cast in a mainstream American film (no really think about it - how many films have more than three significant female characters? How many have more than two?). So make way for Ellen Burstyn Frances Conroy Molly Parker Kate Beahan Diane Delano and Leelee Sobieski; only Robert Altman and Pedro Almodovar have had more impressive female rosters.Beahan's striking features with her almost parodically large doe eyes provide her with the perfect patina of Bambi-like innocence; her increasingly hesitant mannerisms are slyly pitched between ruthless manipulation and genuine distress. Sobieski seems underused but the final shot of her lip trembling is unforgettable; it almost saves a totally botched final scene (the audience should feel the wheels of a ruthless mechanism beginning to turn again but those cheesy bar-room guys seem too lightweight to suffer. A little less characterisation might have been more effective by keeping it in general terms). Delano is a memorable if unsubtle presence although anyone who has seen the 'Randall and Hopkirk (Deceased)' episode 'O Happy Isle' might have a hard time taking her character seriously (in fact the two productions are weirdly similar even taking the influence of you-know-what on the episode into account). Conroy seems to be having fun as Dr. Moss and she has a wonderful knack of seeming benign and sinister with the same facial expression. Best of all is the sublime Molly Parker an extraordinary actress who deserves wider recognition (see particularly 'Kissed'). In this film she barely seems human. Her schoolteacher is both rigid and playful easily provoked and completely in control the one woman on the island who seems to get a genuine malicious kick out of seeing their victim meet his fate. The sight of her in her bird-mask cycling down a woodland lane is enough to justify this film's existence.I'm less certain about Burstyn's performance although her low-key queen bee may well benefit from repeated viewings (although - I have to ask - why is her make-up so damned immaculate? I find it hard to see Sister Summersisle applying lipstick whilst looking in a compact). And last but not least the main man of the piece Nicolas Cage gives a really solid performance bar one line of overplaying (see if you can spot it). I'm coming to really admire Cage - he is never ever anything less than fully 'on' committed to his performance whatever the film. I can't think of a single uninteresting Nicolas Cage performance which is quite a lot more than I could say about almost any of his peers.(footnote: after 'Ghost Rider' 'Next' 'Bangkok Dangerous' and 'Knowing' you might say my good will towards Cage has become a little tarnished since I posted this review...)None of this really gets past the problem that the film is short on atmosphere and the scares are for the most part cheap shocks. The bee imagery is fun although those familiar with mid-period 'X-Files' may find it a little familiar. The film does tease the unknowing quite cleverly however - those familiar with (sigh) the original might miss that LaBute sets the audience up for a 'Jacob's Ladder'- style twist that never comes (it starts with the hero rendered unconscious in a traumatic accident he's plagued by visions of the deceased there are non-sequiturs and surrealism - see also 'Carnival of Souls' 'Dead End' 'Soul Survivors' even 'The Wizard of Oz' for where this might seem to be going) allowing him to slip the real knife in without arousing suspicion.

I watched this recently with my girlfriend for a laugh. Its bad. Really bad. In the trailer you see a child being hit by a truck. This is in the film for about 20 minutes then completely forgot about! The film has SO many unneeded scenes and so many loose ends. I will say the ending is actually not bad though stupid and careless. Also for anyone who's watched it (not a spoiler) he looses his "Everythings OK" Cd's in the film he makes an effort to find it then never questions his belongings being tampered with. I really wanna know where his CD is! Id say give it a watch its quite funny to mock. Id like to see remake of this film because the story is strong just cut the loose ends and get better actors! Mr. Cage although i liked you in "National Treasure" i do not like you as an actor your acting is somewhat boring and i just cant actually see you in the part of anything. What i mean is you look like a man with a family a dog and i lovely wife not some cop who goes looking for some girl who's missing. Im not sure if anyone else agrees but my girlfriend also made this point.

The worst film I have ever seen actually worse than Spawn.I won't bother going into the story line but needless to say you will wish that you never wasted your time or money on this title.Seriously if you ever want to take heed of a stranger's views start now. This film is utterly gash! Don't put yourself or your friends through the torture of what will put you in a bad mood for days.My reasons for this are the following; the storyline is poor acting was mediocre had potential but was wasted with the poorest of endings.And by poor I mean really poor this is what put the nail in the coffin.I haven't actually seen the original but from the other reviews I think that may be worth watching so looking forward to getting that.I pray to God though that it is infinitely better than this version.Once more please keep your distance.

column4: you bitches! killing me wont bring back your honey!
column5: It's so sad that the plot was so outrageously retarded because the value of production and cinematography and sound and budget was so high. Wicker Man is shot so well but virtually impossible to sit through because of the mindless plot and dialogue. But it is hilarious in the Mystery Science Theatre 3000 sort of way. So to explain my 4 stars it was for the cinematography and sound cause they are both great. The digital effects are good but really out of place. Everything else is terrible. The magic of movie making was lost 25 minutes into the film and in the beginning of the "third act" LaBute (the director really?) just gives up trying to keep the viewer scared or emotionally invested at all. BUT IT IS SO DAMN FUNNY SOMETIMES. i don't want to give anything away but it is one of the funniest (clearly unintentional) movies i've seen in a while. Especially when Nick Cage just starts randomly throwing knockout haymakers at every woman he sees. O and he's in a bear suit for that part for no apparent reason. Overall... pretty bad.

column4: This is a movie is not for normal people to watch. It is not horror movie because it is not scary. This is a different one it will make you truly mad
column5: This is the most stupid movie ever. My hole day I was angry how could I have the idea of watching this.This is not a horror movie. It is the impersonation of someone's sick mind. How could you let it out man. Who in the hell wrote this s***t. The acting is awful and about the idea....my information to the guys in the mental house: keep a good eye on this one he has lot of potential.I am wondering which one is the sickest. The guy with the idea or the guy who actually release it.Make yourselves a favor and do something useful rather than watching this crap. I wanted to rate this lower than one. I am sorry that there is no such option. ;(

This movie is so awful! It is not "scary" - little children in the theater were laughing out loud. Burstyn and Cage must have owed someone or some company a very big favor that made them agree to appear in this dog. There is no character development; there are many questions left unasked and unanswered. When Cage meets up with his old flame there is nothing about them together that suggests chemistry now or ever. The story comes across as misogynistic AND misanthropic as well as anti-law and order. The island society's reasons for holding onto these beliefs is baffling; somehow these beliefs are connected to the successful raising of bees. Hunh...! It is a waste of time and money.

column4: Unwarranted unnecessary unbelievably silly...this one has it all!
column5: Does every movie need to be remade? The answer is a resounding NO. The insipid and tortuously silly recent remake of "The Wicker Man" is a prime example of this. Only the Adam Sandler interpretation of "Mr. Deeds Goes to Town" has offended me more in recent memory. You're going to remake a Gary Cooper movie? WHY? Anyway while the original WM was a cult hit and a good eerie tale helped by a wonderful score good performances and a brooding unsettling atmosphere leading to what was at the time a somewhat horrific and disturbing ending the 2006 interpretation is a tiresome and predictable slog past Nic Cage's slack jaw. I'm not playing art-house critic snobby-guy here either. This movie is absolutely the biggest waste of film and catering I've ever seen.I think Cage has done some good work here and there and I know actors alone don't make movies sink or swim but it's hard not to blame him for this. He's just...all over it. His character is gullible stupid and obnoxious. And we have little to look at for the duration of the film but his dopey incredulity abrupt fits of shouting and the endless brooding walks he takes around the island trying to figure out what is made painfully obvious to the audience in my opinion. We're not idiots. Let us have SOME little mystery to figure out.To backtrack Cage's character is a motor cop who picks up a doll he sees thrown from a moving car. The little brat in the back seat promptly throws it out again when he pulls over the car and returns it. As he stoops to retrieve it a semi plows into the car and the occupants die in flames despite his somewhat lame efforts to save them. Of course no bodies are recovered he receives a letter everyone is not who they seem etc. etc. It's just too silly of a story-line to bore you with the details.There is a weird feminist pagan cult on an island where Cage's cop's ex-wife lures him with a letter. Kate Beahan who is kind of hot in a waif-like way I have to say turns in an agonizing saucer-eyed confused-looking performance as the heroin-chic ex-wife. Any man who would believe anything this idiotic spaced-out twit said without a DNA test would not get through the police academy.The menace is heavy handed and the clues as to the upcoming "ritual" fall like bricks. We all know the "Don't split up and look around!" sentiments horror movies have elicited for decades. This movie elicits more of a "If you can't figure it out just go home and quit boring us!" feeling.Just a taste...crows in school desks of missing children "our hero" punching several women in the face full closed-fist blows mind you. Cage's Edward (salut Mr. Woodward) dons bear suits commits bicycle theft against the openly hostile schoolmarm engages in insanely stupid explorations into untenable environments where (guess what) "someone" traps him. A man who states he is fully aware he has a serious allergy to bee-stings somehow manages to ride his bike into a bee-farm and roll down a hill caroming off hive after hive. He is alternately a bully a spaced-out hallucinater and a dunce. The dialog which I shall not utter here is beyond belief.The talented Ellen Burstyn is wasted as the sinister matriarch of the island and given ominous passive/aggressive lines in a final attempt to make sure even the people who were dozing making-out or perhaps building a ship-in-a-bottle for the first part of the movie get it. Yes old twins and young twins the gender structure of beehives (drones/breeders=male workers/Queen=female...get it?). Good god I hope so by now.Leelee Sobiesky is also a strange addition; she is sullen rude unhelpful moody and inexplicably tries to talk Edward into taking her off the island. Why? He doesn't seem to have any way to leave and apparently she does as we see later. You figure it out. I dare you.The Christian vs. Pagan themes that made the original WM interesting are absent. Why they want a human sacrifice is unclear. There is talk of a crop failure but have these people ever heard of fertilizer? They're certainly aware of the modern world. And their main export seems to be honey anyway. At least feed the sacrifice to the bees or something. The island's cult members seem less like true-believers and more like sadistic con-artists preying on a mental-deficient.When the charming missing little girl shows up and ignites the towering wicker man with Cage's Edward trapped predictably and almost deservedly in harm's way it is like watching a kitten fed to pit bulls. It is pathetic and graphic without being in any way moving.Director Neil LaBute has taken a disturbing and darkly quirky story (think Shirley Jackson's "The Lottery") and crafted something shallow and meaningless from it. It's as if the source-material were shaken upside down until all the passion and mystery and meaning fell out and then was thrown up on the screen. This film treats it's characters as dumbed-down paper cut-outs of clichés and its audience as unable to absorb any subtlety.There is an attempt at a 'twist' or 'surprise' ending as if everyone hadn't had enough punishment. I know my comments are scathing but if we accept this as anything worthy of any kind of audience we just open ourselves to the next travesty. Say NO. As I watched I couldn't help thinking about how these millions of dollars could have otherwise been spent. Perhaps on "Stop Or My Mom Will Shoot 2." I just can't stand it...

column4: Miscalculated remake of a horror classic
column5: THE WICKER MAN (2006) ** Nicolas Cage Ellen Burstyn Kate Beahan Frances Conroy Molly Parker Leelee Sobieski Diane Delano Michael Wiseman Erika-Shaye Gair (Cameos: Aaron Eckhart James Franco Jason Ritter) (Dir: Neil LaBute)Miscalculated remake of a horror classicWhy can't Hollywood ever leave well enough alone when it comes to remaking classics or in this case a cult classic? The latest sacrilege is the sluggish rehashing of the 1973 occult cult classic directed by Robin Hardy and written by playwright Anthony Shaffer about a mysterious island of pagans investigated by a pious self-righteous and virginal Scottish constable played by Edward Woodward facing his destiny with the cult leader played by horror icon Christopher Lee (who claimed this was his favorite film and his best role!) The original film was maligned by its own studio and eventually developed its cult audience years later when a campaign began to re-release its original director's cut after the British studio British Lion relinquished a cut-and-paste hack job that was to be released originally stateside by maverick film producing legend Roger Corman (who owned a print luckily since the studio destroyed its original supposedly as land fill for a British highway!)I must admit I hadn't seen the original until just recently after speaking with a lovely young British babe at a friend's birthday dinner who had informed me she was a huge horror film fan and we were discussing our favorites when I mentioned the forthcoming re-make of this film! She suggested I see the original first � and after a lengthy search found a copy (the Americanized cut too) to rent and was surprised at how good it actually was. So when I went to see this new version I admit I was expecting something of it � something to hope would do justice to its original.Needless to say it did what I would've normally expected had I not seen the original: tank.The film takes place now in Puget Sound in Washington where California cop Edward Malus (Cage) is beckoned by his ex-fiancée Willow Woodward (Beahan late of "FlightPlan") who is living in a commune known for its honey exporting to help her find her recently missing young daughter. Malus is also recovering from a horrible auto accident that has psychically scarred him so he figures to head to the woodsy isle � Summer's Isle to be exact � to get away from his demons and to possibly find out why Willow left him after all these years.When Malus arrives after negotiating a pick-up ride with the sea-plane pilot who brings the denizens their daily supplies he discovers that the locales aren't exactly the welcome committee and have nothing but disdain for this man regardless of his being of the law (he's told his law doesn't matter there which fuels his anger/need to find out what became of Rowan the little girl even more). When he reunites with Willow she is skittish and full of paranoia suggesting something horrible has happened to Rowan. Malus continues to investigate and winds up deeper and deeper into this odd island's customs which seem to be a pagan cult eschewing any Christianity or morality much to Malus' increasing chagrin. What follows is a daisy-chain of unexplained red herrings and a wild goose chase to his fateful summation. To say more would ruin the original film's shocking close but here it is something of a relief for its trodding and ill-kept pacing.What is largely absent is the religious overtones that caused the struggle of the main character in the original piece whereby the post-feminism and misogyny LaBute ("In The Company Of Men") is best known for and makes a few significant changes including the aforementioned piety as well as a matriarch (Burstyn as Sister Summerisle) and a predominately female hierarchy that is only touched upon its most basic of principles.While Cage makes the most of his character it would have been real interesting to have someone like Edward Norton or Johnny Depp adding their own shadings to a possibly interesting protagonist but to have Malus resorting to an old chestnut (spoiler: the girl is actually his daughter too) to have motivation only takes away from the mystery at hand. Is God really dead?LaBute is better known for his dense dialogue than camera-work and although a few nice moments of Cage getting his ya-yas out it doesn't quite gel and feels half-hearted in the long run. Supposedly both LaBute and Cage (whose production company Saturn Films is responsible for the remake) love the original and it's surprising how in such capable hands a remake was ill-advised.

Prepare for the most terrifying ordeal for your life; prepare for a movie which will force to you confront your deepest fears and will not leave you unscathed as you enter a world where nightmares and reality merge.Then when you've finished watching the original Japense version of The Ring you can have a good hearty laugh at the Wicker Man a heap of old junk seemingly thrown up by Nicolas Cage and Neil La Bute after a boozy weekend and largely made by throwing together whatever bits they could remember of the original classic Wicker Man and patched up with a load of clichés stolen from much better horror movies.Whether it is Nicolas Cage's stoned performance or La Bute's hilariously wrong dialogue ("aaah my legs!") you won't be disappointed.

The only redeeming factors were the costumes and scenic location. If I wanted a story to be resolved with needless death and violence I would simply read the newspaper. I really don't see how the claim "a 1973 remake" made anyone want to work on this project in the first place. Perhaps the words "classic novel written in 1973" would work but this? What were talented artists thinking? The plot also smacked of misogyny as if anyone in this lifetime could actually take away white male privilege in the U.S. Odd how the subject of the "poor emasculated man" comes up more often than one would expect in films and theatre when the reality is nearly always completely the opposite.

This could very possibly be one of the worst films made in the history of mankind. A clear paycheck ride for nicholas cage whose career could have been killed off by this film had he not captured the hearts of America's lowest common denominator with other cardboard performances years past. Look for this one to storm the razzies with particular note to Ms. Beahan whose "bee stung" lips detract attention from her over earnest eyes and hollow poses of her underfed frame one half expects her to sit at a piano and rip out a Fiona apple cover...again apple bees. so many bees. why not bea arthur? Neil LaBute should be spanked vigorously for this insulting debacle that cost an astounding $40000000 to make. That figure is worth seeing it alone. I sure hope they had great catering on set because the money is no where to seen on screen.

The Wicker Man seemed like a good choice when I was trying to decide which movie to go to yesterday. It looked mysterious and slightly spooky which I tend to like. So I bought tickets for my husband and myself. What a mistake. The Wicker Man really did have the potential to be good. But it's not. It's not spooky or mysterious either. It's BORING. It was obvious how the movie was going to end within the first ten minutes. I should have left the theater then. I didn't find the movie to be offensive at all. I am familiar with the Druid ceremonies of millennia past and kind of expected the ending. However my husband is not familiar with the legends and he STILL knew what was going to happen. It was so boring that my husband actually fell asleep in the theater which he has never done before. I looked around and saw several other people snoozing as well. That's two hours of my life that I'll never get back. Total waste of time and money.

column4: Nicholas Cage should be ashamed of himself for making this movie!
column5: I cannot believe that the same Nicholas Cage that starred in The Rock and Face Off actually agreed to make this THE MOST GOD AWFUL MOVIE I HAVE EVER SEEN (and I'm 43 years old)! Note: I will never be led to watch another Nick Cage film. Know when to say "no" to your agent Nick!! You just lost a fan big guy...Now on with the "review"...I did not know that this was a remake but it wouldn't have made any difference. This movie had absolutely the worst acting imaginable and was totally devoid of a coherent plot. If you watch this movie after reading my review all I can say is that you were warned! Here are a few questions about this "movie": Why were we shown the scenes of him trying to save the girl in the burning car about a dozen times during the movie? It had absolutely no relevance at all to the "plot". Actually there was no point to the semi hitting the car with the girl in it at all. And if a semi had hit the car that girl would likely have been killed instantly not left sitting up in the back seat looking at Nick totally unfazed and without a scratch on her...Why did he finally get a cell signal if no one was going to show up and attempt to rescue him? Why did he have to spend the night in the water if they were ultimately going to do him in? Why didn't they just kill him when he arrived on the island? The time he spent trying to track down the girl was a total waste of film and my time.I have to say that when the credits rolled at the end of this disaster I was just as disappointed as I was when the credits rolled at the end of Full Metal Jacket. These are the only two movies that I can recall that ended with me staring at the TV screen (yes this was only a $3 DVD rental thank god!) wondering what the hell just happened why I wasted a slice of my life viewing it and why anyone in their right mind would agree to pay to have a pile of crap like this distributed for viewing?

column4: Save your money - I preferred Ishtar
column5: Sorry to say it but it was one of the few times I've felt like asking for a refund. The movie was slow unimaginative contrived and predictable. Though the acting was solid enough the characters were unbelievable.The trailers on TV and in the theaters are totally misleading...they have nothing to do with the film. Nor do many of the pieces of the plot.**mini-spoiler** For instance the traffic accident which seem to be the premise for the film -- if you stop to analyze it not only doesn't play into the story line; it does not support the final "conclusion" that there is nothing supernatural going on.Contrived plot lines: Cage's character who was "chosen" by Willow years ago just happens to be involved in a horrific traffic accident which puts him on leave from his duties as a police officer and puts him in a position to respond to the mysterious note. He goes to the island which has a commune that survives by raising bees and making honey and he just happens to be allergic to bees (which by the way has no real consequences in the movie); when trying to sneak into the final ritual he just happens to come across the one person on the island who wears a full-body costume; he carefully checks his weapon for ammo but when he really needs it it has had the bullets remove and Willow just happens to have them in her hand at the ceremony; at one point his cell phone rings but there is no connection -- what does that have to do with anything???? I should have suspected something when the 10:00 O'clock showing of the film on the first Friday of its run was 2/3rd's empty. Do yourself a favor and skip this one. (BTW: I am a big Nicolas Cage fan but I feel everyone involved with this turkey should apologize.)

I have to admit I rather enjoyed this movie although I knew walking out of the cinema a lot of people were going to tear it to pieces. This is indeed what has happened and the movie has been predictably compared in an unfavourable light to the original.The updated story sees a trauma-stricken traffic cop (Nicholas Cage) summoned to a distant island Summersisle by a letter from his ex. She needs him to help her search for their missing daughter whom the rest of the islanders devout pagan-worshippers may be hiding in preparation for a ritual sacrifice...The problems are neither in the production or the performances but in the plot. Whilst the central character (Nicholas Cage's Edward Malus standing in for Edward Woodward's Sergeant Howie) has been updated in an interesting way this was not handled to the best effect and any emotional impact it could have registered was completely lost. The second half of the movie played far too quickly. More patience and care with this particularly the climax could have significantly heightened the overall effect. Furthermore the addition of a coda at the end to suggest the possibility for sequels was completely pointless.Given the religious zealotry which seems to occupy both Western and Middle East politics these days I would have enjoyed seeing an updating of the religious conflict (Christianity versus Paganism) of the original placing this conflict in a contemporary light. The gender-reversed society depicted in the remake with dominant women subjugating the males did not hold water. Plot threads from the prologue with Malus the traffic cop failing to rescue a woman and child from burning in a car crash were never really followed through leaving their inclusion in the story questionable. The fate of the unfortunate pilot who takes Malus to the island leaves another gaping plot hole.All this said the movie certainly looks good. The production is well-shot by director Neil LaBute and the surroundings of the islanders make for sunny heavenly contrast to their sinister intentions. Some night time sequences with Malus searching for his daughter in the dark or underwater are also of note. I quite liked the new look of the briefly seen Wicker Man with its human occupant snared inside its head this time.The performances while not outstanding are more or less satisfactory given the obstacles faced by the actors in the script. Nicholas Cage had my sympathies until towards the end when he started to turn violent and manic. This move did not seem wholly logical or grow out of what had gone before. Ellen Burstyn does fine in the role of Sister Summersisle but sounds a bit embarrassed when she has to repeat lines spoken by Christopher Lee in the original. But her quiet-seeming passivity belies her enormous power and this worked well in the performance.Although worth a look for its production values and efforts of the principal performers I am afraid I would still recommend the 1973 original above this brave but misguided effort.

what can I say that hasn't already been Jesus... this is one god awful film. I love Cage normally as he's a decent actor but this is an insult to anyones intelligence and such a missed opportunity Cage is funny in sections but it just doesn't fit in with the film.. what were they trying to do? Any that bear suite... OMG... I Can't comment anymore... it's up there with Lady In The Water Feast Body of Evidence in the worst films ever made and id Defoe the worse sequel ever made! Pleas whatever you do don't see this film or dare buy it it'll be the biggest waste of money since anyone seen The Hulk... Why couldn't they just have Left this film alone... please Cage Next is a good film stick with what you know...

column4: Great Movie can't understand the bad votes
column5: Great Movie can't understand the bad votes...This Movie is not Cage's best movie (Lord of War for example is my favorite one) but this movie is really entertaining and keeps an high tension. I really liked it. don't know why people vote this film just so bad... i give it a 9 cause i really enjoyed itYou can really watch and enjoy this movie don't care about the bad voting here just give it a try!Nicolas Cage rocks like always :-)Acting was also very good. the story is also believable. some parts are funny (when cage is kicking and punching women ;-) )...

column4: too family friendly.would have been better with more of an edge
column5: before i begin i should offer some advice.this movie is better viewed without having seen the original.you will probably get more out of it that way.i saw the original 1stwhich makes it hard to give a fair review of the remake.neverthelessi will try.casting Nic Cage in the lead role was a good move.Cage is credible in his role.the whole film is populated with current and past big name actorssome of whom have small rolesand some who have larger roles.not all do convincing job.some were rather lacklustre in their roles.this 2006 version is a remake of the 1973 classicand adds very little to its parent.there is a lot more music and noise in all the appropriate placesof course(I'm being sarcastic here).the story is pretty much the sameinvolving the occult and paganism.the biggest problem with this movie is it's rating.because of it's PG13 ratingit lacks the edge and risqué than the original.to be more effectivethis type of movie should have a more adult rating.this is also problem with logic in this movie.there are just some things that don't make sense and there is no real attempt to explain them.the truth isthis movie is just a louder version of the originalminus the the scenes minus the edginess.as a stand alone movieits not half bad.like i saidif you watch this movie without having seen the originalyou will have a higher opinion of it.i will give "The Wicker Man" 2006 version 7/10

column4: Weak Performances In A Silly Story
column5: Obviously sometimes even good actors will agree to star in a movie simply for the sake of the paycheque. Equally obviously this was one of those examples. What we have here is a decent enough cast (headed by Nicolas Cage and Ellen Burstyn) simply going through the motions without putting anything that even remotely seemed like passion or even effort into it. Lack of passion and effort aside I thought Cage was in any event rather poorly cast as Edward Malus a California cop who investigates the disappearance of a young girl on a mysterious island off the coast of Washington State. That of course led to one of the anomalies of the movie as Sister Beech (Diane Delano) after she and the women in her café were told by Malus that he was there on official police business challenged him with the words "official California police business - but this is Washington." True. Someone involved with this movie apparently forgot the concept of police jurisdiction! Alongside Cage's unconvincing portrayal of Malus was the weak performance of Burstyn in a very silly role as Sister Summersisle - a sort of pagan high priestess in this commune of women who like to sacrifice men to gain the approval of the gods and goddesses. Seeing Burstyn with her face painted half blue at least was worthy of a laugh. Yeah there's a little bit of worthwhile suspense as we wait to find out what actually happened to young Rowan but overall this just struck me as a truly bad movie. 3/10

column4: not nearly as bad as critics claimed
column5: Cage's acting certainly isn't consistent but the movie manages to maintain a creepy mood. Overall it felt like a twilight zone episode.if you are hesitant to see it bc of bad reviews you cant go wrong seeing it for a reduced price early in the day.an "R" rating would have benefited this film greatly however.Many of the children look similar which makes sense but I got the feeling that the script may have had a different plot in mind and then changed gears after filming started....I haven't seen the original so perhaps this is an incorrect assumption. I'd say see it if you're at all interested.

column4: Forget the negative nelly's - watch and enjoy!
column5: I found this movie entertaining. It was well-paced and had an interesting premise. I had not read anything about this film nor had I seen the original so the clever unexpected twist at the end was a genuine surprise.Nicholas Cage does a good job as the outsider investigating a creepy island full of residents who barely seem to tolerate him. Its always nice to see Ellen Burstyn on screen though she's largely on autopilot here.I loved all the references to the hierarchy of the bee colony; queens workers and the drones. This becomes part of the plot.Forget all the negative reviews ... my advice is to go with it and enjoy a well made film as it plays itself out.Who knows; maybe I'll catch the original from the early 70's some day.7/10

Its not often a remake is better than the original. However in this case it is.As in the original there is no real action its all physiological at the basest level.Nicolas Cage's character could be regarded as being more human than Edward Woodwards one as he shows more emotion than in the original - and also doesn't have to suffer an awful song either.Various new things have been added which all give it a slight horror feel and do actually enhance the film.You'll only really enjoy it if you can sit through 80-odd minutes of talking and nice scenery - if you want action every few seconds then you certainly wont like this...

column4: Not as bad as i thought
column5: When i went to see this i really didn't know what to expect. I hadnt seen the original but I'm also aware that remakes are seldom any good. This film starts well with the opening car wreck. Nicolas Cage portrays a fairly average but often believable character throughout this movie. For people who haven't seen this movie you may well enjoy this as you don't really see the end coming by cage being tricked by all the women. The only quibble i had was that in the trailer it shows cage with his head in a tank full of bees which was supposed to be part of cages 'pre burning' routine but only surfaced in the form of sound in the final cut. I have since watched the original and didn't spoil my enjoyment of either film. There are many differences not least in the form of hippies vs women and there is no nudity in this film and possibly the lack of britt ecklund but all in all i came out of this having got my moneys worth. I would point out that any men with feminist girlfriends as mine is will probably enjoy this as they did hard candy.

Literally.... Culturally...Terribly....Completely the worst movie i have ever seen. Absolutely terrible. Never watch this unless if maybe your high or something. Which even in that case i doubt you will enjoy it. This is the kind of movie that you buy for someone who you want to commit suicide. The worst ending in history. It starts out as a kind of decent suspenseful horror movie that builds up a weird kind of tension based on the fact that the community in this movie is absolutely bizarre in every way you never want to see. Nicolas Cage's acting is absolutely despicable and irritating. The movie just digresses further and further into a pile of ashes while you are learning more and more weird and disturbing things about the people on the island until you do not even care what happens you do not care about anything and the only part of the movie that has your disgusted attention in the latter half of the movie is the ending Which is the kind of material that makes you want to jump off a bridge and live with the fishes. I can't go into detail since i don't want to spoil this terrible movie for you But i'm just warning you It is inevitable that anyone will be completely disappointed when they see this movie for the first time.

Now I thought this movie would be okay. I had never seen the original. I was ready for a decent movie experience. What did I get? A hilarious film! It's got all of the qualities that a good comedy needs. Explosions! Nic Cage killing bees. Nic Cage punching a fat chick. Nic Cage swimming and this made me laugh because of his facial expressions. Anyway this movie starts off with Cage being a cop then picking up a doll for some brat and then he has to go to some island where everything is all Amished-out but with less men and more appeal. Cage has to look for a girl blah blah blah. You know for an island with about 90 percent women you would think that some would be good looking. Like two of 'em are. Oh well that doesn't matter. I'm about to give you a spoiler. A HUGE ONE. So don't read on unless you want to know how the movie ends. I'm kidding but I will say that the ending sucks.

After recently watching and thoroughly enjoying the original 1973 movie I thought I'd try the 2006 remake. The positives first of all I found the movie to be entertaining enough. It kept me engaged for most of its run time. There is also some nice scenery and good shots around the island. While I found Cage's delivery of his lines more akin to an American action movie than to the original Wickerman such heavy use of the original script meant I could compare lines to the original film which I enjoyed doing.The impact of the 1973 Wickerman for me came from 3 elements within the movie:Firstly the islanders religious beliefs. There is a complete lack of exploration into the islanders beliefs instead portraying them as a 2 dimensional cult. Without understanding their religious motivations the realism of the film is lost.Secondly the outward 'normalness' of the original islanders and their lives outwith religious beliefs and practices. I felt their portrayal in the remake leant somewhat on slightly modified cultural tropes in particular mainstream understandings of the Amish community in so much as islanders all wore similar clothing and seemed to shun modern technology in their lives. It was easy to imagine the original islanders coming across to the mainland and blending in with the society around them in the remake this isn't so.Finally the main characters. The original's Sergeant Howie while a somewhat aloof character is unique and believable. He is a model of Scottish Presbyterian attitudes which influence his outlook and interactions. Anyone of a certain age living in Scotland has met a Howie type character in their lives. Unfortunately in their efforts to make Nicolas Cage's character more vulnerable and approachable 'Edward Malus' becomes instantly forgettable. Some of the acting felt out of place at times for instance towards the end Nicolas Cage indulges in some violent and aggressive outbursts several young women in white dresses get punched in the face without any real reason. Ellen Burstyn's Sister Summersisle is fine but given Christopher Lee's masterful portrayal of Lord Summerisle in the original his star outshines hers.Overall as a remake I've judged largely against the light of the original rather than in its own right. That being said the 2006 Wickerman certainly lacks the impact and authentic feel of the 1970s version. For those watching the remake without having seen the original I'm sure it comes across as a reasonably entertaining if standard American thriller. There are some nice hat tips to the original particularly through the naming of some characters. I did wonder towards the end if it would have been better for the film makers to have made a more original Wickerman inspired piece rather than a direct remake. Overall as film it is ok. As a remake it is poor.

column4: It deserves all the flack it gets and then a little more. The Wicker Man comes off as one continuous mess further embedding greatness upon the original.
column5: In years to come and when people look back at certain films from certain times this version of The Wicker Man will surely go down as one of the more pointless remakes; holding its own up there with films like Psycho and Get Carter. But it's not that The Wicker Man is a dead on arrival film that hurts the more and more you watch it it's the other sort of 'bad' film the sort that just feels incompetent at best; the sort that has you thinking if what is going on and how things are unfolding is really how they wanted it to all go down.The primary problem The Wicker Man has holding it back the whole time is its aspiration for success. This is an American remake of a British (or more broadly a 'European') film from many many years ago. The film in question brought up many issues to do with religion and had many things to say politically about an ever changing world and society. The film raised issues to do with what's right; who's right and tried to make a statement on the balance between new beliefs in then 1970s Britain and older much older religious beliefs to do with the ancient world � namely sacrifices and the dismissal of science and the attention to nature and mother Earth being the sole thing to take care of in life. But this edition of The Wicker Man updates timeframe and setting into early 21st Century America falling pretty darned flat in the process whilst delivering a filmic experience that is unintentionally funny at best.So what's the film actually about? Policeman Edward Malus (Cage) travels to an isolated island on which a ritualistic community get by in the modern-age without phone signals or electricity. It seems the daughter of Malus' ex-partner has gone missing and Malus is the man to find her after he received a letter explaining the situation. After an opening involving a traffic accident we get rather a quick title card flash up complete with bizarre sinister music: 'The Wicker Man' it says and the odd sensation of 'was that supposed to perhaps be scary?' lands itself for the first time. It is a feeling that does not lift. The film is a series of pratfalls and unintentional scenes that play out in bizarre and comical fashion. Along the way Malus will beg his way onto a flight to the island when informing the pilot he was a policeman would have been enough; he will swim down darkened underwater tunnels seemingly without reason and he will be chased through woods while dressed in a bear suit.In fact the film is so far detached from not only the original but most films in general that basic logic at times will be ignored. In the original every scene after arriving at the island which doubled up as the pre-film credit sequence was an eerie and foreboding clue as to the fact she may exist and everyone's in on something. Here the protagonist is needlessly given a prior tragedy which acts as a mere reason for him to have 'scary' flashbacks and other such hallucinations involving the young girl he could not save from a car crash � notice the obvious parallel here: hero has chance to redeem oneself after prior tragic event by finding a girl on an island dystopia. But the film for the best part is a series of illogical scenes rather than strange establishments of bizarre townsfolk.Here we get Malus messing about in a farmyard barn climbing the beams and then falling off them; we get an accidentally hilarious exchange between two people during a wood-chopping scene: the girl wood chopping wants to leave the island and sees Malus as her ticket out but it's against the rules to leave; and yet the inhabitants can come and go as they please anyway. There is a scene in a classroom in which a chicken flies out of a desk: what's it doing in there? How long has it been in there? Did they put it in there for him to find? And if so how did they know Malus was coming and would stop at the school in the first place? Then there is the brief revelation when it appears Malus has previously had sex completely going against why the original's antagonists did what they did and the girl Malus is looking for is connected to him more so than he first thought. Also the way in which Willow (Beahan) maintains a 'deer in the headlights' expression throughout and constantly gets-half-way-through-a-sentence...........but then stops and allows Cage to finish it for her. That grated on me very quickly. There is also the rare instance in the film of a 'dream within a dream' sequence. I haven't seen one of them in a while. The scene in which Cage swims down into a watery abyss for absolutely no reason other than he has a 'hunch' the girl might be down there and then gets locked in overnight has to evoke laughs of some sort.Then there is the climax which is ruined in the first place by way of having seen the original. Rather than sacrifice someone INTO the ground so that the crops may grow back OUT of it the theory on this American Summersisle is that you sacrifice someone into the ground so that BEES which are of a third party nature will begin to re-produce honey like they used to. Where's the logic of killing someone so that something completely unconnected with what you're doing MIGHT begin to do what they're supposed to do once again? I don't know maybe using the word 'logic' is a bad move here but for sure the epilogue at the very end proves that the cycle of sacrifices (and idiocy) will not stop any time soon in this crazy (or downright stupid) little community.

column4: Where was I when the world did a 180 on art?
column5: OK NOW I'm really confused You people can watch the new version of 'The Hills Have Eyes' and give that piece of cinematographic excrement 7 out of 10 points and now there are 3000+ people on IMDb saying in one voice that the new version of 'The Wicker Man' is a bad movie beyond any reason.What have I missed? Where was I when the world descended back to the dark ages?!? It seems that as soon as the plot of a movie goes beyond 'random people getting killed by evil monsters for 90 minutes but in the end a man with latex tights calling himself Superman will save the day'  people will get bored as in the movie has no potential because YOU ACTUALLY HAVE TO FOLLOW A STORYLINE IN ORDER TO ENJOY IT! It seems that the only thing that the masses will get off on is complete and utter PORNOGRAPHY because it's the easiest and least resource-demanding product of entertainment. I ask you what happened??? It has been going on for quite some time now. You can see it in all the new comedies horror-movies and even action thriller and (i'm crying when i say this) Drama for gods sake. Wherever you turn it's over-exaggeration of idiotic moments.I could have accepted a shining 5/10 score on a movie like 'The Hills Have Eyes' which carries absolutely nothing more than OLD NEWS but for crying out loud when people start badmouthing movies that are actually not bad at all - ....... I'm at a loss for words! Compared to the utter s*** that's been poring out of the US movie-scene recently this move should win an Oscar.I was going to give this movie 6/10 points after I had seen it but after I had seen 'The Wicker Man's' score here on IMDb I decided to give it 7/10. One extra for proving a point. Dear god people... read a book!PS- I'm confident most of you idiots don't even understand what I'm talking about because you're too busy eating Hamburgers..PPS- I appologise to every single person who shares my beliefs. This text is not directed at any persons rather is commentating the outrageous and indescribable idiocy that the media is sending out and that the masses seem to be OK with.

column4: Watch the original 1973 version with Edward Woodwood - Much Better this remake is rubbish
column5: OK I'll try not to write a spoiler here but why did they remake this movie? It's like Nicholas Cage thought�'Wow that a good twist' after he watched the original then decide to produce a US version that rips any meaningful parts of the original out adds a few pointless ones and then tries to have the same ironic and dramatic effects at the end�please it didn't work Nick!What they have done to this script is Americanise it yeah nowadays the 73 version may seem dated but the story and concepts behind the twist are far superiorWatch both and make a judgement for yourself� you have the 73 version that has Woodwood's character the fool at the end - perfectly done! Or the 06 version which has Cage the fool period both as lead actor producer and dunce who thought this film needed to be remade not his best work by a long shot

I never expected everyone else to tear into this movie the way they have.Is it a masterpiece or even particularly admirable? No but I have seen tons of horror/thrillers that are about the same quality. Cheesy heavy handed stories without much substance or atmosphere but at least this movie throws itself into itself and seems determined to not leave you bored.Someone once asked me if I liked Nicholas Cage. It apparently resonated with the group when I said "I like HIM a lot more than I like his movies". Cage is good in this. When I say "good" I mean just forget he is supposed to be some big manly copper trying to save the innocent from evil and just treat him like the clown he is in this movie.If there's something to like in this movie it is just how it backed itself. It really went for it and even if it crashed and burned (or even because of that) at the very least was a lively experience even if it dragged in many parts.It's a movie brave enough to have little girls talking about phallic symbols and has Nick punching a woman. I know that sounds misogynistic but he would do the same to a man in the same context. In the fight against heteropatriarchy we need to learn to maybe love them less respect them more.A penpal I had (wow I miss her...) told me she loved "Not the bees!". And I agree it's one of those things you just gotta see at some point. Like the moon landing.So in summary there are technically better movies but I want to wave the flag of this movie that didn't succumb to the pressure of subtlety.

column4: not the worst film or remake ever done
column5: I'd like to say firstly I haven't seen the original so cant judge or compare this film to the the 1973 version. Nevertheless I'm amazed at the vitriol and angry comments heaped on this movie. It was a watchable film and kept me guessing as to what would happen to cage and his "daughter" it was actually good to see it didn't succumb to the typical Hollywood ending of everyone being "rescued" and Cage not suffering the fate he did. I take what I saw in front of me and not the fact that it was a remake of something done 35 years ago. The flick wont win any awards but it didn't send me to sleep or have me throwing things at the screen some people here should take a reality check!

column4: A good friend who was beaten and molested as a child said this film was the worst experience of his life.
column5: I wish I was joking. I had a bad movie marathon one night and showed this gem to a very close friend. For a bit of context my friend had what you would describe as a horrendous abusive childhood. As the credits rolled he told me that Nicholas Cage had helped create the two worst hours of his entire life and he would rather re-experience any trauma from his past than watch this film again.It is seriously that bad. Not Manos the Hands of Fate/Plan 9 from Outer Space so bad that it is a cult classic. It is just bad. A couple of the scenes are unintentionally comical but they do not make up for the horrendous writing and acting that plague the rest of this film. I've never seen a video inspire an expression of such anguish. I... can't write about this anymore.

Seriously? That was the movie? Oh my god in heaven i have never been so p*ssed off or angry about seeing a movie before it was just horrible Mr. Cage For shame man seriously your acting was so f*cking bad that Cory Feldman shakes his head in disgust. thats right i brought in the Feldman. and what was with the prominent (in my opinion) actors in sh*t and i mean sh*t roles....come on Aaron Eckhart as trucker #1! Trucker #1 and Joe blow plays Cage's friend that sh*t is disrespectful then James Franco and Jason Ritter playing respectively Guy in the bar #1 and #2 !angry! then the ending i am sorry nick cage looked to weigh maybe at most 150 that f*cking behemoth of a woman was at least 265 easily there is no way he really thought that one punch was gonna knock her large a** down and keep her down. and then the Bum Bum Bum twist ending.....how in the h*ll does someone not see a 4 story high man made of sticks?!?!?!?!?!?! oh and then the whole scene gets dark and you hear them hitting Nicolas cage okay then you hear that crunch and he yells "MY LEGS!!!!" but doesn't even a moan when they string him up by said legs to get him into the wicker man BTW it made of sticks um.....break them and get out sh*t how dumb was this character that the audience yells at the screen and no one cares

THIS IS THE WORST MOVIE I HAVE EVER SEEN. I have only said this about one other movie in my entire life but it has been bumped down and this has become the new low. Honsetly I am a pretty big Nicholas Cage fan; he has done some great work in the past. However I am honestly in shock of how poorly this movie was made. When I left the theater I turned to my friend and said "It was almost like they wanted to make it a bad movie to hopefully make it a cult film but then decided to keep it the same way and go in a serious direction." I don't claim to be the definitive brain on movies but I know an awful movie when I see one and this one takes the cake. Poor storyline poor acting poor directing poor scenery poor everything.There are exactly three things that were relatively worth watching but they couldn't even dream of bringing this film out of the dirt.I am sure that the book was actually pretty entertaining and that the story was as bad as it was portrayed in the movie. However they should have left the book a book and left that at that. No Movie was a bigger waste of $6 than this one.

column4: By far one of the worst films to date.
column5: I work at a movie theater so I nearly never pay for admission when viewing a film. I take advantage of this and see every film that comes in.
