This summer we've seen our share of bad movies: Crossover; You Me and Dupree; etc.So hoping that a movie with Nicholas Cage's name attached to it would be half tolerable I sat down in the front row of Wicker Man with a bag of popcorn and a 54oz coke. I couldn't have been more shocked and appalled at the crap I was seeing on the screen: terrible acting terrible directing and more importantly a terrible story.I was so offended nay insulted that Nicholas Cage was partaking in this travesty of a film! His acting was reminiscent of a high school play and I couldn't help but laugh at every line he delivered.When was it last when good directing acting and story was combined into one film in Hollywood? I mean we've resorted to remake after remake after remake. It is a TRAVESTY. Thank God for films like Lady In The Water where the film as a whole is like an experience and not a trip to the dentist.Pleae do not waste your time with this film.

I love Neil LaBute and I love the 70s Wicker Man but it was with mounting dread that I approached this film and I was not disappointed. Actually having said I love the 70s version I initially didn't see why everyone was so outraged at the very thought of remaking it. In fact it's quite a sensible candidate for a re-imagining (as they're now so hideously called) and the story lends itself quite well to being recast amongst American cultism. Really what everyone remembers about the 70s Wicker Man is the amazing ending and Edward Woodwards fascinating performance handily forgetting Britt Eckland's weird porno folk music video and the tendency for any actor cast as an islander to mercilessly chomp down on some scenery. So good choice Mr LaBute let's see what you make of this I innocently thought.Good Lord this movie is bad. It lacks any atmosphere whatsoever and surely it can't be that hard to build suspense in a film set almost entirely on a freakish pagan island where the matriarchal rule is so extreme that men are little more than slaves and not allowed to talk. And then all of a sudden what should be a tract on the extremes of belief and religious fundamentalism turned into a misogynistic diatribe. "Women are evil!" is what The Wicker Man screams. Ellen Burstyn wants to kill boy babies and finish off Nicolas Cage for good measure! There's a feminist conspiracy to kill Nic Cage! And just when it couldn't look any blacker for Mr Cage he starts punching women left right and centre. Poor little Leelee Sobieski gets flying kicked in the stomach and left for dead. And you want to cheer! Just like when Heath and Jake get it on in Brokeback Mountain was somehow breaking a Hollywood Taboo violence against women becomes Blockbuster eyecandy (not that homosexuality is directly comparable with hitting a woman!). "You Bitches! You Bitches!" screams Nicolas Cage at Ellen Burstyn and the mum off Six Feet Under. Serves him bloody right.And then just when you thought it was safe to leave the multiplex comes the most ridiculous wink-to-camera shock ending ever. But I don't want to spoil the end for you. Neil LaBute's done a good enough job of that already.

column4: For someone who had not seen the original it was good
column5: And having Nicholas Cage die while at the same time feeling sorry for him is a rare combination that only this movie could achieve. Almost sheer brilliance. This has not been done since City of Angels.I will have to see the original though as I'm sure it's probably better. Since Hollywood can't produce anything original anymore they have to do offer updated versions. This may or may not be bad or good I don't know. I read someone elses review who was extremely critical of the way the producer took this movie adding his twist to it and saying it was not worthy. I obviously can't say until I've seen the original but I think updates of well written movies should be updated to match today's environment so they are more believable.Another thing the movie had Nicholas Cage in it so you KNOW it was going to be semi-cheesy. I usually can't stand Cage but he played his part VERY WELL in this movie. Kudos for his performance.

I watched the original one and this back to back and this is clearly a parody I think that's really the reason why this one is rated so low - the people who haven't seen the original won't understand why the things are said and done as they are - it's all supposed to be hilarious! Every scene and dialog is over-the-top to the extreme and Nicolas Cage is clearly the perfect cast big key chunks of the original story are missing and it comes as poorly stitched together reenactment with very low production value but then again - if you'll view it as a parody everything suddenly begins to make sense. It's epidemy of "it's so bad it's good" and if you're Nicolas Cage fan and you have seen the original Wicker Man first I think you'll really find some fun with this flick.

column4: crap on a reel *somewhat spoiler alert*
column5: This is absolutely the worst Nick Cage Movie I have ever seen even though without him this movie would be ten times worse than it already is. I haven't seen the original and now definitely will not. Give me Face Off or Con Air or hell give me the Weather Man anything but this! This movie would have been much better with a rescue at the end! Not that repeat with that poor cadet at the end what the hell! Arnt Pagans or what not generally nice and easy to get along with? At least in my experiences they have never tied me to a pole like Joan of Arc! This movie even gives honey a bad rap? Hmmmm before I buy this honey honey do you think some psycho witch cult cultivated it? Is this police officer friendly honey? Free of body parts and magic spells? screw this Im going to buy it from the Amish!!! *end of Rant* watch movie at your own peril!

If you'd hold a survey among TRUE horror fanatics exclusively and request them to put together their top ten of all times the original 1973 version of Anthony Shaffer's "The Wicker Man" would be one title that returns at the tops constantly. It also happens to be one of the only films that the genre fans consider to be sacred and "untouchable" ...and I'm one of them. Whatever demon possessed the mind of Neil LaBute when he thought he could improve this genuine horror masterpiece is anyone's guess but he did it anyway. And we could all hate him for it or we might take a moment to sit down and actually watch it with an open mind. Okay it's still bad and redundant...but at least it's not entirely hopeless. I don't care what anyone says a film that stars Nicolas Cage Ellen Burstyn and Leelee Sobieski is always worth a look. And believe it or not but some of the minor script modifications LaBute introduced are actually making sense and even add logic to the original concept. I suppose everyone already knows that "The Wicker Man" revolves on a lonely police sergeant traveling to the remote island community of Summersisle to investigate the disappearance of a young girl. Naturally in this remake it's an American community instead of a British one and LaBute also added an actual connection between sergeant Edward Malus and one of the island's female inhabitants. He was formerly engaged to 'sister' Willow but she mysteriously vanished until now she's asking him for help finding her daughter Rowan. A minor flaw in the 1973 original was how they never really explained why sergeant Howie (Edward Woodward) was the chosen one for the island's rites of sacrifice. Another bizarre difference between this remake and the original version is the extreme emphasis on feminism! 'Lord' Summersisle (one of the most memorable roles of horror-deity Christopher Lee) is replaced by Sister Summerisle (Ellen Burstyn) and the entire island is reigned by women. The men on Summersisle are barely able to speak only girls enjoy the right to education (where they learn how men are merely just walking phallus symbols...) and none of the men are present during the essential harvest celebrations. The rest of the film is pretty much identical to the original. Edward Malus encounters strangely behaving & truly unhelpful people in his search for little Rowan only in this version the island and its curious inhabitants are a lot less menacing and their fertility rituals are a whole lot less imaginative. Unquestionably the biggest omission in this remake is the original's fascinating music! Apart from a compelling mystery-thriller and a unique folklore horror-tale Anthony Shaffer's "The Wicker Man" also is a brilliant musical! Moments like the Maypole-dance and especially Britt Ekland's siren song contributed in making it an extraordinary experience but Neil LaBute deliberately ignored all the musical greatness of the original and replaced it with dull sub plots like for example Nicolas Cage suffering from reoccurring nightmares about the victims of a car crash he couldn't save. The climax sequence � which shouldn't be a secret to anyone anymore � is competently elaborated and the epilogue is quite entertaining too. Like the case with "The Texas Chainsaw Massacre" "The Wicker Man" surely didn't require a nowadays hi-tech remake but still the result could have been worse. Younger audiences who never heard of the story and refuse to watch movie made prior to 1990 will think it's a brilliant film.

I have gained a lot of respect for Nicolas Cage based on his previous films but this remake just made me ask myself 'why did he bother?' If you are going to remake a film then I'd assume that you thought there was something you could add to the original or twist it in a way that would give fans of the first a reason to like the remake. As far as I can tell the only notable changes are a shift to an obviously matriarchal society for which the symbolism of a society of bees is evident; honey harvests and the destruction of the drone to indicate fertility. The lost girl becomes the daughter to the protagonist thus giving him reason to find her (like doing the right thing is not enough) and the conviction that the protagonist had any strong belief system to revival the strong Christian faith the Edward Woodward character had in the original. In addition to this the feeling of an ancient Celtic ritualistic society just doesn't come across in the film it feels more like a twisted 'hippy' commune run by an extreme feminist. Other than these differences the plot is exactly the same so I ask again 'why did they bother?'

By sad I mean sad in the original meaning of the word. The original Wicker Man was a work of art ranking alongside Walkabout ParisTexas and The man Who Fell to Earth (inter Alia). I personally know one of the musicians who contributed (and can be seen in the film) to the original. This is not the worst film ever - that would be an accolade. This is just pointless.The original Summerisle was an island of men and women who worked together and loved together and that was essential to the plot because they were pagans NOT feminists. I realise that a scene of men and women copulating freely in the open air would probably offend the prudish WASP community and ultimately affect the certificate of rating. But the way society was working on this new Summersisle was more like Planet of the Apes. It isn't even as if the original had special effects that could be improved upon. Why bother?

What a damn shame! I don't know who Cage was trying to play  it had nothing to do with the character in this movie . I can understand why he took on this script some interesting concepts. I can't understand why he did such a bad job acting. Totally detached. Awful  lame  and a needlessly brutal ending. Really; don't bother with this film. I can't even imagine which demographic it would appeal too? Even a hard core Cage fan couldn't enjoy this. I only finished watching it out of curiosity. If you've seen some other roles Cage has played  you will definitely doubt if you really thought he was such a good actor. Once again ; What a damn shame! Then again  you know what they say "you're only as good as your last performance"�better things to come lets hope so.

column4: Awful attempt at a cult classic
column5: Alright this movie made pagans look like Hollywood satanists and I find this to be one of the biggest problems of the story. Sure its nail biting for a few scenes when random occurrences keep happening like lots of twins spooky bees old creepy ladies with football face paint among other things like old men half naked with missing eyes. Not to mention the fact that for some odd reason most of the conversations going on in the film is only understandable after a few pints of beer.So many questions start to be asked as to why do all the men not talk? Sure I understand its a matriarchal culture but thats no reason for men to act like drugged mules half the time. Cage basically tries to be the good guy and atone for his inability to save a little girl however all the sorry and pity felt for the poor character is "really helped by the ending." *sarcasm*The basic moral of the story without giving away many spoilers is as follows. You livesomething bad happens crazy things keep happening you become even sadder then when you finally feel like the world around you can be changed you realize feeling sorry for yourself is useless since you have your destiny in your hands...you die a horrible death involving bees and the evil women from Hollywood satanism do a little happy dance around your corpse.

I don't understand why everybody is putting this movie down. Well the original is a cult classic right? Well this one is certainly better then the original. That's something that's very rare. (another example is "the hills have eyes).The directing is proper nothing exceptional so is the acting (Cage you love him or you hate him). But what really hit me was the scenery and some sort of fairytale atmosphere that was created and where the community lived in.It was so beautiful and that's why the climax of the movie is so shocking.This movie kept me thinking about the good old point and click adventures of computer games. The ones like broken sword and king's quest etc.It a movie with a magic atmosphere.OK it's no masterpiece but I can recommend it to anybodyCheers

KILLING ME WON'T BRING BACK YOUR GOD DAMN HONEY!The original film was a masterpiece and one of my favorite films. I can't believe that they just desecrated the memory of a great film with an utter balderdash like this.I love Nicolas Cage as much as everyone else but this ain't it chief. Even Cage himself acknowledged that the film was "absurd".I saw the theatrical version that doesn't have the alternate ending where Cage gets tortured by bees. After finished this I went to YouTube and absorbed the memefying scenes with its full glory.

column4: So awful I should have asked for my $10 back
column5: Admittedly I never saw the original nor did I read the short story. So I walked into the theatre having zero idea of the plot.So the story line in hindsight had possibilities for sure. But the acting consisted of 90 minutes or so of overacting. N. Cage must have been bribed into playing the part and his overacting was his way of getting back at the producer. Not one actor did a credible job.Was this a horror story? I wasn't shocked even once nor did I gasp at all (except at the bad acting).There were scenes put in for shock value that bombed. One particular scene was not necessary to the story was never explained and was not even scary. They must have needed an extra 45 seconds to fill.I say save your money and - if you MUST - rent the DVD which should be out in a matter of weeks.

I'm writing this review in the hope that I might save someone else from seeing this movie.I love suspense and I love Nic Cage. I also like schlok and cheese. The Wicker Man missed on every count.It's not bad it's horrible. It's not interesting but rather tedious boring and insufferable. It's not so-bad-it's-good it's just so-so-so bad. Oh and it's long. At least 40 minutes could be excised and the "plot" would not suffer because there is no plot.Really. It's not frightening it's not suspenseful it's stupid.And the script is woeful.Leaving the theatre last night I stopped in the lobby and yelled for people not to see it. My date was mortified but I feel a sense of duty to warn folks away from this movie.

I'm sorry to sound so biased but it's been a long time since a movie made me this angry. I felt entirely cheated out of my $10 and couldn't help but furiously mutter "That was bulls--t" to my friend the moment the credits rolled. This movie has all the depth and plot intricacies of baked ham and one can basically predict every second of this awful film especially if they've seen the preview. The only part I didn't see coming a mile away was the ending twist which the film creators made somewhat surprising by having it really not make any sense at all. Perhaps most infuriating of all were the glaring cinematic moments thrown in utterly shamelessly with no point whatsoever but to try to make the audience jump--such as Cage's totally irrelevant medication problem that serves just to allow him frightening hallucinations. I am so mad at this film all I can say is trust my and the overall rating of it on this site and don't give the greedy creators the opportunity to take your money.

column4: The greatest movie ever made!!!!! Brilliant
column5: Now that I got your attention... This is the #%$#%#%! movie of all time... THE WEAKER MAN! I feel bad for NicolAss Cage. I've been visiting IMDb for a good 6 years now and I registered only today just to bash this movie. That's how bad it is. When me and my significant other went out of the movie house I felt bad the wicker man got burned.. I wanted to burn the whole movie house as well. If you're thinking of watching this movie think again your money would be more worth it if you place it on red at the roulette table. The only good about this movie is the trailer and the movie posters (which were misleading). I did not see NicolAsses daughter's eye turned white.

Ellen Burstyn and Nicolas Cage must have really needed a payday. This is by far one of the worst movies I've seen in a very long time. Cage came closest to "acting" despite being given nothing to work with but he looked like he was begging for help through the whole thing wanting someone anyone to please start acting along with him. Burstyn should just be embarrassed.There are no redeeming qualities to this movie - none. The story is hokey at best. The acting is pathetic. This doesn't even look like a decent independent movie. The music score was horrible and didn't come close to fitting the movie ever.Ugh - shame on you Nicolas Cage. I usually like your work but this was garbage.

column4: The Wicker Man a Hollow Experience
column5: In The Wicker Man Edward Malus (Nicolas Cage) is a cop. During the course of a routine traffic stop there's a terrible accident that injures him and leaves him helpless to rescue a mother and her daughter from a fiery death. Far worse than his physical injuries are the nightmares � occurring both when he's asleep and awake � involving the people he couldn't save. So when a letter arrives from a woman he loved years ago he's all but helpless to refuse her plea for assistance in finding her missing daughter.So Malus travels to Summersisle where Willow (Kate Beahn) now lives. He has a difficult time getting to the secluded island and once there is viewed with a good deal of suspicion by the island's mostly female inhabitants. Willow who is called Sister Willow by the other women takes him aside and warns him that the others will lie to him. But she also emphasizes what she believes to be looming danger to her missing daughter Rowan (Erika-Shaye Gair).Malus fuels his search for Rowan not only with his memories of his old relationship with Willow but with his anguish over his inability to save another little girl from her fate. He needs that commitment since he finds his efforts thwarted at virtually every turn by women who are hostile at best and who look him in the eye and lie as a matter of course.Sister Beech (Diane Delano reluctantly offers him a place to stay but remains leery of the California cop. Sister Rose (Molly Parker) is a teacher who expends most of her energies teaching her charges lessons with which Malus thoroughly disagrees. Dr. Moss (Frances Conroy) seems willing to care for everyone � even Malus � but she also comes across as evasive which causes Malus to become more determined than ever to get to the bottom of the mystery.Malus finally has the opportunity to meet the woman in charge of the isolated community. In a conversation with Sister Summersisle (Ellen Burstyn) Malus' internal alarm bells are ringing louder than ever. But he ignores his intuition in the hopes of saving Willow's daughter and thus redeeming himself. What Malus doesn't realize of course is that the dangers on Summersisle extend far beyond the life of one missing little girl...Nicolas Cage is typically a capable actor even when he's saddled with a less than optimal script. In the Case of The Wicker Man background information has it that Cage was so affected when he viewed the original that he promoted the remake. Perhaps he thought better of it as filming commenced though because his performance here is all but phoned in. Every emotion is heightened to the point of melodrama in an episode of "bad acting theatre;" every facial expression is both stereotypical and exaggerated.Frances Conroy is fine and Molly Parker is just terrific. Supporting cast members Leelee Sobieski and Diane Delano are also all right (though Sobieski is miscast in a role that requires a far more delicately pretty woman than she is). Ellen Burstyn is thoroughly wasted in a part that sees her spew some of the most godawful lines ever penned in a movie with a budget while Kate Beahn is just plain godawful (if there's somebody else out there who can speak more woodenly or convey less emotion despite huge doe-like eyes I don't know who she might be).The greatest insult to audiences (not to mention fans of the original movie) though is a really bad screenplay. Director Neil LaBute penned the script which is based on the original by the late Anthony Shaffer. While his direction is largely okay and the cinematography spectacular the script is rarely less than implausible and it often crosses the line into the just plain ridiculous. Though the movie begins with some promise with the grave psychological impact of the accident the lead character witnesses it quickly devolves into a series of utterly predictable and entirely unbelievable events.The bottom line: Think about renting the original (again I can't recommend it not having seen it but a lot of people who have seen it do) and don't even think for a moment about seeing the 2006 remake. It's not worth even the price of a ticket let alone the time you'll never get back.POLITICAL NOTES: One of the most ham-handed plot devices in The Wicker Man involves what is apparently an isolated community of witches (though the words "pagan" or "Wiccan" are never mentioned there is a reference to Salem as well as to various medieval pagan ceremonies and celebrations that imply strongly that that's what they are). Every witch that I know � and I do know a few � would be appalled by vast majority of the actions depicted in The Wicker Man. Unfortunately there are those devout fundamentalist Christians who would take every opportunity to condemn pagans as minions of Satan. Though they're wrong films like The Wicker Man will give them the unneeded opportunity to gloat "I told you so!"FAMILY SUITABILITY: The Wicker Man is rated PG-13 for "disturbing images and violence language and thematic issues." In the case of portions of the story line PG-13 may actually be a little weak though none of those thematic issues are visually depicted in an R-rated manner. If you've got kids who insist on seeing The Wicker Man because it's being billed as a horror film (the most horrific thing about it is the movie itself rather than the plot per se) I'd deny unqualified permission to kids of 14 or so and younger. As for the rest well the good news is that you can always tell them that you told them so after they've been as duly disappointed as I was by this dud.
Neil LaBute is one of the worst directors of the whole history and this movie it's a clear example of what i mean.

column4: Worst then The Wicker man (1973) and that was an awful movie
column5: This is a remake to a terrible movie. It was even worst then the original. The fellow up to the The Wicker man (1973) The Wicker tree is a better movie and that was a an awful movie. This movie has an awful story line. It also has an awful ending. A cop goes to an Island to look for his wife and daughter. He find an evil cult that worship a sun god. Do not see this movie. It is an awful movie. Do not wast your time. Do not wast your money. For thirty three years The Wicker man (1973) was the worst horror movie ever. So they had to make something worst. Now this is probably the worst horror movie ever. I do not know why people like the original. But at lest they know this one sucks.

First of all to Murraydeschot of the Netherlands - the island was off of the coast of Washington State which is also consistent with the cult's trek to the west! Try not to compare remakes with the original as they are inevitably panned as they are not exactly the same!Overall I found the film OK. I haven't seen the original British version so I can't compare them. The plan (or plot) as it was stated required quite a few coincidental events. If Edward had reacted differently things wouldn't have worked out....He never left a message with anyone about where he was going. - He could have rented a boat to get to the island. - When he went to rescue (or so he thought) Rowan he never checked his weapon and was surprised when it didn't fire! - There was fishing gear -- including lobster traps -- on the dock. There was probably a boat around somewhere. Once he realised how weird everything was he should have looked for a boat to get off the island and find help.It would have been interesting if they had explored the cult a bit more and it's connection to Salem to flesh out the story. The self-proclaimed pagans who commented on this film shouldn't fear as I do not believe anyone would seriously believe they are burning people in giant wicker structures.I preferred the alternate ending where you get to see his legs broken. The way the mallet crunched those femurs was cringe worthy. Although I'm pretty sure he would have lost consciousness from bleeding out in his thighs from the fractures!

Completely unexpecting and terrifying The Wickerman is a must see. I saw this movie last weekend and found the movie a lot better than expected. Nicholas Cage performed magnificently to pull off the sick twist to the story.Unlike the original movie that took place on a remote mysterious Scottish island this movie brought to life a sheltered community in the Puget Sound off the Washington coast.Based on old 70's flick a story written by Anthony Shaffer Neil LaBute (producer) brought back this horror to big screen with a thrilling 21st century roller-coaster bang.Here's a quick synopsis: The main character goes on a journey to investigate the disappearance of a young girl. He discovers that the locals are weird and unhelpful and becomes determined to get to the bottom of the disappearance.Loved it.

I marked this movie 8 out of 10 judging on this movie onlyI haven't seen the 1973 versioncause dear reviewers when u criticize a movie don't compare it to any other versions please. as a horror not much of horrorlots of funny situations and moments not used for cage.the story itself is not bad at all and please Good people it's not always that the hero conquers so that the movie would be nice. Whatever the reason Malus bumbles around the island growing increasingly more and more horrified by the events transpiring around him. A feminist bitch teaching an English class about the atrocities of men? Clearly this island is the bastion of Satan himself. Ah but we find a clue here. Despite the fact that all of the residents of the island insist that there is no girl there is a single unoccupied desk in the middle of class. Cage then opens the desk only to be startled by a crow and screams "What?!" At that point we are thinking along the same lines.

column4: How'd it get burned? How'd it get burned?! How'd it get burned?! How'd it get burned?!
column5: What an odd and puzzling film. I genuinely think I've sacrificed some of my brain cells by choosing to watch this but in a weirdly good way. I'm not sure whether Nicolas Cage's involvement in a film has the writer(s) change it accordingly to fit him or if his choice of movies is always ones that seem so original.Still it's impressive how both films of his I've seen so far Vampire's Kiss and this one have such a peculiar identity and feel to them that you're not going to get elsewhere not even films you've never heard of with barely a budget. Yet at the same time it's hard to tell whether that's because of his involvement (subtly as he's not the director or writer) or if his film choices are genius. And that's so fascinating.Thank God for Nicolas Cage for caring about acting instead of caring (more) about his image/reputation like mostly every other actor especially those highly regarded. Thanks to that he's pumping out all kinds of roles in all types of films while other actors micromanage their acting careers and the roles/films they choose. So what if most of his movies don't have super high budgets with highly regarded directors and writers? He's keeping cinema alive regardless of how you feel about most of his films and everyone is oblivious.Based on this film's consensus most people hated it thinking it was one of the worst films ever and I'm at a loss. I guess that it's mainly due to how it's a remake especially of a well-received film. That has to be at least 90% of it as aspects of the film were good.For example the budget wasn't that low so the overall production value was solid. Quite solid even: the island locations looked great. As an extension of that the cinematography by Paul Sarossy was good. The score by Angelo Badalamenti was even better; by far one of the best aspects of the film and reminiscent of Brian Tyler's score for Law Abiding Citizen with an eldritch-esque twist. The themes of isolation and indoctrination as well as the general eerie and sinister tone were quite effective. And of course Nicolas Cage's performance was good: there were also a few signature moments of Nicolas Cage-esque outbursts that he does so well which is probably intentionally included in his films now akin to Tom Cruise and his efficiency at running; the other acting performances particularly by Molly Parker and Kate Beahan as well as Ellen Burstyn were good as well.When it comes down to this film and Vampire's Kiss the only Nicolas Cage films I've seen both are pretty much the same more or less regarding objectivity. Based on audience reception they're not even comparable. Most people detest this film while the reception toward Vampire's Kiss was more evened out or mostly enjoyed to an extent. My outlook is that I found the latter significantly more enjoyable. However I also found this film enjoyable. I think its hate is excessive. I don't think this was a bad film.

column4: Superfluous remake but not that bad.
column5: I have watched the original a few times and think although it is good it is an overrated film. Although I was aware this remake had been slated (par for the course for any remake) I watched it with an open mind.Although it has a good cast I felt the performance of Cage was a little muted and not on a par with Edward Woodward's. Although the setting is different the plot is very similar. The air of menace so prevalent in the original is mainly lacking here though this could be in part because I knew what was coming. The ending is left the same but it really is not as affecting second time round.As it is although it is nowhere near as bad as the rating suggests this is no more than an average remake. It may be worth watching if your not familiar with the first one but if you are it's unlikely you'll find much to satisfy you.

column4: The Question I Ask the Movie Gods: Why T'Was This Movie Made?
column5: I went to see this movie at an early screening with some of my fellow co-workers at our movie theatre. I think the majority of us including myself thought that this was a horror/suspense/thriller. I have not had the chance to catch the original yet so I was still kind of foggy on the plot of the movie but luckily for me the movie didn't have a plot.I guess the plot summary for the movie would be that after a traumatic event Nicolas Cage goes on a personal hunt to find the kidnapper and the little girl the girl supposedly taken that is the daughter of a former girlfriend of Cage's. So basically he goes to this Amish-like village to find this little girl who everybody except the mother denies existence. But then later...they know who she is. This goes back and forth all the time I think mainly because they couldn't make up their minds. Cage wanders through the village questioning people and whipping out his badge. He screams "I'm a cop!!!" five thousand times but nobody really believes him. Cage doesn't even believe he's a cop.The music in this film is horrible and doesn't add anything to it. The direction is weak and standard but at least there wasn't any shaky-cam.I would suggest not seeing this film because well it sucks.

A dreadful disappointment for a number of reasons: uneven pacing a miscast lead the lack of subtlety loss of (religious) context and beautiful soundtrack from the original as well as elements of misogyny: the audience I saw the film with laughed when Malus (Cage) punches women towards the film's denouement. And here lies one of the film's greatest flaw. In the original you suspended your disbelief as Lord Summerisle an Aleister Crowley type figure dominates proceedings. Anyone with a knowledge of pagan religions would realise that women are creative nurturing forces in nature.The film fails on so many levels. I went in with an open mind hoping it would be better than I anticipated but I realise why so little publicity was released beforehand. Because it is a huge leaden disappointment.There are some interesting scenes: the old women who greet Malus like the witches from Macbeth the blind sisters. The film does possess some frightening moments (the barn & the cellar in the darkness) but it is reminiscent of a Stephen King film a trip on a fright ride and detracts from the genuine foreboding and creepiness of the original.The bee motif is interesting up to a point but overplayed though it was a clever idea to have Malus lured to the island as part of some deliberate plan to secure a male sacrifice. But the original made more sense. Why is it so hard for an audience to imagine the policeman as a virgin? In fact a possible reworking by Robin Hardy of the original set in contemporary Scotland has two members of the Silver Ring Thing become involved with a pagan community.However the few pluses barely make up for a poor script/reworking and it is damning that many of the best scenes are those based on the original. There are also so many plot holes. Why murder the pilot of the flying boat? Why not simply render the character as a woman who is party to the plot? In fact I laughed when Malus is finally confronted with his fate. LaBute even contrives to reduce what should be a horrific moment with a trace of farce as Cage whines 'If you think this is going to save your god-damned honey'. The ending in the original is so powerful precisely because of Howie's faith and his genuine terror. Cage like me seems to welcome his fate because it puts us out of our misery.A word of advice to anyone financing a remake by Neil Labute or anyone in Hollywood like the Ring franchise. Don't bother. And if Stateside audiences are too lazy to watch the originals either because they look dated or are in subtitles then they really do lack imagination.As someone British please try not to ruin more of our classic films. I shudder to think what a US studio would do to 'Black Narcissus'. Probably have Scarlett Johannsen as Sister Clodagh writhing on the ground in a passionate embrace with George Clooney as Mr Dean whilst mad Sister Ruth played by Jessica Alba flagellates herself naked.Be careful a UK studio like Ealing might remake 'Casablanca' starring Hugh Grant. You have been warned.

column4: Wow not my cup of tea
column5: This is quite clearly the stupidest movie I've seen to date. If you've seen The Village it was good compared to this one. I was wanting to go out and see a psychological thriller that would creep me out I absolutely love scary movies. This was not scary at all there are about 2 funny parts in it no scary stuff and the acting was actually terrible even though Nicolas Cage is an incredible actor he is not in this one it looked like he was trying to be a bad actor in this one. I guess I should have watched the old 1973 one I figured from the previews of this movie that it would be great and at least a little bit scary they certainly know how to advertise a bad movie. Well hopefully I am the only one that wasted my money on this one. Hopefully someone will make a great psychological thriller soon I need to see one after being so disappointed in this one.

This is a very poor remake made worse by the fact I'm a fan of the original 1971 Wicker Man. Even if you ignore the comparison to the original what we have here is bad wooden occasionally over the top acting you be forgiven it was a cheesy 70s porno but without the sex (which in a way is worse because you don't to enjoy watching while excusing the bad acting). In its defence there is some topics which this film has which I think they should have made it their own such as the matriarchal society and how men are muted at birth and deprived an education to prevented from becoming a threat to their feminist system. For me the film did reminds me of how society become when the #MeToo movement gone wrong.

This was by far the worst movie Nicholas Cage has ever starred in and has topped my list for being one of the worst movies I've ever seen. Although the trailer makes this movie look amazing and full of suspense and horror it unfortunately contains neither. The Wicker Man is based on no more than an idiot idea which contains the worst ending that you can possibly imagine. If I had known how bad this movie was before hand I definitely would not have wasted five dollars at the video store. This movie is absolute garbage and the only individuals who would find this interesting would be hardcore feminists and people with no taste in actual good movies. In conclusion this movie is absolutely terrible based solely on its moronic idea and it is definitely a waste of money. Hopefully this comment will save some of you the time and money that could have been saved by not watching this.

column4: The Best Comedy FIlm ever made
column5: Notice how I said comedy. If you look at this film as a horror movie you'll come to realize that it is quite possible the worst feces of film reel ever to disgrace the silver screen. However looking at it as a light hearted and somewhat cruel comedy when pertaining to beating up women who look like they couldn't quite get out of the quaker age it is a brilliant achievement in side-splitting and loss of oxygen because Cage never fails to disappoint as a comedic actor.Yet I still have to see leaving Las Vegas.It's honestly hit or miss with Cage. Ghost rider was a miss. This was fortunately both.

Nicolas Cage's worst performance to date....or should I say movie. I have no clue who wrote this script of little substance...but it sure took an hour and a half of my valuable time. He used to be on my "all his flicks are good" list. He's off now. I don't want to spoil it but it was spoiled when it was filmed. Nicolas owes the world at least an hour and a half of his time for that mistake of a film. My friends are still cursing me for lending them that movie. It's like finding out the local pastor did porn....a huge let down. Just the title should have tipped me off. I hate wicker furniture..and the wicker man isn't too far off the mark.

Before seeing this movie I didn't know anything about the original Wicker Man movie I even expected a whole different movie after what I had seen in the trailers shown in The Netherlands.After watching the movie at first I was a little disappointed..Cage isn't performing like he has shown before in other movies and from time to time that results in some strange moments. Now a day later all I can say is that the movie left an impression --> the ending kept me interested even so much that I started reading online about the original movie which I'll probably see as well. The sinister feeling at the end is priceless.I would definitely recommend this movie to anyone who hasn't ever seen the original movie out of 1973. And from those who have seen it: give it a try it's really not so bad as everyone makes it sound...

Wow I can not even some up how ridiculous this movie was. I mean it was absolutely brutal. I wasn't expecting a great movie but I was at least hoping for something decent with some scares... Well the poster for the movie was the scariest thing about it. I wont even right a summary because I am afraid to relive this terrible ordeal. My girlfriend and I actually found this movie funny more then anything else. The bad acting the horrible story that left me lost five minutes in. The people in the theatre were actually laughing hysterically at the fact that Nic Cage was kicking the crap out of a bunch of women. It was ridiculous. The best part of the movie was when the leader of the island had her face painted blue and white and some one in the next row shouted GO BRAVEHEART! Most of you wanting to see this movie will probably say "Well I'll watch it and find out for myself" I seriously would not wish this movie on my worst enemy. PLEASE I BEG YOU SAVE YOUR MONEY AND SEE SOMETHING ELSE. Ten minutes in I looked over and said to my girlfriend lets go see Step Up. Unfortunately we stuck it out for the whole god awful thing. I recommend staying as far form this movie as you can. Unless you want to see a comedy and no real ones are playing at your theatre. My summary horrible!

column4: Nicholas what were you and you're agent thinking....
column5: I don't think that I ever saw a movie like this. 99% of the time Cage looks like somebody picked out of the line in a supermarket asked to perform like a confused dope addict in a movie which the writer was writing along the way with the shooting already taking place. It seems with the script unfolding everyone on the set actors and crew alike was infected by the same virus Cage actually seemed to be carrying(he was not asked anymore to play the confused dope addict he gradually turned into one). So if there's one thing you can say about this one; Great method acting and if you really want to see the schoolbook example of "What were they thinking"? or "What were they on can I have it too"?this is a must-see!

I walked out of this movie. The opening sequence was promising. A sense of place is created with the help of some beautiful cinematography. The main character is intriguing and a shocking event up front of the titles leaves one with high expectations.Unfortunately it is all downhill from there up to the point I walked out and I can only presume it continued on that trajectory.It was filled with one cliché after another. Every scene gave me a sense of deja V. It had either been on one episode of the X-Files or another or one of those bad TV movies-of-the-week. Although one source was a little classier than TV: the director image-checked Nicolas Roeg's Don't Look Now with a ghostly figure fleeing across different levels leading to a scene with a menacing red-cloaked figure in a claustrophobic setting! As IF LaBute!! The pace was slow the acting was oddly bad and the whole thing struck me as preposterous and ridiculous! And it isn't one bit scary. Maybe the second half of the movie improved but I couldn't take that chance! I cut my losses and split.

column4: A clueless writer/director second-guesses a uniquely successful movie ...
column5: ... and makes a laughing stock out of an already over burdened actor who grows ever closer to being deemed overexposed. This wreck Ghostrider (which I did not care for because Johnny Blaze was nothing more than Nicholas Cage with jelly beans) and now Next opening soon. We shall see.Mr. Cage give your fans a rest! Take a vacation. Go shopping.Neil love. Consider making a public apology to the original and talented company who created one of the most provocative glances into just how screwed up ANY religion can make us.You have failed to create a coherent story. You have failed the source material and made asinine choices because . . .A. Dropping the entire pagan/Christian angle shouldn't have even been a slight possibility in your vision. That was the point of the original story. (If you didn't like that you should have wrote an original story yourself.)B. The offense of using the title The Wicker Man just so you could steal the last 20 minutes of the original is shocking. But it appears to me it was the only concept you seemed to understand from the original.Since . . .C. you refused to give an arc to Edward. That was the death Knell. He starts out a flake and remains one much to our disappointment.D. The sudden and odd change in tone prior to the last 20 minutes of the film. One minute we are a thriller (with little thrill)and the next we are a psychotic slapstick comedy featuring silly line readings a bear costume and your leading man trading sissy slaps with bees.TO that end -- A complete utter failure.Hear that laughter? That's not the audience -- that's the original production team laughing their butt's off at you you supercilious American. failed pseudo-film auteur.

column4: An hour and a half of my life that i can't get back. I feel violated.
column5: Well what can I say... This movie started off as pretty bad with the possibility of turning into a decent ending. That was pretty much the theme the whole way through. Any second now it might get OK. I'm here to tell you it never does.There is an opening scene with a mother and daughter blowing up in a car. Throughout the rest of the movie Nicolas cage keeps having flashbacks of that day but every time it is slightly different. Do not under any circumstances assume that this has any relevance to the main story. It really doesn't. It's like they made the movie but it was too short so some guy in the corner said "hey why don't we fill in time with completely random and 100% pointless flashbacks. That'll give us another 20mins".I will admit that this movie whilst trying to be very serious does have it's comedic moments. Watching Nicolas cage in a bear suit run up to a woman who asks him whats wrong only to punch her in the face and keep going is a crack up. Likewise any other time in the movie that he punches a woman. And there are a few. Now I'm not a fan of violence against women but in this case the moments are so random and the way they are portrayed it really is funny.This is by far one of the worst movies I have ever seen. I'm gonna go out on a limb and say that this movie was as bad as Battlefield Earth possibly worse. Nicolas Cage what were you thinking... If at any stage you might feel tempted to watch this movie please trust me on this one don't!

why suck all of an artists vision out of his work and sell it again? i paid 10 dollars to see what i thought would be an honest re-imagining of an excellent movie but the sucked all the soul and magic out of the original added some crappy Asian inspired "dream scares" and made the denizens of Summerisle look like a tribe of lesbian hippy bigots while if you watch the original you will come to like the people of summer-isle..Chris lee in drag was beautiful washed-up old actress in a dress? not beautiful not funny nothing..the original was so creepy this was just trash..my own intelligence is eluding me as the sheer stupidity of this film washes through my memory so i will simply say don't waste your time or money you can smoke at home watch the original after you pay 3 dollars to rent it and not have to listen to all the other patrons of the theater go on about how bad the re-make sucks..eat popcorn smoke cigarettes (or whatever) kick your feet up turn down the lights  and watch the original wicker man...but please avoid the re-make like the plague on art that it is.

column4: SPOILERS: When Nick Cage Needs Money
column5: Nicholas Cage is in this movie. That's the only reason I watched it. And I bet he spends at least 5 minutes of every day regretting it. So will I.Anyone who has ever watched old Twilight Zone episodes or movies or those terrible "Movie of the Week" things that were so popular in the 70s has seen this thing a zillion times. Let me give you a few hints. It is about mysterious CHILDREN and a lot of CORN (get it yet?) in every sense of the word.Obscene acting (and not in the good sense) mind-numbing "plot" from beyond done to death. I was so bored with it (but stuck with it only so that I could warn you away from it faithful reader...that's just the kind of guy *I* am!) that I actually made up a country song ("I've Got a Sticky Wicket for You"...look for it on the charts). And the only thing more painful than sitting through this drek would be hearing me sing a country song.Stay away...Stay far away...That's the warning someone should have given Cage's character Cage himself (who must have had some whopper debts in 2006 to be willing to star in this thing) and me...and it's the warning I'm giving you!

column4: A really bad waste of time
column5: This movie is plain bad. I only saw it because of the original just to see what they would do with the idea. I had heard that it wasn't that good but I honestly didn't expect it to be this catastrophically bad.The motivations of people are non existent. They're just there and they just do what they do - primarily to scare and be creepy. Much of the (over)acting is laughable. Cage hams it up in some scenes. He has made some good movies but in this movie he just plain sucks. At least it sucks consistently from start to finish!The movie lacks subtlety is very clichéd and is grossly overdone. It becomes completely bizarre towards the end. Some of it seems like an unintentional(?) parody of horror movies similar to Scary movie (I'm not kidding).>>slight spoiler<<The tagged on story about the girl Cage's character couldn't save does NOT ad depth or back story it's just utterly pointless. It's just a "vehicle" for some boo scares/dreams later and it becomes annoying.(Update: There's some theory going around that those people were part of the plot to get him there and that they didn't die in the explosion - honestly that doesn't make any sense at all unless they're supernatural beings.)Maybe the director hated the original and wanted to spoof it? Why would anyone want to finance this crap? It just baffles me.Don't see this unless you want to see an unintentionally (I think) funny movie. It was more sad to me sad that I spend all that time watching the whole movie. What a waste of time.I repeat: This movie is REALLY REALLY bad. You have been warned! See the original instead!

OK let me sum this movie up in one word.....sucked. i thought this movie was almost as stupid as 'the village' and that was really stupid!it was a total waste of my time! what a stupid ending! even the alternate ending sucked! Nicolas Cage could have done without doing this one.i love watching Cage in every movie he's done i've thought it was great...but this one i did not like at all. there were so many things with the movie that didn't make sense at all and were not explained in any way...that is so frustrating! the station wagon at the beginning....what was up with that!?

column4: Not as Good as the Original but not as bad as expected
column5: Spoiler at the end I watched this movie expecting to roast it in Mystery Science Theater fashion but it wasn't really in that caliber of bad. It had Nicholas Cage yes so there were several grade grunts and groans about his leaden line deliveries. I was expecting to see Satanic rather than pagan imagery but was pleasantly surprised that some of the things in the trailers seem to have been ploys to bring in the standard horror movie crowd.This movie is still nowhere near the caliber of the original which is one of my all time favorite movies. There really aren't any scenes that match the best scenes of the original. For instance no tempting scene with Britt Eckland pounding the walls in the buff dancing to a tribal rhythm. There was no terrific celtic bar music and bawdy pub humor or semi-travel-log bits which added real charm to the original movie.Not a great movie by a long shot but not really as horrible as I was lead to believe. I bought the DVD with the "shocking" ending which ended up just meaning there wasn't the add on bit with girls showing up in a city looking for fresh sacrifice bait. Not really shocking.

column4: Apparently you're cool if you hate this movie
column5: I read several reviews here that reeked of arrogance and tried a little too hard to tear the film apart. They ended up becoming the very reason I gave it a chance. I saw the original and loved it in spite of some silliness and a dose of 70s naivety. This remake has some slightly greater faults but nothing's anywhere near as bad as the haters want you to believe. The current rating of 36 is absolutely ridiculous especially when compared to the 75+ ratings that cheap exercises in vulgarity like Saw get. It just shows what a refined movie lover the average IMDb user can be.I started watching TWM expecting to give up on it in less than 20 minutes but an hour later I still couldn't find anything seriously wrong with it. It doesn't follow the typical thriller formula it's much more subdued and creepy with a handful of shocks thrown into the mix. If you're in the mood for something more down to earth that for the most part is exotic and mysterious AND you're willing to overlook a couple of tiny moments of unintentional hilarity you won't regret having seen it.The cinematography's gorgeous Angelo Badalamenti's music needs no introduction and Nick Cage creates a sympathetic character that's completely out of his element and is forced to adapt to a world where nobody cares about the rules he's used to. There are no car chases here no shootouts there's hardly any violence but a sense of loneliness and desperation that personally I found intriguing. It's not often that you watch a cop main character being the most helpless guy in the movie but here it's done plausibly and I enjoyed the atypical situation. There's more to be said but I think you'd be better off watching TWM with as fresh a perspective as possible.So expect a flawed minimalist thriller but one in which the good far outweighs the bad. See it in the best available quality because the visuals are the movie's greatest strength.75/10

column4: Don't waste your time and money
column5: This movie was a huge disappointment from the commercials it looks like a suspenseful thrilling movie but in reality it is a boring scattered mess. I rented it from blockbuster a few days ago. I originally did not even want to rent this movie but after they didn't have Little Miss Sunshine I had to leave with something so I just picked it up. Biggest mistake of my life... well at least biggest mistake of the day.. when I got home I decided to watch it and ever since I have been regretting that choice. I usually do not write comments on movies but I have got to warn people not to waste their time and money on this movie. It isn't even worth the 4.99 you pay to rent it. This movie is a complete mess.

It's unfortunate that you can't go any lower than one star. Prior to watching The Wicker Man I had considered Aliens 3 to be the only movie that would actually merit negative stars. In all fairness The Wicker Man doesn't detract from the enjoyment of an earlier film but the fact remains that my cumulative movie enjoyment has been reduced by seeing it.There is a cheap trick all too often used in Hollywood when the producers are too stingy to hire good writers or in too much of a hurry to allow them to bring a plot to a satisfactory conclusion: slap in a shocker ending and hope that the public will mistake it for something artistic or meaningful. It is a gambit that rarely succeeds and in this case manages only to splatter embarrassment on a fine actor and ridicule upon the producers. Even more so in that the "carefully crafted" (or however they put it) conclusion didn't seem to follow logically from the plot (which naturally I can't elaborate on without introducing spoilers) and instead negates what merit the plot had up to that point.It is a film that might logically appeal to psychopaths pedophiles and possibly die-hard Nicholas Cage fans but only to a few of the mainstream audience. If you really want something along these lines I heartily recommend M. Night Shyamalan's The Village instead. Lacking some kind of memory-erasing pill I suppose I need to watch something better to force it from my mind say Attack of the Killer Tomatoes or Pee-wee's Big Adventure?

column4: Save your money wait for the DVD
column5: The commercial shows a promising movie. The names headlining the movie brings one to believe it is going to be a decent move (Cage LeeLee). With a preview of a truck slamming into a car followed by a fire that was probably the most action packed part of the movie.As the movie progressed I had questioned certain aspects and elements in my head only to find out I was correct later on so be prepared on very little suspense and a a very slow plot. If you are one who sees the obvious quickly then you should do as the first reviewer did and just walk out and go see something different.The end is not what I had in mind and to be quite frank I had expected much more. I honestly feel like a refund of my ticket is in order.There were a few funny parts but save your money folks. Cage is a great actor but it makes me wonder if he has become desperate or blind with this script when he read it as this was not his best performance. I still like Cage but I think I might be careful of future suspense movies that he stars in.-NT-

So I thought to myself that I would give this film a try. I am a big fan of the original but I do feel that it's age shows a little and a re-vamp might work.After seeing the film I can now see how silly I was. To say this film is bad is to give it credit. If i did anything as poor as this in my job I would be sacked without a second thought. This is now just another in a long line of horror remakes that has been messed up by Hollywood.Nicholas Cage is not one of my favourite actors and in my opinion has never done any better than Leaving Las Vegas but here he shows a whole new level of wooden and pathetic. Two major points I noticed was the need to pull his gun to steal a bike of a tiny woman and when he tried to wake the pilot awake after finding him with his eyes and mouth stitched together. surely the blood and the pale complexion was a bit of a give away.The procession at the end just made me want to laugh. In the original the cast merrily danced their way to the sacrifice spot. Here they kind of bumble along occasionally flapping their arms and swaying a bit. These people are trying to restore their gods favour and get a bumper crop they look more like a bunch of eight year olds being forced back to school after their summer holidays.At the end in a rather pathetic whine Nickolas Cage asks his former fiancé "Willow Why have you done this to me?". The previous hour and twenty of the film has already answered that for you. His character is probably the most dull and boring ever.People may now ask me after making all these comments why have I given the film a 3 and not lower? The answer to that is simple. Not only was I pleased that the original ending was kept in the film I was glad to see him burn. Any sympathy felt for Edward Woodward in the original is completely lost here. My only regret is that the burning didn't take longer I have wasted an hour and a half of my life watching this rubbish. The least they could have done is made him suffer in the end.

column4: They don't make Wicker Mans like they use to. Oh well watch it anyway it's different.
column5: Concerning the new remake of the Wicker Man (WM)(2006) let's get the 500-pound gorilla out of the way first the Wicker Man (1973). Having seen the first Wicker Man (1973) numerous times and wore out the audio CD. It has qualities that make it unique to the point where both movies need to be judged on their own merits because they are different (frankly the 1973 version has a better twist on being twisted thus is better IMHO). It's kind of like comparing Lost Horizon (1937) (a drama) with Lost Horizon (1973)(a musical). I could also wax poetic about the many differences to fill a book but that is really a waste of everyones time nitpicking. Nevertheless purge your mind totally of the WM 1973 version and watch the WM 2006 version it's a fair movie that has some interesting plot twists that make the new WM worth a watch.Quick Plot Summery:A police officer fails to rescue a woman and her little girl from a burning car and is put on medial leave from the trauma. The officer later receives a letter from a long ago ex-fiancée who returned home to a secluded esoteric commune on Summersisle island in the northwest US. Her daughter is now missing and she fearing the worse pleads for the officer's help to locate her daughter. The officer goes to Summersisle only to discover a matriarchal (female centered) commune more in tune with the old ways (pagan) free from the "normal" world's repressions. Summersisle's main cash export is honey but last years honey production was "cursed" for the first time in many years and the missing girl was blamed. During his stay the officer gets the picture that he is wanted like the plague and receives very little help. While making his investigations the officer comes to the conclusion that the missing girl will be sacrificed in a pagan ceremony to ensure a bountiful harvest in the future. The officer tries to rescue the missing girl only to find that he was being played a fool from the start of the movie in a twisted game of cat and mouse. It seems the commune does not sacrifice their own but outsources the honor to outsiders and the officer now has that honor. You need to see the movie to see what befalls the officer and the recruiting of new sacrifices for the commune.Interesting Points:The commune is modeled on one big happy bee hive. The women are the "worker bees" the men are the "drones" and there is one "queen bee."Little if any technology used by the commune. Low tech.The commune is not based on traditional Christian values which throws the officer off balance.The scenery is peaceful beautiful simple and clean which is the icing that covers the hard rigid chess like calculating but maniacal nature of the commune.Disappointing Points:Sometimes the plot drags and several scenes that did not add much to the plot were stuck in to increase the weird factor.Yes we get all the many many points that the commune is based on a bee hive now get on with the plot. The bees covered nude girl on a chair really clarified everything . . . not.Frankly the whole car crash and burn scene at the beginning could be eliminated IMHO. I would have had the officer officially visit the island to investigate the missing child to save time at the film's start.The officer does not seem to conduct himself in an official manner. Beating up several women holding a gun on a petite bicycle riding school teacher and waving around a badge like a fan seems like over kill. By the time the officer makes it to the end of the movie you start to sympathize with the communes actions and wonder if the police department will even care if this officer comes up missing.All the flashbacks and hallucinations wear thin after a few times especially when they do not help the plot. If you want weird then show weird.Many of us movie goers do not know what May poles are for and what pagans believe so a little hint or two would have make the movie less boring and add true strangeness.I now know why the commune has an "only outsider can be sacrifices" rule. If I lived in the commune long enough I would volunteer as the next sacrifice just to break the monotony. And you thought the "normal" outside world was repressing the spirit.

This movie fails at almost every level. Our audience laughed at what was clearly meant to be serious dialog. The plot is fantastically implausible both in general and in particulars and so is Nicolas Cage's unconvincing and unsympathetic character. Kate Beahan's absurd bee-stung lips are the only memorable thing about her distracted performance and the other female characters including Ellen Burstyn's are painted cardboard cutouts. The film is driven by fear and resentment. It tries to make us believe in imaginings that would embarrass any but the dullest and meanest of adolescent boys. A few plot ideas and images that might have turned interesting are simply dropped without any development. The closing credits brought groans loud complaints and scornful laughter. Although this is not the plot of the movie I was reminded while watching of cartoon mysteries in which crooks dress up as monsters to frighten "meddling kids." That's the level of cheesy implausibility we're dealing with here. Even viewers who actively suspend their disbelief will be dissatisfied and will probably feel as cheated as I did.

column4: Oh the horror! Oh the mystery!
column5: I used to have this goldfish named Flushy. He basically swam around his bowl ate a bit pooped a bit and occasionally ate a bit of his poop. I generally do not consider those who dine upon their own excrement to be of the highest intellectual caliber. I grossly underestimated poor Flushy's commercial value however. When compared to the folks at Warner Brothers who actually chose to release this steaming pile of nonsense Flushy The Fish was a freaky genius.Within 10 minutes of Ed's arrival on Corny Thespian Isle everyone in the theatre knew exactly how the movie would end. Okay to be fair the roaches crawling around on last week's popcorn may have been surprised by the final "twist" of the plot. But I assure you they were the only ones. The rest of us were left suffering through the next 88 minutes of Ed doofily running around the island and wondering why the background noise was that of a Louisiana swamp when we were supposed to be in the Pacific northwest.Maybe the DVD's alternate endings will feature demon zombie ninjas from hell rising from the earth to devour Sister Sumersisle's spleen and drink martinis from her skull.

please keep in mind that i'm not a horror movie buff and i didn't know this was a remake until i visited this site this morning.i liked it. i thought it maintained a thoroughly creepy atmosphere the whole way. it had some very predictable moments such as nick cage finding the doll in the grave. also i laughed out loud when he pulled the gun on sister rose and yelled "step away from the bike!!" but i still wanted to keep watching it to find out what on earth was going on.and now that i know there's an original i want to see it.(even though i'm just a silly American and apparently can't handle movies being set in other countries.)

I regret to say I have no idea what a "spoiler" is. Perhaps some kind fellow IMDb member might enlighten me. As regards this movie I'm deeply disappointed: it's disjointed incoherent tedious frustrating and boring. Furthermore I find it impossible to believe that actors of the caliber of Cage and Burnstyn...the main reason I decided to watch it in the first place... could have remotely lent themselves to such a piece of excrement. "They" CAN choose the movies they elect to star in: I recommend that "they" be somewhat more "selective"--in the future! Why?...simply because "they" have millions of fans worldwide who deserve..and should get...nothing less than the very best from their idols! Terry

I cant believe that i wasted more than hour watching that piece of crap.i cant imagine Cage participated in something like this. The wicker man is the worst movie i have ever seen. no idea no acting no anything.really do think millions of time b4 watching this movie and i wonder is their any one who bought that yucky on DVD?I hope not cos the first thing u will do after u watch it is to tear it up into pieces.i was really nervous after finishing it felt like i want to crash something. well i really got the feeling of sleeping wiz a girl but i at the end i wasn't satisfied just imagine how i felt.For God sake don't watch this.

column4: Not horrible just misguided and amateurish
column5: I saw "The Wicker Man" remake along with the 1973 original with a friend of mine about 2 months ago. We were both curious about the movies for quite some time. My only preliminary exposure to this specimen was the infamous "Not the bees!" scene though that particular sample wasn't my motivation for looking into these films. Though I have seen the original prior to watching the remake I analyzed dissected and rated the 2006 remake on it's own merits keeping in mind only the general setting and idea which were the basis for the 1973 classic.The original "Wicker Man" portrayed a variety of conflicts and problems (perhaps too large a variety) through the main opposition of Christianity vs. Paganism. It was without a doubt an interesting and well crafted piece of art though it did have some minor pacing issues and suffered from a slight inability to properly develop the different aspects of the conflict due to it's relatively short run time. From what I could gather a lot of people were opposed to the very idea of a "Wicker Man" remake. Personally I thought it was a prospect ripe for development as the original presented a wide variety of ideas and allowed a lot freedom to potential re-interpretation. It was in the truest sense of the word a timeless movie one that could take new forms in the works of other directors/writers through the ages if not as a direct remake at least as a general inspiration.The location a sort of occult backwater was ideal for the story's development and choosing to (more or less) keep it similar was one of LaBute's better decisions when it comes to this movie.While a conflict of the genders isn't the first thing that comes to mind when I think of "The Wicker Man" it was a fairly interesting concept. Although I haven't seen any of Mr.LaBute's other works from what I can gather this kind of conflict is a recurring theme in them. Again I didn't mind this direction It's Neil LaBute's remake after all. He has the freedom to re-interpret it as he wishes. That doesn't excuse the poor presentation though.One thing that becomes noticeable after the first couple of scenes is the direction or lack thereof. A lot of people flag the acting in this movie as "bad" though I think directionless would be more appropriate. I'm pretty sure some of the actors especially Nick Cage could do better if they knew what they were supposed to do. What character are they supposed to represent - no one knows. What feelings are they trying to convey - not quite sure. This lack of direction gives the scenes an awkward poorly paced feel. As a result the movie seems to waste most of it's 102 minute run time feeling a lot less complete than the shorter 1973 original by the end.The connection between the scenes themselves seems off too. The whole movie feels poorly cobbled together as a result which is a shame as some scenes are done rather well especially when it comes to scenery and camera work. There are some rather poor computer generated effects in some select moments (the bees come to mind though that scene wasn't in most cuts). The island in particular feels very authentic and manages to pull of the occult backwater in the 21st century look.The whole man vs. woman focus also suffers from lack of direction. They try to present Cage's character as a tormented man who wants to right wrongs but is a complete control freak and even a borderline sociopath as a result of his past failures. At least I thinks that's what they're trying to go for - with all the awkward dream sequences and conversations where Cage steals the spotlight you never get an idea of what his character is supposed to be like. And if Nick gets 1/3 of the movie for himself and still can't portray his character you can imagine what the rest of the island dwellers are like. So if there is no foundation to what the characters who participate in the conflict represent then the conflict itself can't be outlined. As a result all the elements clearly made to tie into this conflict (the hive metaphor the Don Quixote reference) feel tacked on and pointless nothing more than pretentious self-indulgence.In conclusion "The Wicker Man" remake offers an interesting take on the original concept coupled with a wonderful setting but fails to develop it. The poor directing and editing between scenes the resulting slow pacing and plot holes the poorly developed characters and directionless acting and most of all the poorly outlined conflict ruin what could have been an interesting movie.

I haven't seen the original so maybe that's why but I thought this film was actually pretty good. The plot line was very interestingly done and it was definitely an innovative take on the ideas expressed. The ending was not expected (though left some plot holes) and I could really relate to Cage's character.There were a lot of unanswered questions but that contrary to what most people say is not a flaw. The loose plot ends are the beauty of this movie. Sure it gets a little repetitive but the story is very intensely put together with character development and the emotions expressed throughout truly made this movie.Of course it was not without its flaws. As I said the scenes became a little repetitive and some bits were unintentionally funny. Some bits you have to be as clever as me to actually understand and so I would only recommend this film to people who truly appreciate things (which I'm sorry to say is not the majority of the movie-going public).

Quick reminder/suggestion: I'll spoilers in this comment so don't read it if you haven't watched the movie. I'll also be talking about the original 70s movie.This movie has taken over some flaws of the original but tried to eliminate a few too. But I'll start with a change in the script that I liked although it kind of freaked me a out a little bit too.The whole island is like a bee colony mixed in with a black widow ingredient. The women have the power and the men are plain workers. But while as a male companion to the black widow you at least get to have fun (i.e. intercourse with the female) before she kills you the men on this island don't really get to enjoy this part! Not that it is shown on-screen/directly but you can guess every time you see this men.While this is a major change most of the things the original had are included here as well. The why doesn't he try to escape his cage at the end is taken care of here: Because he can't his legs are broken! In the alternate cut/ending this is also shown but was cut for the theatrical version to give it a PG-13. In the theatrical version you overheard this happening.One of the major flaws of this remake to me is that it over explains things. Especially at the end when all is clear but they talk about it.It's a good cast overall but you're not left satisfied after watching this movie :o)

column4: Bait and switch don't even bother with this.
column5: This is one of those movies that just makes me go "huh?" I have never posted on IMDb but I just got done watching this movies and I just had to warn everyone!!!!! Do not waste 90 minutes of your life!!!!!!!! I am a huge fan of films that keep me guessing from beginning to end. I could not be happier than when I come to the end of a movie and am shocked by a plot twist. However when that plot twist makes no sense it leaves sort of an empty feeling. Other members have posted that the set up in this film was great and I would agree with that. However it is all ruined in the last five minutes. It was so bizarre that I actually asked myself "when is he going to wake up from the dream sequence?" More importantly this movie contains some brutal and explicit violence that is not advertised nor expected at the time it occurs. This in and of itself would have been enough to make me stay away from this film had I known about it in advance. Let me be clear I have no problem with violence in cinema. While I have seen worse this particular case was very disturbing in that it was un-needed and not what was expected.

column4: The WIcker Man? Try Godawful Man
column5: I thought there would be a better ending to this movie. Since I am a big fan of Nicolas Cage's work I was excited to rent this movie & watch it since I missed it in the theaters. Good Lord I am glad I waited and only paid a few dollars to rent it this movie was pathetic. I think the build up to the ending was pretty good it kept me shaking my head in wonder at what was going to be revealed at the end but the end was just pathetic. I don't know any other way of describing it. Just the burning of Cage and that was it. So what the heck was the entire story for? Just to show that he got some weirdo chick pregnant and he was drug to the island to be burned? It was a very unsatisfying ending and I was not a happy camper. I am not one to be pissy but damn Nic can't you find better things to do? They could have wrapped it up a lot better than they did. He must have needed the money I was bitterly disappointed.

I was really curious about this movie when I read about it on the web. The plot line looked very interesting and the presence of Nicholas Cage leads me to think that would be a good movie.I'm just back from the theater and I'm really disappointed with this movie. The story is nice but the second half of the movie the main character looks more a scared middle age corporate worker than a cop. The end of the movie is just too plain and has no "wooo nice" at all.This is one of that movies I regret to have spent my money to watch it. I wouldn't use the DVD of it even to make a homemade kitchen wall clock. It's a total waste of money and time.

I was SOOO looking forward to this film as I'm a HUGE fan of the original. This was just plain awful. I really think that some people that make films are so disconnected with reality. I mean our protagonist finds a plane that just lands and cant find the pilot and instead of LOOKING for the pilot or TRYING to get the radio equipment to work he just moves onto something mundane. I swear this film is about the lead actor (Cage) and isn't anything the story was supposed to revolve around. In the original it was about the horror and insanity of this town and in this movie its all about the protagonist and his mental condition. I KNEW this film was in trouble when I saw about 5 studio company labels at the front of the picture. Too many chefs...
