The most entertaining thing in this film was Nicholas Cage having a fist fight with Leelee Sobieski. Yes it was that bad. If you're looking for sex there's no sex. If you're looking for violence there's not much. If you're looking for horror well there is a little but it's not very well done. No gore. A car does blow up in it. As far as all the artsy theatre stuff goes the plot is stupid the acting is mostly awful and the dialog has been thoroughly cleansed of any wit or intellectual content. Even the camera work looks like it was made for TV.The big problem with this movie is that they started out from original film's screenplay and then they scrubbed out all the Christianity all the sexual tension and all the weird creepy/corny stuff. The thing is the original was all about the cultural conflict between starched-collar conservative Christianity and corny/creepy free-loving hippie pagans. It's like remaking Star Wars but replacing the Empire with killer bees. I think they were trying to make sure that nobody could be offended by it except for the audience. Possibly the update in the setting could have worked with a complete rewrite but what happened was that the screenplay and the direction/production are for totally different films. The film just doesn't know where it's going and it sure never gets there.

column4: Wicker Man Comedy Version Completely Sanitized
column5: The original Wicker man had some great things going. It occurred during the hippie revolution and an isolated religious cult pagan worship nude woman performing rites etc. While the investigating police officer was a devoutly Christian religious. It was a clash of Pagan versus Christianity. The new Wicker man in order to please the general audiences virtually eliminated all Pagan worship so as not to offend the Christian viewers. At the same time removed the devoutly Christian Sargent so as not to offend the non-Christian viewers. Completely eliminated nudity so as not to offend the young viewers. Turned the male symbols into somewhat a Freudian joke instead of Pagan beliefs. Because so many fun elements of witchcraft sorcery Pagan worship secret worship nudity were all removed the fun elements were virtually replaced with Giant Beehives irritating bees and a black crow that had no meaning to the movie. In this movie all elements of horror thrills suspense were eliminated to be replaced with National Treasure meets the Wicker Man. To make for fun scene ala National treasure they let Nicolas Cage fall down in a giant cave like farm much like that Aztec like cave but only without the treasure. As to the running and blockbuster sequences they added a truck hitting the car with the mother in the beginning of the scene that had no relation to the movie and the all too exciting bees chase Nicolas Cage. It would have been more exciting to see bees chasing Mr. Bean then Nicolas Cage since he's more clumsier than Mr. Bean. To me it was a funny disappointing film. The original Wicker Man is in nowhere have a resemblance to this Wicker man at all despite the fact that 80% of the scripts are the same the first had horror overtones while this one had unintended joke overtones. They simply completely ruined this.

column4: Worst movie ever..even for Cage fans
column5: I'm a big fan of Nicolas Cage and I never thought he would work on a movie like this. I couldn't believe the other reviews and I thought it shouldn't be bad to watch it at least once...but trust me it is.I haven't seen the old movie..but why would they want to remake a movie like this. The very basic idea of a good horror movie is either it should have an extremely intelligent script or it should be extremely graphic. This film doesn't fall under any of those and just remains dumb.I just kept watching the movie hoping it would get interesting at some point  but it never does.So this movie is a big no no for both Horror movie fans as well as for the Cage fans. You could probably for it show up on television.

First a commendation. The cinematography and location shots on the island are beautifully done. The costuming likewise.Now the criticisms. Cage's character is totally unrealistic. Highway patrol officers simply do not investigate child abductions on their own especially across state borders. And no one seems to be concerned by the end of the film that he's missing... Cage's acting is stilted with lines seemingly cobbed from a MAD TV takeoff of "Cops!" I don't think it was intended to be a comedy was it? Perhaps it was Cage's total embarrassment for having accepted the role without reading the script. At least Burstyn developed her character well as I would have expected.Unfortunately the film has a much worse flaw. It is religious bigotry disguised as a horror tale. It unforgivably perpetuates a centuries-old blood libel against Pagan Witches. Many of the characters are clearly identified as such with references to their Celtic religious roots their negative experiences in Salem and their Goddess-centered worship of nature. The libel that Witches murder unborn children and seduce witless men into being sacrificed in their unholy rites is one straight out of the Dark Ages and the Holy Inquisition. There is no credible evidence that the events at the end of the film ever were practiced by Celtic Pagans with a living person. Sadly it is on historical record that was a common event with another well-known religious body. The bigotry can not be more blatant.Not worth watching. Ask for your money back.

column4: this film is a waste of any cinema-goer's time and money
column5: I've been an avid fan of the original Wicker Man in both its versions (Theater and Director's Cut) for many years so it was with some foreboding that I went to see it today with my wife (who hasn't seen the original). My worst fears were more than justified and I can do no more than agree whole-heartedly with virtually everything that has been said in the other comments. It was a waste of money and I wouldn't recommend anyone go see it; save your cash for watching the original on DVD or on TV. A couple of minor points: many people seem to be under the impression that Summersisle in this film was off the coast of Maine; not so the film explicitly says it is in the N-W Pacific and part of the State of Washington. This error could have been perpetuated from a mistake by one of the media critics. Secondly I've heard that Edward Woodward the police sergeant of the original was offered a cameo role. To his eternal credit he had the foresight and wisdom to turn down the offer.

column4: Not even a single mention of the landlords daughter....!?!?!
column5: After witnessing the trailers for the wicker man remake I was filled with a sort of curiosity. The original being one of my favourite films ever I thought I might as well have a look and see what this version was like. I thoroughly regret that decision.Unfortunately this remake is completely lacking in all departments the acting is unbelievably half-hearted as though the actors just really couldn't be bothered. The script and plot is basically a simplistic version of the all mighty original. The remake left out many important details that made the original an absolutely astounding film - the soundtrack was gone the character of lord summerisle (played by the legendary Christopher Lee) was replace with sister summerisle who was just like a kind old demented auntie the may pole sequence is gone the beetle in the desk has been replaced by a crow it's left out the religious element which was basically the foundation of the original film.. 'Good vs. Evil' so to speak. The most chilling thing for me about the original was the end sequence where Edward Woodward was being burned in the wicker man he was shouting out passages from the bible and the inhabitants of Summerisle were singing it truly was a chilling thing to witness.Another thing that was left out was the overt sexuality of the inhabitants of summerisle. This I feel is a very important part of the plot as it ties in with Paganism.After watching this remake I felt very blaaaah (thats the only way to describe it in all honesty).The trailers for this film really are misleading they've just pieced together random little segments of the film that have promise yet when you actually see the film you feel very cheated. I really am surprised that this came to the cinema I would have thought it would have gone straight to Video/DVD release.Although this remake may make others who have not seen the original feel completely cheated and angry at having paid money to see such an awful production I definitely recommend you see the original - you will not be disappointed it has a much better storyline and the soundtrack is beautifully eerie.

Haunted by a tragic accident a policeman is called out to an isolated island community to search for a missing child only for the habitants' strange rituals and ceremonies to infuriate him which causes him to discover what the real reason was for the ceremony.This has a few considerable flaws going for it. One of the main issues is that there's a problem with the way the investigation is handled which is a huge factor due to the majority of the time this spends on the investigation. Since the film relies on the fact that everything around him is lying and he's being deceived quite obviously this one goes for the society seemingly playing games with him from the start even if they appear to be trying to help him for the first half here. At the very end he starts going around and throwing his weight around to make up for all the lies that were told to him which really seems like an act which should've been done sooner especially after the reception received. It might've worked better and had better results if he had done something sooner rather than let the investigation get that way. This one carries on a joke far too long and really drags this out. Another pretty big flaw is that there are no real surprises to be had from this since it plays out exactly as it originally did and all the surprises and fun to be had from that one are gone because it is so familiar. Even the plot twist doesn't surprise which is the greatest flaw in here as the film is built up to a twist out of nowhere that has none of the fear and dread featured in the original effectively ruining all the momentum it would've had going into it the same. Even the tagged-on epilogue is a failure as the movie should've ended with the twist rather than the lame gag given here which manages to end this on an even more sour note. There's even way too much insistence on jump- cuts and while there's some visual impact or shock effect they're a really irritating distraction. There's so many that it can become blasé which is deadening because there's too many of them. Alongside some truly cheesy and silly set-pieces there are some really big holes as this gets very little right. One of them is that the opening really works for the film as the everyday normality it opens to is expertly shattered with a brutal and shocking crash and the eventual race before the fire burns everything is handled with some nice suspense. The search at times can be quite fun as there are some really good scenes in here that are derived from that especially the sequence where he gets stuck in the underground cavern or the room covered with bees. It gets considerably more active and intense towards the end after the changeover to their celebrations as the revelry and costumes makes for quite a fun cheesy time. These though constitute the film's only good points.Rated PG-13: Language and Violence.

I have been; and still am a Nicholas Cage Fan. Although I have not seen all of his movies I've seen a lot. The movies that I have seen always ended good. I'm the type of person that won't go near a movie if I know that it doesn't end good. I actually sat there in shock. I kept waiting for someone to save him; but nothing happened. I was so furious. I can't for the life of me understand why this great actor took such a role! This movie had a lot of "loose ends" was not well made and left me not only with a horrible feeling but lots of questions. I hope that Mr. Cage never takes a role like that again.In the very beginning where the car accident happened; did youall notice what a brat that little girl was? I realized in the end (at least I think); that they must have been part of this entire charade as she was growing up to believe the men were vermin.Anyway I hope that Mr. Cage's next movie ends a lot better.Thank you for listening! PC

I don't understand what the matter was with Nicolas Cage when he picked Neil LaBute to make this because the result manages to fumble EVERY SINGLE ASPECT of what made the original film great.Amazingly it seems to be a peculiar hybrid of Hollywoodised rubbish and LaBute's usual anti-female ranting. It starts out establishing that Cage's Edward Malus (a name no-one in the film pronounces properly) has "issues" and when he gets to the pointlessly retitled Summersisle (not unfortunately pronounced "summer sizzle") the local act in such arch melodramatic and generally suspicious manner as to make K9 & Company look subtle.The dialogue is so bad that people were openly laughing at the screen and there were what appeared to be some very poorly-judged attempts at humour which may have been unintentional. Changing the original's Pagan-but-modern society into a bizarre quasi-Amish matriarchy doesn't work and merely shows up LaBute typical apparent hatred of women as the all-female conspiracy to trap and kill the only independent man on the island is revealed. "Look out!" LaBute is shouting "the women are all out to get you and sap your masculine power!" I find it incredible that the subtlety intelligence and wit of the original could have been totally excised from the script and direction but with a talentless cretin like Neil LaBute in charge it should be no surprise that this is as insulting ugly obvious and misogynistic as it is.It is by far the worst film I have seen since Revolver and that really stank.

The Wicker Man (2006): Dir: Neil LaBute / Cast: Nicolas Cage Ellen Burstyn Leelee Sobieski Molly Parker Kate Beahan: Who in hell is the bloody Wicker Man? Apparently these moron villagers with no life worship this guy yet he is nowhere to be seen. They could bow down to an outhouse and it would make about as much sense. It opens with a cop played by Nicolas Cage failing to rescue a mother and daughter inside a car that explodes. Central plot regards a letter from a past girlfriend who claims that their daughter is missing. He goes to a remote village only to discover that everybody worships bees. Directed by Neil LaBute who previously made the much better Nurse Betty. The screenplay here has a conclusion that demanded a happy ending like no other. Cage does well as the no nonsense cop out for answers but his fate is nothing to write home about. Ellen Burstyn is laughable as the bee queen who constantly talks spirit bullshit. Leelee Sobieski plays a deranged bitch who has bees honey for brains. Molly Parker plays a school teacher who is obviously guilty because she lies every time she opens her mouth to Cage. Kate Beahan plays another bee loving crazy honey bitch that should be put away. Beautiful production doesn't bypass that it could have been about the reality of cults. Instead the audience laughed and snickered at its ridiculous bee hive charade. Score: 4 ½ / 10

I just saw it... In New York city utilizing the Fandango web service (you never know if these things will sell out or not) I paid $12.50 to see this film.On a scale of $1 to $12.50 the new "The Wicker Man" is somewhere between $1 and $2.50.HUGE SPOILERS AHEAD.OK as a "Wicker Man" purist at first I didn't want to even know a remake was to be released. Why mess with perfection; what's been done has been done: it's not a play or serial that's meant to be redone. Plus the only person you could get to replace Christopher Lee would be Christopher Lee. Nevertheless assuming it's done well I could see the story translating really well to a U.S. setting with some old cult well-isolated well-insulated still practicing that Old Time Religion...Sure it's derivative! What isn't? Well-told this story always packs a wallop and is solid horror fun. The original Wicker Man has a disturbing unresolved unhappy ending. The story doesn't close (what happens next? who knows?!) and that's it's lasting effect: will Lord Summerisle be sacrificed if the next crop fails as Inspector Howie cries out in hopeless desperation? Good question but you'll never know because the film is over.Not this Wicker Man though.In general casting terms OK Nicholas Cage is good. His character of Edward Malus (ohhh! "Edward" chasing Rowan "Woodward" - nice and Malus? As in "Malleus Maleficarum?" What a clever touch!) has plenty of attitude but he lacks the religious stick up his ass that Insp. Howie had. That was essential to the story because it established genuine antagonism between Howie and the Summerisle cult. Howie's a Roundhead flunky for all it matters and he's up against the Druid of Druids. Tough luck for the Roundheads... Cage's character without question a typical modern American agnostic can only look to cheap truck-stop self-help books to fight his inner demons and probably could care less what a bunch of hippie whack-jobs believe in.Ellen Burstyn. For the sake of argument I couldn't think of a better choice. She has serious horror movie credibility. And she can take charge of the scene - like her character's supposed to.Plot holes: OK so the switch is from crops in general to honey. OK so the Summersisle cult is really a colony of bees with multiple fertile queens with an uber-queen at the head (Burstyn). No problem makes for an interesting story sort of like a reverse of L. Sprague de Camp's "Rogue Queen." Well then why not run with that story? Let's say that Nick Cage is now on the island - get him to replace the old man in charge of shagging the non- menopausal queens! Throw the old guy into the Wicker Man and be done with it!No no... We're going to try and match the original movie line-for-line make-up nuance for make up nuance costume for costume... and it didn't work. Howie's research made it clear why the folks were in costume. All Cage/Woodward's "research" did was determine that a) the cult aborted most of the males (why? Not good enough? The men hanging around were weaklings - why not explain it some more?) and b) someone conveniently left out a manual on ritual human sacrifice - too easy. I must give credit though: the scene with the aborted male fetuses in jars was disturbing disturbing at the right "Wicker Man" level yet the film just didn't run with it. Make Cage burn with right-to-life anger; let's hear the Summersisle girls explain their pre-emptive patricide give the story some interesting provocative controversial dialog. Make the audience uncomfortable - instead there were regular laughs from the audience.Why are the women chanting "The drone must die"? Did he finish fertilizing the "colony"? Apparently he fathered one - but is that enough? Is Willow to be the next queen? Will Rowan then follow in her footsteps? If they're the royal line don't they need more heirs? We saw multiple pregnant girls? Was it all the old man in the bed's work? Did Cage's character do anything that would distinguish himself a drone other than being a man?Annoyances: why is a waitress in California talking like some stereotypical "southern" dunce (using "them" instead of "those"? That didn't make sense.Cheap film: Is the audience so stupid that Cage has to scream "my legs!" so we'll all know that the Queen Bee's minions have broken his legs - off camera? Why not have Sister Summersisle say "bind his legs!" or "break his legs!"? Or similar? And why'd they kill the pilot? That if any action would bring the entire State of Washington police "swarming" all over the island? They didn't even get rid of the evidence well enough! A flight plan was probably filed! The guy might have a family! There's an oil slick on the water! What about other people who needed use of the plane? There's bound to be an investigation ladies!I want my money back part: The epilogue "six months later" - what the hell? Now the Summersisle cult goes out hunting men? For what? If they'd kept Nick Cage drugged up or gave him some special potion to "keep it up" they'd be saved all the trouble. Double I want my money back: the film is dedicated to Johnny Ramone - who no doubt is rolling in his grave. I didn't hear any punk rock music in the film...Four people (two couples) walked out of the movie. One couple left about forty minutes into things (I figured they just didn't get it and were bored). The second couple left after just over an hour - that I didn't get: weren't they interested in how it ended? The theater wasn't crowded it was an evening show on a weekend.

I saw the original the day before I saw the re-make. I thought that nothing could be worse than a woman dancing around her room naked effeminate bartenders and horrible music but I was wrong. I realized I was wrong once Nicholas Cage started punching random women in the face and screaming over a very bad over dub "Ah ouch oh you broke my leg!" It was deplorable! For one thing they totally changed 80% of the original plot line. The lunatic that they had play Rowan's mother was just an excuse to have a minor romantic influence to the horrible recipe that was the movie. Nicholas Cage's voice just doesn't do for the part. He's so breathy and dry that it was difficult to listen to the whole thing. The whole movie went no where and it only got worse and more frustrating at the whole thing played out. No I won't say "play" because play suggests organization. I'll say spewed out. Because that's exactly what it was vomit. Then the whole thing is dedicated to Johnny Ramone. Apparently Nick was really good friends with Ramone and thought that his dead friend a legendary punk rocker deserved this horrible movie in his name. Poor Johnny. I can't even organize any kind of reasonable article for this load of junk. Let me just say see the original maybe and then don't see the re-make. DON'T see the re-make. I wish I could go on a pilgrimage across the US and Germany telling people not to see this excuse for cinema. Thank you Neil LaBute for robbing me of my seven dollars and hour and a half of my life that could have and I would have even preferred to have had been giving birth to a small calf. A small calf that would be more interesting and less painful than watching that pile of ranky stanky vomit.

column4: A lame script badly made into a movie.
column5: The reason I went to see this movie is Nicolas Cage. After his role in The Lord of War I thought - even an horror movie would be OK if he plays there. I was dead wrong. During the entire movie it's clear that the act of the main character cannot be understood and well looks just plain weird. At the end of the movie - you understand why. However the turning point at the end movie is ridiculous. The poor direction takes place in the scene where they all shout: "The victim must die". I would just like to get my two hours back - the movie had no suspense cheap horror tricks doubtful acting and a lame ending. If it's for Nicolas Cage you should go watch Wild At Heart.

column4: the dumbest movie of the year
column5: i can think of no other movie that made less sense this year. while crossover and zoom make take the cake for worst movies of the year this one is definitely the dumbest. with a somewhat descent acting job by Nicholas Cage the movie held for a while and then finally fell very very far from being even recognizable as a movie. with zero substance and zero plot the only parts of the movie that made me feel the slightest bit okay with paying for it was seeing Cage beat the crap out of some ugly girls and then running around in a bear outfit for no explainable reason. while i would have enjoyed seeing more of it and more of Cage just go ballistic on these psychotic women i just didn't care enough by the end of the movie. actually i didn't care throughout most of the movie. it wasn't scary and it scraped the definition of entertaining. all i can say is better luck next time.....

column4: Possibly tbe worst film ever made....
column5: Just terrible and to why they remade this is at best questionable as it was far from a classic. The film is dire and boring...go iron your underwear as that would be a better use of your time!!!!

column4: An astoundingly bland unsubtle common remake of an exceptional classic
column5: It's difficult to approach this movie with total objectivity; images and clips from this 2006 remake of the 1973 classic have spread like wildfire across the Internet in the years since its release. One might reasonably say that in revisiting its progenitor one can at least see where some of those isolated images might seem far more sensible in context - though that doesn't wholly ameliorate the infamy especially given a particular scene of star Nicolas Cage waxing poetic about Apis mellifera. Still one tries to keep an open mind. How bad could this updated version of 'The wicker man' be? Well it's bad enough that even given basic narrative similarities comparisons are pointless. Even from the opening scene it becomes clear that this is far inferior to much of cinema at large let alone its exemplary antecedent.The exposition fifteen whole minutes are completely unnecessary along with that persistent story idea that haunts protagonist Edward thereafter. The dialogue immediately comes across as tired if not hackneyed and characters feel like bland hollow conventional Hollywood thriller figures instead of you know actual people. These same descriptors readily seem to apply to the scene writing and narrative at large and furthermore there are more inclusions than not herein that are wholly arbitrary and pointlessly superfluous. Meanwhile there are some very recognizable and respected names in the cast and I assume that even those I'm less familiar with would demonstrate their capabilities in another picture. Yet pretty much across the board the acting can be described in the same terms: while Cage's career has been revitalized in recent years this title came in the middle of a long slump for him with performances that simply failed to inspire in any number of ways. And so it is Cage and all his co-stars in this instance either over the top or underwhelming with no in-between. To be fair it's just as likely if not more so that the shortcomings can be chalked up to filmmaker Neil LaBute's lackadaisical direction - as stuffily cotton-headed as his writing - as a Bad Day on the part of the actors.All these broad criticisms come to mind well before we're even one-third of the way through the runtime and if anything they only grow more pronounced thereafter. Yet perhaps they can be summarized more neatly: LaBute tried to update a quintessential classic of British and folk horror by giving it the thriller sensibilities of Hollywood genre fare in the late 90s and early 2000s yet these notions plainly oppose and negate each other. Moreover there's not the slightest air of urgency tension suspense or atmosphere to be found here. There's not the slightest trace of subtlety or nuance anywhere to be found least of all in the acting but nor in the writing direction music cinematography editing or anything else. Every measure taken to build the lore and mythology of "Summersisle" feels hopelessly forced and inorganic. To be frank in pretty much every way 2006's 'Wicker man' is almost completely the opposite of the 1973 feature. That was a joyous celebration of life that upended genre assumptions; This is dour and direly humdrum mediocrity that's mostly indistinguishable from most of its contemporaries.For the sake of all the work that went into this and the cast and crew that put in their time I'd love to say I have some baseline level of appreciation for this title. Yet all the best possible value is reduced to ashes in the wake of such roundly poor craft that's effectively the cinematic equivalent of "slash and burn" disallowing any new growth to take hold. It may in actuality have a finite length of just over 100 minutes but 2006's 'The wicker man' is nonetheless one of the longest movies I've ever seen. The extraordinary backhanded slap in the face of "normal society" in 1973 becomes in 2006 bizarre and weak ruminations of cult activity that are somewhat misogynist. The stupendous third act of the 1973 film crafted with loving care and passion and being twisted yet warm and inviting becomes in 2006 a nigh-farcical cavalcade of forthright bombast and heavy-handedness. All the best expectations we might have of the 1973 film sights unseen are met or exceeded; all the worst assumptions we have of the 2006 film are confirmed and somehow fall lower still. It can't be overstated how senseless and flailing this remake is; I feel bad for everyone that was involved and I even feel pity for LaBute that this somehow became the picture that was made.I suppose if one is desperately curious then there's a good reason to watch this provided one is fully aware of what they're getting into. Otherwise 2006's 'The wicker man' is simply to be avoided. What a sad legacy.

column4: Better -- yes better -- than the original
column5: This is the first time I've felt compelled to leave a review due to how far off the existing average score is for this film. Most of the negative reviews come from people who compare this to the "classic" and "perfect" original from which they can't shake their bias.I usually like the original of a movie much better than its remake. I also prefer older movies over current ones. But this one is no contest. Some say Nic Cage over-acts in this film but I find his performance far more relatable than that in the original. The story itself is more interesting minus some predictable cliches among the changes.The second half of the original is mostly just the main character repeatedly being chocked that the island inhabitants aren't Christian and saying "What about Jebus?!".Ignore the other reviews and watch this. Also the alternate/expanded ending which I find to be better.

Didn't even want to give this film 1 - it's truly truly awful. Yes I have seen the original & no I didn't compare them - when I go to see a film I take it as it comes & judge on what I see - not what I've seen before. The script was pathetic the acting even more so - there are so many plot holes whoever wrote the script should go on a very long holiday & never subject the paying public to this rubbish again - the whole film was utter s****! If 'America's' sorry excuse for pagans (sorry but they were terrible) hadn't burnt Nic Cage's character at the end I'd be building a bonfire myself.... I love the experience of going to the cinema but the films this year have been so p***-poor I'm becoming utterly disillusioned. Is this Hollywood's worst year ever?

This is one of the worst movies ever made. I knew that and still watched it for the comedy of watching something so bad. Unfortunately I did not get too much enjoyment even from laughing at it. I was mostly just shocked at how something like this was allowed to happen. I did however enjoy watching the Chris Stuckmann Hilariocity review about this movie. the movie MADE NO SENSE. It was fun making fun of it after. It's not worth watching though just watch Batman and Robin again (1 viewing)

column4: a very good movie! ridiculously underrated
column5: This movie is great i enjoyed every moment. I was shocked to see the ridiculously low rating it has on IMDb i don't care much about all the non significant criteria for professionally criticizing movies cause they are BS what matters is the whole package and by that i don't mean to say that i admin its bad in those criteria i just mean that i don't mind burdening my mind with such useless BS what matters is do i enjoy myself watching the movie or am i bored while watching it or parts of it maybe people hate the movie because the have seen the original and they are unwilling to open their minds to anything different maybe they just see everyone vote low and they are afraid of saying what they think so people want say they are stupid anyway i have seen many movies and almost always movies i thing are very good are also rated very good on IMDb also i am not a professional in cinema (thanks god for that otherwise i would be concentrated on BS non significant intelligent-wannabe criteria other then pure enjoyment)and to my opinion this movie is a beauty! its fun its suspenseful its shivering its surprising (i didn't see the original so didn't know what to expect) and it lives you shocked. and of course i am talking about the whole package (geshtalt style) and not about the different non-significant-by-themselves criteria like acting script sound directing plot character development and cetera and cetera. forgive my spelling i am not native English.

column4: best COMEDY i have ever seen
column5: I absolutely enjoyed reading all of your comments because I had no idea that people could actually take any of this seriously. I have to say that this movie was so disgustingly terrible that it turned out to be wonderfully funny!! I've seen it 5 times now with my friends just for a few  no A lot of laughs!! I've been debating what the worst part is... I'd have to say the script. Me and my friends quote it weekly. It makes me sad that most of you couldn't enjoy the humor of the movie and could only be disappointed. I also would like to say that I would choose the original ending instead of the "surprise alternate ending" on the DVD. Although there are only two differences between the two the differences are CRUCIAL in my opinion. The ending scene in the original ending is my FAVE!!!!!!!!

I really hope people aren't discouraged from watching the original after seeing or hearing about this terrible terrible terrible remake.LaBute should spank himself for not only remaking this film badly but for altering it into a pseudo pagan/feminist stereotype. And posturing the characters and story of this film in some pathetic diatribe that is nothing more than a really poor attempt at a feeble social commentary.This film is a joke. And pooed on the original. I feel violated. So very violated. Bad Neil LaBute bad Nick Cage (and I really liked the Weather Man as well Lord of War wasn't bad either).NOT THE BEEES!!!! AAAAAAHHHH!!!! AHHHHHHAAAHAHAHAHAAAAAAHHHHHH!!!!

column4: Well I thought the movie might be worth something!!
column5: Most of the movie is actually kind of interesting. You know the entire movie that something is going to change. The problem with this movie is that the plot twist is at the end of the movie. The entire movie changes and then ends. I don't want to tell you the ending and spoil it for you. You need to watch this to witness the awful movie that it is. I can't explain how much I hate this movie just because of the last twenty minutes so you have to go watch it. Some of the other people that I watched the movie with said that it wasn't as bad as I thought it was but I really don't understand that concept considering I am in awe of how bad it is. I normally like Nicholas Cage movies but this was definitely the worst movie he has been in. Nicholas Cage did a good job of acting but even his talent couldn't save this masterful crappy movie. Honestly I have no idea how there have two of these movies.
You met your friends at home if you want to watch a funny movie watch this movie it's so ridiculous that you will enjoy watching it.

column4: Not as bad as people say!
column5: I just wanted to ask "xiaoyuboo" first: You pay $11.00 to see a movie? That sucks.Anyways this movie wasn't at all bad like some people have pointed out. True the movie did have its unanswered questions but you have to admit that the acting was good and the ending was really unexpected and (to my point) quite disturbing. Its good but some points are pretty dumb. And the people that lived in the village really angered me. Didn't like them at all one bit! But I guess that's why there were in the movie. I wouldn't go to the point and say "skip this movie" or call it "the worst movie of the year" because there has been some horrible ones! This movie IS NOT (and I repeat) IS NOT A "WORST MOVIE" movie. Its one of those "alright" movies. I give it a 5/10.

...because I can't have my time back. I'm glad that I saw "The wicker man" 1973 first. But that made the film from 2006 even worse... Well I was warned everybody told me that I should stop after seeing 1973 one 'coz remake is a crap. Curiosity won. and killed the cat. and two hours of my life. i don't understand this - both films had big stars the same idea money. How the first one can be so logic scary and great and the second one so pooooor? In the middle of the film I started to suspect that director didn't understand "The wicker man" at all. He changed few things - essential ones. I gave 2 because it was still better that the movie of Cradle of Filth...

column4: Can't complain had his chance and in modern parlance blew it.
column5: I love the original film though I accept that it's got a very particular sensibility that is quite unique to the time and place it was made. I had never prior to this weekend seen the remake knowing that the reviews were scathing and not needing to risk tarnishing my feelings about the original. However "How Did This Get Made" did the film and so I decided it was finally time to take the plunge - it's awful.A policeman Edward Malus (Nicholas Cage) is called to a remote island off Washington State at the request of his ex-fiancé Willow (Kate Beahan). Willow's daughter Rowan (Erika Shaye Gair) has gone missing though Willow suspects that she is still on the island and that the secretive pagan cult that control it has something to do with her disappearance. As Edward arrives he meets a baffling array of characters that despite proof to the contrary refuse to acknowledge than Rowan even existed.I should say first that I watched the theatrical cut of the film on Amazon Prime so got the James Franco postscript but was cruelly denied "The Bees. The Bees" scene that has become the films most iconic moment.I don't think I buy into the idea that was proposed after the fact that the film is an absurdist black comedy. I just think that so many moments of it are horribly misjudged. In sticking to the overall story of the original any tension is taken away as I knew what the resolution of the film was at least likely to be. Knowing that does make some aspects of the film make a little less sense they do seem to put Malus in real jeopardy at times and it's only through luck that he makes it though. The pagan aspect of the original is largely replaced by the idea of a matriarchal society with the Bee motive hammering that home further. The film does feel a little American puritanical in that regard which is ironic given the themes.As I say I don't buy that black comedy idea I just think that it's a really awkward film. Often the interactions between Cage and the other characters are just the wrong side of bizarre a beat held a bit too long an unneeded clarification "Not tomorrow the day after today". Then it's patently hilarious on the three occasions he flat out punches a woman in the face as hard as he can or spin kicks Leelee Sobieski into a wall.It is I have to say at least entertainingly bad and not just boring but the original is far superior.

column4: lamest thing i have ever seen
column5: yeah i saw this dumb movie today and i was like this is 1 weird 2 boring and it had a lot of cussing...to me.... and it was all about cults of women and it didn't even creep me out and it wasn't even shocking at the end i was expecting a shocking ending but there was nothing there.. they just made him come to the island and the girl was alive after all wow what a horrible film come on i could do better than that...i hate Nicholas cage in the first place he is a horrible actor he is extremely boring and stuff but yeah i would not recommend this film to anyone that even likes Nicholas cage. i really hated it with passion it was horrible at the end they try to kill him and that is just mean. how could you do that to a person? his wife was kind of hot though. but she was very weak as a person but hey! she was hot nobody cares about this film so don't go and see it please take my word for it!!!

Well The Wicker man. Lets see well to start with they had Nick Cage in it so everyone was going oh yea thats good right. WRONG. There was actually no need to make this at all the original was made in the 70s and it suits the 70s very weird and VERY DIFFERENT but this remake it really just turned it in to a stupid horror mystery the legendary Christopher Lee replaced by Ellen Burstyn (nothing against her) its just why????? they also stuck in a cruddy back story about a "iffy" car crash. Acting is so-so Cage isn't that bad(!) whilst everyone else sort of floated around in the background doing nothing. Whilst the stupid love story added some boring sub-plot. Hey and is it just Cage are can we all survive being in cold water for over 12 hours and still manage to smash down the doors of most of the houses and trail through the woods. Hey they still managed to fit some of the new horror and mystery movie films classic dialogue "something bad is gonna happen i can feel it" SNOR! The ending had NO shock value what-so ever in the original it generally scared me. this i laughed (terrible i know) but it was just so bad. But generally this is just a bad stupid and OTT remake. I really don't recommend it. Sit down and watch the original far more enjoyable!

I saw this film last weekend as part of a triple feature at my local drive-in. I did not pay attention to the TV commercials and I am so glad. Not having read any reviews or even knowing what it was about was an advantage for me. The only thing I knew about WickerMan was that it was a thriller with Nicholas Cage. Since I like most of his movies I gave it a try. My mind (for this movie) was a clean slate and really soaked up the eerie world of Summersisle. I enjoy Cage's acting and certainly felt for the plight of his character. IMO the acting highlight of Wickerman was Leelee Sobieski. I hadn't even heard of her before seeing the credits for this film. Her performance stood out and commanded my attention whenever she was on the screen. I'll certainly be looking for her work in the future.If the point of the story is to creep you out and cover you with an eerie and disturbing mood- then it worked on me! The entire presentation gave me a bad dream kind of feeling. The entire film held my attention from the opening scene to the epilogue. IMO it is a very well told story. I don't know if this version tops the original but it is certainly on top of my 'creepy movie' list. If you like weird scary creepy tales- this one is for you.

column4: Is that a pig roast? No but close.
column5: No. Don't buy it don't rent it don't pay per view it and don't even waste two hours of your life watching it on some late night movie channel like I did.It certainly has a few good parts even some funny "fight" scenes. Nicholas Cage is a good actor and while it might not seem so he plays his part well. He maintains the demeanor of a cop writing a speeding ticket throughout the whole film. Unfortunately this is perfectly annoying. I grew up around them all I know.The ending is god awful I won't give it away but you will hate it. This is coming from a guy who likes almost everything Shyamalan has done. It's one of those things you'll guess to yourself five minutes into the movie and then discard because your dog has had more creative ideas licking himself.If you liked The Skeleton Key ending then watch this it's only slightly worse but please off yourself immediately afterwards for our sake. If enough of the target idio-I mean audience- for these types of movies is sacrificed maybe no one will make them anymore.

column4: The Wicker Man is on a whole different level of entertainment.
column5: The infamous remake that defines the "so-bad-it's-good" type of film. The internet phenomenon that produced two of the greatest memes to have ever graced our monitors. The start of Cage's downfall into lunacy and madness solidifying his name as a legend. Nicolas Cage gives birth to "Cage Rage". You've all seen the reviews. You are all aware of its status as being one of the worst remakes of all time. Neo-paganism makes a full comeback as a police officer investigates a missing girl case on a mysterious island where women after named after plants and bees are everywhere. And yes this film is terrible. Inept. Catastrophically tame. Absurdly non-sensical. The script is atrocious and the horrifically exaggerated performances of monotony and craziness only adds to this detrimental...thing. I have no need to review this my opinion will not enlighten you with wonderment. Yet I found myself entranced. I'm putting it on record that I enjoyed The Wicker Man. For all the wrong reasons sure. But its unintentional humour made for one of the best viewing experiences I've had in quite some time. So. Many. Laughs. A colleague stating "I heard you are resigning?" to then immediately ask "so you are going for the detective position?". Cage maniacally running around the island for a good five minutes. "How'd it get burnt?...How'd it get burnt? HOW'D IT GET BURNT!?". Cage dressed in a bear costume galloping to a woman and punching her in the face. "I'm a police officer see my badgeeee!". Cage is coincidentally allergic to bees and runs through a bee farm. Everything is a hexagon. "Colony". Dream-caption. "Not the bees! No! Ahhhh! My eyes! My eyessssahshlahsha!". Phew I'm done. This this is just a thing of beauty. It's so damn good and I don't even care. The most shocking claim I shall make is it's not the worst film I've seen. In fact it's not getting my worst rating (due to some scenes genuinely holding my attention). This has absolutely nothing on the original and advise you watch that. Still God damn loved this.

column4: Like Open Water without the water. Or the sharks.
column5: The beginning has an average sort of feel it's Cage he's a cop it's been done. What follows is a near excellent build up the plot is laid out with an original setting and just enough intrigue. Cage fits the protagonist role very well but I suspect any actor with a hint of ability could have been cast for the other characters they're all the same - which seems to be deliberate - but they're also all shallow and dull. I personally perceived it to be essentially a sound attempt at a Depp style chiller/thriller and I'm very disappointed that somebody of extreme poor judgement chose to give it a pointless twist that poses a lot of important questions that will never be answered. To avoid spoilers let's just say my reference to Open Water in the title is well chosen. Oh wait is that a spoiler anyway? Lets have more Sleepy Hollows and less of these Pan's Labyrinths vote with your wallets.

Crap absolute crap. Are some of you feminists happy now? What has happened here? Are some people so anti-male that garbage like this has to be made? My fantasy ending is that a few months after the ending of the worst film of last year the damn women of this island are gleefully exterminated by the likes of Kiriyama Satomi and Kitano - see Battle Royale - and bloody EXTERMINATED WITHOUT MERCY. They ought to annihilate the brat bitches in the school wipe out that damn teacher butcher the twins blast the other women and men and burn that damn leader of theirs - after hanging her. Avoid at all costs skip this film when you see on TV and stomp on the DVD cover at your favorite BlockBuster. Do not see this movie.

column4: a police officer witnesses a horrible car accident that begins a crazy journey to discover the possible whereabouts and reason for this accident
column5: I thought the movie was very good. I have not seen the original and did not know what to expect. From the trailer i was expecting just another scary movie. As i went into the theater expecting something entirely different then i had when i came out. At first it would seem that you had the movie figured out and then there was another twist that made you wonder if your conclusion was correct and then it satisfied it in the end by reaffirming your conclusion but not in the way you thought it would. Nicolas Cage is in my opinion a relatively bland actor but the intensity and attention to detail throughout the rest of the movie makes up for that. I enjoyed this movie and am interesting in doing more research upon a second watching.

column4: Who's looking a fool now... or should I say bear!!
column5: Loved the original looked forward to the remake... It's awful.The screenwriter's thought process is clunkingly obvious... change Summerisle's harvest to Honey and hey presto let's make the hero allergic to bees! Have him experience a horrific event at the start and hey presto you can throw in loads of flashbacks to jolt the viewer from their slumbers. Include also the most embarrassingly obvious 'Don't Look Now' reference ever ( Nic Roeg must find it all hilarious or utterly depressing!) and this viewer was longing to see the original again. Nothing against the director he has a good track record BUT he can't do creepy! This should have been remade by the team behind British comedy series The League of Gentleman... it would have been freaky! Instead we get Nic Cage dressed in a bear Suit (get it? the honey connection? Whoever wrote this is a genius!). Christopher Lee and Robin Hardy must be laughing their heads off it's great publicity for their original and I look forward to their planned sequel of sorts 'Cowboys for Christ'.So in summary this remake proves that the original film was a true one off just like that final shot of the wicker man's head bowing to the sunset on cue! Who needs CGI eh?

Unnecessary remake of an old horror film that in my opinion still manages to entertain well even if there are many plot holes and many unnecessary passages that make the film confusing and meaningless in many places.

column4: Watching This Movie Won't Bring Back Your Honey!
column5: Without question 'The Wicker Man' is one of the best most hilariously awful movies I have ever seen. Most of the movie consists of Nicholas Cage wandering around with aimless direction stopping only to showcase moments of confusion stupidity and pointlessness. Indeed 'The Wicker Man' thrusts all of these feelings directly into the viewer granting the unprivileged of us the unique sensation of being lobotomized. It's not all bad though. The movie draws a lot of unintentional laughs thanks to the sheer absurdity of a few scenes.The only real shame that comes from 'The Wicker Man' is that there isn't a show like 'Mystery Science Theater 3000' to lampoon this little gem.

I hadn't seen the original (else it now seems I might have walked out of this remake) so I had no expectations but I was still disappointed. Cage was unconvincing even for a stupid motorcycle cop (an insulting idea in itself); he never asked an intelligent question. The actress who played Willow was dreadful(her bee-stung lips distractingly annoying) and her character's shenanigans were obvious from the start . The dialogue was ridiculous. And what was with Burstyn's squared-off teeth? (Do queen bees have lips?)About the only thing worth watching was the scenery. And even that has been done better in postcards.

column4: A remake of an old classic
column5: Firstly I'd like to say this is nowhere near a scratch on the original but having read the other views about being a terrible film or the worst film ever I'd like to defend it slightly. If we take the fact away that it was a remake of a classic and stood it in the light apart from the original then it's certainly not total crap. it's average border lining on OK. The story is OK it holds your attention it's never going to win any awards but maybe some of the younger readers who haven't seen the original might like it. There are far worse films even remakes which this Wicker Man is better than. Overall nothing too thrilling but a mediocre film.

column4: For all the hate this film got i personally found it to be a decent enough Chiller even if nothing great.
column5: Nicolas Cage is a great actor FACT!!!! But like most he doesn't always star in great films but he does always commit to give a solid performance no matter what type of film it is & here he does deliver again a solid & decent performance in the role of a Detective that goes to a mysterious & isolated island to in search of a missing little girl well you know the story it's the same as the 70's Cult Classic!!!!Cage ends up at that weird island with it's weird cult of freaky people especially the women!!!!What i found in this remake was a very freaky mood & atmosphere & the people are genuinely weird & location is very creepy because of it's loneliness & isolation from "normal" civilization. These are freaky Cultists & the uneasiness is felt as soon as Cage arrives & you can feel that no one is what they seem & there's a thick mood of strangeness all the way through this creepy Thriller. Now i know it's no Cult Classic or a loved film at all but i enjoyed most of it to be honest & i felt for Cage's tormented Detective as he tries & tries to get answers about this little girl but everywhere he turns he gets weirdness & Cage is on fine form & i enjoyed it when he finally has enough of the weirdo's & starts to get angry & kick some ass!!!The ending is still a nasty ending & yes there's those damb bees lol but it's still tragic ending that still shocks or it did in my opinion.Instead ripping this solid movie apart like everyone else just watch it for yourself you may enjoy it?A Decent enough remake of an overrated cult flick & we get a solid Cage & a creepy atmosphere. Yes nothing spectacular but decent enough even if that ending is abit too nasty & cruel for my liking.

column4: Just a slight spoiler. If you've seen the original film don't bother with this one. A film ostensibly about a love gone wrong and a missing child.
column5: This is certainly not a thinking person's film. I haven't been to a good scary movie in a long time and now I remember why. It is really difficult to make a good scary film. This film is poorly directed and barely plausible - even for the genre it is in. I was offended by the choppy editing and the inability of the director to keep us in suspense. M Night Shamylan (not sure of spelling) could probably do this right! After a while I wondered why Nicholas Cage took this role. What was he thinking?? I was offended by the way the women in the film were portrayed - even within the context of the story. Mostly I was bored.

Have you seen it? No? There is likely a very good reason for that...it stinks.Like nearly ALL the endless remakes and reboots that have been plaguing movie goers for the past decade or so....all this is is a heartless version of the original.It has no heart.It has no soul.It is a retelling of a film that we all love and cherish...and it adds nothing to the story. It improves nothing but the special effects--which held up very well over time--and in some cases belittles the fans of the original...particularly in the fact that they remade the movie at all without adding anything clever to it.Like so many other remakes it is a hallow shell of the original.

I've heard much about this film most of it scathingly negative. I myself watched it with an open mind & afterwards can confirm it's not nearly as bad as made out. Now as of writing this review I have not seen the 1973 Original with the late Christopher Lee yet but plan to do so soon after.The film follows a Deputy Sherriff Edward Malus who after suffering from a traumatic event involving a mother & daughter getting hit by a lorry & burned to death gets sent a letter from his Ex-Fiancé Willow stating that their daughter Rowan has gone missing. This prompts Edward to head off to a remote but private island off the mainland to look for her but the investigation starts to reveal that all isn't what it seems & a dark revelation involving Edward is about to be revealed...!I found the film to be alright it's not amazing by any means but it's watchable. Now like I said above I haven't seen the 1973 Original so I can't exactly compare but can say that in it's OWN merit it's ok.Most of the film focuses on the investigation with Edward getting ever frustrated with the locals & their eccentric ways/beliefs as he tries to do his job as a detective. Not a great deal of action is seen until the last 5 minutes but the film does keep you interested as more bizarre & weird goings on occur making you want to watch till the very end of the film.With a runtime of 93 minutes this is alright however the film does feel longer at points with the pacing being just a tad off here & there. But it's not overly long for what it is & does what it does for the time given. The twist at the end was pretty good and pretty much the only high light of the film sadly. You so feel sorry for Edward at the end & I hoped some other twist would come around at the last minute sadly it didn't.Overall it's an alright watch watch & in its own merit is a ok & watchable film. 5/10.

Last night I watched "The Wicker Man" which now I belatedly found out is being vilified as one of the worst films in history. You know OK the dialog was cheesy... there were plenty of unexplainable plot points... the character of Nic Cage had to wear a bear costume hit and karate kick women.... But overall it isn't that bad... I would not call it the worst movie I watched this year. Since I haven't had the chance to watch the original 1973 film on which this was based the main story was OK. Maybe my opinion will change if I get to watch the original? Anyway even worse movie I have seen this year were "Lady in the Water" and "Little Man".

Nic Cage made a terrible decision acting in this Awful movie. Worst movie I have ever seen. We decided to see it when we were late for Invincible. What a bad choice. Thats two hours we will never get back! That will probably be the last movie I will go see in the theater in a while. I have lost a lot of respect for the Movie Industry for allowing this movie to go to Theatres. Bad choice! Now when he punched out that lady that must of been the only good thing about this movie. Not saying punching women is a good thing but hey she had it coming and the movie needed some excitement. Two Big Thumbs Down! Maybe Cage can concentrate on the circus or being a mascot after he did such a great job in that stupid bear costume. A better ending would of been if a suname wiped out the Island of morons.

If you are interested in seeing this movie because the trailer looked really good then please for the love of God DO NOT SEE THIS MOVIE.It's nothing like the trailer and this movie has so many plot holes that you'll definitely want your money back! I don't recommend this movie at all unless you watch it as a really bad B-level comedy (like Scary Movie) and it's free.Do not pay to watch this because according to the commentary the director says (at the end of the movie) that he doesn't care if you liked it because he's already got your money.Again it is nothing like the cool trailer you've been warned.

column4: I joined This Site After Watching This Movie To Warn People!!!
column5: I have always been a fan of IMDb and made a huge mistake when I paid for this movie on pay-per-view before reading the reviews. Honestly I have seen some bad movies before and this is absolutely the worst I have seen. I have seen "B" movies better than this crap it is just scary how bad this movie is and makes no sense at all.Anyway if you feel like wasting money today go ahead and get this but at least I warned you. Anyone here who gave this movie more than a 1 has another agenda because there is no reason what so ever to do so. I can't believe they actually released this either they had to be on crack.

All I can say is thank goodness I didn't watch this in the theater or I might have asked for my money back! Let's start with the beginning which in my opinion was the coolest part of the movie. So Nicholas Cage is going up to the car on the side of the road when...WHAM!!! Disaster strikes the car....cool right? Unfortunately it has absolutely NOTHING AT ALL to do with the rest of the movie in my opinion. Even if it was just to set up that he was going crazy it still didn't fit with anything else.Did it remind anyone else of the opposite of Stepford wives only REALLY REALLY poorly done?!

Most fanatics of the original seem to be having a difficult time seeing how good this movie is. I prefer it to the original which seems to have been made for college pot-heads. This remake was more clear. The acting was great as was the setting. The humor was in fact intentional. The ending was amazing much like the original only without a bunch of drunken B-list actors singing some goofy song.I think (in fact I know from the reaction of people I was with in the theater) that people who have never seen the original -- and that's a lot of people -- will enjoy this very interesting and beautifully made movie.Thank you for making this much needed remake.

column4: I don't know what to write on the headline
column5: The plot of the movie was basic but interesting. I have to admit I had high expectations about the movie eventually it wasn't good. The characters and the casting were good. The storyline was nice but after the first 30 minutes it was weird and kinda silly. The filming location of the movie was so good. Also sometimes the movie had some similarities with the movie "Midsommar" (2016). Anyway it wasn't a perfect movie just watchable. Moreover the only thing I didn't understand about the movie was the meaning of the bees (because they were used a lot in the movie).

I watched this back to back with the superior original 1973 version. Its underrated and definitely not as bad as it's reputation. It stays close enough to the original screenplay with a few updates and twists. The 1973 version is obviously the clear winner out of the 2 but there is still a good film here to be rediscovered. I believe the movie has fallen victim to bad overexposure via online reviews and YouTubers that tend to copy each other and follow a trend of burying films over minor issues. Yes everyone knows the now infamous "not the bees" scene and the 2 scenes where Nicolas Cage kicks and punches 2 women...but really are these moments really sooo jaw dropping that you have to make an entire video about them? The aforementioned scenes amount to 10 seconds and are what the entire movie is usually made fun about and judged for. The performance by Nicolas Cage is corky and a bit over the top...but it's Nicolas Cage we are talking about..that's his style of acting while unusual as always it's solid.

This movie was absolutely horrible. I don't know whatCage was thinking about when he made it. I hope he was paid very well!!!! Men seeing this ---- will look at the worst in women ---- It was sick!!!! I have never seen a movie belittle women the way this belittled men.If someone saw something else let me know!! Say a slap in the face to all Muslims etc.I am horrified ---- I hope this movie hits the producer where it hurts!!! It needs to flop!!!!!I am very disappointed.

Saw this film a long time ago and was slightly impressed. Saw the original decades ago and was not impressed in any good way. I rewatched both the original from 1973 which blew me awayand then this remake. I am isolating during this pandemic and must work hard to maintain interest in life. I had to pay $ in order to see them. Money well spent. I think it was simply ahead of its time. It's an excellent scary film

It would seem to me that the people who trashed Wicker Man as one of the worst movies ever made were not taking their daily dose of anti-depressants. Sure I read many user comments and then I rented the DVD and watched the movie. Sure you might not like Nicolas Page but hey come on there's nothing wrong with the movie. One user says Wicker Man was not mysterious or suspenseful. Sure every community has an island like this so what's the big deal eh? Has any one here read Shirley Jackson's "The Lottery"? I suppose some of you didn't like it because things happen that make no sense and are unexplained. Wow....I didn't think WIcker Man was the best movie I ever watched but it certainly did what it was supposed to do. It showed me one weird place with a group of messed up people. One user said the dialogue was ridiculous. Have you ever spoken with a messed up person? I found the dialogue very close to the reality of a very troubled mind. I think it is sad that a lot of people just seemed to have had a mental breakdown because they watched Wicker MAn 2006. Again if you're not taking your medication don't watch the movie.

column4: Abhorrent horror remake provokes far more laughter than scares
column5: Neil LaBute's re-imagining of the 1973 classic horror serves as just another representation of horror remakes falling deeply interior in their original outing with scares that more often than provoke unintentional laughter than spine chills; and not in an effective way incorporated in comedy-horror hybrids. The film never rises at the surface level of the cinematically inept and instead relies heavily on a poorly executed plot and a script that falls shallow of nuance but feels sorely miscalculated at the point of leaving the average scratching their head pondering "What was director LaBute thinking?". And a laughably incompetent performance uprooted by Nicolas Cage certainly doesn't do much justice. So this film follows Seattle police officer Edward Malus (played by Nicolas Cage) recovering from an horrendous when he is informed by his ex-wife Willow Woodard (played by Kate Beahan) that her daughter Rowan has gone missing. This lead Edward on the investigation to a mysterious island for the missing girl but discovers the island inhabited by individuals of a mysterious paganistic cult lead by Sister Summersisle (played by Ellen Burstyn) who apparently represents the goddess. Upon learning the nefarious dangers of the cult Edward must discover the terrifying their terrifying secret and save the little girl from the sinister cult.After sitting through an hour of this I honestly could have not tell if this film was supposed to be dark comedy or just a poorly conceived supernatural horror flick. Though it supposedly falls in the latter category it really makes you wonder if its possible the movie suffers from a identity crisis. Why is this? The poster showing a terrifying Exorcist-like image of the little girl leads you to believe you're for a spine-chilling thriller but Neil LaBute's misguided direction proves otherwise. As the film deals with the lead character investigating an island influenced by paganism and practice human sacrifices for reasons vaguably explained. The idea would be interesting enough if the story actually took the time to vividly explain some of the concepts other than occasional commentary on the Salem Witch Trials or maybe if the plot made much sense before descending into a misguided mess. While the first film put religious conflict as the central theme of it's plot this installment replaces the theme with women rebelling against men which frankly fails work here. The idea is is profoundly interesting on paper but when Neil LaBute's translates it on screen it results in 102-minutes of unintentional comedy and lack of scares. From there on we are forced to endure a plot that not only grows silly before the first hour but also an over-the-top performance by Nicolas Cage who's scenes of hollering at Kate Beahan are painfully unconvincing and scenes of his character being threatened by a crowd of pagans that don't even amount to the slightest suspense. And it doesn't certainly doesn't help that his character is poorly drawn engages in cheesy and takes a hateful audacity of hitting women in multiple scenes.The Wicker Man is sorely incompetent remake of the 1973 horror classic with nothing to offer but a sheer lack of authenticity and scares. This film is laughably bad to the point of only being worth enjoying on a guilty pleasure level. But if you are looking for a good horror film with good scares and plenty of smarts you are probably best looking further. For a list of the worst movies of 2006 this one definitely fills in a position.

column4: wtf...did we see the same movie????
column5: i think that people should understand that a movie should be able to entertain...well guess what i was. OK i ll agree that this remake isn't bether than the original one it surly isn't Oscar material and the acting wasn't either. you would expect more from such a cast.but if you haven't seen the original and you don't have the opportunity to do so its worth a rent. actually its worth a rent either ways. i mean if you say that this is the worse movie you have ever seen you haven't seen nothing. it isn't a great movie surly it isn't gonna be a classic but it ain't the worst. normally i would give it a 6 out of tenbut in this case ill give it a 10 out of 10 just to even the score.ps. sry for my grammar

column4: Don't u even think about paying 4 this movie!!
column5: I've seen an comment about this movie before I go see it and I did't believe it ;it was said that it's awful but I wanted to see for myself..so I went. BIG mistake!!!!!!!!And I also went with another 5 friends;we all have the same opinion: it's WORST MOVIE EVER! The producers probably run out of imagination as they were writing this story .It has no thrillno real storyand instead of a thriller u will get a comedybecause U will find it amusing at some point. I don't know what was in Nicolas Cage's mind to accept to play in this kind of movie?! If u're thinking about going on this moviewell DON'T! Trust me! U will want your money back!

I am wincing in pain. I feel robbed. I feel like a small period of my life was laid waste by the absolute pointlessness of this cinematic vomit. I honestly cannot understand why anyone would want to do such a thing.A remake is occasionally excusable for instance if the original is interesting but technically lacking or damaged by time or knee-deep in cultural references which nobody understands anymore.None of those things is true of the original Wicker Man. The references are drawn primarily from Frazer's seminal work on folklore The Golden Bough (more readily available today than it was when the movie was made). The print of the film is maybe a little grainy but rich in texture and captures the beauty of the Scottish Islaes in a way few films before or since have done. And the original boasts career-best performances from Edward Woodward and Christopher Lee (even the generally poor Britt Ekland is rather good in that film).Any excuse offered for this nonsense is inadequate. The remake rips great chunks of the original only ineptly insert them into a hokey horror movie with ridiculous "modernizing" touches (like a female Summerisle) and pathetically obvious references (like the character names being taken from the actors in the original film).It looks pretty good if film stock is one's measure of a good film. But why add FX? Why add back story? Why does the copper have to have an ex there for him to get all worked up? It's so transparently trying too hard.And failing.Horribly.Every single leaden step of the way.(For additional perspective here are some pertinent remarks from my daughter a mini film critic.)For a start no effects needed on this movie. There were NO FX on the original none needed either. Instead of best performances there were possibly worst! The whole "Oo I'm scary" thing is ludicrous. The Wickerman is not scary. It is in the sense that you would never want to meet any of the people on that island but horror? Please!

Leveling off at an extremely chilly 14% approval rating on Rottentomatoes.com THE WICKER MAN got pummeled by critics large and small. Some called it "over-the-top" while others mentioned its unbelievability factor. Both criticisms are correct but that doesn't mean that The Wicker Man isn't a guilty pleasure for some viewers ...like me.Nicholas Cage (WORLD TRADE CENTER) stars as Officer Edward Malus a beat cop who one day stops a car that had a doll fall from its window while speeding along a desolate highway. When Edward returns the doll the little girl in the back seat again tosses it back onto the road. Edward goes to pick it up again and while he's scooping it up a semi smashes into the car on the shoulder eventually killing both the driver/mother and the daughter in the backseat.Haunted by this horrible event Officer Malus seeks refuge at home whenever he can. But a letter soon arrives from a lost love named Willow (Kate Beahan) beckoning him to come to her at a place called Summersisle in Washington State. The letter goes on to say that Willow has had a child named Rowan (Erika-Shaye Gair RV) that has mysteriously disappeared.Once on the island of Summersisle Edward quickly surmises that all is not right here. Women rule the place and the few men present are docile. He also notes (with a hint of sarcasm) the tree-ish first names of all its residents (the aforementioned Rowan and Willow along with Beech and several other colorful names).Willow Edward's lost love finally tells him that Rowan is his daughter thus pumping up his need to find her dead or alive.As the minutes tick by Edward discovers a strange cult-like following almost Druid in fashion that stretches from one end of this small island to the other. Was Rowan a victim of some sort of ritualistic demagoguery? Was she sacrificed and burned alive? Nicholas Cage has never been one of my favorite actors but he is entertaining at times. His part in LORD OF WAR was one of his more recent acting successes. Here in The Wicker Man he's entertaining too if often times a bit over the top (as the critics have pointed out...the obvious part being the now infamous bee helmet scene where he screams "What is that?! Oh bees! Bees! They're in my eyes!").Probably the biggest boost for the film is that its pacing is done pretty well gradually ratcheting up the tension as the story progresses. The ending is also a bit of a shocker especially the leg breaking scene that nearly made me nauseous and brought to memory the Kathy Bates bit in MISERY.The whole premise however is pretty faulty. The Druids never made it to America but some of their fans certainly did later on (much later on). There's also the fact that Edward (Cage) is a cop and if a cop went missing for any length of time people would start looking and asking questions.Even so if you force yourself to ignore these blatant oversteps you might find The Wicker Man a guilty pleasure like chocolate syrup on a rapidly melting sundae.P.S. Much has been made of the fact that this film is a remake of Anthony Shaffer's 1973 film by the same name starring Christopher Lee and Edward Woodward. Not having seen this version I can only comment on the story seen in this updated version

I truly don't understand how this movie has such a low rating. This is an entirely competent film with an intriguing mystery that keeps you involved throughout well-executed cinematography and with competent-to-really-good acting. Nick Cage's funny moments have been blown out of proportion for this film; there really are only about two moments in the whole movie where he acts in a very goofy manner that breaks the tension. Otherwise he really does a great job in the role. This movie is certainly not bad and in fact is fairly good. If you want to know what a bad movie is watch Angry Asian Murder Hornets-then come say this is a 3.

This film fully believed itself to be mysterious and disturbing yet as it went on I began to question whether or not it actually meant to be mocking its own actors and their scripts or was going on in total sincerity. Kate Beahan's rambling unconnected lines were indisputably straight from one of the popular Scary Movie comedies which are MTV type mockeries of modern-day thrillers. A few chuckles in the beginning lead you to think the movie is about to get somewhere but just when it starts to get going is when it starts getting bad. As soon as he arrives on the island it plummets to the level of a grade school film project. The efforts it makes in being haunting and mysterious are painfully embarrassing. Half way through I began looking around at others in the theater wondering if they were as disturbed as I was by the fact that such respected actors as Nicolas Cage and Ellen Burstyn agreed to do this film after reading the script. The cinematography was clunky the timing and rhythm was completely off the music score and lack of was confusing when matched with the scenes and the casting was just bad. If there was any good acting in it I didn't notice being distracted by the laughable lines and strange concoction of the island and its inhabitants. Odd moments kept popping up here and there such as a random and unexplained kiss between Nicolas Cage's character and Kate Beahan's - just to name one of many. Plus we could have been given the story with just the beginning and end as the middle part of the movie did nothing to push it along. It gave no revealing hints to entice us or keep us guessing. However it wasn't that necessary to have hints with such a predictable ending. This movie goes in the hall of fame of unintentionally hysterical films. So bravo filmmakers I'll never forget this one.

This was simple dreadful. To take an excellent thoughtful and genuinely scary film and to create this hash from it is blasphemous.Where it kept to the same lines as the original it was always outshone. On every level it was unable to generate the creepy suspenseful feel of the original. In the original one could believe Summerisle existed it was on the surface normal it was what was underneath that menaced. In this version everything was unreal (and thus unthreatening) from the start.Where the film deviated from the original it normally debased itself. The gratuitous violence and CGI did nothing to save it.The acting was uniformly porcine but perhaps we were able to sense the guilt the actors had when they realised what they were doing

Okay so if you compare this to the original film then of course you will be severely disappointed. However I don't think it warrants the bad reviews it has received. If you can treat this movie as a piece of film-making in it's own right then it becomes a passable composition.Cage is (as always) Cage and you get some reasonable performances from the supporting cast it's a shame they decided to re-film it in the States as opposed to the Scottish Highlands as I think the highlands have a lot more feel about them. If the original location had been kept then I believe the movie may have been more atmospheric and the mood would have suited the genre better.All in all never gonna be in anybody's top 20 but it ain't THAT bad!!!

column4: This movie made me so mad I wanted to punch a baby!
column5: (SPOILER ALERT!!)OK first of all there are some of you that said this was the worst movie that either you have ever seen or that has been EVER MADE. Well I certainly understand your feelings on the issue. However I don't think it was the WORST movie I have ever seen ONLY because it arose so much ANGER in me.
