The unintentional humor was definitely beyond my expectations. Worth a watch with a good group of people that can all make fun of Nic Cage. There's almost no value to the rest of the film. But so long as you can watch ol Nicky and make fun of his role the overall film and his incredibly bad acting you're in for a good time.

column4: I have enjoyed bouts of food poisoning more than this movie.
column5: This is without a doubt one of the worst movie's of all time.I have not felt more depressed after a Nicholas Cage movie since "Leaving LasVegas" but for much different reasons. At least the subject matter of "Leaving Las Vegas" is what left me feeling depressed after leaving the theater unlike this movie that left me feeling depressed that I had wasted $9 of my money and 2 hours of my life that I can never get back.The only upsides were seeing the beautiful Leelee Sobieski in another roll and Nicholas Cage's typical sarcastic remarks that are good for a laugh from time to time. Other than that this movie is an utter waste of time.

column4: Enjoyable if you don't attempt to take it seriously
column5: I liked this movie just because it was "pretty" to watch - great scenery I loved the beauty of the surroundings & the characters & costumes were colorful. It had a great cast. The plot itself is pretty silly & does not really hold up even for what it is but I do think that it was supposed to be funny. I do not believe these people were so stupid that they thought this was horror. I like Nicholas Cage but cannot remember a single good movie he played in this was so predicable that the only thing that surprises you is that it was too easy you expected just a little twist.... I would still recommend it if you just want to be entertained for an hour or so I have seen LOTS of MUCH WORSE movies that were taken seriously. Always ignore critics.

column4: You see kids this is why you pay your taxes....
column5: Wow. My wife and I just sat through this nonsense on Netflix. My lovely wife loves Mr. Cage but oh my what a piece of dung. More than anything this film makes no sense! What the heck were they thinking? Nic won an Oscar for crying out loud and he is reduced to this mess. One positive is his what must be intentional over acting. He really takes it over the top in this one. He has plenty of company in this train wreck however as everyone has taken the script to 11. Movies like this always have my wonder how folks get mixed up in movies this bad. I mean Cage is taking anything and everything for a while now to get the IRS off his back but who read this thing as was like oh yeah this looks awesome. I don't have to worry about spoilers because I can't give any. I have no idea what this film is about do yourself a solid and stay away.

The movies is a waste of time and money. I've wasted 2 hours of my life with this and I regret it more than anything!!! Hope other people will be better inspired then me and avoid watching this movie. It's by far the worst movie that I've ever saw. I hate it and i don't recommend anyone to view this movie it's a waste of time a waste of time I tell you. I could stare a white wall all day long and it will not compare with this waste of time. I think Nicolas Cage was short on money... that's why he accepted this role in this crappy movie. I pity him I really do. I pity me for watching this movie. I pity all of you out there who watched this movie and I pity all of those who will watch this crap... cause it's crap not a movie. Sorry for my pour English. Cheers.

It is a shame that a wonderful actor such as Nicholas Cage has been involved in some bad movies for the last couple of years been "The Wicker Man" one of them."The Wicker Man" flaws are its weak characters a predictable plot (but yet the ending is not what you would expect) silly costumes and self-indulgent acting. I was eager to see the movie because of the cast (Ellen Burstyn for one) and because it was featured as a scary movie; I guess my expectations were too high.I consider this one of the worst movies I have ever seen. I just wish Nicholas Cage starts picking up better movies because I like to see him on the big screen.

column4: One of the BEST comedies you will ever see.
column5: This movie sets the new standards for how comedies are supposed to be made. Forget Animal House and Porky's this is a new classic comedy. The lines are unforgettable and Nic Cage as a bear will have you on the floor in tears. This is a MUST SEE for all comedy lovers. The set for the movie is simple young girl goes missing cop goes to a mysterious island Nic Cage gets attacked by bees and punches women HOW could it get better than that. Truly a masterpiece in the comedic arts. Also (SPOILER) he gets burned alive in a wicker man screaming about honey honey. This is true comedic material that only Nic Cage could pull off truly a comedic genius.

I like Nicholas Cage and have no idea whatsoever why this famous wealthy and hopefully intelligent actor would make such a silly film. The characters the actors portray show no emotion have constant silly befuddled looks on their faces and the entire premise of this story in this particular rendition of this story (I know there is another earlier Wicker Man but I have never seen it although I hear it is better......has to be anything could be better!) is totally out of reality without any suspense or even interest. To be honest I was what the media fears the most.......a bored audience. I could have been home doing something useful.

Pretty awful movie. The only redeeming moment would be when Nicholas Cage walks up to some woman and level's her with a punch. Woke me out of my half slumber as I cheered for the first sensible move his character made in the last hour and a half. Now I don't condone violence against women but this movie needed something. That was it. After that I stared in awe as what you could call the plot was revealed and I nearly fast forwarded to the end. But my roommate is a glutton for punishment and preferred to finish the film in it's entirety continually thanking his girlfriend for subjecting him to such a wonderful title. Please for the love of all things worth living for do not watch this movie. I leave you with this quote from the feature... "AAAhhhhhhh....AAAAAhhhhhhh....AAAAAAhhhhhhh" - Nicholas Cage

column4: Where's Mike Crow and Servo when you need them?
column5: The only thing that could make watching this movie tolerable would be with a little help from the guys of MST3K it is that bad. The only thing it has in common with the original is the Wicker Man itself the story is absurd and the acting is wooden at best. If someone had said that this movie was a parody I could well have believed it as it was so unconvincing as its intended genre. If you want to see a great and creepy and unsettling horror movie do yourselves a favour and watch the original version and leave this rubbish well alone.

OK I saw the trailer and my friend said it looked good. From the trailer it looked like another "Silent Hill" type movie. Boy was I wrong This was the first movie I actually got mad at. I did a little research and saw the first one did bad due to editing. Same for this one. The story was in pieces and parts had nothing to do with main story. The car getting pulled over had nothing to do with the movie except explain why he might be weirded out sometimes. They keep showing flashbacks of the accident and it amounts to nothing. The little girl's real mom changing her story and not elaborating and Cage just going along was so annoying. Really frustrating to as he tried to get answers and people not answer and he just trusts everyone. The whole woman island and how they lure people in was a bad idea too. The ending was so bad too. I don't mind the hero dying but usually they accomplish something before they pass. This movie amounted to nothing. I poorly written wild goose chase that ends in cage getting burned alive. There's a lot more that I'm missing but I saw it over the summer but just finally decided to register here now.
Great acting from Nicolas Cage in this classic movie from 2006.

Historically inaccurate incredibly banal and insulting to anyone of pagan belief. Easily the worst movie of any of these actors and actresses careers. The Wicker Man makes M. Night Shyamalan's The Village seem like high art. Right from the beginning the script is horrible and the acting is worse. The premise as seen in the preview holds a lot of promise and could have been developed into a decent movie. However what follows is just stupid. Maybe when this story was written and the original movie made there was enough superstition and lack of information to make this story into a fair drive-in B movie but in today's age one has to question not only the motives behind the remake but the competence of whoever funded this waste of time.

I have to agree with most people. Somehow the remake lost what made the original fantastic. Cage did not live up to Woodwards character. The back-story interrupted what could have been a sure Oscar front-runner. However The female characters by far surpassed Cages performance. The female leads actually made up for his lack of substance. Ellen Burstyn was remarkable. Ellen breathed life into the pagan aspect of the film. Bravos should go to Ellen. Surely she will deserve a nod. I did enjoy the retention of the "wicker" icon. Also noteworthy was the timeliness with the Burning Man festival held the same as the opening weekend. It would be wonderful to see what was edited out. Perhaps that might explain the gaps in the new version that fell to the cutting room floor.

I haven't seen the original Wicker Man (1973) but the remake is very weak. While the premise of the movie is interesting it is not developed in an effective manner. Nicholas Cage's character blunders around throughout the movie like a moron ignoring repeated warnings of imminent danger and walking into a trap that an intelligent 5-year old could have avoided. His relationship with the woman is not convincing and the movie comes across as somewhat ridiculous overall. I don't know how the directors/producers managed to get so many recognized actors to participate in this piece of crap but I'm sure after they saw the finished product they wished they had never heard of this project.

drone: 1. A male bee especially a honeybee that is characteristically stingless performs no work and produces no honey. Its only function is to mate with the queen bee 2.To make a continuous low dull humming sound 3.To pass or act in a monotonous way Any or all of the above definitions are apt for this utter farce of a remake of the 1973 cult classic. As a comedy it does the job very well especially in the penultimate scenes where Nicolas Cage kicks a couple of women who get in his way and dons a bear suit to join a parade of paganistic and predominantly female islanders in an attempt to rescue his daughter from being a human sacrifice to the nature gods. Unfortunately for him things are not what they seem and he realizes too late that he was the intended victim all along.The misogynistic outlook of director LaButte is clearly evident in portraying the women of Summersisle island as a domineering self-contained self-righteous heartless lot who have absolute control over the few men that do inhabit the island enslaving them and rendering them speechless by removing their tongues. Far cry from the 1973 original where both genders are treated as equals and respected in whatever occupations they practice.The spiritual overtones of the original film are non-existent in this remake. Sergeant Howie in the 1973 version could come across as having died a martyr to his (Christian) faith and even Lord Summerisle commends him for this before having the former consigned to be a living sacrifice to propitiate the nature gods. But in the remake Cage as Edward Malus is simply another sacrificial lamb along with the other creatures confined within the wicker man. There's no chanting of ancient hymns dancing around maypoles nor feasible explanations for performing certain rituals as in the previous version. Which might pose a problem for those who haven't watched nor are aware of the 1973 original.And there's the opening scene with Edward Malus witnessing the car accident involving a mother-daughter pair and subsequent flashbacks that he experiences afterwards which affect him so much he's had to take medication. The significance of this to the main storyline is poorly if ever explained and eventually forgotten as the plot thickens.Why the police force would allow one of its members who is clearly psychologically and emotionally disturbed to go on a missing person case is beyond me.And the statement he utters when he's in the wicker man and his daughter rushes up with a burning torch "Put it down HONEY" is just so appropriate. Or poor choice of words depending on one's viewpoint.

column4: Americans leave classic film alone....don't re make them!!!
column5: Dreadful..... Nicholas should put in a " Cage forever " and made to look at the original as a punishment. Incredible that this film was ever made and somehow it got released.Yes check out the British 1973 classic yourselfit is well worth the effort.A true horror film for genuine fans.

Every time I see someone give a 1 rating to a film I ask "did you really find it worse than 'Manos: the Hands of Fate?'" I have actually re-watched "Manos" a few times for its unintentional humor. I watched "The Wicker Man" just once and definitely found it less watchable than "Manos." At least "Manos" could be forgiven for being completely produced by amateurs. "Wicker Man" can't use that excuse. I have a few other high-production value films that I give horrible ratings for simply because in the end they don't rise above the level "Manos" and other films like it.Oddly enough I generally like Nick Cage. I have enjoyed a lot of his films. I don't think he performed any better or worse than normal. This film's problem came from over-rating the value of the script. There are just some things that shouldn't be committed to film regardless of production values. "Wicker Man" was one such film. Cinema Sins wasn't nearly as kind to it as I would have been and yet they ripped so many new ones only "new ones" were all that was left.

The second film is completely out of context in comparison to the British original. Edward Woodward (a theatre actor) and Christopher Lee are two fine British actors of the highest calibre. Whereas Nicolas Cage has a limited and unconvincing stance either as a cop or a victim in this rather shabby second version.The first film is quite a brilliant concept the theme is built upon ideas of the ancient pre - Christian Religion. Which was discredited historically and given quite a bad name. Wicca or Paganism as it is sometimes called was never actually started as a Devil worship. This is something that was added and deliberately connotated to make Wicca an evil concept. Some may argue it was and still is practiced as a relatively harmless worshiping of nature and giving thanks to various god's such as the sun god and moon goddess for growth and abundance of crops. It's philosophy 'If it harm none' (basically states no harm should be done to anyone during practicing of its magic not to be confused then with Black Magic!) By those British and European people of very ancient and simple times. Who had by today's standards a very tough lifestyle! With no 'Mod Cons'It is common knowledge in England and obviously something new weird and completely unknown about in America! Who in this poor replica of 'The Wicker Man' Very cleverly or stupidly (depending on how you look at it and from what angle) manage to totally distort and destroy the entire theme of the British Pre - Christian Cult film and its Devil worshiping connotations which (as all educated Britians might know) was originally brought about by the early Christians to destroy the Cult itself rightly or wrongly.Also the film in my opinion as a woman is offensive to womankind. I would go so far as to say it carries with it dangerous overt and covert messages to the viewer. It appears to be saying that for example (the scene of Nic Cage having his legs broken deliberatelyby women while the 'all women coven' watch and smile and grin gleefully) That in general women are naturally unkind cruel and insanely sadist. This is reaffirmed when the lost child in question is encouraged by each generation in turn (Grandmother and Mother) to ignite the fire below her own father. Who incidentally she has neither met or known of til he is chosen for sacrificial purposes.I can see why Edward Woodward politely declined to partake of a role in the second film. It bears no resemblance to the first somewhat brilliantly suggestive historically anti - establishment and intellectually stimulating although slow moving epic. The first film is based loosely on Factual British theological history and does make you think deeply if you are familiar with the facts or not!The second is sexist rubbish mumbo jumbo and complete and utter nonsense. I am sorry i wasted my time watching this rubbish! I wouldn't even give it a 0. It was so bad. Yes the scenery and rural countryside was pleasant enough but when compared to the peaceful tranquility of the Scottish location in England no contest.

column4: Worships the evil god of milking the cash-cow
column5: A painful attitude of many big studios is that tried material is trusted material and prime for turning into a revenue stream...sorry an exciting new take on a story the director/write/lead just loved as a kid.Part of the reason the original worked was because the story isn't a horror story it's a suspense story. Unfortunately this film tries to use the modern horror style and it falls flat. Nicolas Cage delivers a Nicolas Cage performance but it's not suited to the pace of the story. The cast do their best with what they're given but the fault lies in the tone. Avoid watch the original.

column4: Horrible Movie! No wonder I'd never heard of it!
column5: Who on EARTH decided to make this book into a movie?? I love Nick Cage and even he couldn't make me watch this again! Unfortunately he didn't do a very good job acting in this either but like someone else said in another review he didn't have much to work with! What a horribly confusing and utterly disturbing movie! There are many instances where the viewer is absolutely lost as to what is happening (but then maybe that's the whole point?) however I do have to say one good thing about it - it DOES keep you guessing - you will think you've got it figured out changing your mind again and again but the ending is definitely a surprise! Please don't waste your money or your time!

The only thing more upsetting than the horrible mis-marketing of The Wickerman is the audience's complicity in going along with it. I'm instantly reminded of another movie called Hellcab. Everything about it sucks but the movie itself. The title. The box. The tagline: "Do you dare to pay the fare?" But again the movie itself � very good. Go rent it.Here lies the problem:Not every film fits into a nice little box. Not every film can be summed up. Drama. Horror. Comedy. Romance. Some films walk the line. Other's eschew it altogether. Such is the case with The Wickerman. A strange almost Lynchian film about a man who receives a letter from a long lost love begging his help in recovering her missing daughter. Sound like an interesting premise? It is.He goes to the island and is confronted by a strange matriarchal society of strong women and mute men and searches for the girl who everyone else claims either never existed or is dead. The mystery doubles upon itself as he suffers hallucinations vivid nightmares and scorn from the estrogen empowered populace. Anyone familiar with Labute's previous work will understand and revel in the battle-of-the-sexes subtext. What it means exactly is up to the viewer to decide. Women are evil? Men are being castrated by an increasingly PC society? Pick your poison and drink it. Because ultimately what we have here is not the dime-a-dozen horror flick the studio machine seems to want us to think it is. Instead Labute and company have crafted an enjoyably creepy diabolically clever forum for debate while keeping tongue firmly planted in cheek and never losing track of their source material.This is a movie highly recommended for thinking viewers and those looking for something more than a few forgettable scares.

column4: How to put greatness into a piece of crap?
column5: And I thought The Beach was bad with the difference that this movie has one of the greatest actors of our time Nicolas Cage. Don't blame him for the awful script if any one can make any sense of what the hell was the point of that movie give your self a pat on the back. Its a cross between The Village and a crappier script. Its starts off kinda catching your eye and then as it goes further into the plot it just makes no sense and don't get me started about the ending!!!! What was that? The only thing that makes this movie exist is Nicolas Cage usual great humor and his ability to be funny in the weirdest situations. If you go to a blockbuster and this is the only movie to watch save yourself five bucks and just go back home and turn put some thing on fire and when some ones asks you why just say the stupidest thing that comes into your mind and there you go!

The original Wicker Man is one of my favorite films but I was very open to the remake and I assure you that my opinion is unbiased.In the remake it seemed like they struggled to formulate a new plot with many convoluted subplots that truly ruin the integrity of the film. It felt like a movie at all times. You are never so wrapped up in the story that you forget unlike the original version. The original has an unbeatable authenticity that isn't found here.Another huge problem with this film is that it tried to incorporate elements from the original that either led nowhere or just made no sense. For instance the failure of the crops is significant in both films but in this film they aren't crops - in any manner of speaking. Also the natives practiced the same festival in the remake but it isn't explained nearly as well it is passed off as "just some festival".One thing the remake did a terrible job at is foreshadowing. I knew how the film ended and when I saw the original I had no idea but as I watched the remake I noticed little hints throughout the film - most were blatantly obvious. It does a terrible job of leaving the audience in tension and it doesn't let us figure anything out for ourselves. I hate that.A final issue I had with the film was the ending. I found the original to be much more emotional and shocking. The ending to this film tried to be more shocking and falls flat on it's face. In fact I like the movie much less because of the new twist at the end. All in all the original is superior in every way. See the remake to satisfy your curiosity but for no other reason.*Also the 4 people I saw the film with have not seen the original and they thought it was "just okay". Take my word for it.

column4: Too bad the script didn't meet Wicker Man
column5: When I saw this movie's trailer I was actually intrigued by the whole "wicker man" idea figuring the wicker man is an actual documented ritual. I planned a week in advance to go see the movie and was excited by the fact that finally I was going to see a good movie.>_< I couldn't have been more wrong! The movie was insanely stupid. And the acting by N. Cage!! OMG!! I haven't seen him act that bad since that Arizona movie he was in a long time ago. If I didn't know better I'd say he acted that bad on purpose. Maybe he was being forced to do this movie by gun or something and so he didn't give it his all.The idea for the movie was actually really good but the script sucked. Someone should have thrown it in an actual wicker man.Do not go to theaters and see this. Do not rent this. Do not buy this. Do not even go to your local library and rent it for free and if you do decide to do the last then please for the sake of all other potential viewers: Lose the lame thing.

column4: One of the worst movies i have ever seen in my whole life
column5: First off in this review I am going to contain a spoiler so if you plan to go see this movie than do not read any farther than right here.This movie was so bad. It left so many unanswered questions that I wanted answered.First question Why were all of the men not talking? I assumed that they all had their tongues cut out because when Nick Cage ran into one it kinda grunted like he couldn't use words. This led me to believe that they all had vocal cored because he could make sound. So why were all the men not talking?Second question why was the doll burnt? I don't know why this bothers me but it does i want to know why the doll was burnt!Third question why was he hallucinating? There had to of been a reason why he was hallucinating. I mean I know he was traumatized by witnessing that car get destroyed by the semi but there was something wrong with him before that because he bought those tapes.Last question and this one is the best one of all What happened to his tapes you know the ones of "Everythings OK"? He bought them at that diner and he CLEARLY wanted to listen to them so why did they disappear?In conclusion I would not want anyone else to see this movie because it actually caused me pain to sit for that whole hour and a half that the movie wasted of my life.Thank You

If I would have never seen the original or never knew it to be a remake of the 1973 original I may have liked it. I was expecting the plot to be the exact same with only the technology used to produce the movie being different. Boy was I wrong and disappointed. For those of you who have seen the original you will understand that in this new movie the only thing that links it to the old one vaguely is a guy looking for a missing girl and ending up burned. The original took a look at Briton's pagan past and its beliefs and rituals. The guy was a Christian who thought himself "better than those heathens". He had no fatherly link to the missing girl and was rather disrespectful to the people as only a Christian can be. This new movie is just an excuse to watch a famous guy punch a woman. In the original movie men and women were equal as they are in most British pagan beliefs. The God and Goddess are respected evenly. In the new movie there is something about this woman being a queen bee. Honestly I think this movie was just a bunch of filler for a twisting plot. I am so disappointed.

column4: nicolas cage took a stupid pill
column5: i am a huge fan of nicolas cage. but what the hell was he thinking when signing on to do this movie. i have never fallen asleep during a movie. well there is i first time for everything. this movie made no sense what so ever. the only benefit this movie could have is if you are suffering from a sleep disorder. if you can't get enough of nic cage just wait a little bit longer until ghost rider is released. save your movie for a movie the will probably have something interesting in it. i would enjoy having a root canal done more than seeing that crappy plot less movie. the only good thing about the movie is when cage smacks somebody and where's a bear suit. if you see this movie don't say i didn't warn you.

column4: Almost passed this one up because of you people
column5: This movie wasn't the greatest but I can tell you that it wasn't the worst either.Before I went to see it I checked out the user comments on here and almost passed up on it. I saw 1 star after 1 star and thought "hmm better not if it's that bad then forget it." But my brother liked the original and wanted to go see the remake. I haven't seen the original yet but after enjoying the remake I really wanna see it now.There were some pretty funny moments in the film I'm not going to spoil it for you but it was quite funny. This movie is more of a mystery than a horror or thriller.When the credits rolled after the ending I turned to my girlfriend and said "wow that wasn't nearly as horrible as everyone was saying!" She agreed and I said "what is wrong with people? I guess they were fans of the original and just hated this because of it." In any case I liked the remake and I'm definitely going to check out the original now. You can pass on this one if you want like I said it's not the greatest but it has it's moments. column4: I saw this for free and I still want my money back.
column5: I rented this title from the local library over the weekend for free. I like Nicholas Cage so I figured it had to be somewhat entertaining. It wasn't. It was full of B-movie stunts like loud music and chanting preceeding a dangerous moment for the main character which didn't add to story telling but got predictable and grating. I couldn't get sucked into this movie as I spent the entire time being annoyed by the soundtrack or trying to guess why the actors looked so...well like they had wicker shoved up their ***. With such stilted acting I couldn't feel any compassion for the characters and didn't really care about the huge betrayal in the end. I was just glad it happened because it meant the end of the film was near. Please don't get me wrong I love B-movies it is how I like to spend a rainy afternoon. I like most of the remakes in their own rights not in comparison. I loved that it was filmed where I grew up at. I liked all the actors of this film (in other films). Yet this movie still somehow managed to suck enormously. Skip it unless you are REALLY bored or a die hard Cage fan.

column4: I thought it was pretty good
column5: I thought the setup (if you're referring to the little girl & her mom in the car) was explained. He lost one little girl which obviously had a profound effect on him and he was determined to find the other girl since he hadn't in his mind succeeded in saving the first one. I thought this was quite obvious. I really liked this movie. I wasn't expecting the ending...I was very surprised. I think some people watch movies and want everything spelled out for them. This move actually makes you think at times. If you rent it on DVD you can watch the alternate ending which was pretty...disturbing. I would definitely recommend it.

Awful Awful Awful- why did they take do long to show he was being sacrificed? Why did he act in this horrible heap of trash? WHY????? Save yourselves! Don't watch this!!!

column4: Delightful bit of retelling by campy star/director
column5: The wonderful thing about Nicolas Cage is that he throws himself into the role good or bad 100%. Which is exactly what a movie like this needs of its leading man who is on screen almost the entire film. Therefore if you're willing to watch Cage ham it up with reckless abandon in this remake of the 70s cult thriller then you're in for an enjoyable experience.Eerie in a way that movies now a day just aren't The Wicker Man uses the most of all the production devices at its disposal. Sets and surroundings are surreally bizarre; the musical score is creepy and uncomfortable and the costumes are unsettling and sometimes disturbing. It figures that a stage director like LaBute would find inspiration in all these cinematic devices as they are equally if not more important to the stage work world he comes from.However without the smoke and mirrors of the production crew the plot is rather thin and develops at a snail's pace. In true seventies fashion the film is more character driven and unconcerned about delivering a definitive beginning middle and end story arc that wraps up nicely. It's more about Cage's character's journey and how he deals with the situations he finds himself in.As the film progresses the situations seem more and more bizarre yet answers fail to come and as an audience member it can prove to be frustrating. However Cage's performance and LaBute's direction propped up by a great supportive cast compels you to watch it. The island Cage finds himself on investigating a missing child is just slightly unlike the rest of the world. The sense is that we're watching an Amish community based on the principles of a beehive. Burstyn's queen bee performance is every bit as powerful as her turn in Requiem for a Dream (why isn't this woman working more often?) and the supporting females are the most unlikely bunch of femme fatales yet every bit as menacing.The film plods along and requires the audience's trust as we are often as much in the dark as Cage is. The twist ending is a slight shock but probably not as much as it was 30 years ago. Yet it was interesting enough to give this film a slight recommendation though i do realize it isn't for everyone's taste especially those who like their films quick and tidy.Grade: B

I wonder why this remake was necessary? Edward Woodward was vastly superior to Nicholas Cage. Why was it vital to change the antagonist role from a man Christopher Lee to a woman Ellen Burstyn? This film was a doctrine of the Women's Lib Movement instead of a religious philosophical film which was the original. Very few other plot lines were different from the original. I hope people get a renewed interest in the original and see it. The change of setting did not help either. I realize there are cults in the United States but the original Scotish setting was more sinister. How come they police wouldn't look for Cage when he did not return? At least two of his colleagues knew of his plans and destination.

column4: An officer is called to his ex-fiancé's side when her daughter goes missing on a strange female dominated island.
column5: Sad to say I too was disappointed in the film. Perhaps I was expecting a better Pagan connection or more film of ritual. They needed to have someone sit down and explain the male's purposes on the island a bit better or have him see a few rituals (instead of maypoles and fertility rituals we see 5 pregnant women pass him on a trail and we see a finished maypole in the school yard. The island operated more as a 'bee colony' than any sort of pagan or goddess-centered society.I liked how they had a small tongue-in-cheek reference to the original film when Cage pops out of his room to ask if anyone has unpacked his things and we see a woman eating an apple.However I feel any dialog they tried to mimic from the original (the school room scene for example) was inappropriate and out of place.The only scary parts excluding the crash as scary (it actually just disturbed and saddened me) are these dreams he has or daydreams such as finding the dead child under the dock. I found nothing of the film 'psychologically' frightening save for the breaking of Cage's legs to make him identical to a wingless drone. The society did not frighten me so much as tick me off. I was on Cage's side in this film not the islanders (probably the point that disappointed me the most!) Anyway this movie had a nice location but again it made me think of a campground or lake-side cottage more than any sort of goddess/pagan-based society.Go see it judge for yourself. You may like it it may work for you. I think for this to become a "good" movie in my standards I will have to watch it a few more times to see if anything grows on me.

Saturday night it's raining outside and my husband is watching this film right now despite my advice protests and finally walking out of the room. Having been subjected to this travesty on a flight last year there's not a snowball's chance in hell I'm watching it again.I recently introduced him to the original which he really enjoyed but in his naivety has reasoned that an up to date version with a solid cast must be worth watching. He actually thinks a lot of films can be improved with age/experience/Hollywood tinkering.Poor dear.He'll learn.

column4: Almost as good as the original
column5: I'm not a big fan of Nicolas Cage and love the original movie so I was a bit unsure about this one.......and although I read reviews I'm lucky I'm not swayed by them otherwise I'd have missed out on a really good entertaining movie.I thought it was well acted (even N.Cage!) very atmospheric and the slight change to the plot added to the suspense. The scenery/use of light/cinematography were out of this world. It restored my faith in 'simple' movies (little or no special effects).Watch the movie let yourself be transported to a time when people lived a simple life and held dances round the maypole. Imagine life on a little island where everyone knows everyone else - they have their routines and rituals and 'outsiders' are shunned.It's not real - it's a movie - it's entertaining - ignore everyone's comments and make your own mind up.....you might be pleasantly surprised.

I didn't even spend much time watching this movie.OK so I saw this movie a while ago. It was on HBO and I was switching to this movie during commercials. I saw enough throughout - and the last 30 minutes - to know that this movie is not something that appeals to me at all.Sure the mystery portion of the movie held my attention and made me want to figure it out.But after some pain is inflicted I was disturbed.I was wondering when it would get better. It didn't. It got worse and worse and then just got dumb.When the girls are out on the hunt again...that did not make me feel scared apprehensive or anything really. It was just dumb and a waste of time.It wasn't thought provoking. What's it trying to teach? Don't trust strangers? Don't try to help save anyone? Stay away from any place that has bees? If anyone ever said they were thinking of renting this movie I'd emphatically let them know to not ever give it a second thought. This is one of the worst movies I have ever seen.

OK let's remake the greatest British Horror film of its generation and make it so bad that you'd wish it was you in the Wicker Man.The movie was terrible. Where the original was held together by the music and the pagan rituals the remake had nothing to bring the separate pieces together.Cage's acting lacked the naivety that the role demanded. The cop needed to be an innocent a fool not just someone who came to the island of his own free will.The last ten minutes were the best and echoed the original. But that's what the movie needed throughout its entire length. We needed to see more of what held the island together what kept the women in charge and why the men were subservient.Cage's character was Cameron Poe on Prozac. Thank God for Ellen Burstyn! If you haven't had the pleasure of watching the 70's classic version watch this first then rent the DVD.

I saw both versions and though there may have been differences in the presentation of details neither one really connected the beginning to the middle to the end of this movie. The more one tries to make a linear coherent story line out it the more one becomes aware that there are additional little "loose ends" apparently just thrown in to "hang."Was the sheriff being tested to see how far he was willing to go in saving a child in the beginning? Could he not have been contacted to start the search just on the basis that he had already been chosen to be the father years earlier? Since no bodies were found in the wreck are we to assume that these particular Wicca actually possessed supernatural powers? When our hero inquires about what happens to male offspring he accepts the non-answer without a blink. Is finding a missing girl more important than uncovering continuous infanticide? What is the connection with the doll and the red dress all about anyway? Does the woman out farming that appears to be almost identical to the schoolteacher indicate another unexplained mystery? Is that the old man that flew him lying in that bed and just why is he there? Or is he instead the one with the bloodied face he finds on the beach?I just don't have the time to view both versions again to see if I have missed some of the connections. I also don't care of I had failed to view them the first time. A bit of a disappointment. The alternate ending with the two women apparently out to get pregnant in the outside world is either an poor set-up for a sequel or merely an indication that the kook group is getting prepared for some future bad crop. But then of course that's the way everyone gets pregnant in that society-or is it? By now do we care?

This movie has such a low rating which is shocking. I don't consider this one to be boring or to be a bad movie. Some users have criticized particular users that they have not watched enough movies because they considered this to be a good movie. That is BS. I would like to know what kind of movies that they enjoy. This is a movie where either people would really like it or they would hate it. So if anyone enjoyed Village watch this and you would enjoy. All others spend your money on something that all of you would like such as Napoleon Dynamite(losers) or The Condemned (predictable ending). Have fun who ever watches it. And I would appreciate feedback on what I said.

column4: Some Studio Paid Money for This
column5: The Wicker Man stars Nic Cage in one of his most notorious roles spewing some of the internet's favorite memes in what is ultimately a terrible film. I wouldn't say it's the worst movie I've ever seen by any stretch but there are so few redeeming qualities to be found in The Wicker Man that it's hard to imagine anyone watching it and thinking it's even average.The plot of a man flying off to find his daughter on a mysterious island full of pagan women could work. It did in the original film and it's a decent enough idea for a plot that could do all kinds of weird and mysterious things. What we get instead is a slow moving and absolutely boring slog with uninteresting characters portrayed by terrible actors a script with some of the most stilted writing imaginable underwhelming and extremely bland direction and no hint of mystery horror or suspense to be found. It fails as a horror movie it fails as a mystery...it just fails.The only redeeming quality is Nic Cage's awful performance does lead to some unintentionally funny moments. The final twenty minutes where he kicks and punches the women around and the infamous bee scene are worth a chuckle but you've seen those scenes already and they aren't any funnier in the context of the film. So...there's really no reason whatsoever to watch this.The Wicker Man is godawful and doesn't warrant your time.

I saw this "movie" with my 13 year old daughter and we both laughed out loud during several parts. I cannot believe this didn't go straight to video!! The theater-wide laughing and groaning throughout this awful film didn't bother me one bit.I would only recommend seeing this if you're in the mood for a comedy....and are confident you won't get kicked out of the theater for laughing uncontrollably!! I'm still trying to decide what was funnier...1) a freaked out baby daddy sucker punching a 50 year old 200 lb mead selling woman and then STRUGGLING to overpower a 100 lb blond barmaid 2) The Whack A Mole/Girl trio by the water popping up like little munchkins! 3)"AAhhhh My Leg" 4) Cage in a bear costume fighting women 5) Cage in a business suit riding a "seized by force" bike Seriously...see it ONLY if you want a good laugh.

First of all I'd like to point out that i haven't seen the original so the whole film was new to me. I'm seriously glad that i hadn't seen the original as it would have spoiled an enjoyable film with comparisons and obviously nothing would shock me. It starts off well with swift pace and introduction but veers off course slightly time passes. Howevever good ol' Nic Cage managed to keep my attention focused on the screen and not my nuts (peanuts.. not the other... never mind). He puts in a performance that is significantly better than the rest of the cast whom i thought were rather bland or maybe that was the point.So things to consider when watching The Wicker Man:1) Don't make comparisons to the original or rate the new against the old.2)Stick with it during the dull moments and savour the moments of tension.Overall an average movie thats definitely worth a watch because of Cage. It'll pass the time but not a memorable film.7/10

Although I realized that this movie hadn't received good reviews I decided to watch it today (there's not a great deal of HD-DVD movies out yet and I took a chance on it).It was clear early on that this movie would not be good. While that's certainly not my preference it's unfortunately common and I settled in to watch a bad film. But this film raced past "not good" and quickly became very frustrating. Frustrating because there appeared to be some potential. Potential to make a decent film and that's what is so annoying and disappointing.(1) Nicolas Cage is generally a good actor but needs strong direction. The first 3/4 of this movie was way off the mark for his character and was distracting and irritating.(2) Serving up predigested plot only appeals to the lowest common denominator. Possibly this was LaBute's goal as he did edit to a PG-13 to reach the 10-16 market (not exactly a group known for their discriminating taste in films).(3) Burstyn was acceptable in her first scene but became unfortunately mired in LaBute's re-write and directing in the final scene.(4) The cinematography ranged from beautiful vistas to hackneyed "portending doom" and the same is true of the score. Why oh why are they trying to create the wrong tone and pace?As I've only seen the film on HD-DVD I haven't seen what was apparently the "theatrical release." I'm surprised that it would be acceptable to change the ending without any statement to that effect. I rented the movie online and may have missed the box art emblazoned with "Director's Cut" or something to indicate the difference. Nevertheless I'm surprised that there's no option on the disc to view the "original ending" or anything that would even imply that the ending is different. I only just found out about the difference by reading on this site.Very frustrating film. And again - not simply because it's poorly done but because all of the pieces were in place to make at a minimum a decent film.

This was hands down one of the worst movies I've ever ever seen. It's so comically bad that it's almost good. Key word... "almost". Even despite some classic Nick Cage freak-outs and screaming it was 2 hours of my like that I'll never get back. It got 2 stars for these reasons:1) Nick Cage inexplicitly randomly goes on a rampage running around punching and karate kicking women in the face.2) Nick Cage puts on a bear suit.That is all. The other hour and half plus will claim a small piece of your soul never to be returned. On my death bed I'll look bad at the minutes stolen of my life watching this and curse the heavens while shedding bloody tears of regret.

column4: I really hated this movie! Shame on everyone involved!
column5: I never saw the original so I did not know what to expect. The script was insulting. And as a practicing wiccan I was insulted I lost all respect for Nicolas Cage I will never watch another movie of his as long as I live! I know its just a movie but I don't care IT was insulting to anyone involved in what Christians call a "Pagan" religion. Oh ya the one liners really sucked some say they researched for the original movie. I say no! Human and animal sacrifice is forbidden and alway has been. This movie portrayed pagan/witches as man hating you know whats. Yes I bought it before I rented it and now it is lying in the landfill in 30 different pieces!

Honestly I didn't care too much about Nicolas Cage's crazy acting and stuff which gets a lot of flak. What I hated was that they had a decent flow and setup for a cool ending and then just left it hanging in the most unsatisfying way ever. It just has no redeeming qualities at all.

The plot line above reads: "A sheriff investigating the disappearance of a young girl from a small island discovers there's a larger mystery to solve among the island's secretive neo-pagan community."I'll finish that sentence by saying "Yeah. The mystery is this movie SUUUUUUUUUCKS."Don't waste two hours watching this movie. Do something else like shoving bamboo under your fingernails...... Considering the cast of this movie I was really surprised it was as horrible as it was. In the trivia section it was written that a lot of scenes were removed to reduce the rating from and R to a PG-13. Maybe they should have left those scenes in; it couldn't have hurt.

First off I'd like to say I was incredibly disappointed when I watched this movie that the iconic "NOT THE BEES" scene was not in the film? Turns out that scene was a deleted scene from the unrated cut of the film but the version on Amazon Prime was a lower age rated version which cut the torture scene. I was rather disappointed that this scene wasn't there.Now the complaining is out of the way I can talk about why this film is in my opinion underrated. The film follows the incomparable Nicolas Cage as a cop who gets summoned to a cult island by the mystery of his missing daughter he didn't know he had. The mystery of the island keeps you intrigued as we follow Cage through his investigation of this strange society. As the movie goes on though the true nature of the film is revealed; This film isn't a horror at all but a somewhat dark comedy mystery. And in all honesty I didn't expect that the missing daughter bit was a trap to sacrifice Nic for a good harvest. Admiral Ackbar would be truly shocked for those who've seen Star Wars. The ending of the main character being burnt alive was unexpected to me but worked well (though I'd half hoped Cage would find a way to escape and enact revenge upon the islanders).Additionally this movie contains some hilarious moments of Cage-iness. Notably him running in a bear suit him yelling "How'd it get burnt?!" repeatedly and of course "NOT THE BEES!" which is made funnier by the obviously CGI bees being poured into his helmet like a liquid.Take this movie for what it is: a comedy mystery which certainly does its job in both departments.A solid five from me. It was an enjoyable time but an instant classic or one I'd rewatch soon. Maybe in another year or two I'll come back to the strange bee tribe to see Cage question how a doll did indeed get burnt.

I can't tell how angry I was on my way out of the cinema. When I saw Nicolas Cage in the cast I thought it would be nice but not. I can't believe he agreed to film it. At the beginning I thought it would be a nice mystery but the more the story progressed the more foolish it became. At a point all characters seemed ridiculous - talking and acting like crazy. Some scenes made the audience laugh although they should have been tragic or at least serious. The costumes - I was wondering whether they used the same in Star Trek. And the end was such a crap I just can't find words to describe it. So are you going to watch it? Please don't!

I would give this a minus 10 if it was available. I did not watch in the theater. I think anyone who ever paid to watch this should be compensated for emotional distress. I need ten lines to post this. Sucks. New Black Panther Chairman Malik Zulu Shabazz discussed inciting racial tensions by picturing George Zimmerman with a noose around his neck on the cover of New Black Panther Newspaper in order to sell more papers in Florida.New Black Panther Chairman Malik Zulu Shabazz discussed inciting racial tensions by picturing George Zimmerman with a noose around his neck on the cover of New Black Panther Newspaper in order to sell more papers in Florida.

Fortunately for me I didn't see the original 1973 version so I was not burdened by undue expectations upon entering the theater. I am giving this film a 7 although just barely perhaps 6.5 would be more fair. Like most films these days yes the plot is flimsy and it requires an extra dose of suspended disbelief.But I enjoyed it because it held my interest completely for the whole 2 hours. It built up the suspense very nicely. It was a who-dunnit mystery that turned out not to be such a mystery after all. I did see it coming but not from afar as is the case in most movies. If you think this plot is transparent then go see the Illusionist: no illusion there(but I still liked it).Fabulous scenery good mystery loads of suspense. AND very very creepy. Plus lots of good silly laughs which I think is a good thing in a mystery/suspense/horror-lite film. Throw in some very sexy performances by Kate Beahan and Leelee Sobieski and you have a winner as far as I am concerned!!It is a very typical Nick Cage performance. He honed his on-screen persona by the time he was in "Leaving LasVegas" and it hasn't varied much since then which is bad or good depending on how well you like it. As usual he is manly impassionedand valiant yet confused full of self-doubt and vulnerable. I have to say that this wasn't one of his best performances but the script had a lot to do with that. Very weak dialogue. They should have hired me to brush it up ;) When he delivered the line "Step back from the bike!" I must confess I was taken aback. There are a lot of actors who would have ad-libbed something more appropriate there or just outright refused to say it. I wonder what Brando would have done? Probably just mumbled something incoherent. At the risk of being arrested as a security threat I have to say that I nevertheless enjoyed this Cage performance far more than his "World Trade Center" performance. Now that was really painful!So it was just a beautiful movie to watchand good escapist entertainment. A pleasant way to pass the time. You really can't expect every film to be a masterpiece.For those numerous reviewers who said "Worst movie I ever saw" I say check the current theater listings: "Accepted" "Beerfest" "Material Girls" "Idlewild" "Trust the Man" "Snakes on a Plane" "How to Eat Fried Worms" "Factotum" "Invincible" "The Barnyard" and "Lady in the Water." Not a single one in the bunch is better than Wicker Man and most of them are far worse. Worst movie ever? Not even the worst this week not by a long shot! Get real!

As always Cage puts on an excellent performance which really holds the movie together. Unlike the original wicker ma it does not contain the the religious element of the main character but only of the inhabitants of the island. A tad bit repetitive but on the whole a captivating 2 hours with brilliant performances from the majority of actors and a shocking twist at the end if your watching it for the first time. Basically it is about a group of bizarre pagan inhabitants on an island who have strange sexual rituals. When a girl goes missing on the island cage who is a cop in the movie is called in by his former lover (whos girl it is) to investigate. Arriving on this island he observes the strange behaviour of its people and slowly unfolds a spine-tingling plot.

column4: A surprisingly high quality disturbing remake
column5: I watched the directors cut of the Wicker Man 2006 the other night. I and my wife were expecting to see a travesty of the original however we were surprised that the eeriness and surrealism had survived through into this remake. While certain scenes have been updated to fit into a more modern audience the overall narrative of the original is here. The ending of this version is even more surreal than the original one and quite disturbing. Be warned not for the faint hearted. As I've said that is the directors cut and as I believe a lot of scenes have been reinstated that was cut in the cinematic version so that it could be bizarrely cut down to a PG 12 certificate when it was quite clear that this film was never intended for a family audience.

This "film" was terrible. It tries so hard to be scary but you'll end up laughing like there's no tomorrow. Not to mention the ridiculous lines. From such masterpieces as "Killing me won't bring back your goddamn honey!" to "Ahh my legs!" (or of it's Unrated "Ahh my eyes!") or the scenes of Nic Cage running around karate kicking and punching women in a bear outfit the one just doesn't let up nevermind the ridiculous story and the fact that it makes zero sense. How the director would let the bad guys win no matter how horrible they are I don't know but you'll leave with nothing but a sense of "damn that's 5 bucks i'm never getting back." Avoid like the bubonic plague.

Lets face it; it was all destined to end in tears. And as optimistic as we all tried to be the very idea of remaking The Wicker Man was never a good one. What truly floors me however is that in remaking a contemporary British chiller the producers thought it would be a a good idea to cast an American action stay in the lead role. Is this a joke? Nocholas Cage was good in Face/Off Con Air and the like. But Jesus stick to what you know man! Because at the end of the day you are not the best actor in the world.And whilst in the original film the lead character was a devoutly religious unmarried virgin in this film he is allergic to bees. Allergic. To. Bees. Wow. Thats much better. Seriously the only thing that kept me from bursting into tears and rolling up into a foetal position on the floor was the unintentional comedy; did they honestly think people would be able to take the sight of Nicholas Cage roundhouse kicking little old ladies seriously?? Or forcing them off their bicycles at gunpoint? And whilst some might praise director/hack extraordinaire Neil LaBute for at least having the balls to keep the original ending intact i found it simply staggering that his incompetence is of such a grand scale that he couldn't even make the sight of Nicholas Cage being burnt alive look satisfying.But in all seriousness this film was destined to crash and burn. the plot (which has been "cleverly updated" to include the idea that the little girl who goes missing is actually his daughter) is far too out there to find acceptance amongst a mainstream audience whilst fans of the original and lets face it fans of common decency in general will probably avoid this like a plague. I meanwhile am simply floored that they ever dared to attempt this in the first place.

column4: Awful...Nick needs to be careful with his roles lately
column5: The plot was pointless and dragged throughout the entire movie. Cage's role was upsetting. He played a man that was as idiotic as it gets by going to an unknown village to help an ex girlfriend who later turns out to have planned his demise all along. Turns out the woman from this village do this to all men from the outside world. I could barely keep my eyes opened in the theater and was upset that I wasted money on this. This movie reminded of the movie "The Village" another bust. Similar plot of things occurring in a secluded village that made no sense and proved to be extremely boring. It's amazing how a preview to a movie can appear to be so dramatically different from the movie itself. A royal bomb of a movie!!!

column4: Worst directing worst acting worst scripting worst movie I have EVER SEEN.
column5: Do NOT see this movie. It was a waste of 6 dollars and a Sunday afternoon. The only redeeming quality is the fascinating story...that the director obviously biffed. It had such great potential. But everything about the movie is just plain awkward.I expected that with Nicolas Cage acting as the main character it would be at least a decent film but it's very obvious that he felt totally lost the whole time. Viewers might even wonder if any of the actors or actresses were given a script. All Willow does is fumble around for words. Leelee Sobieski is just as bad...despite all the hope I had for her. Every part of this film is either laughable or just plain awkward...never suspenseful never engaging and NEVER scary.They missed the mark big time on this one.Please trust me. Don't see this awful remake.

I read this book at least 15 years ago. Since the book itself is rather slow it is no surprise that this movie is too. I never saw the original movie but I will just to be able to compare. Nicholas Cage is as always a great actor. In some ways it is worth it just to see another one of his wonderful performances. I also really enjoyed the performance of Ellen Burstyn. There are a lot of ambiguous comments by the players in this movie to intrigue but they are never really explained either by the action or by words. The premise is good; it just doesn't ever seem to really take off. It is the kind of movie that although it is too slow to really take you away you stick with just to see how it comes out. The ending is a surprise with a bit of a twist so it is worth it to stick with it to see how it comes out.

i actually walked out of this movie it was absolutely the worst movie i have ever seen! (and I've seen quite a few) now Nicholas cage is either really good (con-air) or really bad (this wicker man) in movies these days...why did they even go through with this movie??? it was a waste of money. recommendation Don't WATCH IT!!! oh but there are some must watch movies out right now....but if you plan on renting this movie DO NOT DARE WASTE YOUR MONEY!!! i wasted about thirty minutes watching this movie (i only watched 30 minutes of it i hated it so bad) i almost fell asleep and I've never done that before now the first one is much much much better so i will recommend that one so like i said do not waste time money or gas renting this movie it is not worth even a nickel!

This movie starts out interestingly but becomes very tedious as soon as one recognizes that the woman the protagonist (played by Mr. Cage) has come to a remote island to save isn't very interesting--or worth saving for that matter. Plus upon arrival the feminist community he encounters is absurd even in fantasy terms. There is nothing endearing about it and frankly most sensible males would have immediately debarked upon encountering the sour-faced and well to put it nicely ample Sister Beech.But our hero decides to pursue the case. (The screen writers were evidently uneasy about tenacity with which Malus stays on the case so midstream we learn from Sister Woodward that the child in question is really his daughter conceived what I inferred was a single coupling.) After some reconnaissance of the local flora and a couple of clandestine meetings with "Sister" Woodward our hero finally meets the "queen bee" Sister Summersisle of the colony and tries to confront her concerning the whereabouts and fate of a young girl with the absurd name of Rowan. (But it was evident that all the women were named after trees so there you have it!)Sister Summersisle's responses are meretricious and patronizing and the viewer knows she's gonna get him in the end. The incongruity between the flower-child paganism of the female inhabitants with their likeness to bees and trees and the miserable emasculation of the men is disturbing but somehow it doesn't come off right; because it is almost believable! It's just the kind of queendom that formed the fantasies of the feminist coeds I encountered in my college days in the late 60s. As it was then it just makes you (me anyway as a guy) frustrated and talking to the screen asking Malus why he doesn't jack up these male bozos for being so wimpy; at least enough to find out whether their servility is based on weak character or some mysterious rewiring of the human male along the lines of a bee drone. (I asked the same questions almost 50 years ago!)Now I admit that police officer Malus is kind of an to use that word so endearing to modern feminists a**hole but he is sincere in his response to the call to help. Does this warrant his final incendiary end with the gleeful complicity of an cute little girl (who scarcely knows what she's doing)? Probably yes because as the movie makes clear his macho is the dilithium power source of the cult and so must be harnessed.You see unlike the feminists and very much like the bees they've learned how to utilize maleness. Ultimate simplicity no wrangling no male unemployment so destructive to an ordered society (and it is!) no physical contest naturally favoring men just emasculation for lesser beings and an auto da fe for those occasional potent types who are selected in advance to "mate" with the queen (we learn towards the end that Malus' and Woodward's consummation was no accident as she is the daughter of the queen bee). And I'm reasonably confident that this is the movie's ultimate and intended message. So guys beware!
It's a decent movie and a bad remake. I suggest watching the first one. It would be a horrible experience if you watched the first one before watching this.

column4: DEFIANTLY the worst film I have ever seen.
column5: After copious amounts of begging from my girlfriend to watch this I gave in and watched it.I would have had more fun watching ice melt.The film drags on at a steady pace constantly hinting that there will be a sudden twist at the end Nicholas Cage's now dreary acting doing nothing for the film and BANG! it ends.There was once a time when I used to think "ooh a new Nicholas Cage film that's gonna be good" - Now it seems the man is very used to signing up to any old film for a quick buck. Do yourself a favor Nick? hang on for a GOOD film and make us remember how good you really can be.There was no twist no massive shock and then it ends.Please please for the love of films don't watch this film.
I enjoyed the part where he punched a bunch of people.
Awesome place for an alpha female to grow up. Strong women prevailed and there was tranquility.

I accidentally reviewed this movie on the 1973 version because when I typed in Wickerman it automatically took me there! In fact I had a hard time even getting to this page for some reason. Anyway if your feel like it and I have no idea why you would you can read my review on that page. Oops! In a nutshell though WORST MOVIE I HAVE EVER SEEN IN MY ENTIRE LIFE!!!!!!!!!!!! Please don't waste your money people! I don't think even a two thumbs down is enough justice. Nicholas Cage was obviously doing this for one reason only money. This was such a waste of time and money. It was messy pointless boring and predictable. How anyone could enjoy this movie is mind boggling.

column4: Bad script comes to life-Run for your life
column5: I have seen many movies that were far from good that I simply label as "entertaining" . This one forced me to create a new category. It's called -I want my 2 hours of life back- . My wife had this one pegged within the first 20 minutes and it was far worse that we thought. At the end we were just sitting there looking at each other while my eye developed a twitch. I'm glad that I didn't pay to see this. I would have been terribly upset. The acting was horrible. At some point you'll find yourself saying "I hope this all makes sense pretty soon". Do not watch this movie. I'm amazed that it scored as high as a 3 on the all mighty IMDb. I should have trusted the voters and not watched it. At least I had a good glass of wine while I suffered.

column4: Plays out like a dated Tales from the Crypt Episode
column5: This movie would have worked really well in a different shorter format. Maybe a Tales From The Crypt or even The Outer Limits episode. The plot full of gaping holes left me with way to many "huh?" moments and went on for about an hour or so too long. There were several times that I thought "Wow they could have cut that whole scene and it wouldn't have mattered". That's a bad sign I think. Nicholas Cage has done better but the script may have tied his hands a bit. Not sure what actor available today could have pulled off such dry unemotional dialog. There were a few times where he seems to forget his dialog for a minute and may be trying to adlib. May have had his career tanking on his mind. There were a few laughable scenes where Mr.Cage had a pained constipated expression on his face for no particular reason. Now I'm thinking he may have been realizing what kind of turkey he was making. Ignorant and misinformed paganism references as well make you feel like the writer had a cross to bare (pun intended).An unfortunate waste of everyone's time. Would have given it a zero if IMDb had let me.

Step away from the bike are you kidding me?! I received lots of sexual rewards from my girlfriend as it was her idea to waste two hours and $15 on this "film". Confirms that Nicholas Cage is a horrible actor and I refuse unless I can get more sexual favors to see another of his films.Who goes to an island to investigate a missing child without notifying the local authorities? Didn't he tell his police partner where and what he was doing? Wouldn't they have investigated and shut the place down? Why am I wasting my time commenting on this wretched movie? Do yourself a favor and spend the time rearranging your sock drawer and the money on premium gas it will be a much better investment.

column4: This movie is unforgivable but unintentionally funny
column5: question: how did Nicholas cage go from "matchstick men" and "adaptation" to THIS? his acting as well as others was laughable most of the time like when he punched sister beech after he ran hysterically through sister summerisle's house. i was expecting this to be a serious mystery/scary movie but all of the actors made it seem like this movie was actually another addition to the "scary movie" series. i wouldn't be surprised if this is spoofed in the next scary movie. the most disappointing part of the movie was the ending. despite the decent attempts at foreshadowing a creepy and shocking ending the movie didn't deliver as promised. i found myself shaking my head as i and the rest of the audience heard Nicholas cage expositorally screaming about how the villagers were hurting him before they dragged him off to his fate a very lackluster and not too terrifying wooden pyre in the shape of a man. i will give the movie credit for being far too amusing and comical than it was intended to be especially with the lack of talented acting the clichéd plot elements and directing and the predictable "scary" moments. if he wasn't already the wicker man confirms that Nicholas cage is officially washed up.

Whoever was responsible for this abomination didn't have the slightest idea what the original film was about. The original was an intelligent study of the tension between ancient Pagan and Christian values done with wit and irony. This remake is a laughable travesty written by somebody who knows absolutely nothing about either Christianity OR Paganism. Every key concept in the original is missing or garbled. The most important aspect of the pagan culture (that it delights in nature and sex and is joyous and festive --- beautifully portrayed in the movie) is completely absent. The pagans are portrayed as grim shuffling fanatics instead. In the original the point is that the policeman while he is stiffly pious and puritanical nevertheless faces his martyrdom bravely sincere in his faith. You are supposed to laugh at him in the beginning but slowly come to respect him in the end. All of this was completely over the heads of the nitwits who made this remake. How could this have even gotten off the ground as a project? The real horror is that a classic film has been remade by complete idiots. For that kind of sacrilege it would be nice if human sacrifice was still an option.

column4: Not as good as the 1973 version but still an intriguing remake.
column5: Firstly I would like to say I am a huge fan of the original despite thinking this movie was going to be really bad I went ahead and watched it anyway. I was pleasantly surprised by this remake. I read so many negative reviews and it has a really bad rating here 3.4/10 is harsh.I'm a big Nicolas Cage fan and I think he did very well in playing the role of Edward Malus and had a lot of good moments I was impressed by the quality of the performances all round. I thought LaBute's direction was good too and the movie had a good feeling of dread and tension that was created throughout the story very much like the original.I feel in a way how The Wicker Man went wrong is that it wasn't daring enough to really be different to the original (other than the island being controlled by women) some of the scenes were basically identical I think it would have been interesting if LaBute made it that Cage found some way of escaping at the end or at least made his death more violent I was even more disappointed with this when I read an interview in Total Film with LaBute where he said:"Some torture scenes towards the end of the movie ended up just getting cut. There was a kind of purifying ritual they put Cage's character through before they take him to the wicker man. They broke his knees and they put a helmet of bee's on his head. (you see him with the helmet on in one of the trailers). He was stung virtually to death then brought back with an adrenaline shot - only to be hauled up by his legs in the wicker man. It was a pretty savage wonderful section"Again I don't understand why this wasn't included that extra stuff sounded cool to me would have made the scene much more violent and better maybe even better than the original's!However I enjoyed this movie overall and I still feel this was a quality remake of a horror classic and perhaps harshly overlooked by many movie fans and critics.

column4: Bait and Switch? A deceptive trailer leads to the worst film of 2006
column5: After recently viewing Writer/Director Neil LaBute's greatly-hyped "In the Company of Men"  I expected this update of the 1973 classic "The Wicker Man" to (at least) have a decent script. Imagine my surprise when this turned in to a veritable laugh fest from beginning to end. The best/worst moments? Too many... 1. Burstyn shouting "THE DRONE MUST DIE!" 2. Cage muttering "Oh God not the BEES!" (BTW - What was the point of covering him with bees essentially risking the death of their sacrifice? Same as when he's trapped in the underwater waterway didn't these people realize they were a few slippery fingers away from losing their beloved sacrifice to the Wicker Man? What the Hell would've happened to the harvest then? Seriously.) 3. The "shocking" alternate ending (which is basically LaBute copying that one scene in "Misery" when Kathy Bates knocks the crap out of James Caan's legs). 4. And of course three words for anyone who has seen this film: THE BEAR SUIT! How do movies like this get made?

column4: Killing me won't bring back your career NICHOLAS CAGE!!!!
column5: We should have never seen this movie...I saw it coming from Nicholas Cage's recent string of anti-climatic movies. Pure drudgery. What is wrong with him? Why would he associate himself with such a failure? I am sure he saw the script before scene 1-take 100. This movie is still in the first scene as absolutely nothing happened no development of a plausible character or plot. This is suicide...I am never seeing another of his movies until it comes to network TV.As you can see I am blaming this whole thing on Cage as I don't know who the other people are...just a bunch of people reading dumb lines and calling themselves actors. I would love to meet the person who directed this piece of crap. If you played this movie for prisoners of war it would be against the Geneva Convention...TORTURE...RUN FOR YOUR LIFE...The WICKER MAN IS COMING TO GET YOU!!!!!!

Give it a chance I thought to my self. Some re-makes have worked and this could too. Sadly however this sanitised version is not a patch on the original horror musical. Once you have taken away the religious sexual horrific plot the fabulous acting of the pious and determined lead role and (most disappointing of all) the famous speech of the final scene then you have truly ruined what could have been a wonderful film.How can a studio take such a great original and make it into this boring (yes boring) nonsensical load of old tosh? There are some nice individual performances here but with the story now so thin it doesn't really make up for it. Great shame and a missed opportunity to being some much needed story based films back into the mainstream.

Absolute waste of a evening money that should not have been spent on 103 minutes of filmmaking. Ten minutes in you know it's bad and it only gets worse. I'd be embarrassed to have my name on the castlist.

column4: Easily the worst film I've ever seen.
column5: I would sooner endure hour upon hour of "A Clockwork Orange" style torture; forced to watch soap operas and cat food commercials until my eyeballs bleed before I would ever watch this movie again.The acting was stiff and tired and there were plot holes big enough to drive a semi through.The end result was an unintentionally funny flat sad excuse for a suspense/thriller.I can't believe so many talented actors would subject themselves to this.Spend your money to support better films and they'll stop making this crap.

column4: I hated this movie because of it's ending.
column5: The ending made me want my two hours back. Cage should have been smarter. He should have also told more people where I was going so there would at least have been an investigation. He should have been more suspicious of his ex-fiancé. I would have left the Island as soon as I realized that everyone was lying. Then I would have called the FBI. I'd have made a raft out of logs or something that floated well. The ending was such a disappointment. I don't even understand what the movie was trying to make the audience feel. If I were Nicholas I would have kept talking about Jesus and praying to God in the name of Jesus. I would have done more preaching. I think he would have escaped if he would have tried that route.

column4: Run away from it!!! Do not waste your time with this one.
column5: I believe this is one of the worst films I have ever seen in my entire life. The ending is unsatisfactory the plot is full of holes and we are lead to a path where there is nothing to know about. The car scene in the beginning has nothing to do with the entire film except to draw a back story to the character but it keeps itself repeating on and on with different flavors that end up meaning nothing. The middle of the story doesn't sag it is a fact. It could have been a great one if it really concentrated on a different path. I see a film with many GOD EX-MA CHINA and convenient holes. A pure waist of time. No wonder why it has a poor 36 evaluation. Run away from it!

I only heard about this movie more than 30 years after it was filmed. Luckily I was able to pick up a DVD that contains the 'Director's Cut' meaning all footage still existing has been put together to form the entity.I'd watch Star Wars and LotR even if those were bad movies just to see Christopher Lee. Yet him in his first major as Lord Summerisle was...Wait!Oh man this is about that abominable Neil LaBute flick with Nicholas Cage and stuff?!?Cripes!Hell yes there's one thing about it that's not totally f**ked: Amongst all futile USish attempts to remake European (specially British) movies The Wicker Man is only the worst but one: The Hitch-Hiker's Guide to the Galaxy is the one failure to exceed it in miserability!

I think I speak for everyone that doesn't have the testicular force to say it when I say this "The Wicker Man" sucks dick! Seriously this movie is a piece of crap and you shouldn't go watch it. It was so predictable that even a moron can foretell that Nicolas Cage did the worse and crappiest job of his entire career. He sucked ass as all the people that lived in the island.
